United Group B.V., a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) incorporated under the laws of the Netherlands (the “Issuer”), is offering (the
“Offering”) €580.0 million in aggregate principal amount of its % Senior Secured Notes due 2030 (the “Fixed Rate SSNs”) and €400.0 million in aggregate principal amount of its Floating
Rate Senior Secured Notes due 2029 (the “FRNs” and, together with the Fixed Rate SSNs, the “Senior Secured Notes”). The Senior Secured Notes will be issued under an indenture (the “SSN
Indenture”) to be entered into on or around the Issue Date (as defined herein) by and among, inter alios, the Issuer and U.S. Bank Trustees Limited, as trustee (the “Trustee”). Proceeds of the
Offering, together with cash on hand, will be used to repay in full and cancel the indebtedness expected to be incurred under the Bridge Facilities (as defined herein), including accrued interest
thereon, and pay fees and expenses in connection with the Offering. The amounts drawn under the Bridge Facilities will be used, together with cash on hand and amounts borrowed under the
Existing Revolving Credit Facility (as defined herein) and/or certain working capital or local facilities, to (i) pay, directly or indirectly, the cash consideration for the acquisition of Crystal
Almond Intermediary Holdings Limited (“Crystal Almond Midco” or the “Target” and, together with its consolidated subsidiaries, the “Target Group” or “Wind Hellas”) in connection with the
Wind Hellas Acquisition (as defined herein), which is expected to occur on or about January 12, 2022, (ii) refinance certain existing net indebtedness of Wind Hellas (including the Wind Hellas
Indebtedness Refinancing (as defined herein)) and (iii) pay transaction costs associated with the Wind Hellas Acquisition, the entry into and drawing under the Bridge Facilities and the Wind
Hellas Indebtedness Refinancing. See “Summary—the Transactions” and “Use of Proceeds.”

The Issuer will pay interest on the Fixed Rate SSNs semi-annually in arrears on each and, commencing, 2022. The Fixed Rate SSNs will mature on, 2030. Interest on
the Fixed Rate SSNs will accrue at a rate per annum computed against the principal outstanding on the Fixed Rate SSNs equal to %. The Issuer will pay interest on the FRNs quarterly in
arrears on each,, and, commencing, 2022. The FRNs will mature on, 2029. Interest on the FRNs will accrue at a rate per annum computed against the
principal outstanding on the FRNs, reset quarterly, equal to EURIBOR (as defined herein), plus %.

Prior to, 2025, the Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Fixed Rate SSNs by paying a “make-whole” premium, as described in this offering memorandum.
The Fixed Rate SSNs may be redeemed at any time on or after, 2025, at the redemption prices set forth in this offering memorandum. In addition, prior to, 2025, the Issuer may
redeem at its option up to 40% of the Fixed Rate SSNs with the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price of % of the aggregate principal amount thereof, plus
accrued and unpaid interest thereon and additional amounts, if any, to the applicable redemption date, provided that at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Fixed Rate
SSNs (not including the principal amount of any additional notes) remains outstanding after the redemption (unless all of the Fixed Rate SSNs are redeemed substantially concurrently). Prior
to, 2025, the Issuer may redeem during each calendar year up to 10% of the original principal amount of the Fixed Rate SSNs at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount
thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to (but not including) the applicable redemption date.

Prior to, 2023, the Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the FRNs by paying a “make-whole” premium, as described in this offering memorandum. The FRNs
may be redeemed at any time on or after, 2023, at the redemption price set forth in this offering memorandum.

In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the Senior Secured Notes. In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for the
Senior Secured Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of such relevant outstanding Senior Secured Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Senior Secured
Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases all of such relevant Senior Secured Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn
by such holders, the Issuer or such third-party will have the right to redeem, in whole but not in part, such Senior Secured Notes that remain outstanding following such purchase at a price equal
to the price offered to other holders of such relevant Senior Secured Notes.

Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to purchase the Senior Secured Notes at 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus
accrued and unpaid interest, to (but not including) the date of repurchase. However, a change of control will not be deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated net leverage ratio is not
exceeded in connection with such event.

The Senior Secured Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer and will, subject to the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein) and as further described and at the times detailed
herein, be guaranteed (the “SSN Guarantees”) on a senior secured basis by Adria Midco B.V. (the “Company”) and certain subsidiaries of the Issuer and be secured by the Collateral (as defined
herein). The validity and enforceability of the SSN Guarantees and the security interests in respect of the Collateral will be subject to significant limitations, as described in “Limitations on
_Validity and Enforceability of the SSN Guarantees and the Security Interests.”_

This offering memorandum includes information on the terms of the Senior Secured Notes, including redemption and repurchase prices, security, covenants and transfer restrictions. See
“Description of the Senior Secured Notes.”

There is currently no public market for the Senior Secured Notes. Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”) for the listing of the Senior
Secured Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”) and to be admitted for trading on the Exchange. There is no assurance, however, that the Senior Secured
Notes will be listed and admitted for trading on the Exchange.

memorandum. With effect as of January 1, 2019, we have adopted IFRS 16 (Leases). For the impact of

**_Company Segment Reporting_**

We are a pan regional distribution platform of cable and satellite Pay-TV, broadband internet and
telephony services in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Bulgaria, Croatia, North
Macedonia and Greece. Our business has grown substantially in terms of scale, geographic reach and
service offering since 2018 through both organic growth and acquisitions. As a consequence of this
growth, our Group-level financial reporting has evolved during the last several years.

In order to provide a meaningful analysis of our results of operations during the period under review
discussed under “The Company’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and
_Results of Operations,” in addition to a discussion of our Group-level consolidated results of operations_
based on IFRS measures, we also present a discussion of revenues, UG Adjusted EBITDAaL and UG
Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases of our Serbia Group, Slovenia Group, Bosnia Group,
Montenegro Group and Media Group segments for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020,
and the nine months ended September 30, 2020 and 2021. We also present a discussion of revenues,
UG Adjusted EBITDAaL and UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases for the year ended
December 31, 2020 and the nine months ended September 30, 2021 and 2020 of: our Croatia Group,
which we added following the completion of the Tele2 Croatia Acquisition (as further described in this
offering memorandum); and our Bulgaria Group, which we added following the completion of the
Vivacom Acquisition (as further described in this offering memorandum). We also present a discussion
of revenues, UG Adjusted EBITDAaL and UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases for the year
ended December 31, 2020 and the nine months ended September 30, 2021 of our Greece Group, which
we added following the completion of the Nova Acquisition (as further described in this offering
memorandum).

Under IFRS 8 “Operating Segments,” we present our segment data in the notes to the annual and interim
consolidated financial statements. In Note 5 to the Company Unaudited Interim Financial Statements,
we disclose the segment results for nine business segments, which are as follows:

- _Slovenia Group segment. This segment includes the results of our cable and mobile services and_
DTH operations in Slovenia;

- _Serbia Group segment. This segment includes the results of cable services in Serbia and DTH_
operations in Serbia, and North Macedonia, including the results of Ikom (acquired in April 2017).
This segment also includes the results of Absolut Solutions, (although these results are not reflected
in the statutory consolidated results of the Serbia Group segment);

- _Bosnia Group segment. This segment includes the results of our cable and DTH operations in_
Bosnia and Herzegovina;


-----

- _Montenegro Group segment. This segment includes the results of our cable and DTH business in_
Montenegro;

- _Bulgaria Group segment. This segment includes the results of our telecommunications operations_
in Bulgaria, including the results of Net 1 EOOD, ComNet Sofia EAD and Digital Cable
Television OOD;

- _Croatia Group segment. This segment includes the results of our mobile services in Croatia. We_
expect that following completion of the Optima Telekom Acquisition, the results of Optima
Telekom will be included in this segment;

- _Greece Group segment. This segment includes the results of Nova’s telecommunications and media_
operations in Greece. We expect that following completion of the Wind Hellas Acquisition, the
results of Wind Hellas will be included in this segment;

- _Media Group segment. This segment includes the results of our media and content business in_
Southeastern Europe including the results of N1 Info, Grand Production, Orlando Kids, Nova TV,
Nova M and Nova BH as well as United Media S.à r.l., United Media Network AG, Direct Media,
Nova BG, Dan Graf and Vestnik Telegraph EOOD; and

- _Other segments. This includes our other operating business, EON TV International (previously_
known as Solford Trading Ltd.) (which operates NetTV Plus), Shoppster, Mainstream and D

**_Capital Expenditure, UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure and UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after_**
**_Leases_**

Capital expenditure represents purchases of tangible and intangible assets, consisting primarily of settop box purchases and other customer capital expenditure, installations (including capitalized labor
costs), cable and mobile network build out, upgrades, maintenance and other investments, computer
hardware and software, as well as certain programming rights and licenses.

In this offering memorandum, for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we have derived
capital expenditure for the Company from the Company Audited Financial Statements and, for the nine
months ended September 30, 2020 and 2021, from the Company Unaudited Interim Financial
Statements.

UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure represents capital expenditure, as adjusted by programming rights
and intragroup adjustments, assets held for sale, application of IFRS 15 for customer acquisition costs
in SBB Serbia and overflow between periods.

Programming rights adjustments represent the difference following a change in how we account for
programming rights. Until December 31, 2016, our Media Group segment included the total value of
license agreements signed for programming rights with a term longer than one year in its UG Adjusted
Capital Expenditure. For the purpose of IFRS, however, the Group had recognized these programming
rights as capital expenditure in the period, only to the extent of assets available for broadcasting (i.e.,
one season). Starting from January 1, 2017, our Media Group segment has followed the Group’s
approach. However, as certain programming rights prior to this date had already been reported as UG
Adjusted Capital Expenditure by our Media Group segment, there was a difference compared to the
Group’s capital expenditure for the period. This adjustment has been decreasing since December 31,
2016 as long-term license agreements (which had previously been reported as UG Adjusted Capital
Expenditure) are expiring.

Intragroup adjustments relate to unrealized profit on the intragroup sale of end-user equipment by SBB
Serbia. When SBB Serbia sells this equipment to other United Group companies in compliance with
applicable transfer pricing requirements, it makes an unrealized profit on the sale. These unrealized
profits are eliminated for the purposes of preparing our accounts in accordance with IFRS, but are not
eliminated for the purpose of our management accounts (which are not prepared in accordance with
IFRS).

The application of IFRS 15 for customer acquisition costs in SBB Serbia reflects the additional effect
of harmonizing our accounting policy with respect to the capitalization of subscriber acquisition costs
for rebinding, upselling and cross-selling (which in the past were not eligible to be capitalized, but under
IFRS 15 qualify for capitalization), which were determined subsequent to the preparation of our
management accounts.

Assets held for sale relate to programming rights acquired by our Media Group segment for other Group
segments which were recognized under IFRS as intangible assets and were invoiced to other Group
segments after March 31 and September 30, 2021.

Overflow between periods relates to the fact that our management accounts are closed prior to the
closing of our accounts prepared in accordance with IFRS. Overflow between periods in any given
period reflects the additional capital expenditure incurred between the preparation of our management
accounts and our accounts prepared in accordance with IFRS for such period.


-----

In addition, in this offering memorandum, we present UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases,
which is calculated as UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure excluding the impact of right-of-use asset
additions and, starting from 2021 the right-of-use asset modifications and prepayments. See “—
_Company Segment Reporting” and “Summary of Company Historical and Group Run-Rate, Wind_
_Hellas Historical, Unaudited Pro Forma Rune-Rate and Certain Other Financial Data.”_

In addition, for informational purposes only, we describe our anticipated UG Adjusted Capital
Expenditure after Leases for the year ending December 31, 2021 based on management estimates,
which may vary from our actual Group level capital expenditure data when it is prepared in accordance
with IFRS.

UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure, UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases and our future UG
Adjusted Capital Expenditure and UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases estimates are prepared
based on management accounts rather than IFRS.

PricewaterhouseCoopers d.o.o. Zagreb has not audited, reviewed or performed any procedures with
respect to UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure, UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases, future UG

offering memorandum. With effect as of January 1, 2019, Wind Hellas has adopted IFRS 16 (Leases)

isolation or as a substitute for our or a relevant group’s results or any performance measures under IFRS
as set forth in our consolidated financial statements or the Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Statements.
Some of these limitations are:

- they do not reflect our future requirements for capital commitments;

- they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

- they do not reflect the interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest or
principal payments on our debt;

- they do not reflect any cash income taxes that we may be required to pay;

- they are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in our consolidated
profit and loss statement;

- they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters we consider not
to be indicative of our ongoing operations;

- assets are depreciated or amortized over differing estimated useful lives and often have to be
replaced in the future, and these measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such
replacements; and

- other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their
usefulness as comparative measures.

Because of these limitations the Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of
discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will
be available to us to meet our obligations. You should compensate for these limitations by relying
primarily on our IFRS results and using these Non-IFRS Measures only supplementally to evaluate our

**Overview**

We are the leading telecommunications player in Southeastern Europe, with a unique media ecosystem
to complement our regional distribution capabilities. As of September 30, 2021, we provided services
to approximately 15.2 million RGUs and covered approximately 4.3 million homes passed after giving
effect to the Wind Hellas Acquisition and other signed acquisitions. We offer a diverse and
differentiated line of products and services and are the clear multi-play leader in our footprint across
Slovenia, Bulgaria, Serbia, Croatia, Greece, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro, with an
addressable market that comprised 13.4 million households as of September 30, 2021. We also produce
and distribute distinctive and attractive content for our Pay-TV channels across a wide range of media
formats. The Group’s revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €1,383.9 million,
and the UG Adjusted EBITDAaL for such period was €523.4 million. The Pro forma Group had RunRate Revenue for the annualized last two quarters ended September 30, 2021 of €2,536.2 million and
Pro forma Run-Rate Last Two Quarter Annualized Adjusted EBITDAaL for September 30, 2021 was
€969.0 million.

We have grown rapidly through both value-accretive acquisitions and organic growth. In August 2021,
we signed an agreement to acquire Wind Hellas, a leading integrated telecommunications operator and
the number three mobile-telephony services provider in Greece, furthering our penetration into the
Greek market following our acquisition of Nova (formerly Forthnet S.A.) in 2020. After giving effect
to the Wind Hellas Acquisition, approximately 1/3 of our pro forma revenues for the twelve months
ended September 30, 2021 would have been derived in Greece. We have also made a number of smaller
acquisitions in Bulgaria, building on our leading positions following completion of the Vivacom
Acquisition in 2020 and the acquisition of Nova BG in 2021, and in Croatia, where we acquired Tele2
Croatia in 2020 and we have signed an agreement to acquire Optima Telekom in 2021. We have also
continued to expand our in-house media and content offering through acquisitions, with a focus on
expansion in euro or euro-pegged currency jurisdictions. We have significantly improved our business
profile in terms of scale, geographic exposure and currency mix and product diversification.

Our in-house content business produces distinctive and attractive content for our Pay-TV channels and
has historically driven Pay-TV subscriptions. We currently produce over 50% of the total content in our
national (terrestrial) and most of our Pay-TV operations, and our main prime-time programs typically
receive ratings of between 20% and 50% in the markets in which they are available. As part of our
media business, we also provide advertising services and digital production and distribution in our
markets. We are also a distribution partner of choice for premium regional and international content
owners because of our well-known brands, large network and our focus on Southeastern Europe.

Our core telecommunications business is complemented by our two over-the-top (“OTT”) distribution
platforms that customers can access through internet-based streaming: (i) EON, our regional OTT
platform in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Greece, which enables customers connected
to our competitors’ broadband internet connections outside of our cable footprint to access our attractive
portfolio of Pay-TV channels; and (ii) NetTV Plus, our international OTT platform, which delivers
ethnic and local language content to the ex-Yugoslav diaspora around the world. In July 2020, we
launched Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online shopping platform, which offers more than 20


-----

popular product categories, and is available as an integrated online and TV shopping platform in Serbia
and Slovenia.

We believe that we are well-positioned to maintain and grow our market-leading positions, as we
provide a well-invested network, some of the fastest download speeds, access to desirable media content
and high-quality customer service, all of which has led to relatively low churn rates and high customer
loyalty. Our customers view the telecommunications products and services that we offer as part of their
everyday lives, which results in recurring, high demand and makes our business more resilient to macroeconomic disruptions, including the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic where we saw data and voice traffic
increase.

**Competitive Strengths**

**_We operate in structurally attractive markets._**

We operate in countries across Southeastern Europe that are attractive telecommunication markets due
to favourable competitive dynamics, relatively low penetration of broadband and Pay-TV, and a
predictable regulatory environment. Our countries of operation have also generally experienced
stronger real GDP growth than the Eurozone average in recent years. Most recently, in 2021, real GDP
in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Greece, Montenegro, Serbia and Slovenia grew by 5.7%
on average compared to 5.0% on average in the Eurozone. In addition, real GDP in these countries is
currently estimated to grow at an average of 2.9% by 2025, which is higher than the average estimated
growth of 1.4% in the Eurozone (source: IMF).

After completing the Wind Hellas Acquisition, across most of our footprint, there are only one to two
other companies in each of the countries where we are present that own and operate the majority of the
broadband infrastructure. While in some of our markets a few small players own their broadband
network, we have competitive advantages over them given our nationwide presence and the benefits of
scale that we enjoy as nationwide network operators. Within the four major geographies where we offer
mobile-telephony, with the exception of Slovenia, there are only three mobile network operators
(“MNO”) in each country. The presence of fewer players owning broadband and mobile networks
within a single competitive environment typically results in healthy competition in the retail market
which leads to profitable investments.

The countries in which we operate are characterized by growing Pay-TV and broadband markets that
are currently underpenetrated relative to some other CEE and Western European markets and therefore
present an attractive structural growth proposition. Between 2018 and 2020, fixed broadband internet
household penetration rates increased from approximately 65% to 72% in Bulgaria, from approximately
59% to 66% in Serbia, from approximately 73% to 75% in Slovenia and from approximately 100% to
106% in Greece. Over the same period, overall Pay-TV market penetration rates increased from
approximately 73% to 89% in Serbia and from approximately 76% to 77% in Slovenia, and remained
stable at approximately 68% in Bulgaria. As a result, over the past few years we have experienced a
steady growth in the number of subscribers across our markets and we expect our subscriber base to
grow further over the next couple of years. Subscribers are increasingly upgrading to higher speed
broadband offerings due to a variety of factors including, among others, the increase in remote working
and continued growth in high bandwidth applications.

The national telecommunication framework in each of our countries of operation is overseen by
competent national regulatory authorities. As members of the EU, Bulgaria, Greece, Slovenia and
Croatia which together account for than 3/4 of our revenues after giving effect to the Wind Hellas
Acquisition, have national regulatory frameworks that align with EU guidelines and directives, which
provides for a relatively stable regulatory environment.

**_We are the leading integrated multi-play provider across Southeastern Europe._**


-----

We are the leading integrated multi-play provider in Southeastern Europe based on market share by
number of subscribers, a position that we have reinforced through acquisitions we have made which
have allowed us to expand geographically, diversify our business and increase our customer base. Our
leadership position in the region will be further strengthened following the completion of the Wind
Hellas Acquisition, which will add 3.4 million RGUs as of September 30, 2021. In addition, the
Vivacom Acquisition has increased our addressable market by 35%. Our scale and presence across
Southeastern Europe and across our product portfolios allows us to cross-sell our services and expand
the number of multi-play packages we provide, creating opportunities to further expand our customer
base and continue to strengthen our leadership position in the region.

In the Pay-TV market, we have leveraged our complementary cable and DTH platforms to gain leading
market shares in Southeastern Europe and become the pan regional leader with 2.1 million unique
subscribers as of September 30, 2021. In particular, we are the leading Pay-TV provider in each of
Serbia, Slovenia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, with market shares of 45%, 39% and 40%, respectively,
as of September 30, 2021, each based on number of subscribers; and we are the second largest Pay-TV
operator in Greece, with a market share of 27% as of September 30, 2021, and the largest in Bulgaria,
with a market share of 27% as of September 30, 2021, each based on number of subscribers. In addition,
we are the largest DTH Pay-TV provider in Montenegro and are among the main providers of DTH
Pay-TV in North Macedonia and Croatia. Among high-speed cable broadband internet providers, we
are the leader in each of Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina within our footprint and have a
large broadband market share overall, behind only the respective incumbents with national footprints.
We are also the leading provider of broadband internet by number of subscribers in Bulgaria. In
addition, we are the market leader in fixed-line telephony in Bulgaria and the second-largest fixed-line
telephony provider in Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. In mobile-telephony, we are the
third largest MNO in each of Slovenia, Bulgaria, Croatia and, after giving effect to the Wind Hellas
Acquisition, Greece, with market shares based on the number of subscribers of, respectively,
approximately 24% as of June 30, 2021, 29% as of December 31, 2020, and 19% and 24% as of
September 30, 2021.

**_We are a recognized media leader benefitting from content ownership, own production and strategic_**
**_partnerships._**

We believe we are the recognized media leader in Southeastern Europe, offering fully integrated
production and distribution of attractive and distinctive local content for the entire region, which has a
population of approximately 40 million, with similar languages, cultures and entertainment preferences.
Our focus on the entire Southeastern European region allows us to maintain and serve some of the
smaller markets where smaller operators are less able to provide first rate localized content on an
economically efficient basis. At the same time, we believe international players would find it difficult
and costly to expand into the region, due to language and cultural barriers.

Through our owned-content business we directly own many of the region’s popular pay-TV channels.
In addition, as of September 30, 2021, we produced 50% of our content locally. Owning our content
allows us to control the end-to-end creation process, produce a wide range of diversified and attractive
local and genre specific content and maintain a structural hedge on content costs. Our in-house
production has significantly increased over recent years, and the content offered has continuously
improved. In addition, we have established a digital music production and content distribution business,
and have leading full format TV stations with appealing content in Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina
and Montenegro. In March 2019, we launched Nova S in Serbia, Total TV and EON. Following the
Nova Acquisition in November 2020, we also offer content under EON-branded channels in Greece,
and in January 2021, we acquired Nova Broadcasting Group, Bulgaria’s largest multi-platform media
company, becoming a major content player in Bulgaria.

In addition to our owned content offerings, our pay-TV distribution platforms typically license the rights
for the distribution of our own channels, as well as third-party owned channels. We believe that our pan
regional presence, large subscriber base, advanced network, cable and DTH platforms, leading market


-----

positions and relationships with all major third-party distribution platforms make us an attractive partner
to third-party content owners, including major sporting leagues (such as the World Cup qualifiers and
the League of Nations). As a result, we are able to enter into strategic partnerships with third-party
contract providers to distribute their content to the entire region on attractive terms, whereas competitors
operating in a single country within the region cannot offer similarly broad coverage. We are also able
to offer our content partners value added services such as subtitles for television shows and can spread
the costs across our operations in the entire region, whereas we believe such costs would not be
economically justifiable for a competitor operating within a single country in the region. The table
below highlights our differentiated media offering:

**_We have a large infrastructure portfolio of fiber, cable TV and mobile networks, that is advanced,_**
**_well-invested and with a broad reach across the region._**

We strive to be the most advanced media and telecommunications company in Southeastern Europe
and we believe that our fiber, mobile and cable TV infrastructure allows us to provide higher quality
digital TV, high-speed broadband and fixed-line telephony and mobile telephony than other operators
in our markets. Our network is well invested and has a relatively low cost to upgrade. In March 2021,
we announced an investment of more than €500 million over the next five years to extend our fiber
network into new areas and upgrade the existing network with 10 Gbps-enabled infrastructure based on
XGS-PON.

We operate the largest fiber network in the region across metropolitan areas in Southern Europe,
extending for approximately 50,000 kilometers. In Bulgaria, we operate the largest Fiber to the ×
(“FTTx”) network, which covers more than 1.3 million homes passed as of September 30, 2021 with
symmetrical upload and download speeds of up to 10 Gbps. Together with the VDSL network, our


-----

broadband network covers more than 1.8 million homes passed as of September 30, 2021, which
represent approximately 64% of homes in Bulgaria. In Greece, Wind Hellas is one of the major fiber
operators with a nationwide network of more than 3,000 kilometers and close to half a million homes
passed as of September 30, 2021 through a mix of fiber to the home (FttH) and fiber to the cabinet
(FttC) networks. We see significant further growth opportunity in FttH networks in the underpenetrated
Greek market where we have a dedicated rollout platform and wholesale team in place. In Croatia,
Optima Telekom has a nationwide optical fiber network over 3,000 kilometers and covers over half a
million homes passed as of September 30, 2021. We plan to invest €100 million in the coming years to
further upgrade our network in Croatia.

We also operate an advanced proprietary hybrid fiber coaxial (“HFC”) network which is fully bidirectional and EuroDOCSIS 3.0 enabled, covering all of our homes passed in Serbia, Bosnia and
Herzegovina and Montenegro, and approximately 99% of homes passed in Slovenia as of September
30, 2021. As of September 30, 2021, our cable network covers approximately 1.8 million homes passed,
and 94% of our core network was DOCSIS 3.1 ready. In addition, our network has an average homes
passed per fiber optics node ratio in the range of approximately 242, 206 and 219 across Slovenia,
Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, respectively, which we believe is unrivalled in Southeastern Europe
and compares favourably to other European cable operators.

We also believe our average recorded download speed is consistently faster than those of our main
broadband competitors. In particular, we believe it is 1.7x faster in Serbia, 3.3x faster in Slovenia, 3.9x
faster in Bosnia and Herzegovina and 1.2x faster in Bulgaria.

We have nationwide mobile networks in Bulgaria, Croatia, Greece and Slovenia, where we own
approximately 4,700 towers, including both passive and active equipment, and have spectrum across
2G, 3G, 4G and 5G bands. Our mobile network covers the majority of the population in each of our
countries of operations through our extensive 2G/3G/4G networks, and at present we have the capability
to provide 4G (LTE) and 4G+ (LTE-A) coverage to approximately 99 % and 98%, respectively, of the
Slovenian population, approximately 100% and 98%, respectively, of the Bulgarian population,
approximately 99% and 96%, respectively, of the Croatian population. Following the completion of the
Wind Hellas Acquisition, we will have the capability to provide 4G (LTE) coverage to approximately
98% of the Greek population. To further develop our networks, we have successfully tested and are
rolling out next generation 5G networks across our mobile-telephony footprint. We were the first mobile
operator to have launched 5G services in Slovenia in 2021 and our mobile network in Bulgaria was
named the fastest mobile in Europe by Ookla in both 2020 and 2021.

**_Our low churn rates demonstrate our loyal customer base and differentiated proposition._**

Our business model is attractive and resilient. We believe our portfolio of must-have products and our
superior offering have resulted in a growing and loyal customer base with relatively low churn rates of
approximately 9-11% per annum, combined with the ability to up sell and cross-sell products. Our
customers view the telecommunications products and services that we offer as part of their everyday
lives, which results in recurring, high demand for our products and makes our business more resilient
to macro-economic disruptions when compared to other discretionary products and services. For
example, during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic our products and services have been instrumental in
providing connectivity and entertainment, as an increasing number of people began to work or study
remotely and spend significant amounts of time at home, which resulted in a significant increase in our
voice and data traffic. In this recurring, high demand environment, we believe we offer superior
products, faster broadband speeds and higher quality content than our competitors. Customer loyalty is
evidenced by our relatively low historical churn rates, which is defined as the percentage of customers
that no longer subscribe for a certain service compared to the average number of customers in a
particular month. For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, our unique cable subscriber churn
rate annualized was 10%, which is below recent reported cable subscriber churn rates of certain Western
European peers. We believe our relatively low churn rates provide, among other benefits, recurring cash


-----

flows and visibility with respect to future revenue. Moreover, these churn rates have persisted
notwithstanding regular price increases.

**_We have a strong track record of profitable growth driven by structurally attractive markets, cross-_**
**_selling opportunities and the successful integration of acquired assets._**

We have a strong track record of profitable growth, underpinned by relatively low penetration rates in
the markets in which we operate and cross-selling opportunities due to our scale, as well as a record of
successfully integrating acquisitions. We operate most of our business across countries in Southeastern
Europe that have relatively low penetration rates in Pay-TV and broadband, which we can capitalize on
via cross-selling due to our scale and comprehensive offering portfolio. As of September 30, 2021, our
Pay-TV penetration of homes passed and broadband internet were 61% and 89%, respectively, in
Slovenia, 63% and 74%, respectively, in Serbia, and 61% and 83%, respectively in Bosnia and
Herzegovina. As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas’ Pay-TV and NGA fiber penetration in LLU &
NGA fiber base were 11% and 44%, respectively, in Greece. In addition, due to historically strong
regulatory constraints on bundling Pay-TV, broadband internet and telephony services, RGUs per cable
subscriber ratios in our key markets have lagged behind CEE and Western European cable markets. We
believe this demonstrates that there are strong opportunities to continue to utilize up selling and crossselling opportunities to grow our cable RGUs per subscriber ratio. The following table shows
comparisons of RGUs per cable subscriber in certain key CEE and Western European markets with
those of certain other industry members:

We have leveraged the significant industry experience and corporate background of our senior

**Strategy**

We aim to strengthen our telecommunications and media leadership positions in Southeastern Europe,
deliver exceptional revenue growth across segments and capitalize on operating leverage and continued
operating efficiencies to deliver strong profitability and cash flow generation, all while providing our
customers the best products and services in each of our segments and markets. In order to achieve these
goals, we have identified the following strategic pillars:

**_Continued focus on our competitive market positions by leveraging our advanced network,_**
**_differentiated content offerings and loyal customer base._**


-----

We are the leading multi-play provider in Southeastern Europe and hold leadership positions across
each of our countries of operations and product categories. We have achieved these competitive market
positions over the years and we aim to maintain and strengthen them going forward and to further
develop our business in attractive markets in Southeastern Europe. In order to achieve this, we intend
to continue to expand the coverage and capacity of our superior next generation infrastructure in our
footprint, including 5G capability, where the return on investment is appropriate. We also intend to
continue to offer our loyal customer base the most attractive and differentiated content offerings in the
region, with better content choice, speed, functionality and service quality compared to our competitors,
at prices that allow us to deliver compelling value.

**_Increase service penetration across the region by cross-selling products and services and up selling_**
**_value adding products to existing customers._**

We intend to continue to focus on pursuing subscriber growth opportunities in our relatively underpenetrated markets. Over time, we expect our businesses in Serbia, Bulgaria, Greece and Bosnia and
Herzegovina to converge with Slovenia in terms of broadband and Pay-TV penetration as well as in
service penetration (measured by RGU per subscriber). To achieve this, we aim to increase triple play
(and in the case of Slovenia and Bulgaria, quad-play) penetration and reduce churn rates by continuing
to shift focus in marketing and subscriber interactions from single services to bundled services. We
intend to continue to promote our bundled services by further leveraging our high-quality network and
utilizing our next generation digital television services, attractive local content and high-speed
broadband services and, where applicable, mobile-telephony services. We plan to offer more add-on
products and incentivize longer term contracts by offering better pricing and subsidies for certain
products. We also aim to capitalize on our superior high-speed broadband capabilities to increase
revenue. Specifically, we intend to continue migrating our existing high-speed broadband subscribers
to higher speeds, which we believe will further support broadband ARPU growth and reduce residential
subscriber churn rates. Following the Wind Hellas Acquisition, we intend to leverage the combination
with our existing Greek pay-TV provider NOVA to seize significant cross-selling, bundling and pricing
optimization opportunities in Greece.

**_Continue to consolidate our position as the leading media company in Southeastern Europe._**

Since inception, our media strategy has been centered on differentiating our offering by producing
superior and/or exclusive Pay-TV channels for our customers. We have applied this philosophy to all
of our Group companies with great success, and we have created an attractive portfolio of full format
national as well as specialized, thematic Pay-TV channels that we believe are a must-have on all
regional distribution platforms. Following the acquisition of Vivacom, Nova BG and Nova and their
integration into our operations, we are applying this philosophy in Bulgaria and Greece. We intend to
consolidate our leadership in Southeastern Europe and continue to grow our content offering by further
developing our portfolio of owned content, entering into strategic partnerships with third-party content
owners and acquiring other content owners in the region, as in the past with the acquisition of Nova TV
Croatia and Direct Media/Pink.

**_Further expand our addressable market by utilizing our OTT platform and attractive content._**

Leveraging our strong brands and our attractive content, we intend to continue to develop our two OTT
content platforms, our regional OTT platform, EON, and our international OTT platform, NetTV Plus,
to further expand our addressable market to areas outside our cable footprint. While our DTH Pay-TV
platform aims to deliver our content to subscribers in rural areas in our markets without cable
infrastructure, our regional OTT platform enables customers in metropolitan areas outside of our cable
footprint, who have subscribed to the broadband internet services of our competitors, to access our
attractive portfolio of Pay-TV channels and unique user interface and customer experience.
Additionally, NetTV Plus allows us to provide over 200 local language channels showing ethnic content
to the entire ex-Yugoslav diaspora around the world. By expanding our geographic reach to customers
in countries in Western Europe and North America, we believe that we are well positioned to further


-----

increase our RGU base and earnings potential. We have a plan to further invest in our in-house software
development of customer premises equipment for our TV and broadband services. With a unified
software solution, we will be able to provide all our service through a unified TV Box or broadband
gateway to any type of networks (OTT, Fiber, Cable or Mobile). We also plan to start developing a new
generation of digital streaming social applications, based on automated content, personalization and
advanced targeted advertising solutions. In addition, we have recently started the in-house development
of artificial intelligence engine software solutions, with dedicated teams who will develop machine
learning models for our content production, content recommendation system and advertisement
solutions.

**_Continued focus on innovation._**

We seek to continue innovating and enhancing our product offering to offer our customers an improved
use experience across our products, further strengthen our leading position across our countries of
operation and enter new markets. Our centralized in-house technology innovation and software
development center, United.Cloud, enables us to focus on leading the introduction of cutting-edge
television and broadband internet services and solutions such as EON (our next generation video
delivery platform which allows customers to watch their favorite channels on a broad range of devices),
UNIFON (our proprietary VoIP application connecting customers’ fixed-line telephones outside of their
homes), our self-help application, enhanced TV features such as VoD and CatchUp TV services and
many others. We also intend to continue promoting the digitalization of internal and external processes
to improve customer satisfaction and profitability. In July 2020, we leveraged our position in both the
broadband and Pay-TV markets to launch Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online-shopping
platform. We intend for Shoppster to continue delivering the simple, reliable and secure e-shopping
experience that modern consumers expect.

**_Continue to grow our customer base and operations through value accretive acquisitions and_**
**_optimize our portfolio._**

We have a successful track record of making acquisitions on attractive terms and successfully
integrating those acquisitions. Between 2011 and September 30, 2021, we have acquired and integrated
(or are in the process of integrating) approximately 50 cable TV operators, content platforms, media
companies, mobile service providers, B2B service providers and internet service providers (“ISPs”) in
Southeastern Europe. Most recently, we have expanded our addressable market through the acquisition
of Vivacom and Nova Broadcasting in Bulgaria, Nova and, pending completion, Wind Hellas in Greece
and Optima Telekom in Croatia, as well as various other recent acquisitions. As a result, we have
significantly improved our business profile in terms of scale, geographic exposure and currency mix
and product diversification. Our acquisition strategy consists of expanding our scale in a value accretive
manner, enhancing our content offering, expanding our fixed-line and mobile-telephony operations and
leveraging our experience and successful acquisition history to continue to integrate businesses and
generate additional value by increasing scale and product offerings.

The Wind Hellas Acquisition provides us with the opportunity to increase our penetration into the Greek
market following our acquisition of Nova in 2020, increasing our scale and leadership across
Southeastern Europe, further diversifying our revenue streams and improving our currency mix, while
also providing significant upside arising from our strength in cross-selling, bundling and pricing
optimization. We intend to leverage our know-how arising from our highly successful acquisition track
record to successfully integrate Wind Hellas and realize its upside potential. As part of our integration
plan, we intend to combine Wind Hellas with our existing Greek pay-TV provider NOVA to develop a
quad-play market challenger operator, and the number two player in Greece in both broadband internet
and television services. We believe this combination will enable us to deliver a higher value to our
customers in the Greek market by providing a broad range of new technologies and superior services.

Going forward, we plan to continue to make value accretive acquisitions at attractive multiples to
integrate regional service providers, cable assets and fixed-line and mobile-telephony operators into the


-----

business. We intend to continue taking a disciplined approach to acquisitions by assessing individual
opportunities as and when they arise on the basis of merit, ability to integrate assets into our existing
business plans and potential for value creation.

While we continue to grow our business, we also continue to assess opportunities to optimize our
portfolio of assets and maximize value for our stakeholders as those opportunities arise. To that end,
we have taken initial steps to explore a possible sale of our mobile tower portfolios in Bulgaria, Slovenia
and Croatia. As of the date of this offering memorandum, we have not begun a sale process, identified
a buyer or determined any price or other terms for such a transaction. We currently do not have a
definitive timeline or commitment for any such sale, and we could decide not to proceed with such a
sale at any time.

**_Continue to focus on Environmental, Social and Corporate Governance (“ESG”) Matters_**

We and our shareholders recognize that developing a sustainable and responsible business that has a
positive social impact is key to our future success. As we have grown our Group, we have increased
our emphasis on integrating ESG considerations into the key aspects of our operations, including our
decision-making and reporting processes, and we intend to continue to increase our focus on ESG
matters going forward, including by implementing the ESG action plan and roadmap prepared by our
dedicated ESG coordinator in 2020 in consultation with external advisors.

To promote environmental sustainability in our operations, we are taking active steps to minimize our
environmental footprint, while also collecting and analyzing Group historical data to set future KPI
targets. We are committed to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and ultimately make all of our
operations carbon-neutral. We intend to leverage our experience in establishing a solar power plant in
Slovenia in 2019 to look for additional green energy projects which could cover a significant part of
our carbon emission footprint. For example, on November 30, 2021, we completed the acquisition of a
majority ownership in Tessa Energy in Bulgaria, which we expect will invest in the Kremena Wind
Park, which has a 70MW capacity and will allow us to significantly decrease our carbon footprint. We
also intend to continue to use electric vehicles in our operations where feasible, and work to exchange
old, less-energy efficient equipment for more energy-efficient devices. In 2020, we generated
approximately 128.1 thousand tons of CO2 emissions (9.3 thousand tons of scope 1 emissions and 118.8
thousand tons of scope 2 and 3 emissions), including the contribution of acquired companies. We intend
to reduce these by approximately 60%, or 50.6 thousand tons, by 2030. In addition, in 2020, we recycled
1,539 tons of network telecom equipment, batteries, cables, paper and cardboard. Our goal going
forward is to continue minimizing waste by repurposing, reusing or recycling 100% of returned
customer devices and accessories.

We support social and economic development in Southern Europe and aim to build the region’s most
advanced digital telecommunications infrastructure. In particular, we intend to invest approximately
one billion euros by the middle of this decade to modernize and expand our network to ensure it can
support the future needs of our customers. In 2020, we named a Group-level director for corporate social
responsibility and we plan to continue actively supporting the communities in which we operate. We
have as a Group donated €4.7 million in 2020 and €1.1 million for the nine months ended September
30, 2021, to groups and activities dedicated to protecting the environment, education and the socially
vulnerable, including donations of personal protective equipment to help fight COVID-19. We intend
to continue to engage in community engagement activities such as those we have carried out in the past
few years, with a focus on delivering knowledge to children, students, the general public and
disadvantaged groups, by leveraging our core competencies in broadband internet and other
telecommunications. For 2022, we aim to increase the percentage of staff participating in a community
engagement activity (e.g., volunteering time or knowledge), which in 2021 stood at 7% (excluding
United Media).

We focus on building a safe, fair and inclusive working environment for our employees. To inform our
diversity, inclusion and safety targets, we intend to continue collecting data on our workforce, such as


-----

gender mix, percentage of women in management positions and percentage of disabled employees to
set future targets. We also have mandated diversity and inclusion rules, and have documented these in
employee manuals at our Group companies. To facilitate further transparency and accountability, we
plan to expand our anonymous suggestion boxes already present in certain of our Group companies and
establish whistle-blowing programs as a distinct transparency function. We also plan to continue to
offer training programs to employees focused on improving job-related technical and management
skills, as well as on compliance with our internal policies.

**The Transactions**

**_The Wind Hellas Acquisition_**

On August 14, 2021, the Issuer entered into the Wind Hellas Acquisition Agreement with Crystal
Almond Holdings Limited (the “Seller”) to acquire Crystal Almond Midco, an indirect parent of Wind
Hellas Telecommunications S.A., from the Seller for an estimated enterprise value of €980 million,
subject to certain adjustments in accordance with the terms of the Wind Hellas Acquisition Agreement.
The Issuer’s rights under the Wind Hellas Acquisition Agreement were assigned by the Issuer to its
indirect subsidiary NewCo United Group Hellas S.à r.l. pursuant to an assignment agreement. The Wind
Hellas Acquisition was approved by the European Commission on December 21, 2021, and we expect
it to be consummated on or about January 12, 2022. Although the Seller has given certain customary
representations, warranties and indemnities as to, inter alia, capacity, title and disclosure in the Wind
Hellas Acquisition Agreement, the Issuer may not be able to enforce claims against the Seller relating
to breaches of these representations, warranties and indemnities. In addition, the Seller’s liability for
any breach of a warranty is subject to certain thresholds and limitations. See “Risk Factors—Risks
_Related to the Wind Hellas Acquisition—We may not be able to enforce claims relating to a breach of_
_the representations and warranties provided in connection with the Wind Hellas Acquisition and our_
_ability to recover losses suffered as a result of such a breach may be limited.”_

Wind Hellas is one of the three integrated communication providers with proprietary mobile and fixedline networks in Greece, a large and attractive EU market with 4.3 million broadband and 14.1 million
mobile subscribers as of December 31, 2020. It offers mobile and fixed-line telecommunication, highspeed internet services and Pay-TV services under a unified brand and on a national basis to over 4.1
million subscribers. As of September 30, 2021, household and business accounts represented
approximately 61% of total RGUs. Wind Hellas owns one of the three proprietary mobile networks in
Greece and is the third-largest mobile provider in Greece, with more than 3.4 million mobile subscribers
as of September 30, 2021. Wind Hellas is also the third-largest fixed-line telephony provider. In
addition, it provides Pay-TV services to residential customers through its video platform, Wind Vision,
which it launched in April 2018 and had 0.1 million platform subscribers as of September 30, 2021.

Established in 1992 as STET Hellas, Wind Hellas was acquired by Weather Investments S.p.A. in 2007
and was renamed as Wind Hellas Telecommunications S.A. Since then, it has operated under the
licensed brand name “WIND.” Over the years, Wind Hellas became a well-diversified and resilient
operator and increased its market share. In particular, following the addition of fixed-line
telecommunications in 2008 through the acquisition of Tellas Telecommunications S.A., it became a
leading integrated telecommunications provider. In 2015, Wind Hellas started its LTE roll-out plan, and
in 2018, it launched its video platform, Wind Vision. Wind Hellas benefits from an extensive
nationwide fiber optic network of approximately 6,162 kilometers (backbone and metropolitan access
network) and approximately 600 kilometers of fiber as part of the recently commenced NGA
deployment. Wind Hellas continuously invests in its network to support growth initiatives and enhance
its service offering. It also accelerated investments in digital service capability to take advantage of
emerging consumer behaviour patterns resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic. In December 2020,
Wind Hellas acquired 5G spectrum, which represented a significant milestone and laid the foundation
for deploying its 5G network roll-out while providing visibility on future license payments for seven
years starting from January 2024. As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas achieved 4G and 5G network


-----

coverage of 98% and 24%, respectively, of the 10.7 million population in Greece and continued
investing in its fiber network, reaching 431 thousand NGA lines deployed.

Wind Hellas has successfully scaled in the market over the past few years and has achieved solid growth
and financial performance in recent years, with strong growth in key metrics such as the gross margins
for its mobile and fixed-line services and operating expense optimization, as well as profitability and
cash flow generation. Wind Hellas’ total revenue for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 was
€558.3 million compared to €537.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Its WH Adjusted
EBITDA for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 was €248.5 million compared to €245.4
million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Wind Hellas’ operating performance has been similarly
strong, with increases in ARPU and subscriber numbers. For the twelve months ended September 30,
2021, mobile ARPU increased to €11.4 per one million active customers from €11.2 per one million
active customers for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of 2%. As of September 30, 2021,
mobile subscribers were 3.4 million and LLU & NGA Fiber subscribers were 0.6 million. Fixed-line
ARPU (including Wind Vision) was €21.0 per one million active customers for the twelve months
ended September 30, 2021 compared to €20.9 per one million active customers for the year ended
December 31, 2019.

We believe the Wind Hellas Acquisition provides us with the opportunity to increase our penetration
into the Greek market following our acquisition of Nova in 2020, increasing our scale and leadership
across Southeastern Europe, further diversifying our revenue streams and improving our currency mix,
while also providing significant upside arising from our strength in cross-selling, bundling and pricing
optimization. We intend to leverage our know-how arising from our highly successful acquisition track
record to successfully integrate Wind Hellas and realize its upside potential. As part of our integration
plan, we intend to combine Wind Hellas with our existing Greek pay-TV provider NOVA to develop a
quad-play market challenger operator, and the number two player in Greece in both broadband internet
and television services. We believe this combination will enable us to deliver a higher value to our
customers in the Greek market by providing a broad range of new technologies and superior services.
In particular, we believe we can significantly improve Wind Hellas’ performance by accelerating
growth in its mobile post-paid revenues through cross-selling into Nova-subscribing households,
accelerating growth in its fixed broadband revenues leveraging on Nova’s leading entertainment offer,
growing its subscriber base, accelerating its fiber roll-out, and growing its wholesale revenues on the
back of fiber infrastructure rental.

On or about the Wind Hellas Acquisition Closing Date, FiberCo, a newly established and separate
subsidiary of Crystal Almond Midco holding Wind Hellas’ fiber network business, and the Victus Joint
Operation, the 50/50 joint operation between Wind Hellas and Vodafone-Panafon S.A., a member of
Vodafone Group plc, are expected to be designated as Unrestricted Subsidiaries under the existing
Indentures and the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, and therefore not to be subject to the covenants
therein. In addition, FiberCo and the Joint Victus Operation will be Unrestricted Subsidiaries under the
SSN Indenture and will not be subject to the covenants included therein.

BC Partners is a leading alternative global investment firm focused on private equity, credit, and real

**Recent Developments**

**_COVID-19 Impact on Revenues and UG Adjusted EBITDA_**

Based on our analysis, we estimate that the COVID-19 pandemic had a minimal impact of
approximately 1-2% on organic consolidated revenues during 2020 as compared to 2019. We estimate
that the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was even
lower, with no material effects on our operations. The revenue streams most negatively affected in 2020
include advertising, media selling and mobile handsets sales. Following the COVID-19 outbreak in
March 2020, we implemented cost optimization initiatives and managed our capital expenditure plans


-----

in response to the pandemic, but we did so in a way that would not hinder our ability to achieve future
growth or adversely impact the quality of services provided.

Our telecommunications segments have continued to meet customers’ expectations on service level and
our network operating centers have maintained normal service levels. Based on this, no significant
change in our customer base occurred. As customers were unlikely or unable to easily migrate during
the crisis, in 2020 we experienced somewhat lower gross additions and churn rates, with our operations
normalizing during 2021. Organic revenues and UG Adjusted EBITDA in our telecommunications
segment remained stable during 2020 compared to the previous year.

During the first waves of lockdowns imposed in response to the COVID-19 pandemic between March
and May 2020, as an increasing number of people began to work or study remotely and spend significant
amounts of time at home, we saw a significant increase in our voice and data traffic. In particular, over
this period, our fixed data traffic increased at rates between 50% and 70%, while fixed voice traffic
increased at rates between 50% and 85%, depending on the country. In addition, our mobile data and
voice traffic increased at rates between 30% and 40%, depending on the country. To accommodate such
higher customer demand, we increased capacity on network elements and interconnections.

In our Media segment, we estimate that organic revenue in the segment declined by approximately 56% for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the previous year. This decline was due in part
to the postponement of certain sporting events and a decline in advertising revenue, partially offset by
a decline in relevant costs. Overall, supported by cost optimization efforts, UG Adjusted EBITDA in
the Media segment remained broadly stable year on year prior to giving effect to the Nova Broadcasting
Group Acquisition. During the nine months ended September 30, 2021, we have seen levels of organic
advertising increasing and surpassing pre-COVID levels.

Throughout the pandemic, we have continued to grow the Group through acquisitions, completing the
acquisitions of Tele2 Croatia (completed in March 2020), Vivacom (completed in July 2020), Nova
(completed in November 2020) and Nova BG (completed in January 2021). The impact of COVID-19
on these acquired companies is similar to that of the Group’s existing telecommunications operations.
The expected contribution of the acquired companies has not materially changed given the crisis and
all such acquired companies are performing in line with or above our expectations.

(1) Homes passed represents all homes (households) ready to be connected directly to our fixed-line network.


-----

(2) Unique cable subscribers represent the number of individual end-users who have subscribed to one or more of our
cable-based services. In all of our cable markets, cable Pay-TV is the basic service that a cable unique subscriber is
typically required to subscribe to in order to receive the Group’s other services such as broadband internet access
and telephony, with the exception of Bulgaria. A unique cable subscriber may subscribe to several different services,
thereby accounting for only one unique cable subscriber, but several RGUs.

(3) Cable Pay-TV RGUs includes (i) the sum of our analog and digital cable Pay-TV RGUs in Slovenia, (ii) our total
analog cable Pay-TV RGUs (without separately counting analog cable RGUs that have purchased digital top ups) in
Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro and (iii) our analog and digital cable Pay-TV RGUs in Bulgaria.

(4) DTH subscribers represent the number of individuals across Slovenia, Serbia, Bulgaria, Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Greece, Montenegro and North Macedonia who have subscribed to our DTH pay-TV services. We believe most of
these subscribers are outside of our cable footprint. Typically, DTH subscribers are only able to subscribe to DTH
based pay-TV services and represent a single RGU. However, we re-sell ADSL services purchased from our
competitors in the respective markets to DTH subscribers.

(5) OTT consists of our NetTV Plus and out-of-footprint EON subscribers.

(6) Broadband internet RGUs represents residential broadband internet provided within our network footprint.

(7) Fixed-line telephony RGUs represents residential fixed-line telephony provided within our network footprint.

(8) Mobile RGUs represents mobile-telephony services provided to customers in Slovenia, where we have operated as
an MNO since our acquisition of Tušmobil in April 2015. Following completion of the acquisition of Tele2 Croatia
in March 2020, we also provide mobile-telephony services in Croatia, and following the completion of the
acquisition of Vivacom in July 2020, we also provide mobile-telephony services in Bulgaria.

(9) Out-of-footprint includes multichannel multipoint distribution service-based services, ADSL internet services and
cable services provided outside of our network footprint.

(10) RGU Penetration represents for cable Pay-TV the number of unique cable subscribers at the end of the relevant
period as a percentage of the number of homes passed by our network, and for broadband internet the number of
RGUs at the end of the relevant period as a percentage of the number of unique cable subscribers.

(11) Blended Cable ARPU is calculated by adding together, for each month in a given period, the total cable Pay-TV,
broadband internet and fixed-line telephony revenues (including fixed-line telephony usage revenues and excluding
minor installation fees) for that particular month divided by the average number of unique cable subscribers for that
month and then dividing that sum by the total number of months in the period. Blended Cable ARPU does not include
mobile ARPU, which was €10.9 for the year ended December 31, 2018, €10.8 for the year ended December 31,
2019, €9.5 for the year ended December 31, 2020, €10.8 for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 and €8.9
for the nine months ended September 30, 2021. We calculate mobile ARPU by adding together, for each month in a
given period, the total mobile-telephony revenues (excluding revenues generated by customers of other networks
roaming on our network and excluding wholesale revenues) for that particular month divided by the average number
of mobile RGUs for that month and then dividing that sum by the total number of months in the period.

(12) As of January 1, 2019, we changed our reporting methodology in regards to certain key operating measures, which
has resulted in immaterial differences as compared to previous periods. For the year ended December 31, 2018, OTT
users on our network have been reclassified to Cable and Cable services users on other networks have been
reclassified to Out-of-footprint from Cable. This change has an immaterial effect on all subscriber, RGU, ARPU and
churn data for the year ended December 31, 2018, and such key operating measures have been restated for such
periods in line with this new reporting methodology.

(a) Represents purchases of tangible and intangible assets, consisting primarily of set-top box purchases and

network build out, upgrades, maintenance and other investments, computer hardware and software, as well
as certain programming rights and licenses.

(b) Represents the difference following a change in how we account for programming rights. Until December
31, 2016, our Media Group segment included the total value of license agreements signed for programming
rights with a term longer than one year in its UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure. For the purpose of IFRS,
however, the Group had recognized these programming rights as capital expenditure in the period, only to
the extent of assets available for broadcasting (i.e., one season). Starting from January 1, 2017, our Media
Group segment has followed the Group’s approach. However, as certain programming rights prior to this
date had already been reported as UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure by our Media Group segment, there was
a difference compared to the Group’s capital expenditure for the period. This adjustment has been decreasing
since December 31, 2016 as long-term license agreements (which had previously been reported as UG
Adjusted Capital Expenditure) are expiring.

(c) Represents unrealized profit on the intragroup sale of end-user equipment by SBB Serbia. When SBB Serbia
sells this equipment to other United Group companies in compliance with applicable transfer pricing
requirements, it makes an unrealized profit on the sale. These unrealized profits are eliminated for the
purposes of preparing our accounts in accordance with IFRS, but are not eliminated for the purpose of our
management accounts.

(d) Represents programming rights acquired by our Media Group segment for other Group segments which were
recognized under IFRS as intangible assets and were invoiced to other Group segments after March 31 and
September 30, 2021.

(e) Relates to the fact that our management accounts are closed prior to the closing of our accounts prepared in
accordance with IFRS. Overflow between periods in any given period reflects the additional capital
expenditure incurred between the preparation of our management accounts and our accounts prepared in
accordance with IFRS for such period.

(f) Represents the additional effect of harmonizing our accounting policy with respect to the capitalization of
subscriber acquisition costs for rebinding, upselling and cross-selling (which in the past were not eligible to
be capitalized, but under IFRS 15 qualify for capitalization), which were determined subsequent to the
preparation of our management accounts.

(g) Represents the exclusion of right-of-use asset additions and, starting from 2021 the right-of-use asset
modifications and prepayments.

While we adopted IFRS 16 with effect from January 1, 2019, we did not give effect to IFRS 16 in the calculation
of UG Adjusted EBITDA until January 1, 2021. Starting from 2021, we revised the methodology of calculation of
UG Adjusted EBITDA, which now includes the impact from the implementation of IFRS 16. For comparability
purposes, in this offering memorandum we present (i) UG Adjusted EBITDA in line with the revised methodology
(i.e., incorporating IFRS 16 effect) for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, and for the nine months
ended September 30, 2020 and 2021, and (ii) UG Adjusted EBITDAaL, which is calculated as UG Adjusted
EBITDA excluding the impact of expenses that were capitalized as a result of the implementation of IFRS 16, for
the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, and for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 and 2021. Since
we only adopted IFRS 16 since January 1, 2019, we have not restated any previous historical financial data. As a
result, UG Adjusted EBITDA and UG Adjusted EBITDAaL presented in this offering memorandum for the year
ended December 31, 2018 do not account for the effect from the implementation of IFRS 16, and may not be
directly comparable to the metrics presented for periods after December 31, 2018. For more information, see
“Presentation of Financial Data—Company Segment Reporting.”

(1) ARPU (outgoing) is calculated as the sum of Wind Hellas’ outgoing revenue (including voice, data, roaming and
other outgoing revenue) in a relevant period divided by the average number of subscribers in such period. The
average number of subscribers in a given period is calculated as the average number of subscriber in each month
divided by the number of months in such period. The average number of subscribers in a given month is calculated
as the average between the number of subscribers at the beginning of such month and the number of subscribers at
the end of such month. Subscribers for the Mobile ARPU (outgoing) calculation include post-paid mobile and prepaid mobile (one-month active customers) subscribers.

(2) Average monthly data usage per subscriber is calculated as the total traffic consumption in any mobile service for a
given period divided by the average number of subscriber in such period.

(3) Wind Hellas reports the number of subscribers in its mobile business based on the number of SIM cards in use and
not the actual number of individuals or businesses using its services. Subscribers that pay in advance for services to
be delivered are counted as pre-paid mobile subscribers and subscribers that pay periodically through a contractual
agreement are counted as post-paid mobile subscribers. Pre-paid mobile subscribers are counted in Wind Hellas’


-----

subscriber base if they have activated one of its SIM cards in the previous twelve months (for new subscribers) or if
they have recharged their mobile telephone credit in the last twelve months and have not requested that their SIM
card be deactivated and have not switched to another telecommunications operator via mobile number portability
during this period (for its existing mobile subscribers), unless fraudulent activity has occurred. Post-paid mobile
subscribers are counted in Wind Hellas’ subscriber base if they have an active contract unless their SIM card is
deactivated upon their request or because fraudulent activity has occurred. Wind Hellas reports the number of
subscribers in its fixed-line business, based upon LLU & NGA. LLU & NGA subscribers are counted in Wind
Hellas’ subscriber base if they have an active contract. Any active LLU and NGA customer with a simultaneous
active Wind Vision contract is considered as a Wind Vision subscriber in Wind Hellas’ subscriber base.

EBITDA” as WH EBITDA adjusted for certain exceptional items, such as indemnities, stock option incentive plans,

attributable to specific projects or transactions that have occurred in the relevant period. Wind Hellas defines “WH
Adjusted EBITDAaL” as WH Adjusted EBITDA adjusted to exclude the impact of expenses that were capitalized
as a result of the implementation of IFRS 16. Wind Hellas defines “WH Adjusted EBITDAaL for the Vantage
Towers Disposal” as WH Adjusted EBITDAaL after giving pro-forma effect to the Vantage Tower Disposal as if it
had occurred on January 1, 2020, as calculated in Wind Hellas’ management accounts.

WH EBITDA, WH Adjusted EBITDA, WH Adjusted EBITDAaL and WH Adjusted EBITDAaL for the Vantage

Adjusted EBITDAaL and WH Adjusted EBITDAaL for the Vantage Towers Disposal should not be considered
alternatives to (a) operating income or net income (as determined in accordance with IFRS) as a measure of operating
performance, (b) cash flows from operating, investing and financing activities as a measure of ability to meet cash
needs or (c) any other measures of performance under generally accepted accounting principles. WH EBITDA, WH
Adjusted EBITDA, WH Adjusted EBITDAaL and WH Adjusted EBITDAaL for the Vantage Towers Disposal and
similar measures are used by different companies for differing purposes and are often calculated in ways that reflect
the circumstances of those companies. Caution should be exercised in comparing WH EBITDA, WH Adjusted
EBITDA, WH Adjusted EBITDAaL and WH Adjusted EBITDAaL for the Vantage Towers Disposal as reported by
Wind Hellas to similar measures of other companies.
