Our in-house content business produces distinctive and attractive content for our Pay-TV channels and
has historically driven Pay-TV subscriptions. We currently produce over 50% of the total content in our
national (terrestrial) and most of our Pay-TV operations, and our main prime-time programs typically
receive ratings of between 20% and 50% in the markets in which they are available. As part of our
media business, we also provide advertising services and digital production and distribution in our
markets. We are also a distribution partner of choice for premium regional and international content
owners because of our well-known brands, large network and our focus on Southeastern Europe.

Our core telecommunications business is complemented by our two OTT distribution platforms that
customers can access through internet-based streaming: (i) EON, our regional OTT platform in
Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Greece, which enables customers connected to our
competitors’ broadband internet connections outside of our cable footprint to access our attractive
portfolio of Pay-TV channels; and (ii) NetTV Plus, our international OTT platform, which delivers
ethnic and local language content to the ex-Yugoslav diaspora around the world. In July 2020, we
launched Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online shopping platform, which offers more than 20


-----

popular product categories, and is available as an integrated online and TV shopping platform in Serbia
and Slovenia.

We believe that we are well-positioned to maintain and grow our market-leading positions, as we
provide a well-invested network, some of the fastest download speeds, access to desirable media content
and high-quality customer service, all of which has led to relatively low churn rates and high customer
loyalty. Our customers view the telecommunications products and services that we offer as part of their
everyday lives, which results in recurring, high demand and makes our business more resilient to macroeconomic disruptions, including the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic where we saw data and voice traffic
increase.

**Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations**

The performance of our businesses, our results of operations and the key operating measures discussed
below have been, and will continue to be, affected by a variety of factors. Certain of these factors are
discussed below.

**_Products, Services and Content_**

Our results are impacted by our product mix as well as our ability to introduce new products and
upgrades and successfully sell those products and upgrades to increase our RGUs and ARPUs. We
continually evaluate the suite of products and services we provide to our subscribers to ensure that we
remain competitive with other providers in our markets and have an opportunity to increase our
subscriber base and the number of products we sell to our subscribers. We accomplish this through
product innovation, investments in technology and acquisitions of complementary businesses. For
example, over the years we have expanded our product offering by introducing fixed-line services to
offer multi-play packages in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Bulgaria and
Greece, including, depending on the relevant geographical market, pay television, broadband internet
access, fixed-line telephony, as well as mobile-telephony services in Slovenia and Croatia.

We believe that media and communications services customers will increasingly choose bundled
products because of the convenience and enhanced value resulting from obtaining TV, broadband
internet and telephony services from a single provider for one price. As of September 30, 2021, 86% of
our customer base in Slovenia, 80% of our customer base in Serbia, 88% of our customer base in Bosnia
and Herzegovina and 50% of our customer base in Bulgaria subscribed for one of our multi-play
packages (our customer base is calculated in each case based on unique cable subscribers by bundle).

We seek to be the leader in our markets in pay television content and have entered into long-term
strategic partnerships with key international and regional content owners. We have also acquired
leading regional content owners in key television sub-segments (sports, lifestyle, children and films),
such as providers of the Sport Klub family of channels (which includes Sport Klub, Golf Klub and our
fishing and hunting channels), N1, Fight Channel, Pikaboo and Cinemania. Our ability to maintain the
quality of our content impacts our ability to sell our pay television offerings, as well as bundled
packages.

Our product mix can also impact our margins. For example, our mobile-telephony business and our
content business generally have lower margins compared to our cable-based business. Our success in
growing these businesses may impact our product mix and therefore may affect UG Adjusted EBITDA
margins.

**_Pricing of Our Products and Services_**

Increasing demand for attractive content and higher broadband speeds allows us to increase the prices
at which we provide these services. We regularly review the prices of our products and services,
however, and in the past have adjusted our subscription fees as necessary in line with inflation, changes
in foreign exchange rates or in response to market conditions and content costs. Changes in the pricing


-----

of our products and services impact the revenues and margins that we generate from these products and
services as well as our ability to attract new customers. For example, our multi-play bundles offer
subscribers higher value in terms of channels, speeds functionality and add on features. The pricing of
all our services, including our multi-play bundles, is dependent on market conditions, pricing by
competitors with similar offerings and the perceived quality of our products versus other products. In
some of our countries of operations we may also become subject to price regulations. See “—
_Regulation.”_

**_Subscriber Churn_**

The television, broadband internet and telephony industries exhibit churn as a result of high levels of
competition. In addition to competitive alternatives, churn levels may be affected by changes in our
prices or our competitors’ prices, our level of subscriber satisfaction, subscriber mortality and the
relocation of subscribers, as well as from the termination of agreements. An increase in churn may lead
to increased costs and reduced revenues when subscribers cancel our services as we incur additional
marketing and advertising costs to find new subscribers.

Demand for attractive content and higher broadband speeds allows us to increase the prices at which
we provide these services while maintaining relatively low churn rates, which we believe provides us
with recurring cash flows and visibility with respect to future revenues. We have historically
experienced low churn rates in our television, broadband internet and fixed-line telephony businesses,
and the churn we have experienced in these businesses has primarily been driven by customers moving
outside of our geographic area of services as well as their inability to pay. Only a limited amount of
churn was driven by competition. We believe that launching telephony in our markets, further driving
digitization, providing our subscribers with multi-play packages, expanding our cable footprint to
broaden our geographic reach and benefiting from increasing disposable incomes in the region
(reducing the likelihood of customers’ bad debt), will allow us to maintain low churn rates for cable
Pay-TV. In addition, as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, our churn rates have decreased as
customers have been less likely or unable to easily migrate to another provider during the pandemic.

The churn rates for our mobile post-paid subscribers are higher than the churn rates for our fixed-line
telephony services, as it is easier for mobile subscribers to switch to our competitors since there are no
infrastructure limitations. Similarly, the churn rate of mobile pre-paid subscribers is relatively higher
because of the non-contractual nature of the relationship with such subscribers. We believe, however,
that we have developed an attractive suite of fixed mobile convergence services in Slovenia which,
among other things, has positively impacted the churn of our mobile post-paid subscribers in Slovenia.
Since our acquisition of Tušmobil, our number of quad-play subscribers in Slovenia has increased to
40% of our subscribers as of September 30, 2021, from 1% of our subscribers prior to the acquisition.
The blended annual churn rate of our Slovenia Group segment’s mobile post-paid subscribers as of
September 30, 2021, was 10%, compared to 11% as of January 31, 2017. We define blended annual
churn as net lost subscribers (the number of customers that either on a voluntary or involuntary basis
no longer subscribe for a certain service) divided by the number of all unique cable subscribers at the
beginning of period, which result is then annualized. We have been using the principles learned through
our acquisition of Tušmobil and our experience providing mobile services in Slovenia to inform the
operation of our mobile-telephony business in Bulgaria and Croatia.

**_Cost of Services Provided_**

Our most significant costs include (i) carriage fees which we pay to international and regional
broadcasters such as Fox, Discovery and Pink, to carry their programs on our distribution network, (ii)
licensing fees payable to sports rights owners such as UEFA, the English Premier League, Spanish
Primera League, ATP and Formula 1, to develop content for our own channels, (iii) satellite capacity
costs, (iv) payroll costs, (v) internet and interconnection fees, (vi) costs of materials used to connect
subscribers to our network and (vii) costs for marketing and sales. Most of our costs, such as a portion
of our network operations, customer care, billing and administration costs, are relatively fixed, while a


-----

portion of our marketing and customer services cost is variable. Our content acquisition costs are mostly
fixed and a decreasing portion of these costs are subscriber based. Where possible, we aim to negotiate
fixed rate content costs. This approach allows us to anticipate the input price of our content and price
our products accordingly. However, the costs associated with the growth of our business, such as RGU
acquisition costs, which are primarily comprised of campaign costs and sales costs for attracting new
subscribers, are variable costs.

A large portion of our costs is content costs, accounting for 18% of our operating expenses (not
including depreciation and amortization of intangible assets) for the nine months ended September 30,
2021. While we own a portion of our content, we are dependent on broadcasters and other content
owners for most of our programming. We pay license fees to several regional and international
broadcasters in order to broadcast their programs. For on-demand content purchased by our subscribers,
we generally pay a revenue share of the retail price, subject, for certain on demand content, to fixed
minimum guarantees. For packaged on-demand content (subscription video on-demand), we pay on a
per subscriber basis, sometimes with minimum guarantees. We generally expect that our content costs
(above the minimum amounts) will increase in line with increased revenues from digital Pay-TV and
on demand content. In the past we have successfully obtained rebates and discounts for our content, but
these may not continue in the future.

We pay fees to satellite operators to uplink and transmit our content to our DTH subscribers, and we
also use other network operators to connect telephone calls of our customers to customers of their
respective networks (interconnection). Generally, the amount we pay in interconnection fees in any
period will depend on the level of usage of our services.

Our staff cost is impacted by the number of personnel we employ, the experience levels at which such
persons are employed and increases in salaries and bonuses due to performance factors. Labor costs of
technicians, spent on the construction and upgrade of our network and acquisition of subscribers, are
capitalized as tangible and intangible assets.

RGU acquisition costs include campaign costs and sales costs. We aim to recover RGU acquisition
costs over the duration of the service contract. Factors that contribute to successful recovery of RGU
acquisition costs include our operational efficiency, the density of our subscriber base and our direct
relationships with our subscribers, which enables us not to rely on intermediaries to interact with our
customers.

**_Network and Technological Advances_**

Our ability to provide new high definition and on demand digital TV services, broadband internet access
at higher speeds and telephony services to subscribers depends, in part, on our ability to upgrade and
maintain our network. We incur capital expenditure charges in periods over which these upgrades are
made, with the aim of recouping these investments through increased revenues and profitability.

In particular, we expect certain communications technologies that are currently under development, 5G
technology in particular, to become increasingly important in our markets. We successfully tested and
are rolling out our next generation 5G networks across our mobile-telephony footprint. In Slovenia, 5G
3600 MHz deployment and commercial launch began in June 2021, following a successful frequency
auction result in April 2021. In Bulgaria, 5G has been launched commercially using 4G 1900 MHz
spectrum in September 2020, which was the first available 5G service in the market, and in May 2021,
we secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band. In Croatia, we
secured 15-year spectrum licenses for 5G frequencies in July 2021, and commenced the deployment
and commercial launch of our 5G C-Band in September 2021. We believe that significant investments
in 5G technology will be critical to remain competitive in the mobile market and meet our customers’
needs.


-----

Our ability to compete effectively and maintain or increase our customer base depends on our ability to
anticipate and react quickly to technological developments and evolving industry standards and develop
successful new and enhanced products and services to adapt to changes in our market. We invest in new
or enhanced technologies, products or services in periods over which industry standards change, or to
upgrade our technologies proactively. Additionally, we incur capital expenditure costs relating to the
replacement of existing equipment. We expect to incur substantial capital expenditure costs in the future
relating to new 4G and 5G frequencies and the installation of new equipment.

**_Foreign Currency Exchange Rates_**

We operate across Southeastern Europe, generating revenues in many local currencies, which fluctuate
from time to time in relation to the euro. Our revenues in Slovenia, Montenegro and Greece are
generated in euro. We present our consolidated financial statements in euro. As a result, we must
translate the assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses of all of our operations with a functional currency
other than the euro into euros at then applicable exchange rates. Consequently, increases or decreases
in the value of these currencies against the euro may affect the value of our assets, liabilities, revenue
and expenses with respect to our non-euro businesses in our consolidated financial statements, even if
their value has not changed in their original currency. These translations could significantly affect the
comparability of our results between financial periods and result in significant changes to the carrying
value of our assets, liabilities and stockholders’ equity.

We record the financial results of our Serbia, Bosnia, Bulgaria and Croatia Group segments in Serbian
dinar, Bosnian and Herzegovinian mark, Bulgarian lev and Croatian kuna, respectively, which are then
translated into euros in preparing our consolidated financial statements. In the nine months ended
September 30, 2021, 37% of our revenue was generated in euros or currencies pegged to the euro, with
15%, 4%, 35% and 13% of our revenue generated in Serbian dinars, Bosnian and Herzegovinian mark,
Bulgarian lev and Croatian kuna, respectively. While the Bosnian and Herzegovinian mark is pegged
against the euro at a fixed exchange rate of BAM 1.9558 per €1.00 and the Bulgarian lev is pegged
against the euro at a fixed exchange rate of BGN 1.9558 per €1.00, the Serbian dinar freely fluctuates
against the euro. For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, the value of the Serbian dinar remained
stable relative to the euro. However, due to the historic indexation of the Serbian dinar against the
German mark, which was replaced by the euro in 2002, we believe the Serbian consumer price index
closely tracks the depreciation of the Serbian dinar against the euro which has historically allowed us
to “pass through” a portion of the impact of the depreciation of the dinar to our customers. We believe
that our pricing strategy reflects this “pass through” principle. In the nine months ended September 30,
2021, the value of the Croatian kuna increased approximately 1% relative to the euro compared to the
nine months ended September 30, 2020.

Additionally, certain of our expenses, primarily content and satellite costs, are denominated in euros
and U.S. dollars. Where we are unable to match sales received in foreign currencies with costs paid in
the same currency, our results of operations are impacted by currency exchange rate fluctuations. A
substantial portion of our indebtedness is denominated in euros. Based on our lack of any material
change in exposure to the U.S. dollar in the nine months ended September 30, 2021, we did not enter
into any additional currency hedge agreements during the nine months ended September 30, 2021.

**_Growth in Our Markets_**

Three of our key markets—Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro—are generally
characterized by lower internet broadband household penetration rates compared to elsewhere in
Western Europe and the CEE region and both Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina have lower pay
television household penetration rates compared to elsewhere in Western Europe and the CEE region.
As a result, growth in our markets has been higher than in certain CEE and Western Europe
jurisdictions. We believe this is primarily due to the increasing importance of high-quality broadband
internet and an increasing convergence of our regions with the EU. Slovenia is a more mature market,
with subscriber rates similar to the CEE region, and as a result, growth in that market will depend more


-----

on our ability to effectively compete with other market participants and to continue to offer high-quality
customer propositions. Croatia is a member of the EU with relatively high GDP per capita and growth
rates, and as a result it is an attractive market for our continued expansion. The Croatian mobile market
is characterized by high market stability, as it has a low level of fragmentation and disruption, with only
three MNOs in the market (including us), and the country’s telecommunications infrastructure is highly
dependent on mobile access, with one of the highest mobile ARPU among CEE countries. We believe
that our growth in this market will depend on several factors, such as the ability to expand our territorial
coverage as well as improve the quality of our network and customer support services, including
through investments to increase our capacity and quality levels and through the continued development
of our digital and sales channels. Bulgaria experienced relatively strong real GDP growth at an average
rate of 3.1% per year between 2016 and 2019. Economic activity in Bulgaria shrank by 4.4% in 2020
due to the COVID-19 pandemic (according to the BNSI). The Greek telecommunications market is
characterized by intense competition. This market is concentrated among four main operators with a
focus on fixed-mobile convergent offerings. The total fixed-line market has stable with limited fixedto-mobile substitution, while the broadband market continues to grow at the expense of voice-only lines.
NGA subscribers (those with broadband speeds of greater than 30 Mbps) comprise approximately onethird of total broadband subscribers, but this level remains low compared with the EU average of over
60%. Pay-TV penetration is also low compared to EU averages, with 26% of Greek households
subscribing to Pay-TV. In Greece, the majority of Pay-TV subscribers are served through DTH
technology, while the remainder is served through IPTV.

In each of our markets, a number of factors impacts the rate of growth of pay television, broadband
internet and telephony industries, including economic conditions, political stability, increases in
infrastructure and an increased distribution of wealth. Furthermore, these industries may not grow at
the same rate as they have in the past.

**_Regulation_**

Our operations are subject to various regulations in Europe and in our regional markets. We are
generally free from retail price regulation. Since January 2017, we are no longer considered a significant
market participant in the Pay-TV market in Serbia, thus our Basic TV package is no longer subject to
price regulation, although this may change in the future, and we regularly monitor the market to stay
aware of market conditions which may lead to price regulation. In Croatia, we are currently subject to
price regulation only with respect to fixed and mobile termination rates charged by operators to each
other for interconnection services, which are regulated in the whole European Union. In addition, in
Serbia we are subject to price regulation only to the extent we are required to provide access to our
wholesale network.

However, in Serbia we are currently deemed to have SMP on the wholesale market for call termination
in public telephone networks and the wholesale market of central access at a fixed location for mass
market products, which imposes certain regulatory obligations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to
_Our Business and Industry—We may become subject to more extensive regulation due to our scale.”_
We also implemented price increases in January 2018, which the Serbian Commission for Protection of
Competition investigated, but ultimately accepted. In addition, we may be subject to conditions imposed
in connection with competition authority clearances as we continue to expand our business through bolt
on, value accretive acquisitions and we may be subject to market power analysis from the relevant
regulators, which could force us to adjust our prices or sell various parts of our businesses. See also
“Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We may become subject to more
_extensive regulation due to our scale” and “Our Business—Regulatory Framework.”_

**_Tax Treatment in Local Jurisdictions_**

The results of our operations depend on our tax treatment under the tax laws and regulations of local
jurisdictions. For instance, in Serbia, taxable income can be reduced in the same proportion as capital
expenditure for the year in Serbia divided by the carrying amount of assets in Serbia. Due to our


-----

significant capital expenditure in Serbia in 2016, we believe we have satisfied the requirements to be
granted a ten year tax beneficial status, expiring in 2025, and we recorded beneficial tax treatment for
our Serbia Group segment for the years ending December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and the nine months
ended September 30, 2021. Additionally, under thin capitalization rules in Serbia, interest and related
costs under intercompany loans are recognized as deductible expenses to the extent the intercompany
loans do not exceed four times the borrower’s equity. In 2017 and 2018, SBB Serbia did not capitalize
any intercompany loans. On December 27, 2018, the Serbian Tax Authority notified us that it had begun
a tax investigation of SBB Serbia for the year ended December 31, 2012. The Serbian Tax Authority
issued a decision in March 2019 that it had recharacterized interest payments made by SBB Serbia
under an intragroup loan agreement (and certain debt and equity conversions) as dividends, which
would have been subject to a 5% withholding tax, and found a total contingent liability in respect of
this decision amounting to €21 million, including late interest. On October 12, 2020, the Serbian
Ministry of Finance annulled the Serbian Tax Authority’s decision and instructed the Serbian Tax
Authority to restart the procedure. The Serbian Tax Authority has also informed SBB Serbia that it is
opening a tax review for the years 2013 through 2016. We intend to continue contesting the Serbian
Tax Authority’s findings. For more information, see “Our Business—Legal Proceedings—Investigation
_by the Serbian Tax Authority.”_

Furthermore, in Slovenia, we may use a tax allowance for investment in equipment and intangible assets
(available for investments made after January 1, 2008), whereby the tax allowance is limited to 40% of
the value of the assets, up to the amount of the tax base. In 2018, 2019 and 2020, Telemach Slovenia
used the tax allowance for investments in the amount of €11.5 million, €10.5 million and €9.3 million,
respectively.

In Bosnia and Herzegovina, a taxpayer who invests more than BAM 20.0 million (€10.2 million) in
production assets (property, plant and equipment) within the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina for
five consecutive years is relieved from 50% of taxation on such investments for a period of five years,
starting from the first year in which it has invested at least BAM 4 million (€2.0 million). Pursuant to
this provision, in 2018, 2019 and 2020, we received a tax allowance for investments in the amount of
BAM 6.1 million (€3.1 million), BAM 6.8 million (€3.5 million) and BAM 2.7 million (€1.4 million),
respectively. In Bosnia and Herzegovina, a taxpayer receives a tax allowance when it employs certain
types of employees, and in 2018, 2019 and 2020, we received a tax allowance for certain new employees
in the amount of BAM 1.3 million (€0.7 million), BAM 2.0 million (€1.0 million) and BAM 2.9 million
(€1.5 million), respectively.

In Greece, the corporate income tax rate was set at 24% for income generated in tax years 2019 and
2020, and it is currently set at 22% for income generated in tax year 2021 and onward. From January 1,
2020, withholding taxes on dividends were reduced from 10% to 5%, and on July 1, 2020, Greece
implemented a participation exemption for capital gains from the sale of Greek and EU subsidiaries.
For internet services, customers are charged a 5% tax on top of internet subscriptions (in addition to
VAT of 24%). In addition, a 10% tax on top of Pay-TV subscriptions for Greek operators (in addition
to VAT of 24%) has been imposed, although this has been suspended until June 30, 2022.

**_Implementation of Accounting Policies and Accounting Updates_**

_IFRS 16 Leases_

IFRS 16 introduced for annual reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2019 a single, on
balance sheet lease accounting model for lessees. A lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset representing
its right to use the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make lease
payments. There are recognition exemptions for short-term leases and leases of low value items
available on a voluntary basis. Lessor accounting remains similar to the previous standard—i.e., lessors
continue to classify leases as finance or operating leases.


-----

Under IFRS 16, we recognize new assets and liabilities for our operating leases of satellite capacity,
office facilities, parts of our infrastructure and base stations and the right-of-use of water and land. The
nature of expenses related to those leases changed because we recognized a depreciation charge for
right-of-use assets and interest expense on lease liabilities. Previously, we recognized operating lease
expense on a straight-line basis over the term of the lease, and recognized assets and liabilities only to
the extent that there was a timing difference between actual lease payments and the expense recognized.
There has been no significant impact for our finance leases in which we are the lessor.

We applied the simplified transition approach and did not restate comparative amounts for the year prior
to first adoption. Right-of-use assets for property leases were measured on transition as if the new rules
had always been applied. All other right-of-use assets have been measured at the amount of the lease
liability on adoption (adjusted for any pre-paid or accrued lease expenses).

_IFRIC 23_

In June 2017, the IFRS Interpretation Committee issued IFRIC 23, which clarifies the accounting
treatment of uncertainties in income taxes, specifically in relation to taxable profit or loss, tax bases,
unused tax losses, unused tax credits and tax rates, when there is uncertainty over income tax treatments
under IAS 12.

IFRIC 23 states that an entity should assume that the applicable taxation authority will have full
knowledge of all relevant information when examining amounts reported to it. An entity therefore has
to consider whether it is probable that the applicable authority will accept a certain tax treatment in the
entity’s income tax filing and either adopt an approach consistent with the tax treatment in its income
tax filings or use the expected value of the tax treatment when determining taxable profit or loss, tax
bases, unused tax losses, unused tax credits and tax rates.

IFRIC 23 is applicable for annual reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2019 with early
adoption permitted. In adopting IFRIC 23, we applied a modified retrospective approach whereby the
cumulative effect of initially applying IFRIC 23, if any, should be recognized in opening equity at the
date of initial application. As part of our adoption of IFRIC 23, we have not identified any additional
material income tax uncertainties for which we would be required to recognize a related tax liability.

_Other_

In the nine months ended September 30, 2021, we have also applied certain other amendments to
existing accounting standards that did not have any impact on the amounts recognized in prior periods
and that are not expected to significantly affect current or future periods.

-----

EAD, Digital Cable Television EOOD (N3), Serbian distribution company D Express, local internet

market enabling Telemach Croatia to offer a full range of telecommunication services, including payTV, through its existing infrastructure. Following completion of the Optima Telekom Acquisition, we
will be required to undertake a tender offer for the remaining shares of Optima Telekom not yet

Please refer to Note 21 to the Company Unaudited Interim Financial Statements for additional

On August 14, 2021, we entered into the Wind Hellas Acquisition Agreement with the Seller to acquire

Greece, furthering our penetration into the Greek market following our acquisition of Nova in 2020.

On August 20, 2021, we signed an agreement to acquire an 80% ownership interest in Tessa Energy

On November 9, 2021, we acquired a 33% stake in Marquee TV, a specialist streaming service for arts

On November 30, 2021, we signed an agreement to acquire Telnet OOD, a cable operator in Bulgaria.

In addition, we are currently in discussions to acquire a majority interest in Telelink Business Services
Group AD, a technology company in Bulgaria. The transaction is subject to ongoing negotiations, due

Acquisitions affect our results of operations in a variety of ways. Our results for the period during which
an acquisition takes place are affected by the inclusion or exclusion of the results of the acquired or
disposed of business in our consolidated results. In addition, the results of the acquired businesses after
their acquisition may be impacted positively by synergies. We may also experience an increase in
operating expenses, including staff cost, as we integrate the acquired business into our network.
Acquisitions may also result in higher levels of depreciation and amortization expense. In addition,
because acquired entities are consolidated from the date of their acquisition and disposed of entities are


-----

no longer consolidated from the date of their disposition, the full impact of an acquisition or disposition
is only reflected in our financial statements in the subsequent periods. As a result, the historical results
of operations for the periods presented in this offering memorandum may not be comparable with each
other. See “Our Business—History” for a discussion of these acquisitions.

We are a pan regional distribution platform of cable and satellite Pay-TV, broadband internet and

**Key Operating Measures**

We use several key operating measures, including homes passed, unique subscribers, RGUs and ARPU,
to track the performance of our business. None of these terms are measures of financial performance
under IFRS, nor have these measures been reviewed by an outside auditor, consultant or expert. These
measures are derived from management information systems. As these terms are defined by our
management, they may not be comparable to similar terms used by other companies.

**_Unique Subscribers, RGUs and ARPU_**

Unique cable subscribers represent the number of individual end-users who have subscribed to one or
more of our cable-based services. In all of our cable markets, cable Pay-TV is the basic service that a
cable unique subscriber is typically required to subscribe to in order to receive the Group’s other
services such as broadband internet access and telephony, with the exception of Bulgaria. A unique
cable subscriber may subscribe to several different services, thereby accounting for only one unique
cable subscriber, but several RGUs.

DTH subscribers represent the number of individuals across the six Southeastern European markets
(Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Montenegro and North Macedonia) who have
subscribed to our DTH Pay-TV services. We believe that most of these subscribers are outside of our
cable footprint. Typically, DTH subscribers are only able to subscribe to DTH based Pay-TV services
and represent a single RGU. However, we are re selling ADSL services purchased from our competitors
in the respective markets to DTH subscribers.

Average monthly revenue per user, or ARPU, is a measure we use to evaluate how effectively we are
realizing potential revenues from subscribers. ARPU is calculated by adding together, for each month


-----

in a given period, the total subscription related revenues for that particular month divided by the average
number of subscribers for that month and then dividing that sum by the total number of months in the
period.

Homes passed increased by 158 thousand, or 4%, from 3,669 thousand as of September 30, 2020, to
3,826 thousand as of September 30, 2021, primarily due to organic network expansion and acquisitions
of operators in Bulgaria.

As of September 30, 2021, we had 1,609 thousand cable Pay-TV RGUs, an increase of 116 thousand
compared to 1,492 thousand as of September 30, 2020, primarily due to organic growth and acquisitions
of operators, such as N3 and Net 1, in Bulgaria.

The total number of DTH Pay-TV RGUs amounted to 1,008 thousand as of September 30, 2021, a 43%
increase year-on-year, primarily due to the acquisition of Nova.

As of September 30, 2021, we had 1,513 thousand broadband internet RGUs, representing an increase
of 11%, compared to 1,369 thousand as of September 30, 2020. This is primarily attributable to the
acquisitions of operators in Bulgaria, such as N3 and Net 1, an increase in multi-play subscriptions over
this period and organic subscriber growth.

The total number of fixed-telephony RGUs decreased to 1,252 thousand as of September 30, 2021, a
decrease of 2% compared to 1,272 thousand as of September 30, 2020. This decrease was primarily due
to the declining use of fixed-telephony and the fixed-to-mobile substitution trend at Vivacom. The
number of fixed-telephony RGUs in other segments in the same period increased by 35 thousand as a
result of the growth in multi-play subscriptions over the period and organic subscriber growth.

Our OTT RGUs as of September 30, 2021 increased by 6% to 131 thousand, compared to 123 thousand
as of September 30, 2020.

Our mobile service RGUs increased from 4,538 thousand as of September 30, 2020 to 4,651 thousand
as of September 30, 2021. This is an increase of 112 thousand, or 2%, which was primarily driven by
organic growth in all of our countries of operation.

Our total RGUs increased by 18%, from 9,577 thousand as of September 30, 2020 to 11,323 thousand
as of September 30, 2021. RGUs added over this period were primarily the result of the acquisition of
Nova (1,375 thousand RGUs) and other operators in Bulgaria, such as N3 and Net 1, as well as organic
growth of cable Pay-TV and mobile services and a growing proportion of multi-play subscribers.

**Description of Key Line Items**

**_Revenue. Revenues are generated from the following services: cable television, broadband internet,_**
DTH- TV, value added services (such as OTT), telephony subscriptions and telephony usage, content
and other sources (primarily related to the sale of end-user equipment). Revenues generated from our
bundle subscriptions are allocated to the individual products of standard cable, broadband internet and
telephony subscriptions based on the individual product prices for each product as a percentage of the
sum of the individual product prices. Revenue for these services is charged and recognized in the period
in which these services are provided. We recognize revenues for connection fees upon delivery of
installation and we defer and amortize connection fees over the average remaining useful life of the
customer relationship.


-----

**_Other income. Other income arises mainly from subventions, reversal of provision for legal cases,_**
charged legal cases and other activities nor related to the ordinary course of business.

**_Content costs. Content costs include author rights and royalties we pay to procure our content, and_**
include fees paid to channel providers, primarily related to foreign television channels, as well as the
cost of production of proprietary content. Our content fees are predominantly determined on a flat
monthly amount and to a lesser extent on a per subscriber basis.

**_Satellite capacity costs. Satellite capacity costs relate to the lease of satellite capacity from third-party_**
providers, which currently is EUTELSAT. These costs are impacted by the type and amount of
commercial discounts obtained from satellite providers. With effect from January 1, 2019, satellite
capacity costs are presented under depreciation (right-of-use assets) and finance costs due to the
adoption of IFRS 16.

**_Link and interconnection costs. These costs relate to fees payable in order to transfer data over third-_**
party networks. Internet connection links are leased from various parties.

**_Cost of end-user equipment and other material costs. Cost of end-user equipment and other material_**
costs includes primarily costs to procure handsets and other items sold via Shoppster, as well as office
supplies and other materials. Prior to January 1, 2020, these costs were recorded under the line item
“Material costs.”

**_Staff cost. Staff cost includes wages and salaries, social security costs, pension costs and other post-_**
employment benefits and the cost of temporary and external personnel, adjusted for own work
capitalized based on direct labor hours spent on projects which are capitalized.

**_Media buying. Media buying includes expenses incurred by Direct Media in the territories of Serbia,_**
Montenegro, Albania and North Macedonia. As a leading media network in Southeastern Europe, Direct
Media provides international and local partners with integrated communication, advertising and media
services.

**_Depreciation cost. Depreciation cost relates to the depreciation and impairment of our property, plant_**
and equipment over their useful lives.

**_Amortization of intangible assets. Amortization of intangible assets relates to the amortization and_**
impairment of our intangible assets over their useful lives. Our intangible assets include our customer
base and direct subscriber acquisition costs, which, for our cable and DTH customers, are capitalized
and amortized over the estimated useful life of the customer relationship. For our mobile customers,
subscriber acquisition costs are capitalized and amortized over a twenty four month period (the
estimated life of the post-paid customer contract), while our mobile customer base is capitalized and
amortized over its estimated useful life. Intangible assets also include goodwill, computer software,
licenses and content such as sport rights.

**_Depreciation (right-of-use assets). Depreciation (right-of-use assets) relates to depreciation of right-_**
of-use assets over the shorter of the asset’s useful life and the lease term on a straight-line basis.

**_Net Impairment on trade and other receivables, including contract assets. Net impairment on trade_**
and other receivables, net impairment losses related to impairment of trade receivables, contract assets
and other financial assets. Subsequent recoveries of amounts previously written-off are credited against
the same line item

**_Other operating expenses. Other operating expenses include rent of premises, poles and ducts,_**
marketing and promotion expenses, legal and administrative fees and maintenance costs and other costs.
With effect from January 1, 2019, other operating expenses excludes media buying expenses, which are
included under the separate line item “Media buying.”


-----

**_Operating profit. Operating profit represents the amount of profit from business operations, and_**
includes total revenues less total operating expenses (which contains cost of goods sold, personnel
expenses, contracted work, materials and logistics, marketing and sales, office expenses, other operating
expenses, amortization, depreciation and impairments).

**_Finance income. Finance income includes interest income on funds invested (including short-term_**
bank deposits) and foreign currency gains.

**_Finance costs. Finance costs include interest expense on borrowings and foreign currency losses._**

**_Income tax credit/(expense). Income tax credit/(expense) comprises current and deferred income tax_**
and is recognized in our statement of comprehensive income, except to the extent that such expense or
benefit relates to an item that is recognized as equity in our balance sheet or in our statement of other
comprehensive income.

costs increased by €51.7 million, or 56%, to €143.8 million for the nine months ended September 30,
2021, from €92.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. This increase was primarily
due to higher cost of sales for mobile handsets (mainly due to the acquisitions of Vivacom and Tele2
Croatia), the higher cost of end-user equipment, higher energy and fuel costs mainly as a result of
acquisitions, as well as higher costs of goods sold (mainly relating to goods sold by Shoppster, which
started operations in July 2020).

_Staff cost. Staff cost increased by €102.4 million to €186.2 million for the nine months ended September_
30, 2021, from €83.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. This increase was
primarily due to the increase in staff cost due to the higher number of employees resulting from
acquisitions in 2020 and 2021.

_Media buying. Media buying costs increased by €9.7 million, or 42%, to €32.6 million for the nine_
months ended September 30, 2021, from €22.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020.
This increase was primarily due to the Nova Acquisition and Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition,
which offset the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic (that is, which led to lower media buying volumes
by Direct Media due to decreased overall advertising spend).

_Depreciation. Depreciation increased by €78.8 million, or 82%, to €175.2 million for the nine months_
ended September 30, 2021, from €96.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. This
increase was primarily due to the addition of tangible assets as a result of the acquisitions in 2020 and
2021.

_Depreciation (right-of-use assets). Depreciation (rights-of-use assets) increased by €21.8 million, or_
81%, to €48.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, from €26.9 million for the nine
months ended September 30, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions completed in
2020 and 2021.


-----

_Amortization of intangible assets. Amortization of intangible assets increased by €146.9 million to_
€221.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, from €74.4 million for the nine months
ended September 30, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the addition of intangible assets through
the acquisitions completed in 2020 and 2021.

_Other operating expenses. Other operating expenses increased by €84.4 million, or 70%, to €204.2_
million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, from €119.8 million for the nine months ended
September 30, 2020. While all cost categories saw an increase, the largest increases were in
maintenance, license fee and marketing and promotion costs.

_Net finance costs. Net finance costs increased by €15.1 million, or 15%, to €117.4 million for the nine_
months ended September 30, 2021, from €102.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020.
This increase was primarily due to higher interest expense related to new bond issuances.

_Loss before tax. Loss before tax increased by €28.5 million to €51.6 million for the nine months ended_
September 30, 2021, from €23.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. This increase
in loss before tax was primarily due to the impairment of contract assets from unbilled revenues and
higher net finance costs, which were partially offset by an increased operating profit.

_Income tax expense. Income tax expense slightly decreased to €10.3 million for the nine months ended_
September 30, 2021 from €10.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020.

_UG Adjusted EBITDAaL and UG Adjusted EBITDAaL Margin. UG Adjusted EBITDAaL increased by_
€236.8 million, or 83%, to €523.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, from €286.6
million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the impact
of the acquisitions of Tele2 Croatia, Vivacom and Nova, which were completed in March 2020, July
2020 and November 2020, respectively, as well as the organic growth of our subscriber base, price
increases, continued successful cross-selling, migration of subscribers to multi-play packages and
effective cost discipline.

UG Adjusted EBITDAaL Margin decreased by 1% to 38% for the nine months ended September 30,
2021, from 39% for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to the
contribution of our Croatia Group and Greece Group segments which had lower UG Adjusted EBITDA
Margins as compared to our other segments, as well as the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

_UG Adjusted EBITDAaL by Segment_

We discuss below UG Adjusted EBITDAaL by segment for the nine months ended September 30, 2021,
compared to the nine months ended September 30, 2020.

Slovenia Group segment. UG Adjusted EBITDAaL increased by €5.2 million, or 9%, to €64.7 million
for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, from €59.5 million for the nine months ended September
30, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the organic growth of fixed and mobile RGUs, price
increases in March 2020 (related to mobile services, and EON premium package) and October 2020
(related to both mobile and fixed services) as well as the acquisition of 12 thousand unique video
subscribers in the year ended December 31, 2020.

Serbia Group segment. UG Adjusted EBITDAaL decreased by €0.3 million to €88.8 million for the
nine months ended September 30, 2021, from €89.1 million for the nine months ended September 30,
2020. This decrease was primarily due to the impact of sales promotions from the previous period.

Bosnia Group segment. UG Adjusted EBITDAaL increased by €2.9 million, or 17%, to €20.4 million
for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, from €17.5 million for the nine months ended September
30, 2020. This increase was primarily due to lower programming costs resulting from the non-renewal


-----

of our contract with Arenasport, which generated estimated cost savings of €3.9 million. This increase
was partly offset by the impact of sales promotions from the previous period.

Montenegro Group segment. UG Adjusted EBITDAaL increased by €0.6 million, or 30%, to €2.6
million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, from €2.0 million for the nine months ended
September 30, 2020. This increase was primarily due to lower direct costs and lower operational costs,
while revenues remained at the same level.

Bulgaria Group segment. UG Adjusted EBITDAaL increased by €141.6 million to €176.6 million for
the nine months ended September 30, 2021, from €35.0 million for the nine months ended September
30, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the consolidation of Vivacom into our results following
completion of its acquisition by us in July 2021. The increase was also driven by improved revenue
performance supported by a rationalization of our cost structure, which led to gross margin expansion
despite the negative impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Croatia Group segment. UG Adjusted EBITDAaL increased by €8.4 million, or 23%, to €44.2 million
for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, from €35.8 million for the nine months ended September
30, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the consolidation of Tele2 Croatia into our results
following completion of its acquisition by us in March 2020, as well as growth of our subscriber base
in the mobile post-paid voice segment and a recovery in revenues from roaming customers.

Media Group segment. UG Adjusted EBITDAaL increased by €34.3 million, or 64%, to €88.1 million
for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, from €53.8 million for the nine months ended September
30, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the consolidation of Nova BG in the Media Group segment
following completion of its acquisition in February 2021, which offset the negative effect from the
expiration of certain contracts for carriage fees in connection with the COVID 19 pandemic in the nine
months ended September 30, 2020.

which had lower UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin in 2019 as compared to 2018, largely as a result of
acquisitions.

_UG Adjusted EBITDAaL by Segment_

We discuss below UG Adjusted EBITDAaL by segment for the year ended December 31, 2019,
compared to the year ended December 31, 2018.

Slovenia Group segment. UG Adjusted EBITDAaL increased by €2.7 million, or 4%, to €74.1 million
for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €71.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to the organic growth of mobile RGUs and the price increase of mobile services in
December 2018 and fixed services in February 2019.


-----

Serbia Group segment. UG Adjusted EBITDAaL increased by €3.9 million, or 3%, to €116.9 million
for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €113.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to higher revenues from the organic growth of our subscriber base and a price increase in
January 2019, which was partially offset by increased programming costs and strict cost control.

Bosnia Group segment. UG Adjusted EBITDAaL increased by €3.0 million, or 13%, to €26.4 million
for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €23.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to a revenue increase driven by price increases for subscriptions for the Bosnia Group’s
cable platform in April 2018 and April 2019 and satellite platform in January 2019, as well as an
increase in the number of subscribers with higher priced subscriptions.

Montenegro Group segment. UG Adjusted EBITDAaL decreased by €0.1 million, or 3%, to €3.2
million for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €3.3 million for the year ended December 31,
2018, primarily due to an increase in direct costs and operational expenses which offset the revenue
increase resulting from the organic growth of the subscriber base and the increase in the number of
multi-play subscribers.

Media Group segment. UG Adjusted EBITDAaL increased by €28.7 million, or 56%, to €80.1 million
for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €51.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to the contribution of the acquisitions of Nova TV (Croatia, Bosnia, and Montenegro)
and media selling companies in Serbia in the second half of 2018, offset by organic growth in 2019 due
to increased carriage revenues.

**UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure**

UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases relates primarily to the purchase of property and
equipment, including expansion of our network in terms of capacity and new homes connected,
purchase of modems and set-top boxes to be installed in customer premises, growth in RGUs and
maintenance of our cable and mobile networks and infrastructure, purchase of intangible assets such as
content, software, investments in our core infrastructure and systems to facilitate the addition of new
services and acquisitions. Therefore, UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases is primarily driven
by extending, upgrading and maintaining our cable and mobile networks, the installation and in home
wiring for new subscribers, the cost of cable modems, including high- speed modems for subscribers to
our high-speed broadband internet, and the acquisition of content. UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure
after Leases has also historically included certain investments of a non-recurring nature, as well as costs
to integrate acquired businesses.

UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases also includes increases in intangible assets (except our
customer list and brand names) and does not include financial assets. As part of our strategy to focus
on UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases improving returns, we implemented measures to
ensure a more efficient usage of capital investment. We intend to manage UG Adjusted Capital
Expenditure after Leases to maintain our well invested asset base. UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure
after Leases excludes the impact of right-of-use asset additions and, starting from 2021, the right-ofuse asset modifications and prepayments. The members of our board of directors review all material
UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure programs.

For a further description of UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases, see “—Presentation of
_Financial Data—Capital Expenditure, UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure and UG Adjusted Capital_
_Expenditure after Leases.”_

Over the next several years, we expect that UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases will be
largely success and capacity based. Success and capacity based UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after
Leases includes expenditures related to the expansion of our network footprint to additional homes and
existing subscribers, the replacement of set-top boxes, expanding network capacity, new product and
service development and expenditure incurred when connecting business subscribers to our network.
Success based UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure after Leases does not include expenditures for
maintenance, upgrade and replacement of our systems and infrastructure.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk**

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

Our income and cash flow from operations are affected by changes in market interest rates. Some items
on our balance sheet, such as long-term borrowings, loans to related parties issued at variable rates and
lease liabilities, are exposed to interest rate risk. Borrowings under the Existing Revolving Credit
Facility and the Existing Floating Rate Notes bear interest at varying rates, and as a result we will have
interest risk with respect to this debt. Interest rate hedging arrangements are not in place as of the Issue
Date with respect to the debt under our Existing Revolving Credit Facility or the Existing Floating Rate
Notes. For fixed rate debt, interest rate changes affect the fair market value of such debt, but do not
impact earnings or cash flow.

**_Currency Risk_**

Currency risk arises when future commercial transactions or recognized assets or liabilities are
denominated in a currency that is not the functional currency of the Group entity holding the asset or
obligation. As a result of our operations in various countries, we generate a significant portion of our
sales and incur a significant portion of our expenses in currencies other than the euro. Our primary
exposure is to the Serbian dinar. For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, 15% of our revenue
was denominated in Serbian dinars. The Bosnia and Herzegovinian mark and the Bulgarian lev are
pegged to the euro, while the Croatian kuna and North Macedonian dinar are relatively stable. Based
on our lack of any material change in exposure to the U.S. dollar in the nine months ended September
30, 2021, we did not enter into any additional currency hedge agreements during the nine months ended
September 30, 2021.

**_Translation Risk_**

Translation risk is the risk that the value in euro of the consolidated profit and loss statement and balance
sheet will fluctuate due to changes in foreign exchange rates connected with the translation of our
subsidiaries that do not have the euro as their functional currency. Almost all our indebtedness has been
denominated in euros.

**_Transaction Risk_**

Transaction risk is the risk of exchange losses incurred by us through purchases and sales in currencies
other than the local currency of the relevant subsidiaries.

**Overview**

Wind Hellas is one of the three integrated communication providers in Greece with proprietary mobile
and fixed-line networks. It offers mobile and fixed-line telecommunication, high-speed internet services
and Pay-TV services under a unified brand and on a national basis to over 4.1 million subscribers.

Wind Hellas provides fixed-broadband and fixed-voice services, international roaming and value-added
services (“VAS”), and mobile internet services to both residential and business customers and to other
telecommunications operators through its LTE, HSPA and GSM technologies. Wind Hellas offers
unlimited data services to all customers, and its mobile offering includes pre-paid and post-paid mobile
services. As of September 30, 2021, household and business accounts represented approximately 61%
of total RGUs. Wind Hellas owns one of the three proprietary mobile networks in Greece and is the
third-largest mobile provider in Greece, with more than 3.4 million mobile subscribers as of September
30, 2021. It is also the third-largest fixed-line telephony provider. Its fixed-line offering includes fixedline telephony and broadband internet services, serving more than 0.6 million LLU & NGA subscribers
as of September 30, 2021. Wind Hellas benefits from an extensive nationwide fiber optic network of
approximately 6,162 kilometers (backbone and metropolitan access network) and approximately 600
kilometers of fiber as part of the recently commenced NGA deployment. As of September 30, 2021,
Wind Hellas also benefits from 328 points of presence in its LLU and RSS network with a coverage of
approximately 79% of active lines in Greece and full access to OTE’s last-mile at regulated terms. In
addition, Wind Hellas provides Pay-TV services to residential customers through its video platform,
Wind Vision, which it launched in April 2018 and had 0.1 million platform subscribers as of September
30, 2021.

Wind Hellas continuously invests in its network to support growth initiatives and enhance its service
offering. It also accelerated investments in digital service capability to take advantage of emerging
consumer behaviour patterns resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic. In December 2020, Wind Hellas
acquired 5G spectrum, which represented a significant milestone and laid the foundation for deploying
its 5G network roll-out while providing visibility on future license payments for seven years starting
from January 2024. As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas achieved 4G and 5G network coverage of
98% and 24%, respectively, of the 10.7 million population in Greece and continued investing in its fiber
network, reaching 431 thousand NGA lines deployed.

Wind Hellas has successfully scaled in the market over the past few years, and its total revenue for the
twelve months ended September 30, 2021 was €558.3 million compared to €537.4 million for the year
ended December 31, 2020. Its WH Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021
was €248.5 million compared to €245.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Going forward,
we believe Wind Hellas could leverage other growth opportunities to further improve its performance,


-----

including through offering fixed-mobile convergence bundles, expanding its fiber network and
introducing B2B services.

**Key Factors Affecting Wind Hellas’ Results of Operations**

**_Macroeconomic conditions in Greece_**

Wind Hellas operates exclusively in Greece, a market that has experienced substantial growth in recent
years primarily attributable to an improving economic and political environment. Since the general
elections on July 7, 2019, Greece has been benefiting from increased political stability. The government
is pursuing reforms and economic growth through infrastructure investments and the reduction of social
security costs and corporate tax rates. In 2020, the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic had a significant
effect on the Greek economy, prompting the country to take restrictive measures, curbing tourism and
transportation, and resulting in a decline in demand for products and services. In 2021, the Greek
economy is rebounding, supported by a return of private and capital spending and an increase in EU
funding. Greek’s real GDP increased by 1.9% in 2019, and despite a 8.2% decrease in 2020 due to the
lockdown and other restrictive measures imposed by the government in response to the COVID-19
pandemic, it is estimated to grow by 6.5% in 2021 (source: IMF), supported by critical macroeconomic
factors including, among others, a declining unemployment rate and increasing disposable income and
private consumption in the country. In particular, the unemployment rate in Greece, which has been
declining since 2013, is currently forecast to decline to 11.7% in 2026 from a peak of 27.5% in 2013
(source: IMF). The Greek market also remains relatively underpenetrated compared to other European
countries regarding mobile data usage, fixed-line NGA penetration and Pay-TV adoption. Greece is one
of the few markets in Europe with a merely nascent nationwide FttH network and no existing cable
infrastructure, representing significant market potential. The confluence of a favourable
macroeconomic environment, structural drivers of demand for telecommunications services and the
prospect of increased market penetration across the country creates an environment where Wind Hellas
can capitalize on further growth opportunities.

**_The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic_**

In 2020, Wind Hellas’ results of operations were impacted by the unprecedented challenges presented
by the COVID-19 pandemic and the restrictive measures implemented by the Greek government in
response thereto. The health and well-being of its employees and customers remained Wind Hellas’ top
priority throughout the pandemic, and strict social distancing measures were implemented promptly and
as needed. Work from home procedures were also introduced, where practicable, for both Wind Hellas
employees and call center agents. The successful implementation of these procedures was supported by
a well-functioning infrastructure, which evidenced Wind Hellas’ ability to manage its networks
remotely with minimal operational difficulty. At the same time, Wind Hellas seamlessly supported its
customers’ increased need for data and voice telecommunications, home entertainment and online
transactions, as well as the transition of many activities that are normally carried out in person to the
digital environment due to the nationwide lockdown measures implemented by the government. Despite
these measures, Wind stores remained mostly open throughout 2020 in accordance with government
guidelines, albeit operating with reduced employees and hours to perform essential functions and serve
customer needs that cannot be met online. This resulted in a collective drop in sales activity through
Wind stores of approximately 25%, which was counterbalanced by improved sales conversion rates
(i.e., the ratio between successful sales and customer visits at Wind stores), resulting in a 10% increase
in annual sales, which has kept Wind stores sales contribution at 70% of overall sales. Sales through
the stores’ network of Public were also negatively affected. For a significant portion of the year, retail
stores remained closed or were impacted by restrictive shopping measures, which resulted in a drop in
its sales contribution, which however was absorbed by sales via online channels.

With respect to customer care, Wind Hellas had to transition all its customer care agents from an onpremises to a work-from-home set-up. Despite this transition, Wind Hellas improved all the most
important customer care KPIs by introducing a flexible cooperation system between inbound customer


-----

care teams and outbound saving teams to handle call volume spikes using an organized system of sameday call-backs. Wind Hellas also benefited from its significant risk management experience acquired
during the decade-long economic crisis in Greece. In particular, it reintroduced procedures and control
systems that it had applied in the past to deal with capital controls, liquidity, collections and working
capital management. In addition, Wind Hellas has an experienced management team that is aware of
the relevant business continuity and corporate reputational risks in a time of crisis, who performed
thorough and frequent reviews of practices, policies and communications to mitigate risks. Wind Hellas
reviewed and managed operating expenses at regular intervals to scale its operations appropriately in
response to business demand. It also intensified the focus on cash flow generation by continuously
monitoring collections and implementing user-friendly remote payment options to facilitate customer
payments.

In the first nine months of 2021, the COVID-19 pandemic continued to impact Wind Hellas’ business,
although the effects were less pronounced than in 2020. Certain nationwide lockdown measures
imposed by the Greek government in late 2020 were gradually lifted since then including as a result of
the vaccination campaign. Specifically, in April 2021, the Greek government commenced a controlled
“unlocking” of the country’s economy with the reopening of high schools. This was followed by a
gradual easing of other restrictive measures throughout May and June 2021 and a partial relaxation of
travel restrictions. Although many of the restrictions have been lifted, which has led to a higher level of
economic activities, especially in the critical tourist sector, the situation remains uncertain, and specific
restrictions continue to remain in place in regions where the count of COVID-19 cases is higher,
including caps for on-site working and testing requirements. In connection with a renewed spike in
infections towards the end of the third quarter of 2021, the government is considering the
implementation of a series of new measures, including to incentivize vaccination. In 2020, Wind Hellas’
formulated a business continuity plan, which contemplated the possible scenarios related to COVID19, and this guided its response to each step of the Greek government unlocking of the economy in
2021. To counterbalance the decline in sales of its door-to-door sales channels in 2020, Wind Hellas
focused on strengthening its online sales capability, and as a result, its online pre-paid top-up revenue
increased by 24% for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, with online top-ups (i.e., recharges
of pre-paid airtime made via the mobile app or website) comprising 27% of its total pre-paid recharge
revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 compared to 22% and 15% in the years ended
December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, in 2020, Wind
Hellas’ Phygital channel was ramped up by expanding online campaigns on affiliated partners’ website
sites, to counterbalance the drop in sales of its door-to-door sales channels, which were negatively
impacted by the lockdown measures implemented in Greece. Digital and Phygital channels combined
accounted for 10% of Wind Hellas’ overall post-paid sales in the nine months ended September 30,
2021, compared to 5% and 3% in the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. In
connection with the re-opening of Wind Hellas’ door-to-door channels following the ease of the
lockdown measures, Wind Hellas’ overall sales capacity increased compared to before the beginning
of the pandemic. Despite the negative impact from the COVID-19 pandemic, Wind Hellas’ customer
base in its Consumer division increased by 1% to approximately 819 thousand customers as of
September 30, 2021 compared to approximately 808 thousand customers as of December 31, 2019.

Overall, the COVID-19 pandemic significantly affected Wind Hellas’ operations and business
performance, decreasing demand in certain areas (mainly pre-paid services and business roaming),
reducing the number of visitors to Greece and affecting Wind Hellas’ ability to acquire new contract
customers. However, the pandemic also presented attractive opportunities to evolve Wind Hellas’
business model in response to changing consumer and business needs, and, for example, has
significantly accelerated its digital transformation plan. Wind Hellas continues to focus on mitigating
the risks posed by the COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, it remains vigilant in its efforts to protect the
health and well-being of its employees and customers. Wind Hellas’ implemented a rolling program to
allow its employees to continue to work from home as required, and currently, approximately 50% of
Wind Hellas employees are working remotely. For those who returned to the office, the use of masks is
mandatory in all public spaces, and the measuring of body temperature is performed before the
employees and visitors enter Wind Hellas’ premises. Following a €9.8 million decrease in revenue to


-----

€522.0 million in 2020 from €531.8 million in 2019, Wind Hellas’ revenue in the nine months ended
September 30, 2021, increased by €18.8 million to €411.9 million from €393.1 million in the same
period of 2020.

**_Mobile business_**

Wind Hellas’ mobile telecommunication services business has generated, and is expected to continue
to generate, the largest part of its revenue, accounting for 52%, 53% and 52% of its WH Service
Revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 and the years ended December 31, 2020 and
2019, respectively. Revenue from mobile telecommunication services accounted for €270.5 million and
€267.3 million for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, respectively, and €201.0 million and
€205.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 and 2021, respectively. The performance
of Wind Hellas’ mobile business is primarily dependent on the ARPU it achieves, the quality of its
network and its churn rates. Any changes to these elements could significantly impact Wind Hellas’
mobile business and overall results of operations.

_ARPU evolution_

Mobile outgoing ARPU remained stable for the years ended December 2019 and 2020 at €11.2, and
further increased to €11.5 for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, primarily driven by increased
bundled and roaming revenues in post-paid and value-enhanced initiatives encouraging both usage and
spending in pre-paid.

_Improved network quality through Wind Hellas’ spectrum_

In the periods under review, Wind Hellas has made significant investments in its mobile network,
benefitting from high spectrum allocation per customer. The acquisition of sufficient spectrum has been
a key factor for Wind Hellas’ high customer satisfaction in recent years. The strategic acquisition of
spectrum has also allowed it to compete in the high-value segment of the sector and to monetize its
offerings, including its offerings that are targeted to benefit from the increasing demand for mobile data.
In December 2020, Wind Hellas acquired 5G spectrum, which represented a significant milestone and
laid the foundation for deploying its 5G network rollout while providing visibility on future license
payments for seven years starting from January 2024.

_Improved network reach through the Victus Joint Operation_

The Victus Joint Operation is a scheme through which Wind Hellas has efficiently and cost-effectively
improved and expanded its 2G, 3G and 4G networks. In 2019, Wind Hellas agreed to extend its 4G
network nationwide (including Attica), and this extension was completed in 2020 following regulatory
approval. As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas estimates that its 5G network covered approximately
24%, its 4G network covered 98%, its 3G network covered 95% and its 2G network covered 99% of
the approximately 10.7 million population of Greece, and Wind Hellas has sufficiently addressed the
coverage gap compared to its competitors. For more information on the Victus Joint Operation, see
“Business—The Victus Joint Operation.”

_Consistent decline in churn rates_

Churn rate refers to the percentage of subscriber disconnections during a given time period, and it is
generally calculated by dividing the total number of subscriber disconnections for a given period by the
average number of subscribers for that same. Wind Hellas deems a pre-paid mobile subscriber to have
churned if it has not recharged its mobile credit for a full twelve-month period, its SIM card is
deactivated either upon its request or by Wind Hellas if fraudulent activity has occurred. Wind Hellas
deems a post-paid mobile subscriber to have churned when its SIM card is deactivated either upon its
request or by Wind Hellas if fraudulent activity has occurred. Wind Hellas deems a fixed-line subscriber
to have churned when its fixed-line connection is deactivated either upon its request or by Wind Hellas
if fraudulent activity has occurred. The figures for any period less than twelve months are annualized


-----

churn rates. Such annualized churn rates are calculated as the relevant churn rate multiplied by twelve
months and divided by such a period that is less than twelve months.

A lower churn rate increases visibility of Wind Hellas’ future revenues, indicates greater stability in its
customer base and decreases subscribers acquisition cost in the aggregate. Churn rate levels affect
various key performance indicators, including total subscribers and ARPU levels. Wind Hellas’ postpaid mobile churn rate decreased by 1% from 11% for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 to
10% for the nine months ended September 30, 2021. The table below sets forth Wind Hellas’ annual
churn rate for the periods indicated.

The decrease in post-paid mobile and fixed-line churn rates in the periods under review is due to

evidenced by a reduction in total market portability volumes. Furthermore, Wind Hellas observed an
even lower churn rate for converged customers. Mobile pre-paid subscribers are not contractually bound
in the long-term to use Wind Hellas’ services and are free to move to other operators with more

significant metric, but it rather monitors value return for pre-paid customers.
