**_Fixed-line (including video platform) business_**

Wind Hellas’ fixed telecommunication services business, which include its video platform (i.e., Wind
Vision), generated 32%, 33% and 32% of its WH Service Revenue for the nine months ended September
30, 2021 and the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. Revenue from fixed
telecommunication services accounted for €164.3 million and €169.1 million for the years ended
December 31, 2019 and 2020, respectively, and €126.5 million and €128.9 million for the nine months
ended September 30, 2020 and 2021, respectively. The increase was primarily attributable to the strong
LLU and NGA fiber performance driven by customer base expansion and NGA fiber penetration, which
represented 44%, 36% and 23%, respectively, of Wind Hellas’ fixed base as of September 30, 2021 and
December 2020 and 2019, supported by cross-selling initiatives. Fixed-line (including Wind Vision)
ARPU declined by €0.1 million to €20.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 from
€21.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. Fixed-line (including Wind Vision)
ARPU increased by €0.1 million to €21.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from €20.9
million for the year ended December 31, 2019. Wind Hellas’ LLU & NGA fiber base reached
approximately 646 thousand subscribers as of September 30, 2021 from 623 thousand subscribers as of
December 31, 2019, representing an overall growth of 4%, supported by NGA fiber base growth of
more than 100%. Wind Hellas’ fiber rollout plan in urban areas across Athens and rest of Greece has
been progressing rapidly, with approximately 351 thousand lines activated as of September 30, 2021
compared to approximately 264 thousand lines as of December 31, 2019. The churn rate in Wind Hellas’


-----

fixed-line product offering decreased on a year-on-year basis to 12% for the nine months ended
September 30, 2021 from 13% in the same period of 2020, and 13% and 16% in the years ended
December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. This decrease was primarily due to household and
convergence strategy, and improved customer experience.

_Improvement of fixed-line network_

In recent years, Wind Hellas has made significant investments in its fixed-line network, focusing on
growing its NGA fiber platform. The rapid rollout of Wind Hellas’ fixed NGA fiber-based networks in
areas where it has exclusive rights boosts its higher-margin NGA subscribers. Wind Hellas has also
become more cost-efficient as LLU subscribers are on-boarded on its own NGA network, saving
approximately €7 per subscriber per month on LLU fees payable to OTE. Moreover, this provides Wind
Hellas with access to incremental revenue from leasing NGA lines to other operators like Vodafone and
OTE. As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas had increased its NGA activated lines to 351 thousand,
and NGA penetration of its fixed-line broadband customer base had reached 44%. Wind Hellas’
wholesale revenues totaled €35.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, and Wind
Hellas expects it to continue to grow.

_Convergence strategy_

Wind Hellas’ position as one of the largest fixed-line telephony providers and the third-largest mobile
network operator in Greece, which has no major MVNO competition, enables it to offer a variety of
bundled service offerings of mobile and fixed-line telephony and broadband internet (ADSL/NGA
fiber), which provide customers the convenience of having a single provider for their
telecommunication needs. Wind Hellas believes this puts it at the forefront in terms of the number of
Consumer Converged Households in Greece. Bundling Wind Hellas’ services helps maximize revenue
from customers as the customers could have all of their telecommunication requirements serviced by
Wind Hellas, reducing the need for them to engage other service providers and hence the risk of losing
them to competitors. Wind Hellas’ focus on household offers is also further supported by its Pay-TV
offerings. As of September 30, 2021, the number of Consumer Households Converged accounts
amounted to approximately 273 thousand, representing a 18% increase from approximately 230
thousand accounts as of December 31, 2019. The bundling of services is now common in Greece and
promotes consolidation in the market, and Wind Hellas’ convergence strategy has allowed and will
continue to allow its mobile and fixed-line businesses to grow.

**_Cost reductions and efficiency measures_**

Wind Hellas continues to focus on cost reduction and efficiency measures to achieve higher margins.
WH Adjusted EBITDAaL Margin decreased to 24% for the nine months ended September 30, 2021
from 29%, 27% and 27% for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 and the years ended December
31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. This decrease was mainly due the impact of the Vantage Towers
Disposal. The calculation of WH Adjusted EBITDA Margin is set forth under “Summary of Company
_Historical and Group Run-Rate, Wind Hellas Historical, Unaudited Pro Forma Rune-Rate and Certain_
_Other Financial Data —Wind Hellas Other Financial Data.”_

Excluding the impact of the Vantage Towers Disposal as calculated in Wind Hellas’ management
accounts, Wind Hellas has reduced its operating costs primarily through rigorous cost monitoring,
ongoing digital transformation initiatives across sales and service, as well as headcount reduction
following organization efficiencies and automation initiatives with a direct effect on staff costs. The
Victus Joint Operation supports Wind Hellas’ network expansion by enabling a decrease in Wind
Hellas’ costs through joint cost-sharing arrangements. Wind Hellas’ fixed-line products also benefit
from further cost savings via its own deployment of FttC, as Wind Hellas’ fees to OTE are reduced
through the transition away from LLU, as well as via the FttC to FttH conversion that reduces access
fees. Wind Hellas also regularly renegotiates all third-party contracts in line with its strong focus on
operating expenditure rationalization.

**_Subscriber Acquisition and Retention Costs_**

Wind Hellas’ primary subscriber acquisition and retention costs associated with post-paid subscribers
include: (i) commissions related to sales generated by agents, distributors and resellers (together
forming Wind Hellas’ indirect distribution channel) and (ii) the cost of handsets sold to its customers,
as handsets are typically sold to its subscribers for a price lower than their cost as an incentive for
customers to subscribe or renew their subscription. Wind Hellas’ increasing focus on direct distribution
channels and its converged product offering are therefore key factors for decreasing its subscriber
acquisition and retention costs.

**_Capital expenditure and license payments_**

Wind Hellas has made significant capital expenditures in growing and modernizing its network during
the periods under review. Wind Hellas’ capital expenditures (excluding capital expenditures for
spectrum license acquisitions and renewals) amounted to €58.6 million for the nine months ended
September 30, 2021, and €89.9 million and €87.1 million for the years ended December 31, 2020 and
2019, respectively. Following the network sharing agreement with Vodafone Greece, the 5G licenses
acquisition, the ongoing rollout of Wind Hellas’ LTE network and the launch of its 5G network, Wind
Hellas is well-positioned to capitalize on the expected growth in data usage. Wind Hellas also continues
to invest in the rollout of IPTV network to improve the quality and scope of its offerings and to allow
for better customer experience. For more information on Wind Hellas’ capital expenditure, see “—
_Liquidity and Capital Resources—Capital Expenditures.”_

**_Seasonality_**

The performance of Wind Hellas’ mobile business is subject to seasonality, as revenue typically
increases in the third quarter of each year, driven by foreign visitors and other pre-paid customers that
travel to Greece for the summer. With tourism in Greece peaking in the summer months, 57% of Wind
Hellas’ annual revenue from roaming customers are generated in the third quarter of each year.
Following the lockdown measures implemented in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the share of
Wind Hellas’ revenues generated in the third quarter of 2020 and 2021 from roaming customers has
increased to 69%. Domestic voice and data usage also typically peak during the summer months, leading
to an increase in pre-paid revenues (which are more driven by usage than post-paid revenues) of 9% in
the third quarter of each year compared to each of the other quarters. Furthermore, Wind Hellas
generally experiences cash inflows in the fourth quarter that are associated with the increased network
usage by tourists visiting Greece in the summer.

Wind Hellas’ fixed-line business is less affected by seasonality and it only experiences a small decrease
in revenue during August of each year due to certain portions of the Greek population going on vacation.

**Key Factors Affecting Comparability of Wind Hellas’ Results of Operations**

**_The Vantage Towers Disposal_**

On July 24, 2020, Wind Hellas Parent entered into an agreement (the “Contribution Agreement”) with
Vodafone Europe B.V. (“Vodafone”), fully owned by the Vodafone Group plc, for the contribution of
the Greek tower portfolios of both Wind Hellas and Vodafone into a jointly-owned entity. In November
2020, Wind Hellas transferred its tower portfolio in Greece to Crystal Almond Towers Single Member
S.A., a newly established subsidiary of Wind Hellas Parent. Wind Hellas also transferred a corporate
loan due by it to Wind Hellas Parent, amounting to €87.5 million, to Crystal Almond Tower Single
Member S.A. On December 18, 2020, a jointly owned entity of Wind Hellas and Vodafone was
incorporated under the name Vantage Towers S.A. (“Vantage Towers Greece”). Vantage Towers
Greece operates approximately 5,200 towers. Pursuant to the Contribution Agreement, on December
21, 2020, Wind Hellas Parent contributed its shares in Crystal Almond Towers Single Member S.A.
into Vantage Towers Greece in exchange for 38% for the issued share capital of Vantage Towers Greece
and an aggregate payment of €112.5 million from Vodafone effected by way of a cash payment of €25
million and a cash repayment of the €87.5 million corporate loan that had been transferred to Crystal
Almond Towers Single Member S.A. At the same time, on December 21, 2020, the parties executed a
sell-down sale and purchase agreement (“SPA”) and a shareholders’ agreement. By virtue of the selldown SPA, Vodafone received an option to acquire Wind Hellas Parent’s 38% share in Vantage Towers
Greece at any time up to December 31, 2021, which was triggered by the initial public offering of
Vantage Towers Europe, which up to then held the remaining 62% interest in Vantage Towers Greece.
The consideration upon exercise of the call option was €287.5 million, which, together with the
aggregate payment of €112.5 million made by Vodafone on December 21, 2020, brought the total value
received by Wind Hellas Parent for the transaction to €400.0 million.

As part of this transaction, on December 12, 2020, Wind Hellas and Crystal Almond Towers Single
Member S.A. signed a new long-term master services agreement (“MSA”), with an initial term of eight
years, which can be extended, subject to certain conditions, to a maximum of 32 years. On August 2,
2021, Crystal Almond Towers Single Member S.A. merged into Vantage Tower Greece. Under the
MSA, Vantage Towers Greece will be the preferred supplier of new towers for Wind Hellas and
Vodafone Greece, each of which has agreed to commit as an anchor tenant on 250 new sites (500 in
total) to be built by Vantage Towers Greece over five years starting from November 17, 2020.

As a result of these transactions, in November 2020, Wind Hellas derecognised a net liability of €64.0
million related to its tower portfolio in connection with its contribution to Vantage Towers Greece. In
December 2020, upon completion of the transaction contemplated in the Contribution Agreement, Wind
Hellas ceased to control its subsidiary Crystal Almond Towers S.A. As a result, a net gain of €377.0
million related to the transaction was recognised in Wind Hellas’ profit or loss and other comprehensive


-----

income statement, and the investment in Vantage Towers Greece was recorded as an “Investment held
for sale” of €310.0 million in the Wind Hellas’ consolidated statement of financial position. In March
2021, Vantage Towers Europe executed an initial public offering which triggered the call option granted
to it by Wind Hellas Parent pursuant to the Contribution Agreement and Vodafone acquired the 38%
share of Wind Hellas Parent in Vantage Towers Greece for a consideration of €287.5 million. The
transactions described above are collectively referred to herein as the “Vantage Towers Disposal.”

Following completion of the Vantage Towers Disposal, Crystal Almond Midco made a further €212.0
million distribution to Wind Hellas Parent in order to fund a capital return to its ultimate shareholders
of €210.0 million and payment of certain parent company expenses (the “Distribution”). As of
September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas Parent has no investment in Vantage Towers Greece.

After giving pro forma effect to the Vantage Towers Disposal as if it had occurred on January 1, 2020,
Wind Hellas’ WH Adjusted EBITDAaL for the Vantage Towers Disposal for the year ended December
31, 2020 was €114.0 million compared to WH Adjusted EBITDAaL of €139.0 million, and its WH
Adjusted EBITDAaL for the Vantage Towers Disposal Margin for the same period was 22% compared
to WH Adjusted EBITDAaL Margin of 27%. For a reconciliation of Net income gain/(loss) to WH
Adjusted EBITDAaL for the Vantage Towers Disposal, please see “Summary of Company Historical
_and Group Run-Rate, Wind Hellas Historical, Unaudited Pro Forma Rune-Rate and Certain Other_
_Financial Data —Wind Hellas Financial Data— Wind Hellas Other Financial Data—Wind Hellas_
_Adjusted Other Financial Information.”_

Through the Vantage Towers Disposal, Wind Hellas unlocked significant value in its infrastructure,
secured the long-term maintenance and development of its passive tower assets and at the same time
strengthened its active network sharing agreement with Vodafone Greece.

- Finance income comprises interest income on loans related to companies, interest income on bank
deposits and foreign exchange gains.

- Finance costs comprise interest expense on financial liabilities measured at amortized cost, interest
cost of defined benefit obligation, interest expense for lease liabilities, unwinding of discount on
asset retirement obligation and other financial expenses and foreign exchange losses.

- Loss on sale of equity investment comprises the loss recognized from the sale of Nova’s shares
(previously known as Forthnet S.A.), where part of it is recognized under net finance costs, and a
loss on revaluation is recognized in other comprehensive income.

**_Income tax benefit/(expense)._** Income tax expense comprises current and deferred tax. Current and
deferred taxes are recognized in the consolidated profit or loss except if they relate to a business
combination or items recognized directly in equity or in other comprehensive income. Under applicable
Guernsey tax legislation, the standard corporate income tax rate applicable to companies residing in
Guernsey is 0% (2020: 0%; 2019: 0%). Under applicable Luxembourg tax regulations, the overall


-----

maximum corporate tax rate applicable for companies located in the city of Luxembourg is 24.94%
(2020: 24.94%; 2019: 24.94%). Under applicable Greek tax legislation, the corporate income tax rate
that is applicable for companies residing in Greece has been set to 22% (2020: 24%; 2019: 24%).

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

**_Overview_**

As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas’ principal sources of liquidity were cash and cash equivalents,
cash flow generated from its operations and debt financings, including Wind Hellas Existing Notes and
drawings under Wind Hellas Existing Revolving Credit Facility. As of September 30, 2021, Wind
Hellas’ cash and cash equivalents were €142.1 million as compared to €155.5 million as of December
31, 2020. As of December 31, 2020, the amount drawn under the Wind Hellas Existing Revolving
Credit Facility was €75.0 million. On January 18, 2021, Wind Hellas Parent repaid the €75.0 million of
the drawn amount from the Wind Hellas Existing Revolving Credit Facility, and as of September 30,
2021, no drawings were outstanding. In connection with the completion of the Wind Hellas Acquisition,
the Wind Hellas Existing Revolving Credit Facility is expected to be cancelled on or shortly following
the Wind Hellas Acquisition Closing Date. See “Summary—The Transactions—the Financing of the
_Wind Hellas Acquisition and the Wind Hellas Indebtedness Refinancing.”_

On October 17, 2019, Wind Hellas Parent issued the Wind Hellas Existing Notes in an aggregate
principal amount of €525.0 million at a fixed interest rate of 4.25% per annum. In connection with the
completion of the Wind Hellas Acquisition, the Wind Hellas Existing Notes are expected to be fully
repaid and cancelled on or shortly following the Wind Hellas Acquisition Closing Date with a portion
of the proceeds from the Bridge Facilities. See “Summary—The Transactions—the Financing of the
_Wind Hellas Acquisition and the Wind Hellas Indebtedness Refinancing.”_

On July 15, 2011, Wind Hellas Telecommunications S.A. issued a PIK toggle corporate bond loan (as
subsequently amended and in force from time to time, the “Corporate Bond Loan”) for a total principal
amount of up to €567.7 million and a revolving tranche, which was ultimately subscribed by Wind
Hellas Parent and Crystal Almond Midco. On November 17, 2020 a nominal amount of €87.5 million
of the Corporate Bond Loan was transferred to Crystal Almond Towers Single Member SA and fully
repaid on December 21, 2020. The Corporate Bond Loan bears interest at a fixed rate of 5.5%, matures
on July 15, 2025, and may be extended up to July 15, 2027. As of September 30, 2021, the principal
amount of the Corporate Bond Loan was €580.2 million, and the outstanding balance under this loan
was €488.7 million, plus accrued interest of €1.1 million.

For further details on Wind Hellas’ financial risk management objectives and policies, refer to the Wind
Hellas Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

**_Capital Expenditures_**

Wind Hellas defines WH Total Capital Expenditure as investments in mobile and fixed network, Wind
Vision and IT platforms, Wind Stores, the SYZEFXIS II project, other customer related projects and
digital investments. Capital expenditures include investments in relation to (i) mobile core to maintain
high network availability and business continuity, (ii) fixed-line networks to replace equipment no
longer supported by suppliers, (iii) measures enhancing its internal IT systems to allow for improved
efficiency, (iv) existing facilities to improve the robustness of its network, (v) NGA, which involves
the Victus Joint Operation and the SYZEFXIS II project, as well as 5G and LTE to expand Wind Hellas’
proprietary network, (vi) rollout of new network stations to improve 2G and 3G coverage and capacity,
(vii) Wind Vision, (viii) the modernization of Wind Hellas’ physical stores and (ix) other customer
related initiatives.


-----

Wind Hellas’ capital expenditures (excluding capital expenditures for the acquisition of spectrum
licenses) were €57.0 million and €58.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 and 2021,
respectively, and €87.1 million and €89.9 million for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020,
respectively.

In the periods under review, Wind Hellas’ capital expenditures were focused on mobile and fixed
network expansion, including ongoing investments in 4G, 5G and fiber network rollout. Furthermore,
Wind Hellas’ capital expenditures included investments related to SYZEFXIS II project, as well as

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that Wind Hellas will encounter difficulty in meeting obligations associated
with its financial liabilities that are settled by delivering cash or another financial asset. Wind Hellas’
approach to managing liquidity is to ensure, as far as possible, that it will always have sufficient liquidity
to meet its liabilities when due, under both normal and stressed conditions, without incurring
unacceptable losses or risking damage to its reputation. Wind Hellas monitors its risk of risk of a
shortage of funds taking into account the maturity of financial assets and financial liabilities and
projected cash flows from operations.

**_Market Risk_**

Market risk is the risk that changes in market prices, such as foreign exchange rates, interest rates and
equity prices that will affect Wind Hellas’ income or the value of its holdings of financial instruments.

**United Group geographies**

**_Macro-Economic Overview_**

We operate most of our business across the following eight countries in Southeastern Europe: Bulgaria,
Greece, Serbia, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina (“B&H”), Montenegro and North
Macedonia. These countries have a combined population of approximately 36 million people,
distributed across approximately 13 million households. Despite economic differences, these countries
share a joint history and form a single market in which small local differences are overshadowed by the
influence of similarities in cultural preferences and language across the region. As a result, this region
is one of the three largest markets in CEE, along with Poland and Romania. The following table provides
an overview of our countries of operations:

Over the past fifteen years, our eight countries of operations have implemented significant political and
economic reforms aimed at, among other things, reducing economic and structural imbalances,
increasing the flexibility of their respective economies (including liberalization of the media and
telecommunications sectors), and creating a business friendly environment that is conducive to foreign
investment. As a result of such reforms, Slovenia and Croatia were admitted to the European Union in
2004 and 2013, respectively. Bulgaria joined the European Union in 2007 and Greece in 1981 (and
adopted the euro in 2001). Serbia officially applied for European Union membership in 2009, received
full candidate status in 2012 and in January 2014, the first accession negotiations took place.
Negotiations are ongoing with several Chapters having been opened up for discussion and review.
Montenegro was granted candidate status in 2010 and the accession negotiations started in June 2012.
North Macedonia has been a candidate for accession to the European Union since 2005, and in 2009
the European Commission recommended that accession negotiations be opened. Bosnia and
Herzegovina formally applied for EU membership in February 2016 and in December 2016 and has
received the accession questionnaire from the European Commission.

The macroeconomic environment is improving in our four core countries (Bulgaria, Greece, Serbia and
Slovenia). Real GDP growth in our four core countries is and will continue to be the key driver of
private consumption and disposable income growth.


-----

Bulgaria’s economy has experienced a slightly negative growth for the period from 2018 to 2020, with
real GDP decreasing by 0.2% from 2018 to 2020. However, real GDP per capita from 2018 to 2020
increased by 0.5%. Furthermore, in 2020, unemployment rate increased by 0.9 percentage points, driven
by COVID-19. From 2018 to 2020, the unemployment decreased by 0.1 percentage points.

In Greece, positive growth in disposable personal income is expected to continue, supported by
expanding employment, wage growth and a stable inflow of worker remittances. Unemployment rate
dropped by 0.9 percentage points in 2020. From 2018 to 2020, the unemployment decreased by 2.9
percentage points.

In Serbia, the growth in real GDP per capita is expected to continue, driven by monetary policy
relaxation, structural reforms and supported by expanding employment. Unemployment rate dropped
by 1.5 percentage points in 2020. From 2018 to 2020, the unemployment decreased by 3.8 percentage
points.

Growth is further driven by solid expansion in household spending as well as a trade surplus. Capacity
utilization levels in industry and services have reached their highest level since 2007 and conditions for
investment (e.g. high profits and low interest rates) remain favorable, which could potentially drive
capital spending growth. Higher than expected employment and rising disposable income has led to
healthy private consumption growth. Strong fiscal performance could support gradual reduction of
public debt as a share of GDP. Eurozone membership allows the country to benefit from the credibility
of the European Central Bank’s monetary policy and access to the Economic and Monetary Union’s
highly developed capital markets.

In Slovenia, the economy has been significantly hit by the COVID-19 pandemic, with real GDP and
real GDP per capita decreasing by 4.8 percentage points in 2020. However, the country has experienced
an increase in disposable personal income (+5.7% YoY in 2020). Unemployment rate increased by 0.6
percentage points in 2020, while from 2018 to 2020, the unemployment decreased by 0.1 percentage
points.

With respect to the currencies in our three core markets, Slovenia has been a member of the Eurozone
since 2007, the BAM is pegged to the Euro at a fixed exchange rate of BAM 1.9558 per €1.00 and the
Serbian dinar freely fluctuates against the Euro. The Serbian dinar depreciated against the Euro.
Historically, Serbian consumer price index (“CPI”) inflation has tended to more than offset depreciation
of the Serbian dinar against the Euro, leading to a constant “pass through” of the impact of the
depreciation of the dinar to the consumer.

We believe that our pricing strategy reflects the “pass through” principle outlined above. With respect
to the Croatian kuna, the long-time policy of the Croatian National Bank has been to keep the exchange
rate fluctuation of the kuna against the Euro within a relatively stable range.

###### Residential Segment (Fixed) 

 Pay-TV

_Overview_

The Pay-TV market in Southeastern Europe is characterized by relatively low service penetration rates
compared to certain countries in Western Europe, which we believe provides cable Pay-TV players with
attractive growth opportunities in the future.

**_Pay-TV Penetration Benchmark (% of Total Households), 2020_**

__________________________

Source: Ampere

Between 2018 and 2020, overall Pay-TV market penetration increased from 73% to 89% in Serbia, 76%
to 77% in Slovenia and stable at 68% in Bulgaria. This translated into substantial growth in subscribers
at CAGRs of 10.2% (from 1,781 thousand to 2,161 thousand), 1.0% (from 637 thousand to 650
thousand), (0.5%) (from 2,014 thousand to 1,993 thousand) and 7.6% (from 1,032 thousand to 1,195
thousand) during the corresponding period in Serbia, Slovenia, Bulgaria and Greece, respectively.

The growth occurred primarily due to availability of increasingly attractive content, improving output
quality (mainly as a result of increasing digitalization rates), increased product functionality (e.g. video
on demand and CatchUp TV) and higher disposable income per household across the region.

The positive growth in the number of Pay-TV subscribers is expected to continue in Serbia and initiate
in Bulgaria, with estimated penetration rates in 2024 of 92% and 74%, respectively. The positive growth
in Serbia and Slovenia is expected to be driven by increasing demand for digital TV and other value
add services that can be delivered through digital TV platforms, such as VoD and CatchUp TV. While
the Greek Pay-TV market has been historically characterized by the lack of cable infrastructure and
preference for free-to-air TV, the number of Pay-TV subscribers is growing steadily driven primarily
by the demand for sports content, and is expected to achieve an estimated penetration rate of 34% in
2024.

_Technology_

In our three core markets, Pay-TV content is predominantly distributed through cable, IPTV and
Satellite networks:

Source: Ampere

- Cable

Cable Pay-TV is characterized by easy to use technology, quick installation of customer equipment and
reliability of signal delivered directly to the home. Population density is a key factor for cable operators
when deciding whether to invest in extending their existing cable network. A higher population density
reduces the overall cost associated with the deployment, operation and maintenance of cable
infrastructure and allows for mass marketing. Cable operators that operate in urban areas with high
population density benefit from easier access to customers and more cost effective network upgrades
and maintenance expenditures. As a result, cable networks in Southeastern Europe are mainly
concentrated across metropolitan regions in Bulgaria, Serbia and Slovenia. As of December 2020,
approximately 26% of households in Bulgaria, approximately 56% in Serbia and approximately 39%
in Slovenia received their Pay-TV content via cable. The popularity of cable Pay-TV in Serbia is a result
of the attractive content available on cable television, the high service quality and the capability to
deliver interactive services such as VoD and CatchUp TV. There is only limited cable infrastructure in
Greece.

- IPTV

As a consequence of improvements in broadband internet technology, IPTV is increasingly being used
for the distribution of television services and has traditionally been the second most commonly used
distribution medium for television services across Southeastern Europe. In Slovenia, IPTV has recently


-----

become the most used distribution medium (56% of all households as of December 2020), supported
by EU investment in shared open fiber networks, which are accessible to all operators for a fee.
However, as these shared open fiber networks have been built with the objective of making high quality
services available in rural parts of Slovenia, these networks have traditionally had a limited impact on
our cable footprint, which typically covers urban and high population density areas. The principal
providers of IPTV are Telekom Slovenije and T2 in Slovenia, Telekom Srbija (who regularly offers
IPTV at a significant discount to attract subscribers) in Serbia, Bulsatcom in Bulgaria and Cosmote in
Greece.

- DTH-TV

DTH has traditionally been the third most commonly used distribution network medium for television
services in Southeastern Europe region after cable and IPTV. Pay-TV content owners can penetrate
rural areas more cost efficiently through DTH than through fixed line cable networks which are
economically unviable to develop because of low population density in rural areas. Satellite operators,
such as our own Total TV and competitors, such as Digi and Max TV, distribute digital signals via
satellite directly to television viewers. To receive DTH, viewers need a satellite dish and a set top box.
Depending on the service provider, viewers may also require a smart card for the subscription based
and premium television services distributed via satellite.

As of December 2020, approximately 46% and 67% of households in Bulgaria and Greece, respectively,
that had subscribed to Pay-TV services received their content via DTH, compared to approximately
16% in Serbia and approximately 5% in Slovenia. We believe that the majority of DTH Pay-TV
subscribers live in rural areas without access to a cable network, which limits the overlap between our
cable Pay-TV and DTH Pay-TV offerings.

- OTT

Another emerging technology is the delivery of television content “over-the-top” of an existing
broadband internet network, which allows Pay-TV distributors to reach customers through the internet.
We operate two of our own OTT content platforms: our regional OTT platform (which operates under
the EON brand of products and services) and our international OTT platform, NetTV Plus. Our regional
OTT platform offers customers of our broadband internet competitors within the region access to our
full digital Pay-TV channel offering. As a result, EON subscribers can watch all of our digital Pay-TV
channels on their TV screens, computers, tablets, mobiles or other internet enabled devices. Through
NetTV Plus, we deliver extensive local and regional content, to the entire former Yugoslav expatriate
community worldwide. Like EON, our subscribers can watch Net TV Plus directly on their TV screens,
computers, tablets, mobiles or other internet enabled devices. We are a leading provider of Pay-TV
services across our three core markets.

We mainly compete with local incumbents in our three core markets (Telekom Slovenije in Slovenia,
Telekom Srbija in Serbia and Bulsatcom in Bulgaria), Cosmote in Greece, as well as with other local
players (T2 in Slovenia, Telekom Srpske, HT Eronet and A1 Bulgaria in Bulgaria, among others). We
have managed to maintain our leadership and grow our market shares across our three core markets due
to high quality content offering, excellent customer care, positive brand perception and better value and
product propositions.

###### Broadband

_Overview_

The broadband internet market in our core markets is characterized by continued growth and increasing
demand for high speed broadband internet services, which ultimately contributes to increasing internet
service penetration rates:

**_Broadband Penetration Rates (% of Total Households), 2020_**

____________________________

Source: Ampere


-----

Fixed broadband internet household penetration rates in Bulgaria grew from approximately 65% in
2018 to 72% in 2020, in Serbia from approximately 59% in 2018 to 66% in 2020, in Slovenia from
approximately 73% in 2018 to 75% in 2020 and in Greece from approximately 100% in 2018 to 106%
in 2020. This translated into substantial growth in the number of subscribers at CAGRs of 5.3% (from
1,904 thousand to 2,113 thousand) in Bulgaria, 5.6% (from 1,447 thousand to 1,613 thousand) in Serbia,
2.2% (from 607 thousand to 634 thousand) in Slovenia and 3.3% (from 3,996 thousand to 4,263
thousand) in Greece during the same period. At the same time, fixed broadband penetration rates outside
of Greece lag behind the penetration rates of more developed European markets, such as France, UK
and the Netherlands.

We believe that the positive growth in the broadband internet market in our three core markets also
stems from the overall increasing importance of the internet as the primary communication medium of
choice as well as from a decrease in end user equipment costs, leading to increasing usage of personal
computers and smartphones. By 2024, broadband internet penetration rates are expected to reach 85%,
or 2,438 thousand, of households in Bulgaria, 78%, or 1,893 thousand, of households in Serbia, 79%,
or 677 thousand, of households in Slovenia and 112%, or 4,553 thousand, of households in Greece. As
data consumption demand grows in households, the penetration rate of high speed broadband (lines
capable of providing at least 30 Mbps) is expected to increase rapidly in Slovenia and Serbia in the
coming years. The Serbian “Strategy for the Development of Broadband and Networks and Service,”
adopted in 2014, established a target of 100% coverage with 30 Mbps by 2020 and 50% coverage for
100 Mpbs in an effort to align with EU targets.

- DSL


-----

DSL uses basic telephone infrastructure to access the internet. DSL technology leverages the fact that
copper wires used in telephone networks have a much higher bandwidth (7 MHz) than that required for
normal voice conversation (0 3.4 KHz). DSL utilizes the extra bandwidth to provide broadband internet
connections. The most commonly used variant of DSL is ADSL which assumes that internet users
normally receive or download significant more information than they would send or upload. Hence,
ADSL connections normally have three to four times more bandwidth for downloading. However, as
copper is a distance sensitive medium, access speeds for DSL technology decrease substantially as the
distance from DSL hubs increases. The maximum download speed of DSL networks has to be shared
between all services: television, broadband internet and telephony. Under currently available
technology, DSL based multi-play providers can therefore not provide broadband internet and television
services of comparable quality to those provided over cable networks. Another variant of DSL is VDSL,
a DSL technology that provides a faster data transfer rate than ADSL technologies. It is an access
technology that exploits the existing infrastructure of copper wires that were originally deployed for
traditional telephone service as a way of delivering very high speed internet access.

Historically, DSL has been distribution platform and accounted for approximately 7% of all internet
connections in Bulgaria, 37% in Serbia, 28% in Slovenia and 100% in Greece at the end of 2020.
However, its market share has been consistently eroded by upgraded cable networks which offer higher
quality service and higher speed as well as by the steady development of fiber based networks.

- Cable

Cable networks have been designed for the transmission of large amounts of analogue TV and radio
signals and are able to deliver consistent speeds irrespective of the distance to the customer, unlike
DSL. United Group companies are leading cable providers in the region with fully bi directional
network, largely EuroDOCSIS 3.0 enabled and offering up to 220 Mbps download speeds, with the
upgrade path up to 1.2 Gbps. Furthermore, the deployment of EuroDOCSIS 3.1 technology will allow
cable operators to provide data download speeds as high as 10 Gbps and data upload speeds as high as
2 Gbps over existing HFC lines (with full duplex EuroDOCSIS 3.1, upstream capacity will also be as
high as 10 Gbps). EuroDOCSIS 3.1 when deployed enables us to compete head on with fiber networks.
In addition to faster download and upload speeds, EuroDOCSIS 3.1 also offers other tangible benefits,
such as higher bandwidth capacity, better operational efficiencies, higher quality control, real time
performance analysis and lower costs. All these other tangible benefits should be available without
necessarily upgrading existing HFC networks or adding more fiber lines. EuroDOCSIS 3.1 is also
backward compatible with EuroDOCSIS 3.0, which allows us to roll out the new specifications
seamlessly, on an incremental basis.

In 2020, cable distribution accounted for 18%, 49% and 30% of all broadband infrastructure in Bulgaria,
Serbia and Slovenia, respectively. There is limited cable infrastructure in Greece.

- FttH

FttH is based on optical fiber cables and is the only infrastructure that offers similar speeds. Currently,
FttH broadband internet connections play a very limited role in Serbia. FttH had a broadband market
share in Slovenia of approximately 42% as of December 31, 2020, compared to approximately 36% in
2018. The main providers of FttH in Slovenia are Telekom Slovenije and T2. The increase in the FttH
broadband market share is primarily due to extensive fiber roll out by Telekom Slovenije and T2 in
2009, as well as EU investment in municipally owned open fiber networks. As fiber roll out is more
expensive than cable and the open fiber networks have traditionally been built with the objective of
making high speed broadband internet and IPTV services accessible in rural areas, we believe that any
competitive impact on cable operators will be limited, as these operators traditionally provide services
in more urban and high density areas (i.e. no overlap).

FttH is the technology of choice by United Group for greenfield expansion and new buildings in
adjacent areas.


-----

- Other Broadband Internet

We also compete with service providers that use other alternative technologies for broadband internet
access, such as satellite technologies or mobile standards such as WiMax, universal mobile
telecommunications system (“UMTS”) and high speed packet access (“HSPA”). These mobile
broadband internet access technologies may allow both incumbent and new broadband internet access
providers the ability to provide high speed connection services for voice, data, video and television. We
estimate that only a small portion of households were using UMTS/HSPA for primary broadband
internet access via laptops or PCs in 2014. We believe that the majority of mobile broadband internet
users presently use mobile internet services to complement, rather than to replace, fixed line broadband
internet.

_Competition_

We are the leading provider of broadband services within our footprint with 22%, 33% and 29% of the
market share in Bulgaria, Serbia and Slovenia, respectively, as of 2020. We are also a strong challenger
in Greece with 12% of the market share in the country as of 2020:

_Technology_

We provide fixed line telephony services in Bulgaria, Serbia, Slovenia and Greece, using VoIP
telephony technology. VoIP technologies place and transmit telephone calls over the internet instead of
using the traditional PSTN. Following the liberalization of fixed line telephony markets in Serbia, all
telephony markets in our three core markets are now fully liberalized, providing us with significant
growth opportunities. Slovenia is one of the few European telephony markets in which VoIP technology
accounts for the majority of the fixed line telephony connections. We believe that this increase in VoIP
market share was primarily driven by lower prices of VoIP connections compared to PSTN connections
which are often offered as part of a competitively priced cable or FttH internet and television bundle.

_Competition_

Historically, the respective incumbent (Telekom Slovenije in Slovenia, Telekom Srbija in Serbia) in
two of our three core markets, has been the largest provider of fixed line telephony in each respective
market. However, following the liberalization of the region’s telephony markets and the introduction of
VoIP technologies, which allows customers to make traditional fixed line telephone calls using a
standard telephone handset and provides comparable quality to PSTN at lower prices, the respective
Bulgarian, Serbian and Slovenian incumbents have generally lost market share to us. Nova has lost
fixed line telephony market share on the back of a wider broadband market share loss:

_Slovenian Mobile Market Overview_

Following our acquisition of Tušmobil in April 2015, we provide mobile telephony services in Slovenia
as an MNO. There were approximately 2.5 million mobile subscribers in Slovenia as of December 31,
2018, which resulted in a penetration rate of 119%, below the average mobile penetration rate in Europe.
The number of mobile subscribers in Slovenia grew at a CAGR of approximately 1.5% between 2014
and 2018. We believe mobile penetration in Slovenia is still below the penetration benchmarks provided
by certain developed mobile markets in Western Europe, such as Germany and Sweden, supporting
continued subscriber growth potential in the market. The Slovenian mobile market is a predominantly
contract (post-paid) market.

There has been a continuous decline in Slovenian mobile termination rates (“MTR”) since 2008. MTR
asymmetry in the Slovenian market was eliminated as of January 1, 2013, when MTR for all operators
became €0.0324 per minute. In July 2014, the Slovenian regulator, AKOS, announced a significant
reduction in MTRs to €0.0114 per minute and implemented this rate for all Slovenian operators with
effect from September 1, 2014. Following this reduction, Slovenian MTR was brought closer in line
with the target EU benchmark of €0.01 per minute, indicating limited further downside.

_Greek Mobile Market Overview_

As of December 31, 2020, there were approximately 14.1 million mobile subscribers in Greece, which
resulted in a penetration rate of 135% and is above the average mobile penetration rate in Europe. The
number of mobile subscribers in Greece is expected to remain stable at a CAGR of approximately 0.1%
between 2020 and 2024. There are three mobile network operators in the Greek market; namely
Cosmote, Vodafone and Wind Hellas, with their own frequency allocation. Given the strong
competition, especially in the pre-paid mobile market, MVNOs have not been a major feature of the
Greek telecommunications market.

Greek mobile subscribers are well-positioned to benefit from pre-paid-to-post-paid conversion due to
the strong smartphone take-up, existing operational 5G commercial networks of each mobile network
operator and the well-saturated mobile market, which offers a future growth lever.

Following the implementation by the Greek regulator of measures to eliminate MTR asymmetry in
2018, there has been a continuous decline in Greek MTRs, with the rates stabilizing in 2013 at a level
close to EU averages. Greek MTR currently sits at €0.01 per minute, which is in line with the target EU
benchmark, indicating limited further downside.

_Licenses_

- Spectrum Licenses – Slovenia

The first ever spectrum auction in Slovenia was completed in April 2014 with the award of several
frequency bands to three mobile operators: Telekom Slovenije, Si.mobil (now A1) and Tušmobil
(Telemach Slovenia). Three of the four MNOs (T 2 did not participate) acquired the following bands:
A1 acquired total of 90 MHz on paired 800, 900, 1800 and 2600 MHz and a total of 45 MHz on unpaired
2100 and 2600 MHz; Telekom Slovenije acquired a total of 85 MHz on paired 800, 900, 1800 MHz
and a total of 25 MHz on unpaired 2600 MHz band, Telemach Slovenia acquired a paired spectrum of
5 MHz on 900, 10 MHz on 1800 as well as 10 MHz in the 800 MHz band which is widely recognized
as the most efficient band for 4G LTE roll out. The licenses were awarded for a long term tenure of 15
years which we believe represents a significant barrier to entry for a potential fifth MNO.

In July 2016, AKOS announced its decision to conduct an auction for various mobile spectrum bands
in Slovenia that remained unallocated. These included frequencies in the 1800 MHz band and the 2100
MHz band. AKOS set the reserve price at €2.6 million for each block of 2x5 MHz in the 1800 MHz


-----

frequency band, two blocks of which were available for auction, and €1.3 million for the block of
2x5MHz in the 2100 MHz band, one block of which was available for auction. On August 5, 2016, we
submitted our tender for these frequencies. On August 29, 2016, AKOS issued a decision in our favor
on the allocation of two blocks of 2x5 MHz in the 1800 MHz frequency band and one block of 2x5
MHz in the 2100 MHz frequency band for an aggregate amount of €6.6 million. Telemach Slovenia’s
license for the frequencies in the 1800 MHz band is valid through January 2031, and for the frequencies
in the 2100 MHz band is valid through September 2021. Telemach Slovenia currently possesses 60%
less spectrum compared to its main two competitors. In April 2021, we secured 15-year spectrum
licenses in Slovenia for 5G frequencies, and commenced deployment and commercial launch of 5G
3600 MHz in Slovenia in June 2021. We believe additional frequencies will be needed to be able to
address our growing mobile business, especially in the domain of mobile broadband.

- Spectrum Licenses – Bulgaria

On September 2020, we announced the commercial launch of our 5G network in Bulgaria and, to that
end, in May 2021, we secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band.

- Spectrum Licenses – Greece

The first ever spectrum auction in Greece was completed in 2011 with the award of technology-neutral
900MHz and 1,800 MHz frequency bands valid until September 29, 2027 and for 15 years, respectively,
to three mobile operators: Cosmote, Vodafone and Wind Hellas. Cosmote secured four blocks of
2x10MHz in the 900MHz band and two blocks of 2x10MHz in the 1,800MHz band; Vodafone secured
six blocks of 2x15MHz in the 900MHz band and two blocks of 2x10MHz in the 1,800MHz band; Wind
Hellas secured four blocks of 2x10MHz in the 900MHz band.

Further spectrum frequencies dedicated to 4G were auctioned in 2014 in the 800MHz and 2,600MHz
bands and consisted of 24 lots: Cosmote secured two blocks of 2x5MHz in the 800MHz band, six blocks
of 2x5MHz in the 2,600MHz band and two blocks of 10MHz in the 2,600MHz band; Vodafone secured
two blocks of 2x5MHz in the 800MHz band, six blocks of 2x5MHz in the 2,600MHz band and two
blocks of 10MHz in 2,600MHz band; Wind Hellas secured two blocks of 2x5MHz in the 800MHz band
and four blocks of 2x5MHz in the 2,600MHz band. The licenses were awarded for a long-term tenure
of 15 years.

In 2017, Vodafone and Wind Hellas renewed their 1,800MHz licenses for 17 years and Cosmote
renewed its license for 15 years.

In 2020, the Greek regulator opened applications for the 5G frequencies auction, with Wind Hellas,
Vodafone and Cosmote submitting their bids. Cosmote secured 15x5MHz in the 3.5GHz band,
2x10MHz in the 700MHz band, 2x20MHz in the 2,100MHz band and two packets of 26GHz band;
Vodafone secured 14x5MHz in the 3.5GHz band, 2x10MHz in the 700MHz band, 2x20MHz in the
2,100MHz band and two packets of 26Ghz band; Wind Hellas secured 10x5MHz in the 3.5GHz band,
2x10MHz in the 700MHz band, 2x20MHz in the 2,100MHz band and one packet of 26GHz band.

###### Bundles

Customers in our three core markets increasingly seek to receive their multimedia and communications
services in a bundled offer from one provider. In response, service providers are providing television,
broadband internet and fixed line and mobile telephony services in bundled offerings; such bundled
offerings are marketed as the best value for money. We believe that bundled offerings allow media and
telecommunication service providers to better meet customers’ communication and entertainment
demands, increase average revenue per customer while also increasing customer loyalty and attract new
customers via an enhanced value proposition.

As of December 31, 2018, approximately 81% of unique fixed line customers are bundled customers in
Telemach Slovenia. Fixed and mobile convergence was approximately 43% as of December 31, 2018
with 1.9 SIMs per customer on average. As of December 31, 2018, SBB Serbia and Telemach BH had
bundle penetration of 80% and 74% respectively. While such convergence has occurred at a relatively
fast pace in a number of Western and Eastern European markets, notably in Slovenia, a series of
regulations, including those limiting alternative operators other than the incumbent service providers
from providing telephony services in Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, have historically prevented
such convergence to occur in our three core markets. However, the relatively recent liberalization of
the Serbian and Bosnian fixed line telephony markets is accelerating the convergence in our three core
markets. The ability to bundle products and services plays an important role in our three core markets,
and we believe cable operators will be well positioned to benefit from this.

**_B2B Segment_**

Almost all businesses in our three core markets (Bulgaria, Serbia and Slovenia) have internet/broadband
connections. Large companies and small and medium enterprises can receive the following services


-----

from telecommunications companies: infrastructure and transport (dark fiber, wavelengths and
synchronous digital hierarchy), co-location, enterprise connectivity (including internet access, Ethernet
and multiprotocol label switching, virtual private network/wide area network, security and managed
services), hosting & cloud storage (including infrastructure as a service and platform as a service) and
voice.

According to Solon, business fixed data spending (which includes internet access (comprising
connection charges and monthly fees, excluding equipment costs), Ethernet (installation and monthly
services charges), internet protocol virtual private networks (costs of underlying broadband and
dedicated connections, excluding dial line rental and usage charges), very high bandwidth services
(upfront connection and monthly service charges on optical and dark fiber services) and legacy data
services (digital leased line, Frame Relay and asynchronous transfer mode connections)). We expect
the business fixed data spending to remain relatively stable. In more developed markets, additional
spending for co-location, hosting & cloud storage is typically around three times the amount of fixed
data spending.

**Media Overview**

Despite economic differences, the countries of Southeastern Europe have a joint history and form a
single media market in which local differences are compensated by the influence of similarities in
cultural preferences and language across the region. Television is by far the main source of news and
information in our three core markets. Through United Media, we play a significant role in this attractive
market and even offer our own content, including some of the region’s most popular sports, news,
children and general entertainment channels. We currently operate the most viewed channel in Croatia,
Nova TV which we believe enhances our media offering and strengthens our leadership position in
Croatia. In addition, in October 2018 we rebranded the Direct Media/Pink operations in Montenegro,
North Macedonia and Albania as well as its terrestrial TV stations Pink BiH and Pink Montenegro as
Nova S in BH and Nova M to facilitate synergies with Nova TV in Croatia. In 2019, we launched Nova
S in Serbia, which although a Pay-TV channel, is structured as a full format national TV station with
attractive talk shows, sports and own production local fiction series in the market. Since January 2021,
we also operate Nova BG, the largest multi-media platform company in Bulgaria, which complements
Vivacom’s operation and consolidate our media leadership in the country. In Greece, we rebranded
Forthnet to Nova, refreshing its visual identity, and initiated a significant consolidation of the
entertainment and sports offerings.

**_Broadcasting_**

_Overview and Technology_

Television in Slovenia was first introduced in 1958, with the launch of JRT RTV Ljubljana (now RTV
Slovenija) as the first TV station. Following the independence from Yugoslavia in 1991, the Mass
Media Act which was passed in 1994, laid out the specific model for the privatization of media in
Slovenia. The Mass Media Act was revised in 2001 and 2006 to define clear rules for ensuring media
pluralism. Today, TV market in Slovenia is operated by both state owned and for profit corporations
and is mainly shared between public service RTV Slovenia and private stations Kanal A and Pop TV.
Kanal A was the first commercial TV station which launched in 1991, followed by Pop TV which
launched in 1995.

Television in Serbia was first introduced in 1958 with state owned Television Belgrade, now known as
Radio Television of Serbia (“RTS”). The Serbian broadcasting system evolved from a public monopoly
into a dual system of public and private stations. The switch over from analogue to digital terrestrial
television in the country was completed in 2015.

Television in Bosnia and Herzegovina was first introduced in 1956 and since then, it has now developed
into a market with both private and public channels. Three public TV stations (BHT1, FTV and RTRS)
are operating within the Public Service Broadcasting system and are financed from radio and television


-----

fees. Together with private stations, as well as regional public stations, they form the national TV
market. The Pay-TV market is significantly fragmented with the majority of private TV stations being
locally focused. However, there are a number of players that aim to capture a wider audience throughout
the country (for example, N1 of Telemach BH). The process of TV digitalization is still ongoing in
Bosnia and Herzegovina.

Television in Croatia was first introduced in 1956 with Television Zagreb. Today there are four channels
with nationwide coverage. Digital video broadcasting terrestrial signal broadcasting was introduced in
2002, with the full digital switchover being completed by 2010 via gradual ceasing of analogue TV
throughout the country.

Television in Greece was first introduced in 1966 as a service of the National Radio Foundation (EIR).
Greece's switch from analogue to digital terrestrial television was completed in February 2015. As of
the date of this offering memorandum, the Greek television market is dominated by free-to-air DTT
offered by the key state-owned Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation and six private national TV channels.

**_Advertising_**

Across our three core markets, television is the medium of choice for advertising, accounting for
approximately 50% of total advertising spent. The internet, as a medium of choice for advertising, is
expected to grow at higher rates than television, but will still remain below television in coming years.
The average daily viewing time across the three core markets ranges from approximately 3.5 to 5.5
hours demonstrating the importance of TV as medium for information and entertainment. Most
importantly, the demand for TV is relatively inelastic. TV continues to offer a unique proposition to
advertisers: enormous scale, fast reach, very high quality advertisement inventory and an attractive
contextual environment for brand building. As a result, TV advertising should continue to be resilient,
with any gradual volume reductions more than offset by price inflation.

Television broadcasting in each of our markets is regulated by a governmental authority or agency. For
example, privately owned broadcasters in Slovenia are allowed to broadcast advertising for up to 12
minutes in any hour, whereas the public broadcaster, Radiotelevizija Slovenija, is allowed to broadcast
advertising for up to 10 minutes per hour given the additional financing from TV licensing fees.
Between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 11:00 p.m., the advertising time limit is reduced to seven minutes
for the public broadcaster. In Serbia, advertising time is regulated on an hourly and daily basis, where
commercial broadcasters are restricted to 20% of the daily broadcasts and to 20% per hour of
broadcasting. Similarly to Slovenia, in Croatia the permitted advertising time per hour is 12 minutes
with no daily limit and direct sales advertising must be at least 15 minutes.

The advertising markets in Southeastern Europe have benefitted from robust macro-economic
conditions. Advertising spend in our core three countries (Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and
Herzegovina) is expected to grow faster than real GDP, with TV channel advertising remaining resilient.
The recent decline of advertising spend in Croatia resulted from bankruptcy of one of Croatia’s biggest
company, Agrokor, which employed approximately 60 thousand total staff members and its revenues
accounted for more than 15% of Croatia’s total GDP.

The Direct Media/Pink Acquisition, completed in September 2018, focuses on targeted advertising and
specialized Pay-TV and positions us at the forefront of digital advertising in the region. As a result, we
acquired the know-how of more than 100 of the best professionals in the region who provide significant
synergies with the broader operations of the Group.

Our in-house content business produces distinctive and attractive content for our Pay-TV channels and
has historically driven Pay-TV subscriptions. We currently produce over 50% of the total content in our
national (terrestrial) and most of our Pay-TV operations, and our main prime-time programs typically
receive ratings of between 20% and 50% in the markets in which they are available. As part of our
media business, we also provide advertising services and digital production and distribution in our
markets. We are also a distribution partner of choice for premium regional and international content
owners because of our well-known brands, large network and our focus on Southeastern Europe.

Our core telecommunications business is complemented by our two OTT distribution platforms that
customers can access through internet-based streaming: (i) EON, our regional OTT platform in
Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Greece, which enables customers connected to our
competitors’ broadband internet connections outside of our cable footprint to access our attractive
portfolio of Pay-TV channels; and (ii) NetTV Plus, our international OTT platform, which delivers
ethnic and local language content to the ex-Yugoslav diaspora around the world. In July 2020, we
launched Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online shopping platform, which offers more than 20


-----

popular product categories, and is available as an integrated online and TV shopping platform in Serbia
and Slovenia.

We believe that we are well-positioned to maintain and grow our market-leading positions, as we
provide a well-invested network, some of the fastest download speeds, access to desirable media content
and high-quality customer service, all of which has led to relatively low churn rates and high customer
loyalty. Our customers view the telecommunications products and services that we offer as part of their
everyday lives, which results in recurring, high demand and makes our business more resilient to macroeconomic disruptions, including the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic where we saw data and voice traffic
increase.

**Competitive Strengths**

**_We operate in structurally attractive markets._**

We operate in countries across Southeastern Europe that are attractive telecommunication markets due
to favourable competitive dynamics, relatively low penetration of broadband and Pay-TV, and a
predictable regulatory environment. Our countries of operation have also generally experienced
stronger real GDP growth than the Eurozone average in recent years. Most recently, in 2021, real GDP
in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Greece, Montenegro, Serbia and Slovenia grew by 5.7%
on average compared to 5.0% on average in the Eurozone. In addition, real GDP in these countries is
currently estimated to grow at an average of 2.9% by 2025, which is higher than the average estimated
growth of 1.4% in the Eurozone (source: IMF).

After completing the Wind Hellas Acquisition, across most of our footprint, there are only one to two
other companies in each of the countries where we are present that own and operate the majority of the
broadband infrastructure. While in some of our markets a few small players own their broadband
network, we have competitive advantages over them given our nationwide presence and the benefits of
scale that we enjoy as nationwide network operators. Within the four major geographies where we offer
mobile-telephony, with the exception of Slovenia, there are only three MNOs in each country. The
presence of fewer players owning broadband and mobile networks within a single competitive
environment typically results in healthy competition in the retail market which leads to profitable
investments.

The countries in which we operate are characterized by growing Pay-TV and broadband markets that
are currently underpenetrated relative to some other CEE and Western European markets and therefore
present an attractive structural growth proposition. Between 2018 and 2020, fixed broadband internet
household penetration rates increased from approximately 65% to 72% in Bulgaria, from approximately
59% to 66% in Serbia, from approximately 73% to 75% in Slovenia and from approximately 100% to
106% in Greece. Over the same period, overall Pay-TV market penetration rates increased from
approximately 73% to 89% in Serbia and from approximately 76% to 77% in Slovenia, and remained
stable at approximately 68% in Bulgaria. As a result, over the past few years we have experienced a
steady growth in the number of subscribers across our markets and we expect our subscriber base to
grow further over the next couple of years. Subscribers are increasingly upgrading to higher speed
broadband offerings due to a variety of factors including, among others, the increase in remote working
and continued growth in high bandwidth applications.

The national telecommunication framework in each of our countries of operation is overseen by
competent national regulatory authorities. As members of the EU, Bulgaria, Greece, Slovenia and
Croatia which together account for than 3/4 of our revenues after giving effect to the Wind Hellas
Acquisition, have national regulatory frameworks that align with EU guidelines and directives, which
provides for a relatively stable regulatory environment.

**_We are the leading integrated multi-play provider across Southeastern Europe._**


-----

We are the leading integrated multi-play provider in Southeastern Europe based on market share by
number of subscribers, a position that we have reinforced through acquisitions we have made which
have allowed us to expand geographically, diversify our business and increase our customer base. Our
leadership position in the region will be further strengthened following the completion of the Wind
Hellas Acquisition, which will add 3.4 million RGUs as of September 30, 2021. In addition, the
Vivacom Acquisition has increased our addressable market by 35%. Our scale and presence across
Southeastern Europe and across our product portfolios allows us to cross-sell our services and expand
the number of multi-play packages we provide, creating opportunities to further expand our customer
base and continue to strengthen our leadership position in the region.

In the Pay-TV market, we have leveraged our complementary cable and DTH platforms to gain leading
market shares in Southeastern Europe and become the pan regional leader with 2.1 million unique
subscribers as of September 30, 2021. In particular, we are the leading Pay-TV provider in each of
Serbia, Slovenia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, with market shares of 45%, 39% and 40%, respectively,
as of September 30, 2021, each based on number of subscribers; and we are the second largest Pay-TV
operator in Greece, with a market share of 27% as of September 30, 2021, and the largest in Bulgaria,
with a market share of 27% as of September 30, 2021, each based on number of subscribers. In addition,
we are the largest DTH Pay-TV provider in Montenegro and are among the main providers of DTH
Pay-TV in North Macedonia and Croatia. Among high-speed cable broadband internet providers, we
are the leader in each of Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina within our footprint and have a
large broadband market share overall, behind only the respective incumbents with national footprints.
We are also the leading provider of broadband internet by number of subscribers in Bulgaria. In
addition, we are the market leader in fixed-line telephony in Bulgaria and the second-largest fixed-line
telephony provider in Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. In mobile-telephony, we are the
third largest MNO in each of Slovenia, Bulgaria, Croatia and, after giving effect to the Wind Hellas
Acquisition, Greece, with market shares based on the number of subscribers of, respectively,
approximately 24% as of June 30, 2021, 29% as of December 31, 2020, and 19% and 24% as of
September 30, 2021.

**_We are a recognized media leader benefitting from content ownership, own production and strategic_**
**_partnerships._**

We believe we are the recognized media leader in Southeastern Europe, offering fully integrated
production and distribution of attractive and distinctive local content for the entire region, which has a
population of approximately 40 million, with similar languages, cultures and entertainment preferences.
Our focus on the entire Southeastern European region allows us to maintain and serve some of the
smaller markets where smaller operators are less able to provide first rate localized content on an
economically efficient basis. At the same time, we believe international players would find it difficult
and costly to expand into the region, due to language and cultural barriers.

Through our owned-content business we directly own many of the region’s popular pay-TV channels.
In addition, as of September 30, 2021, we produced 50% of our content locally. Owning our content
allows us to control the end-to-end creation process, produce a wide range of diversified and attractive
local and genre specific content and maintain a structural hedge on content costs. Our in-house
production has significantly increased over recent years, and the content offered has continuously
improved. In addition, we have established a digital music production and content distribution business,
and have leading full format TV stations with appealing content in Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina
and Montenegro. In March 2019, we launched Nova S in Serbia, Total TV and EON. Following the
Nova Acquisition in November 2020, we also offer content under EON-branded channels in Greece,
and in January 2021, we acquired Nova Broadcasting Group, Bulgaria’s largest multi-platform media
company, becoming a major content player in Bulgaria.

In addition to our owned content offerings, our pay-TV distribution platforms typically license the rights
for the distribution of our own channels, as well as third-party owned channels. We believe that our pan
regional presence, large subscriber base, advanced network, cable and DTH platforms, leading market


-----

positions and relationships with all major third-party distribution platforms make us an attractive partner
to third-party content owners, including major sporting leagues (such as the World Cup qualifiers and
the League of Nations). As a result, we are able to enter into strategic partnerships with third-party
contract providers to distribute their content to the entire region on attractive terms, whereas competitors
operating in a single country within the region cannot offer similarly broad coverage. We are also able
to offer our content partners value added services such as subtitles for television shows and can spread
the costs across our operations in the entire region, whereas we believe such costs would not be
economically justifiable for a competitor operating within a single country in the region. The table
below highlights our differentiated media offering:

**_We have a large infrastructure portfolio of fiber, cable TV and mobile networks, that is advanced,_**
**_well-invested and with a broad reach across the region._**

We strive to be the most advanced media and telecommunications company in Southeastern Europe
and we believe that our fiber, mobile and cable TV infrastructure allows us to provide higher quality
digital TV, high-speed broadband and fixed-line telephony and mobile telephony than other operators
in our markets. Our network is well invested and has a relatively low cost to upgrade. In March 2021,
we announced an investment of more than €500 million over the next five years to extend our fiber
network into new areas and upgrade the existing network with 10 Gbps-enabled infrastructure based on
XGS-PON.

We operate the largest fiber network in the region across metropolitan areas in Southern Europe,
extending for approximately 50,000 kilometers. In Bulgaria, we operate the largest FTTx network,
which covers more than 1.3 million homes passed as of September 30, 2021 with symmetrical upload
and download speeds of up to 10 Gbps. Together with the VDSL network, our broadband network


-----

covers more than 1.8 million homes passed as of September 30, 2021, which represent approximately
64% of homes in Bulgaria. In Greece, Wind Hellas is one of the major fiber operators with a nationwide
network of more than 3,000 kilometers and close to half a million homes passed as of September 30,
2021 through a mix of fiber to the home (FttH) and fiber to the cabinet (FttC) networks. We see
significant further growth opportunity in FttH networks in the underpenetrated Greek market where we
have a dedicated rollout platform and wholesale team in place. In Croatia, Optima Telekom has a
nationwide optical fiber network over 3,000 kilometers and covers over half a million homes passed as
of September 30, 2021. We plan to invest €100 million in the coming years to further upgrade our
network in Croatia.

We also operate an advanced proprietary HFC network which is fully bi-directional and EuroDOCSIS
3.0 enabled, covering all of our homes passed in Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro, and
approximately 99% of homes passed in Slovenia as of September 30, 2021. As of September 30, 2021,
our cable network covers approximately 1.8 million homes passed, and 94% of our core network was
DOCSIS 3.1 ready. In addition, our network has an average homes passed per fiber optics node ratio in
the range of approximately 242, 206 and 219 across Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina,
respectively, which we believe is unrivalled in Southeastern Europe and compares favourably to other
European cable operators.

We also believe our average recorded download speed is consistently faster than those of our main
broadband competitors. In particular, we believe it is 1.7x faster in Serbia, 3.3x faster in Slovenia, 3.9x
faster in Bosnia and Herzegovina and 1.2x faster in Bulgaria.

We have nationwide mobile networks in Bulgaria, Croatia, Greece and Slovenia, where we own
approximately 4,700 towers, including both passive and active equipment, and have spectrum across
2G, 3G, 4G and 5G bands. Our mobile network covers the majority of the population in each of our
countries of operations through our extensive 2G/3G/4G networks, and at present we have the capability
to provide 4G (LTE) and 4G+ (LTE-A) coverage to approximately 99 % and 98%, respectively, of the
Slovenian population, approximately 100% and 98%, respectively, of the Bulgarian population,
approximately 99% and 96%, respectively, of the Croatian population. Following the completion of the
Wind Hellas Acquisition, we will have the capability to provide 4G (LTE) coverage to approximately
98% of the Greek population. To further develop our networks, we have successfully tested and are
rolling out next generation 5G networks across our mobile-telephony footprint. We were the first mobile
operator to have launched 5G services in Slovenia in 2021 and our mobile network in Bulgaria was
named the fastest mobile in Europe by Ookla in both 2020 and 2021.

**_Our low churn rates demonstrate our loyal customer base and differentiated proposition._**

Our business model is attractive and resilient. We believe our portfolio of must-have products and our
superior offering have resulted in a growing and loyal customer base with relatively low churn rates of
approximately 9-11% per annum, combined with the ability to up sell and cross-sell products. Our
customers view the telecommunications products and services that we offer as part of their everyday
lives, which results in recurring, high demand for our products and makes our business more resilient
to macro-economic disruptions when compared to other discretionary products and services. For
example, during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic our products and services have been instrumental in
providing connectivity and entertainment, as an increasing number of people began to work or study
remotely and spend significant amounts of time at home, which resulted in a significant increase in our
voice and data traffic. In this recurring, high demand environment, we believe we offer superior
products, faster broadband speeds and higher quality content than our competitors. Customer loyalty is
evidenced by our relatively low historical churn rates, which is defined as the percentage of customers
that no longer subscribe for a certain service compared to the average number of customers in a
particular month. For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, our unique cable subscriber churn
rate annualized was 10%, which is below recent reported cable subscriber churn rates of certain Western
European peers. We believe our relatively low churn rates provide, among other benefits, recurring cash


-----

flows and visibility with respect to future revenue. Moreover, these churn rates have persisted
notwithstanding regular price increases.

**_We have a strong track record of profitable growth driven by structurally attractive markets, cross-_**
**_selling opportunities and the successful integration of acquired assets._**

We have a strong track record of profitable growth, underpinned by relatively low penetration rates in
the markets in which we operate and cross-selling opportunities due to our scale, as well as a record of
successfully integrating acquisitions. We operate most of our business across countries in Southeastern
Europe that have relatively low penetration rates in Pay-TV and broadband, which we can capitalize on
via cross-selling due to our scale and comprehensive offering portfolio. As of September 30, 2021, our
Pay-TV penetration of homes passed and broadband internet were 61% and 89%, respectively, in
Slovenia, 63% and 74%, respectively, in Serbia, and 61% and 83%, respectively in Bosnia and
Herzegovina. As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas’ Pay-TV and NGA fiber penetration in LLU &
NGA fiber base were 11% and 44%, respectively, in Greece. In addition, due to historically strong
regulatory constraints on bundling Pay-TV, broadband internet and telephony services, RGUs per cable
subscriber ratios in our key markets have lagged behind CEE and Western European cable markets. We
believe this demonstrates that there are strong opportunities to continue to utilize up selling and crossselling opportunities to grow our cable RGUs per subscriber ratio. The following table shows
comparisons of RGUs per cable subscriber in certain key CEE and Western European markets with
those of certain other industry members:

In addition to organic growth, we have successfully completed and integrated a large number of targeted
and value accretive investments and acquisitions of attractive cable and mobile assets, such as Vivacom,

successfully integrated Vivacom into our Group and have accelerated its growth trajectory by launching

compared to the nine months ended September 30, 2020. Over the same period, Vivacom’s blended
cable ARPU increased by 4.9% to €9.7 from €9.2, mobile ARPU increased by 5.8% to €7.3 from €6.9,
and DTH ARPU increased by 5.0% to €8.4 from €8.0. We believe our strong track record of integrating

**_We benefit from a highly experienced management team with a proven track record and significant_**

We have leveraged the significant industry experience and corporate background of our senior

We also benefit from the market expertise, business relationships, knowledge and experience of BC
