**Strategy**

We aim to strengthen our telecommunications and media leadership positions in Southeastern Europe,
deliver exceptional revenue growth across segments and capitalize on operating leverage and continued
operating efficiencies to deliver strong profitability and cash flow generation, all while providing our
customers the best products and services in each of our segments and markets. In order to achieve these
goals, we have identified the following strategic pillars:

**_Continued focus on our competitive market positions by leveraging our advanced network,_**
**_differentiated content offerings and loyal customer base._**


-----

We are the leading multi-play provider in Southeastern Europe and hold leadership positions across
each of our countries of operations and product categories. We have achieved these competitive market
positions over the years and we aim to maintain and strengthen them going forward and to further
develop our business in attractive markets in Southeastern Europe. In order to achieve this, we intend
to continue to expand the coverage and capacity of our superior next generation infrastructure in our
footprint, including 5G capability, where the return on investment is appropriate. We also intend to
continue to offer our loyal customer base the most attractive and differentiated content offerings in the
region, with better content choice, speed, functionality and service quality compared to our competitors,
at prices that allow us to deliver compelling value.

**_Increase service penetration across the region by cross-selling products and services and up selling_**
**_value adding products to existing customers._**

We intend to continue to focus on pursuing subscriber growth opportunities in our relatively underpenetrated markets. Over time, we expect our businesses in Serbia, Bulgaria, Greece and Bosnia and
Herzegovina to converge with Slovenia in terms of broadband and Pay-TV penetration as well as in
service penetration (measured by RGU per subscriber). To achieve this, we aim to increase triple play
(and in the case of Slovenia and Bulgaria, quad-play) penetration and reduce churn rates by continuing
to shift focus in marketing and subscriber interactions from single services to bundled services. We
intend to continue to promote our bundled services by further leveraging our high-quality network and
utilizing our next generation digital television services, attractive local content and high-speed
broadband services and, where applicable, mobile-telephony services. We plan to offer more add-on
products and incentivize longer term contracts by offering better pricing and subsidies for certain
products. We also aim to capitalize on our superior high-speed broadband capabilities to increase
revenue. Specifically, we intend to continue migrating our existing high-speed broadband subscribers
to higher speeds, which we believe will further support broadband ARPU growth and reduce residential
subscriber churn rates. Following the Wind Hellas Acquisition, we intend to leverage the combination
with our existing Greek pay-TV provider NOVA to seize significant cross-selling, bundling and pricing
optimization opportunities in Greece.

**_Continue to consolidate our position as the leading media company in Southeastern Europe._**

Since inception, our media strategy has been centered on differentiating our offering by producing
superior and/or exclusive Pay-TV channels for our customers. We have applied this philosophy to all
of our Group companies with great success, and we have created an attractive portfolio of full format
national as well as specialized, thematic Pay-TV channels that we believe are a must-have on all
regional distribution platforms. Following the acquisition of Vivacom, Nova BG and Nova and their
integration into our operations, we are applying this philosophy in Bulgaria and Greece. We intend to
consolidate our leadership in Southeastern Europe and continue to grow our content offering by further
developing our portfolio of owned content, entering into strategic partnerships with third-party content
owners and acquiring other content owners in the region, as in the past with the acquisition of Nova TV
Croatia and Direct Media/Pink.

**_Further expand our addressable market by utilizing our OTT platform and attractive content._**

Leveraging our strong brands and our attractive content, we intend to continue to develop our two OTT
content platforms, our regional OTT platform, EON, and our international OTT platform, NetTV Plus,
to further expand our addressable market to areas outside our cable footprint. While our DTH Pay-TV
platform aims to deliver our content to subscribers in rural areas in our markets without cable
infrastructure, our regional OTT platform enables customers in metropolitan areas outside of our cable
footprint, who have subscribed to the broadband internet services of our competitors, to access our
attractive portfolio of Pay-TV channels and unique user interface and customer experience.
Additionally, NetTV Plus allows us to provide over 200 local language channels showing ethnic content
to the entire ex-Yugoslav diaspora around the world. By expanding our geographic reach to customers
in countries in Western Europe and North America, we believe that we are well positioned to further


-----

increase our RGU base and earnings potential. We have a plan to further invest in our in-house software
development of customer premises equipment for our TV and broadband services. With a unified
software solution, we will be able to provide all our service through a unified TV Box or broadband
gateway to any type of networks (OTT, Fiber, Cable or Mobile). We also plan to start developing a new
generation of digital streaming social applications, based on automated content, personalization and
advanced targeted advertising solutions. In addition, we have recently started the in-house development
of artificial intelligence engine software solutions, with dedicated teams who will develop machine
learning models for our content production, content recommendation system and advertisement
solutions.

**_Continued focus on innovation._**

We seek to continue innovating and enhancing our product offering to offer our customers an improved
use experience across our products, further strengthen our leading position across our countries of
operation and enter new markets. Our centralized in-house technology innovation and software
development center, United.Cloud, enables us to focus on leading the introduction of cutting-edge
television and broadband internet services and solutions such as EON (our next generation video
delivery platform which allows customers to watch their favorite channels on a broad range of devices),
UNIFON (our proprietary VoIP application connecting customers’ fixed-line telephones outside of their
homes), our self-help application, enhanced TV features such as VoD and CatchUp TV services and
many others. We also intend to continue promoting the digitalization of internal and external processes
to improve customer satisfaction and profitability. In July 2020, we leveraged our position in both the
broadband and Pay-TV markets to launch Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online-shopping
platform. We intend for Shoppster to continue delivering the simple, reliable and secure e-shopping
experience that modern consumers expect.

**_Continue to grow our customer base and operations through value accretive acquisitions and_**
**_optimize our portfolio._**

We have a successful track record of making acquisitions on attractive terms and successfully
integrating those acquisitions. Between 2011 and September 30, 2021, we have acquired and integrated
(or are in the process of integrating) approximately 50 cable TV operators, content platforms, media
companies, mobile service providers, B2B service providers and ISPs in Southeastern Europe. Most
recently, we have expanded our addressable market through the acquisition of Vivacom and Nova
Broadcasting in Bulgaria, Nova and, pending completion, Wind Hellas in Greece and Optima Telekom
in Croatia, as well as various other recent acquisitions. As a result, we have significantly improved our
business profile in terms of scale, geographic exposure and currency mix and product diversification.
Our acquisition strategy consists of expanding our scale in a value accretive manner, enhancing our
content offering, expanding our fixed-line and mobile-telephony operations and leveraging our
experience and successful acquisition history to continue to integrate businesses and generate additional
value by increasing scale and product offerings.

The Wind Hellas Acquisition provides us with the opportunity to increase our penetration into the Greek
market following our acquisition of Nova in 2020, increasing our scale and leadership across
Southeastern Europe, further diversifying our revenue streams and improving our currency mix, while
also providing significant upside arising from our strength in cross-selling, bundling and pricing
optimization. We intend to leverage our know-how arising from our highly successful acquisition track
record to successfully integrate Wind Hellas and realize its upside potential. As part of our integration
plan, we intend to combine Wind Hellas with our existing Greek pay-TV provider NOVA to develop a
quad-play market challenger operator, and the number two player in Greece in both broadband internet
and television services. We believe this combination will enable us to deliver a higher value to our
customers in the Greek market by providing a broad range of new technologies and superior services.

Going forward, we plan to continue to make value accretive acquisitions at attractive multiples to
integrate regional service providers, cable assets and fixed-line and mobile-telephony operators into the


-----

business. We intend to continue taking a disciplined approach to acquisitions by assessing individual
opportunities as and when they arise on the basis of merit, ability to integrate assets into our existing
business plans and potential for value creation.

While we continue to grow our business, we also continue to assess opportunities to optimize our
portfolio of assets and maximize value for our stakeholders as those opportunities arise. To that end,
we have taken initial steps to explore a possible sale of our mobile tower portfolios in Bulgaria, Slovenia
and Croatia. As of the date of this offering memorandum, we have not begun a sale process, identified
a buyer or determined any price or other terms for such a transaction. We currently do not have a
definitive timeline or commitment for any such sale, and we could decide not to proceed with such a
sale at any time.

**_Continue to focus on Environmental, Social and Corporate Governance (“ESG”) Matters_**

We and our shareholders recognize that developing a sustainable and responsible business that has a
positive social impact is key to our future success. As we have grown our Group, we have increased
our emphasis on integrating ESG considerations into the key aspects of our operations, including our
decision-making and reporting processes, and we intend to continue to increase our focus on ESG
matters going forward, including by implementing the ESG action plan and roadmap prepared by our
dedicated ESG coordinator in 2020 in consultation with external advisors.

To promote environmental sustainability in our operations, we are taking active steps to minimize our
environmental footprint, while also collecting and analyzing Group historical data to set future KPI
targets. We are committed to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and ultimately make all of our
operations carbon-neutral. We intend to leverage our experience in establishing a solar power plant in
Slovenia in 2019 to look for additional green energy projects which could cover a significant part of
our carbon emission footprint. For example, on November 30, 2021, we completed the acquisition of a
majority ownership in Tessa Energy in Bulgaria, which we expect will invest in the Kremena Wind
Park, which has a 70MW capacity and will allow us to significantly decrease our carbon footprint. We
also intend to continue to use electric vehicles in our operations where feasible, and work to exchange
old, less-energy efficient equipment for more energy-efficient devices. In 2020, we generated
approximately 128.1 thousand tons of CO2 emissions (9.3 thousand tons of scope 1 emissions and 118.8
thousand tons of scope 2 and 3 emissions), including the contribution of acquired companies. We intend
to reduce these by approximately 60%, or 50.6 thousand tons, by 2030. In addition, in 2020, we recycled
1,539 tons of network telecom equipment, batteries, cables, paper and cardboard. Our goal going
forward is to continue minimizing waste by repurposing, reusing or recycling 100% of returned
customer devices and accessories.

We support social and economic development in Southern Europe and aim to build the region’s most
advanced digital telecommunications infrastructure. In particular, we intend to invest approximately
one billion euros by the middle of this decade to modernize and expand our network to ensure it can
support the future needs of our customers. In 2020, we named a Group-level director for corporate social
responsibility and we plan to continue actively supporting the communities in which we operate. We
have as a Group donated €4.7 million in 2020 and €1.1 million for the nine months ended September
30, 2021, to groups and activities dedicated to protecting the environment, education and the socially
vulnerable, including donations of personal protective equipment to help fight COVID-19. We intend
to continue to engage in community engagement activities such as those we have carried out in the past
few years, with a focus on delivering knowledge to children, students, the general public and
disadvantaged groups, by leveraging our core competencies in broadband internet and other
telecommunications. For 2022, we aim to increase the percentage of staff participating in a community
engagement activity (e.g., volunteering time or knowledge), which in 2021 stood at 7% (excluding
United Media).

We focus on building a safe, fair and inclusive working environment for our employees. To inform our
diversity, inclusion and safety targets, we intend to continue collecting data on our workforce, such as


-----

gender mix, percentage of women in management positions and percentage of disabled employees to
set future targets. We also have mandated diversity and inclusion rules, and have documented these in
employee manuals at our Group companies. To facilitate further transparency and accountability, we
plan to expand our anonymous suggestion boxes already present in certain of our Group companies and
establish whistle-blowing programs as a distinct transparency function. We also plan to continue to
offer training programs to employees focused on improving job-related technical and management
skills, as well as on compliance with our internal policies.

**History**

Our founder and chairman of our advisory board, Dragan Šolak, founded the company as a Serbian
cable TV operator in 2000. Between 2001 and 2005, we grew our business by constructing an advanced
cable network throughout Serbia. We also consolidated several sub-scale family owned cable operators
and successfully integrated them into our business. We launched our DTH services, Total TV, in Serbia
in 2006 and in Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro in 2007 and expanded Total TV into
Croatia in 2008 (divested in 2018) and North Macedonia in 2009. In 2007, we entered into a strategic
alliance with Sport Klub, and we acquired a controlling stake in the Ultra family of Pay-TV channels
in 2009. As a result of our strategic alliances, as well as the acquisition of local language television
channels, we were among the first pay-TV providers in Southeastern Europe to provide localized
regional and international content.

In 2009, we acquired Telemach Slovenia, a leading triple-play provider in Slovenia. During 2010, our
consolidation of three cable pay-TV operators in Sarajevo, including KT Global Net, BH Cabel Net and
ELOB, led to the formation of Telemach BH. In addition, over time we have amassed a comprehensive
portfolio of owned pay-TV channels, covering sports, movies, news, music, general entertainment and
children’s programming, through our United Media business, which we have grown through focused
and consistent investment. We continue to leverage our position as the sole credible consolidator in the
fragmented regional markets and have successfully acquired and integrated a number of businesses
since 2010, including Maxtel in 2016, a local B2B internet provider in Slovenia, and Ikom in 2017, a
cable operator in Serbia. In addition, following the acquisition of M kabl in 2016, a cable operator in
Montenegro, we have further expanded our subscriber base in Montenegro.

Following the liberalization of the fixed-line telephone markets in Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia
in 2011 and 2012, respectively, we launched fixed-line telephony services in these two markets and,
leveraging our existing cable pay-TV and broadband internet subscriber base, became the secondlargest Serbian fixed-line telephone services provider in June 2013. We also launched our MVNO
services in Slovenia in late 2012 and became an MNO upon our acquisition of Tušmobil in 2015, which
allowed us to provide quad-play bundles (cable pay-TV, broadband internet, and fixed-line telephony
and mobile-telephony services) to our subscribers in Slovenia, in addition to stand-alone mobiletelephony services.

In July 2018, we acquired Nova TV d.d., which helped us further differentiate our distribution platform
and promote our pay-TV channels, creating a strong mainstream media platform for additional bolt on,
accretive acquisitions. In September 2018, we acquired Direct Media, a leading media buying agency
in Serbia, which included Direct Media’s operations in Serbia, Montenegro, North Macedonia and
Albania, as well as our terrestrial TV stations Pink BiH and Pink Montenegro, which have been
rebranded Nova BH and Nova M, respectively.

In March, 2020, we completed the acquisition of Tele2 Croatia, the third largest telecommunications
operator in Croatia based on mobile revenues as of September 30, 2020. Tele2 Croatia seeks to offer
the best value proposition in the Croatian mobile market, for example, through its offering of unlimited
mobile services. Now trading as Telemach Croatia, the acquisition has enabled us to accelerate our
growth and further diversify our operations.


-----

In July, 2020, we completed our acquisition of Vivacom, the market leading integrated
telecommunications operator in Bulgaria (based on revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020)
which offers both fixed and mobile telecommunications services, as well as broadcasting and satellite
services, with a market share of 30% in Bulgaria by revenue as of December 31, 2019, according to the
CRC. Expansion in Bulgaria increased our addressable market by approximately 35% in terms of
population, and the addition of Vivacom’s subscriber base more than doubled our existing subscriber
base. We believe that the acquisition of Vivacom provided us with greater scale and increased business
diversification, expanded our reach, cemented our leadership position as the industry leader in
Southeastern Europe and continued our growth.

In November 2020, we acquired a controlling interest in Forthnet S.A., the second-largest telecom
operator and Pay-TV provider in Greece. In June 2021, we renamed Forthnet S.A. as Nova. Nova
provides home entertainment and communications services to nearly 1.4 million RGUs. This marked
our entry into the Greek market and enabled us to further diversify and strengthen our position as an
industry leader in Southeastern Europe, accelerating growth. In May 2021, we acquired the remaining
shares in Nova following a mandatory tender offer and a squeeze-out procedure.

In January 2021, we acquired Bulgaria’s largest multi-platform media company, Nova Broadcasting
Group EOOD, providing a strong base for our content offering in Bulgaria. In July 2021, we signed an
agreement to acquire a majority interest in Croatian telecommunication operator Optima Telekom.
Optima Telekom offers a broad range of fixed broadband internet services to approximately 111
thousand subscribers and pay-TV services to approximately 56 thousand subscribers in Croatia. Upon
completion, the Optima Telekom Acquisition will allow us to further expand our presence in the
Croatian market enabling us to offer a full range of telecommunication services, including pay-TV,
through our existing infrastructure.

In April 2021, we acquired Bulgarian local broadband and television operators Net 1 EOOD, ComNet
Sofia EAD and Digital Cable Television EOOD and agreed to acquire Networx-Bulgaria EOOD. As of
the date of this offering memorandum, the acquisition of Networx-Bulgaria EOOD has not been
completed.

In August 2021, we agreed to acquire Wind Hellas, a leading integrated telecommunications operator
in Greece, furthering our penetration into the Greek market following our acquisition of Nova in 2020.
The Wind Hellas Acquisition was approved by the European Commission on December 21, 2021, and
we expect it to be consummated on or about January 12, 2022. Wind Hellas is one of the three integrated
communication providers in Greece with proprietary mobile and fixed-line networks. As of September
30, 2021, it offers mobile and fixed-line telecommunication, high-speed internet services and Pay-TV
services under a unified brand and on a national basis to over 4.1 million subscribers.

In August 2021, we also agreed to acquire an 80% ownership interest in Bulgarian energy company,
Tessa Energy EOOD. The transaction was completed on November 30, 2021. Tessa Energy EOOD will
invest in the Kremena Wind Park, which has 70MW capacity. With this investment, we will be
producing more energy than we currently consume in Bulgaria and we expect this will significantly
decrease our carbon footprint.

On November 9, 2021, we acquired a 33% stake in Marquee TV, a specialist streaming service for arts
and culture, for a consideration of £4.8 million.

On November 30, 2021, we signed an agreement to acquire Telnet OOD, a cable operator in Bulgaria.
Completion of the transaction is subject to customary approvals, which are currently pending.

**_Cable Pay-TV_**

We provide analog and digital cable pay-TV to approximately 1,609 thousand subscribers throughout
our network in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria and Montenegro as of September
30, 2021. In particular, our pay-TV subscribers were 213 thousand in Slovenia (61% of homes passed),
733 thousand in Serbia (63% of homes passed), 210 thousand in Bosnia (61% of homes passed), 32
thousand in Montenegro (32% of homes passed) and 419 thousand in Bulgaria (23% of homes passed),
in each case as of September 30, 2021. Following completion of the Optima Telekom Acquisition, we
will also offer IPTV services to approximately 56 thousand subscribers in Croatia. In line with our
business strategy, we leverage our extensive cable network and distinctive cable pay-TV content to
encourage our subscribers to purchase one of our bundles, which offer the convenience of being able to
receive television, broadband internet and telephony services from a single provider. As of September
30, 2021, approximately 65% of our cable pay-TV subscribers (including Vivacom) had purchased one
of our bundles.

We offer high-quality analog and digital pay-TV throughout our network. All of our pay-TV customers
receive our analog pay-TV service (“Basic TV”). Our Basic TV package has been standardized across
our network and offers customers access to dozens of TV channels in Serbia, Slovenia and Bosnia and
Herzegovina. In addition to Basic TV, we provide our customers with the option to subscribe to our
digital cable pay-TV services (currently offered under the EON brand), and we focus on migrating
analog subscribers to digital services and on continuing to take advantage of the cross and up selling
opportunities provided by an influx of potential new customers switching from analog to digital cable
pay-TV. Our digital cable pay-TV service provides our customers with access to up to 428 digital
channels depending on the particular market, including a wide variety of HD channels and radio
stations. We offer channel line ups across a variety of popular genres, such as sports, children’s
entertainment and movies. We believe our high-quality and broad channel and content offering allows
us to take a distinctive position in the market as compared to our competitors. In July 2020, in
cooperation with Bosnian operator Trion Tel, we started offering EON bundle packages in Republika
Srpska (the Serbian part of Bosnia and Herzegovina), where we previously had no cable presence,
through the GPON of Trion Tel. In October 2021, our Greek operator Nova introduced the EON
platform in Greece. EON pay-TV packages are offered in Greece together with superfast fiber internet
and voice services.


-----

In addition to our bundles, we also offer our subscribers digital add-on TV packages, each containing
premium SD and HD television channels, such as HBO, as well as bundled VoD options for subscribers
who have leased one of our digital receivers. Our digital cable pay-TV service also includes CatchUp
TV and VoD services. CatchUp TV provides subscribers with the ability to view a wide variety of
television programs from a group of popular channels at any time within seven days after the programs
originally aired. VoD provides subscribers with access to a library of over 26,000 movies and other
programming titles, either on a transactional basis or a monthly subscription contract.

In 2012, we launched our TV everywhere applications (currently offered under the EON brand) for
computer, tablet and mobile devices. Through these applications, we provide our existing cable payTV subscribers with access to our digital pay-TV content “on the go.” Our TV everywhere content is
also available to our mobile subscribers in Slovenia over our mobile network.

In Bulgaria, we offer IPTV services through Vivacom, including over 240 channels with a wide variety
of HD channels, as well as the corresponding equipment. Our IPTV service includes interactive features,
a “video on demand” library with more than 20,000 titles and an own movie channel called “VIVACOM
Arena.” We have content distribution agreements in place with a number of major content providers
and provides IPTV GO service to customers outside the area of coverage of its network in Bulgaria. We
also offer mobile TV under Vivacom’s TV GO brand. Customers can choose between a mix of channels
and sports content with DiemaXtra and MAX Sport Plus, or one or all of the VOD sections:
VIVACOM’s MAXI, HBO On Demand and Disney English. Our mobile subscribers in Bulgaria can
order any content available on TV GO directly on the recently updated application with a new UI/UX
design.

For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, our analog and digital cable pay-TV business segment
generated total revenues of €160.1 million and an average ARPU of €11.1. In particular, for the nine
months ended September 30 2021, our Slovenia Group segment’s cable pay-TV services generated
revenues of €36.8 million and an ARPU of €18.0; our Serbia Group segment’s cable pay-TV services
generated revenues of €72.6 million and an ARPU of €10.7; our Bosnia Group segment’s cable payTV services generated revenues of €20.6 million and an ARPU of €10.7; our Montenegro Group
segment’s cable pay-TV services generated revenues of €3.5 million and an ARPU of €12.0; and our
Bulgaria Group segment’s cable pay-TV services generated revenues of €26.7 million and an ARPU of
€8.0.

**_Direct to Home Pay-TV_**

Our DTH, or satellite, pay-TV service, known as Total TV, is targeted at households outside our cable
footprint across Southeastern Europe. Total TV provides subscribers with access to up to 165 channels
in Serbia, 155 channels in Slovenia, and 175 channels in Bosnia and Herzegovina, in each case including
a wide variety of channels also available HD format. In Bulgaria, we offer DTH pay-TV with over 165
channels, including HD channels, as well as multi-feed with over 200 additional channels. In Greece,
we offer DTH pay-TV under the Nova Sports, Nova Cinema and Nova Go brands, with 99 channels,
including more than half in HD. As we only actively market our DTH offering in those areas that are
outside our cable footprint, there is limited to no overlap with analog and digital cable Pay-TV offering.
Additionally, there is a low risk of cable pay-TV cannibalization, due to the fact that, for a similar price
as basic DTH pay-TV services, our basic cable pay-TV services offer a better value.

As with our analog and digital cable pay-TV offering, customers can choose from a range of DTH
packages across different price points. Additionally, we have entered into partnership agreements with
Telekom Slovenije in Slovenia and Telekom Srbija in Serbia pursuant to which we offer DTH pay-TV
content and re sell their respective ADSL internet services to customers outside of our cable footprint.

As of September 30, 2021, we provided our Total TV services to approximately 1,008 thousand
subscribers throughout Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Greece, North Macedonia


-----

and Montenegro. For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, our DTH Pay-TV business segment
generated revenues of €113.6 million and an ARPU of €12.4.

**_OTT Television_**

Our OTT content platforms: our regional OTT platform (EON) and our international OTT platform
(NetTV Plus) have enabled us to further expand our reach:

- _Regional OTT. We operate a regional OTT platform under the EON brand in Slovenia, Serbia_
and Bosnia and Herzegovina and Greece. This platform enables customers of our competitors
for broadband internet within our regions (but outside of our cable footprint) to access our
distinctive digital content via the internet. Unlike our DTH pay-TV platform, which aims to
deliver content to subscribers in rural areas without cable infrastructure, our regional OTT
platform delivers pay-TV services to customers in metropolitan areas. By expanding our reach
beyond the traditional cable footprint using a regional OTT platform, we are able to increase
the number of subscribers to our pay-TV content. Please see “—Innovation—EON.”

- _International OTT. Our NetTV Plus platform, which we launched in 2013, provides up to 662_
channels, depending on particular market, including a wide variety of channels in HD and radio
channels, of which more than 250 local language TV channels showing ethnic content,
including all national free-to-air channel offering, to the Slovenian, Croatian, Bosnian, Serbian,
North Macedonian, Greek and Bulgarian diaspora (estimated at over 8 million people) around
the world through the internet. As of September 30, 2021, we had 107 thousand NetTV Plus
subscribers, indicating significant future growth opportunities, supported by the global
proliferation of high-speed internet access, which makes OTT one of the most viable platforms
to access ethnic content. Subscribers can access our NetTV Plus content through their TVs
using a set-top box connected to the internet, “Smart TVs” that have built in internet
functionality or by streaming content via internet enabled tablets, mobile devices and personal
computers. By expanding our geographic reach outside our region to customers in affluent
countries in Western Europe and North America, we are positioned to charge prices that are
higher than the prices we are able to charge for our pay-TV services in our other markets in
Southeastern Europe.

**_Broadband Internet_**

We offer broadband internet in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Montenegro and
Greece. Beginning in 2009, we upgraded our network to EuroDOCSIS 3.0, and our network is fully
EuroDOCSIS 3.0 enabled. Our network offers our customers up to 1.6 Gbps download speeds. We
believe that EuroDOCSIS 3.0 is superior to DSL and on par with the FttH services offered by our
competitors. We currently provide internet download speeds that we believe compare favorably to the
national averages with our average recorded speeds being faster than that of the respective local
incumbent by a factor of 2.0x in Slovenia, 1.6x in Serbia and 2.9x in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as of
September 30, 2021. In Bulgaria, we provide an array of fixed broadband services over ADSL, VDSL
and FTTx connections.

As our broadband internet operations provide us with very attractive margins due to little additional
cost, we leverage our attractive pay-TV offering to sell broadband internet services to existing pay-TV
customers. As a result, we do not sell our broadband internet services on a stand-alone basis and
customers wishing to receive our broadband internet services must, at a minimum, subscribe to our
analog Basic TV package. As of September 30, 2021, we provided our broadband internet service to
approximately 1.5 million subscribers across our Slovenia Group, Serbia Group, Bosnia Group,
Bulgaria Group and Montenegro Group segments. For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, our
broadband internet business generated revenues of €229.0 million and an ARPU of €9.5.

Within Slovenia, in a large portion of our cable footprint, our competitors offer DSL services and not
fiber, enabling us to provide the fastest broadband speed available within those areas. Our total


-----

broadband market share in Slovenia was 31%, our fixed broadband penetration was 54% and 96% of
our customers received broadband speeds greater than 70 Mbps, in each case as of December 31, 2020.

In Serbia, our total broadband market share was 32%, our fixed broadband penetration was 47% and
86% of our customers received broadband speeds greater than 50 Mbps, in each case as of December
31, 2020.

In Bosnia and Herzegovina, our total broadband market share was 22%, our fixed broadband penetration
in Bosnia and Herzegovina was 49% and 85% of our customers received broadband speeds higher than
30 Mbps, in each case as of December 31, 2020. While Bosnia and Herzegovina is generally not yet
making use of high-speed broadband higher than or equal to 30 Mbps, we believe Bosnia and
Herzegovina displays clear trends of acceleration.

In Bulgaria, we offer fixed broadband services over ADSL, VDSL and FTTx connections to both
residential and business customers as well as other data services such as the sale of CPEs, VPN and
MAN services and associated complex solutions. As of December 31, 2020, our total broadband market
share in Bulgaria was 25%.

In addition, we offer out-of-footprint internet services (broadband internet services provided through a
third-party network) across Greece to approximately 529 thousand subscribers through Nova as of
September 30, 2021. Following completion of the Optima Telekom Acquisition, we will offer
broadband internet services to approximately 111 thousand subscribers in Croatia.

**_Fixed-line Telephony_**

We offer telephony services using VoIP, which allows our subscribers to make traditional fixed-line
telephone calls using a standard telephone handset. We offer fixed-line telephony services in Serbia,
Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria and Montenegro. We intend to leverage on our existing
customer base and our extensive network and high-quality pay-TV content to cross-sell telephony
products and bundled products to new and existing customers. Accordingly, other than in Bulgaria, our
fixed-line telephony services are only available to our existing cable pay-TV customers. We also offer
out-of-footprint telephony services (telephony provided through a third-party network) across Greece.
The total fixed-line telephony Greek market in 2020 was estimated at 4,852 thousand subscribers
(compared to 534 thousand out-of-footprint subscribers for Nova as of September 30, 2021), which we
believe represents significant growth potential for us.

Our “Basic Package” in Serbia, Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro offers free calls
within the Group network and only an analog touchtone phone is required to use our service. In addition
to our Basic Package, we offer our subscribers various other packages, which include free calls to
customers of other regional fixed-line telephony providers. Despite the relatively recent launch of our
fixed-line telephony operations in Serbia, we believe it is the second-largest provider of fixed-line
telephony services in Serbia behind the incumbent Telekom Srbija. We are the largest provider of fixedline telephony operations in Bulgaria through Vivacom.

As of September 30, 2021, we provided our fixed-line telephony services to 1,252 thousand subscribers,
of which 193 thousand in Slovenia, 450 thousand in Serbia, 105 thousand in Bosnia and Herzegovina
and 487 thousand in Bulgaria. For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, our fixed-line telephony
services generated revenues of €84.2 million and an ARPU of €4.2.

Our mobile network provides coverage to almost all of Slovenia’s population through our extensive
2G/ 3G/4G and as of June 2021 5G networks. Licenses for use of spectrum for 2G are valid through
2031, while spectrum for 3G is valid through 2021 (5 MHz on the 2100 band), 2023 (another 5 MHz
on the 2100 band) and 2031 (5 MHz on the 900 band). In 2016, we acquired additional spectrum in the
1800 MHz and 2100 MHz bands, which allowed us to expand our 3G and 4G networks. Use of
frequencies in the LTE network currently includes 2x10 MHz in the 800 MHz spectrum band and 2x10
MHz in 1800 MHz spectrum band (which is the key spectrum band used for LTE services). These
licenses are valid through 2029 (800 MHz) and 2031 (1800 MHz). We are capable of providing 4G
(LTE) and 4G+ (LTE-A) coverage to 99 % and 98%, respectively, of the Slovenian population. In
addition, we have successfully tested and are rolling out next generation 5G networks across our mobiletelephony footprint. In April 2021, we secured 15-year spectrum licenses in Slovenia for 5G
frequencies, and commenced deployment and commercial launch of 5G 3600 MHz in Slovenia in June
2021.

As of September 30, 2021, we had 612 thousand subscribers for our post-paid and pre-paid mobile
services in Slovenia. During each month of the first nine months of 2021, we achieved 32% of gross
additions in the mobile market, as compared to 32% during each month of 2020 and 31% during each
month of 2019. Our principal focus is post-paid subscribers, who generate significantly higher ARPU


-----

and generally have lower churn rates than pre-paid subscribers, and as of September 30, 2021, contract
subscribers accounted for 57% of our subscriber base.

For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, our mobile-telephony services in Slovenia generated
revenues of €63.9 million and an ARPU of €10.9.

_Croatia Group segment_

We provide mobile-telephony services in Croatia through Telemach Croatia, the third largest
telecommunications operator in Croatia based on mobile revenues as of December 31, 2020, after

value proposition in the Croatian mobile market, for example through its offering of unlimited mobile
services.

We have an extensive 2G/3G/4G mobile network covering all major cities and important roads in
Croatia. In February and March 2019, we acquired 2100 MHz and 2600 MHz frequencies, enhancing
spectrum capacity. In July 2021, we secured 15-year spectrum licenses in Croatia for 5G frequencies,
and commenced deployment and commercial launch of our 5G C-Band in September 2021.

As of September 30, 2021, we offered mobile-telephony services to approximately 1 million subscribers
in Croatia. For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, our mobile-telephony services in Croatia
generated revenues of €110.0 million and an ARPU of €7.4.

_Bulgaria Group segment_

In Bulgaria, we are among the market leaders in offering mobile services. We offer mobile voice and
data services and products over GSM/GPRS/EDGE and UMTS/HSPA+/LTE networks, on either a
post-paid or pre-paid basis, through multiple volume based and flat rate offerings, each with multiple
tariff options, and we believe that Vivacom’s mobile post-paid offerings are some of the most

products, including the sale of mobile handsets and accessories. Such services include unlimited mobile
data, roaming voice and mobile data packages (within the European Union or within neighboring

commercial launch of our 5G network in Bulgaria, and to that end in May 2021, we secured a 20-year
license for 100 MHz spectrum frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band.

For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, our Bulgaria segment’s mobile operations generated
revenues of €200.4 million. As of September 30, 2021, we had approximately 3.0 million mobile
subscribers in Bulgaria, of which approximately 86% were post-paid subscribers and approximately
14% were pre-paid subscribers. For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, blended mobile ARPU
was €7.4.

_Owned Content Business_

Through our owned-content business we directly own many of the region’s popular pay-TV channels,

channel that we improved through collaborations with notable studios in the United States; Fortuna
eSports, which broadcasts eSports events that we produce and organize; N1, an independent 24/7

sustainable leadership position of our distribution platform. While a significant part of our content

The variety that we offer in our content business allows us to tailor our approach for each individual
country and market in which we operate. We plan to continue to review our content offering and will
continue to develop our own distinctive content. We continue to view content differentiation as the
cornerstone of our strategy and to drive the attractiveness of our content offerings relative to those of
our competitors.

_Third-party Content_

In addition to our owned content offerings, our pay-TV distribution platforms typically license the rights
for the distribution of our channels, as well as third-party owned channels, typically for a period of three
to five years.

As the prominent pan-regional operator, we have been able to negotiate contracts with third-party
providers that we believe are beneficial. For example, we have been able to lock in flat-rate contracts
for content that provide for terms spanning multiple years, which benefits our profit margins as our
number of subscribers increases because we are able to retain the benefits of increases in our subscriber
base, and thereby increase our margins. We also pay royalties based on our subscribers’ usage of our
VoD content. We generally pay such license fees on a “per subscriber” basis. For on-demand content
purchased by subscribers (transactional VoD), we generally pay a revenue share of the retail price. For
packaged on-demand content, we pay on a “per- subscriber” basis (subscription VoD), often subject to
fixed minimum guarantees. If necessary, we also license third-party copyrights through various
collective rights associations. We generally seek to negotiate fixed-fee contracts and attempt to move
away from per- subscriber agreements. We expect that our content costs (above the minimum amounts)
will generally increase in line with increased revenues from digital pay-TV and on-demand content and
continued investment in high-quality content to differentiate our platform from our competitors. We
negotiate our contracts for content and other third-party rights on a Group-wide basis, so that we are
able to maximize the benefits of our scale and best practices across the Group, and we have historically
been successful at renewing these contracts on comparable terms. We plan to acquire additional
broadcasting rights in the future to further enhance our content offering.

In addition to licencing content offerings, we also seek to enter into strategic partnerships with, or make
strategic investment in, other media companies to support the enhancement of the varieties of content
proposition in the market. For example, on November 9, 2021, we acquired a 33% stake in Marquee
TV, a specialist streaming service for arts and culture, in an effort to better serve the vertical markets.

**_Wi Fi_**

Since 2011, we have been expanding our Wi Fi hotspot service in Serbia, Slovenia, and Bosnia and
Herzegovina, and the service is currently offered under our UNIFI brand. In April 2017, we updated
our mobile packages, with more data, more calls and more text messaging, and introduced our UNIFI
Travel Wi Fi roaming application, providing access to more than 70 million Wi Fi hotspots in 120
countries around the world. To increase our brand recognition, all products include free on net calls
with unlimited off net national calls in medium and high end packages, and with the introduction of
new EU roaming regulations which took effect on June 15, 2017, customers can now utilize their text
message and voice minute allotments across the EU with no roaming charges. We intend to utilize
UNIFI to complement our bundled offering and reduce customer churn as well as to incentivize the use
of our products by potentially offering UNIFI free to only our subscribers. We believe this service offers
further monetization potential from users that are not our customers.

**_Multi-Play Services_**

One of our primary areas of focus is to provide bundled services, which consist of a package of two or
more of the following services: pay-TV, broadband internet services, fixed-line telephony and mobiletelephony. This enables our customers to subscribe to these services in a convenient “one stop shop”
manner at attractive prices that are lower when bundled than the sum of the stand-alone services of
similar value. We believe that the several bundled options we have introduced allow our customers to

247


-----

tailor their packages according to their requirements and offer them greater value for money compared
to similar services offered by our competitors. As of September 30, 2021, approximately 65% of our
cable customers subscribed to our multi-play packages. Our multi-play packages have allowed us to
increase our total RGUs for cable-based services to approximately 11.3 million RGUs as of September
30, 2021.

Our straightforward and unified triple-play offering, which includes pay television, broadband internet
services and fixed-line telephony, accounts for a significant percentage of our total new sales,
comprising 81% of our gross additions in Slovenia, 53% of our gross additions in Serbia, and 20% of
our gross additions in Bosnia and Herzegovina, in each case for the nine months ended September 30,
2021. Our best-selling triple-play packages (each based on the number of triple-play gross additions in
the first three months of 2021) are: EON Light in Slovenia, EON Full in Serbia and EON Light in
Bosnia and Herzegovina. We have upgraded our triple-play offering consistently for both new and
existing customers, which has allowed us to raise prices over time.

**_E-commerce_**

In July 2020, we leveraged our position in both the broadband and pay-TV markets to launch Shoppster,
our regional e-commerce online-shopping platform, which offers more than 20 popular product
categories, including electronics, home and gardening, tools, fashion, items for children and kitchen
appliances. Shoppster is available as an integrated online and TV shopping platform in Serbia and
Slovenia. In Serbia, Shoppster operates as a marketplace using the dropshipping operating model,
whereby it does not stock the products it sells. In Slovenia, Shoppster operates as a retailer as a result
of an acquisition that we have completed and stores the products it sells in a leased warehouse. Products
sold though Shoppster are distributed by third-party delivery couriers in both Serbia and Slovenia.
Shoppster is a unique offering which combines the convenience of online-shopping with the audience
engagement of television. Products are presented and available for sale on the Shoppster TV channel,
which are devoted to home-shopping. Popular TV personalities from Southeastern Europe present
offers and products from the many companies that have joined Shoppster. We intend for Shoppster to
deliver the simple, reliable and secure e-shopping experience that modern consumers expect.

**Business Product Offerings**

We utilize our existing fixed-line network in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro
to offer a range of business products including virtual private networks, Wi Fi hotspots, managed
services and network capacity leases to telecommunications operators, financial institutions, public
service customers and multinational companies. We are the first CISCO certified partner for B2B
services in the region, and we aim to continually improve the service portfolio of our business products
by providing innovative and high-quality solutions along with dedicated customer care. We offer tailor
made solutions for modern businesses across various industry segments, as well as to carrier clients.

One of our key customers in the region is Telekom Austria. We provide network connection services
for Telekom Austria’s mobile phone towers as well as ‘last mile’ connection services for Telekom
Austria’s B2B clients. Other key international partners include Romtelecom, Tele2, Telia Company,
Pantel Technologies, Inteliquent, Interoute, Level 3 and PCCW.

We are also a leading provider of a full suite of telecommunications solutions for the corporate segment
in Bulgaria, with a portfolio of services suitable for all business sizes. All business mobile plans include
national and international minutes, mobile data and a range of other features that support companies in
running their businesses. We offer both customized services for larger customers and more standardized
products, such as all-inclusive tariff plans that have a set amount of minutes (national and international)
and data for a fixed monthly fee, for small and medium size companies.


-----

**Subscribers**

We sell our TV, broadband internet and fixed-line and mobile-telephony services, either on an
individual service subscription basis or on a bundled basis, to residential customers and business
customers. Our basic pay-TV subscription serves as a basis for cross-selling and up selling and, with
the exception of subscribers in Slovenia who generally prefer to subscribe only to our mobile-telephony
service, every subscriber needs at least a subscription for our basic pay-TV package to have access to
our other services.

Consumer subscriptions account for most of our revenues. Within the consumer market, we market our
services directly to subscribers in single dwelling units and multi-dwelling units, such as apartment
buildings. We provide our services pursuant to standard form fixed contracts lasting for 12 or 24
months. Our business subscribers typically purchase our broadband internet and voice and other data
services, and we generally target small to mid-size businesses in metropolitan regions. Business
subscriber contracts usually extend over a period of 24 months and cannot be prematurely cancelled
free of charge. We believe that we have a loyal customer base, which is the result of low churn rates
due to our high-quality content, extensive network coverage and high-quality customer service.

Additionally, as our network covers the most affluent regions in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and
Herzegovina, Montenegro, Croatia, Bulgaria and Greece, our business benefits from low rates of
services termination due to customers’ inability to pay.

**Innovation**

United.Cloud is our technology innovation and software development center which we established in
2016 and has offices in Serbia and Slovenia. The centralization of our research and development team
within United.Cloud provides a significant improvement in time to market for our quality and
innovative products, with a high degree of customization and flexibility to ensure new product launches
are in line with our corporate strategy. We can create unified multi-service solutions to apply across all
our markets, such as EON, with the ability to enter new markets quickly due to technological autonomy
without a need to rely on outside developers, and our customers benefit from an improved user
experience across our products. We regularly introduce new products and continue to develop our
existing technology. Starting with D3 GO as a multiscreen option included in packages, we have added
additional features such as UNIFON, UNIFI and UNIFI Travel.

**_EON_**

EON is our next generation video delivery platform and an internally developed content management
and distribution system, which allows customers to watch their favorite channels on a range of devices,
including set-top boxes smartphones, tablets, laptops, and Smart TVs, with the ability to seamlessly
“hand off” and resume watching from one device to the next. EON is the first platform in the region to
allow viewers to watch TV through an application on a Smart TV. In establishing EON, which
developed out of the prior D3 platform, we have prioritized user customization, through the introduction
of user inputs such as reminders, favorites and search functions. The home screen includes editorial
content within a modern and intuitive user interface. The VoD component is extensive, with a CatchUp
feature allowing viewers to access content broadcasted within the previous seven days, totaling over 15
thousand hours of content available at any given time. EON gives users access to over 502 TV channels,
163 radio channels, and more than 25,000 VoD assets. We have also ensured that EON utilizes the latest
media encryption technology in order to protect against digital piracy. We have an additional stream of
game changing updates to be introduced to EON over the next two years, including cloud DVR,
“download to go” and improved connectivity with third-party devices and services. Our partnership
with Google will help us release the 4K Ultra HD set-top box, which will fully integrate Google
platforms such as YouTube and Google Play Store.

**_Digital Platform_**

Our digital platform provides a sustainable channel to future proof our platforms and to address evolving
customer habits around access to media, digital content and advertising consumption.

_Telecommunications_


-----

Our digital platform is an important element of our user experience, and we have recently focused on
innovations in our self-help platform, web portals and e-commerce. Our self-help platform allows users
to personalize their dashboards and access offers, pay their bills and receive assistance. We also utilize
our web portals as a central hub for all marketing activity and offer access to support services and the
ability to order products online.

_Media_

We have grown our media content offerings on our digital platform. Our most successful digital media
offerings are regional news and sport portals N1 and Sport Klub, as well as DNEVNIK.hr in Croatia
and Nova.rs in Serbia. N1 is a fully independent, stand-alone platform with more than 50 million users
as of September 30, 2021. Our regional sports news platform, Sport Klub, is split across three separate
web portals and a dedicated mobile application for iOS and Android, and had over 12 million web users
as of September 30, 2021. Launched in February 2020, Nova.rs in few months became one of the most
influential portals in Serbia with 35 million users as of September 30, 2021. Our news portal Danas has
increased the number of real users to 19 million and grew from the 13th to the 11th position among web
portals in Serbia according to Gemius ratings. In Croatia, our portal DNEVNIK.hr, with approximately
43 million users monthly, as of September 30, 2021, is the most visited web portal in Croatia, according
to Gemius ratings. Our Bulgarian operation NetInfo has reach 81% of total population, with nova.bg as
the most visited web portal in the country according to Gemius ratings.

**Customer Services**

Along with content differentiation, customer service is a key pillar of our offering, and we believe that
we offer subscribers high-quality customer service that is in line with Western European standards. Our
customer service operations are responsible for all customer care activities, including technical support
as well as handling queries and complaints from our customers. We operate dedicated customer contact
centers in Ljubljana, Belgrade, Sarajevo, Podgorica, Sofia and Pleven. As of September 30, 2021, our
customer service team employed approximately 847 employees (798 full-time equivalent). In Bulgaria,
we provide an additional service to high-value business customers who require proactive technical
support. In addition to call center services, customers also have at their disposal a variety of self-service
channels, such as an interactive voice response system, Unstructured Supplementary Service Data on
Vivacom’s mobile network and the My Vivacom application, which was launched in 2018, and provides
customers with 24/7 access to information about their services, customer data and current consumption,
and notifications as to billing information.

All customer service agents are regularly trained in soft skills and educated on new product offerings
and advertising campaigns. As is common in Western Europe, we constantly measure our team’s
response times and offer our subscribers the option to provide feedback on our service immediately
following the call. Additionally, we have a customer service team focusing on business retention, which
reaches out to existing subscribers prior to the expiration of such subscribers’ service contracts to extend
the service contract and advertise our products through various initiatives, including, for example,
Vivacom’s provision of mobile handset and tablet subsidies in order to grow its mobile subscriber base
and complimentary installations for certain business customers. We also have a specialized team for
sales and customer care in relation to our business services.

We believe our customer service representatives are trained in accordance with Western European
customer service standards, and we receive consistently high scores in our subscriber satisfaction
surveys.

**Marketing and Sales**

We work to provide a consistent image as a provider of “best in class” services and customer experience
and high-quality subscriber experience in the key areas that subscribers value. Our marketing, sales and
customer care department is responsible for designing and promoting new products and services to
customers, as well as building a high-quality customer experience throughout the entire “life cycle” of

a customer relationship. We are able to leverage our owned content channels to cross promote our other
products and services to our customers, because we can advertise those other products and services on
our channels. We also market and sell our products using a broad range of sales outlets, including
through our leased retail stores which are located in attractive parts of town in our key regions and
markets, including in Ljubljana, Belgrade, Sarajevo and Sofia, third-party stores, telesales and our

we sell services and products through direct channels, such as Vivacom owned stores and indirect

To strengthen our brand recognition, we have entered into a number of sponsorship and partnership

well-known mobile handset brands, and in 2020, it launched its official partnership with Apple.
Additionally, we make donations to social institutions, such as youth organizations, across the region.

**Network**

We operate an advanced proprietary HFC network which is fully bi-directional and EuroDOCSIS 3.0
enabled, covering all of our homes passed in Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro, and
approximately 99% of homes passed in Slovenia as of September 30, 2021. We also operate the largest
fiber network in the region, extending for approximately 50,000 kilometers across metropolitan areas
in Southern Europe. As of September 30, 2021, our cable network covers approximately 1.8 million
homes passed, and 94% of our core network was DOCSIS 3.1 ready.

We also employ a variety of network technologies to deliver products and services to our customers,
which include, among others, GPON technologies on 29% of our footprint, XGS 10/10 Gbps speed
FttH access network that is set to be introduced throughout the Group in 2021, as well as market leading
broadband speed through our network, of which approximately 70% is gigabit-capable. In addition, we
are the first in the region to offer OTT services to customers, which began in 2013.

_Cable and Satellite_

Cable

We provide our pay-TV, broadband internet infrastructure access and fixed-line telephony services
through our extensive cable network which we believe is one of the most technologically advanced
networks in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. Our cable network covers approximately 3.8 million
homes passed as of September 30, 2021 and generally covers the most affluent areas in our key markets.
Specifically, as of September 30, 2021, our network passed approximately 351 thousand homes, or
approximately 47% of all households, in Slovenia, 1,156 thousand homes, or approximately 48% of all
households, in Serbia, 348 thousand homes, or approximately 30% of all households, in Bosnia and
Herzegovina, 101 thousand homes, or approximately 51% of all households, in Montenegro, 1,856
thousand homes (939 thousand FTTx homes and 505 thousand VDSL homes), or approximately 62%
of all households, in Bulgaria and 3,432 thousand homes (through xDSL), or approximately 78% of all
households, in Greece.

Our network in Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia Herzegovina generally offers better capacity, speed and
quality advantages compared to copper-based DSL networks. In particular, an HFC cable network
offers larger bandwidth than ordinary copper cable and, unlike the latter, it is not significantly affected
by attenuation (a reduction in the strength of the signal) or distortion (reduction in quality of the signal)
when the signal is carried over a long distance. We also offer significantly more bandwidth capacity
than the average broadband customer uses. While broadband data consumption has increased across


-----

Slovenia, Serbia, and Bosnia and Herzegovina, installed capacity is higher than the average used
capacity by a significant margin, as shown in the charts below.

Our HFC network is fully bi-directional in Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina and approximately 99%
of HFC homes passed in Slovenia are bi-directional as of September 30, 2021. Our bi-directional
network enables us to deliver broadband internet, fixed-line telephony, and other interactive services
such as VoD, to our customers throughout our cable network, in addition to regular digital and analog
television services.

Our cable network is EuroDOCSIS 3.0 enabled, covering our cable broadband internet RGUs in
Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, which allows us to offer theoretical maximum speed
levels of up to 1,600 Mbps with 32 allocated frequency channels. In Montenegro, we continue to
upgrade the network to Group standards following our acquisitions. We believe we offer one of the
highest available speeds in our cable footprint, ranging between 100-1,000 Mbps. We also have industry
leading node density. A lower node density mitigates the risk of network congestion and related
reductions in quality of service.

As of September 30, 2021, our HFC network has homes passed per fiber optics node ratios of
approximately 242:1 in Slovenia, approximately 206:1 in Serbia, approximately 219:1 in Bosnia and
Herzegovina, and approximately 126:1 in Montenegro, which we believe is unrivalled in Southeastern
Europe and compares favorably to Central and Eastern European cable benchmarks. This means our
fiber optic nodes typically only extend a very short distance from subscribers’ homes and offices, with
only the last few hundred meters connected through coaxial cables. This allows us to provide high
broadband internet access speeds and advanced services to subscribers.

In Bulgaria, our network provides for a fully digitalized fixed-telephony services and ADSL, VDSL
and fiber connections that offer commercially available speeds of up to 20 Mbps, 50 Mbps and 1,000
Mbps, respectively. Vivacom began its FTTx roll out in 2011 in Sofia and Varna and has since achieved
significant progress from 402 thousand fiber homes passed in 2012 to 1,318 thousand fiber homes
passed with a 29% take-up rate as of September 30, 2021. We believe that our fixed-line network is the
largest in Bulgaria. We also have a fully owned fiber backbone network that includes a Dense
Wavelength Division Multiplexing fiber network that allows for easy capacity extension and is able to
route all backbone traffic via this infrastructure. We maintain a disciplined approach to expanding our
fiber network in carefully selected areas in Bulgaria and adhering to stringent project acceptance
criteria. We believe Vivacom’s low build out costs are attributable to its ownership of the telecom ducts
and the low-cost of labor in Bulgaria, allowing for an attractive return on investments in fiber.


-----

In Greece, we operate and maintain a fiber optic network extending 5,996 kilometers and provide
services based mainly on xDSL technologies. We hold a regulated local loop unbundling agreement
with the incumbent telecommunications provider. As of September 30, 2021, we were able to serve
78.1% (92.6% in NGA eligible fixed lines) of the Greek population through Nova’s co-locations in
local exchanges and interconnections with wholesale providers.

Overall, we operate one of the most extensive backbone networks across the region with an international
backbone consisting of approximately 23,976 kilometers (as of September 30, 2021) owned and leased
dense wavelength division multiplexing fiber links that extend across Southeastern Europe with
international optical interconnections to Vienna, Frankfurt, Amsterdam and London. Such extensive
fiber rich backbone not only supports our HFC cable network but also makes us a partner of choice for
regional telecoms and other business customers. We rent ducts and poles from third-parties as a part of
our network, except in Bulgaria.

FttH is our technology of choice for greenfield expansion and new buildings in adjacent areas. As of
September 30, 2021, we passed 1,093 thousand homes with FttH and had 243 thousand active users
across Serbia, Slovenia, Bulgaria, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro. In addition to FttH
greenfield expansion, during the third quarter of 2018, we introduced Gigabit speeds in areas where
digitalization of analog TV signals was completed.

Satellite Services

We complement our cable network with DTH and mobile offerings. We contract for satellite services
with EUTELSAT, which transmits our satellite programming over their satellite networks to our
customers. Data streams are sent to satellites that transmit the signal to local satellite receivers. Our
transponder allotment agreements with EUTELSAT are valid until December 31, 2024. Pursuant to a
services agreement entered into with EUTELSAT in December 2014, we replaced all our subscriber
reception boxes in Serbia in order to permit the reception of HD and MPEG 4 transmissions to our
subscribers via the transponders currently allocated to SBB Serbia on the EUTELSAT 16A satellite.
Furthermore, EUTELSAT has also agreed to provide us with certain discounts as well as a certain
amount of free additional satellite capacity from the MPEG 4 launch date until 2024.

We also provide satellite services in Bulgaria, including uplink and downlink of radio and TV channels,
playout solutions, fixed and mobile VSAT data connectivity, collocation of satellite equipment and
other services. In addition to being a third-party teleport of EUTELSAT, in Bulgaria we also partner
with Intelsat, SES, Gazprom, Azercosmos and Hellas Sat. Our satellite services offering includes video
uplink services on various satellites, Playout Solution as a Service (PSS), a cloud based service
including playout hardware located at Vivacom’s technical facilities and an IP based tool for content
management, VSAT data links. All of this ensures higher data rates, optimized cost for the customer,
better flexibility and reliability, and are mainly targeted at the maritime business, as well as fixed VSAT
links for corporate networks, in rural areas and as a backup solution and satellite collocation services.

In Bulgaria we also own and operate one of the biggest and most modern facilities for satellite
communications in the region—Plana Teleport, which is able to deliver transmission and connectivity
even to very remote points, including orbital positions in Europe, Africa, Middle East and Asia. Since
2014, Plana Teleport is a member of the World Teleport Association and in August 2021 achieved full
Tier 4 certification, making it among the most modern facilities of its kind. In addition, we operate a
microwave IP based network connecting main sites in Bulgaria. We use a microwave network for
delivery of DTT signal and Bulgarian national radio channels to the main TV towers. The microwave
network is monitored and controlled 24/7 by the National Operations Center.

_Mobile_

In Slovenia, our mobile network is currently fully IP enabled, with single radio access network
technology (“SRAN”) providing full services on 2G, 3G and 4G networks. We currently provide 4G


-----

(LTE) and 4G+ (LTE-A) coverage to approximately 99% and 98%, respectively, of the Slovenian
population. In 2020, we added 54 additional mobile sites to our footprint. In 2021, we expect to launch
a total of 55 new sites in Slovenia, which we expect will lead to 4G (LTE) and 4G+ (LTE-A) coverage
for approximately 99% of the Slovenian population. The technology upgrades and new sites are
expected to increase our coverage in Slovenia, amplify our network capacity and enhance customer
experience. In April 2021, we secured 15-year spectrum licenses in Slovenia for 5G frequency bands
and commenced commercial deployment of 5G in Slovenia in June 2021.

Having successfully launched our 4G service, we also cover all major cities and important roads in
Croatia. In addition, we have acquired 2100MHz and 2600MHz frequencies to support spectrum
capacity. In July 2021, we secured 15-year spectrum licenses in Croatia for 5G frequencies, and
commenced deployment and commercial launch of our 5G C-Band in September 2021.

In Bulgaria, we offer mobile services through Vivacom’s integrated 2G, 3G and 4G/LTE network. In
2018, Vivacom launched a 4G voice service (Voice over LTE) and Wi Fi calling services, which enable
its customers to benefit from high definition voice services. On September 21, 2020, we announced the
commercial launch of our 5G network in Bulgaria, and to that end in May 2021, we secured a 20-year
license for 100 MHz spectrum frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band. To scale the development of our 5G
network quickly, we use dynamic spectrum sharing on our existing 4G network, enabling us to provide
5G coverage to all 27 district cities in Bulgaria. Other than its 5G network, Vivacom’s network is based
on: GSM/EDGE (2G technologies), UMTS/HSPA+ (3G technologies) and LTE/LTE-Advanced
(4G/4.5G technologies).

As of September 30, 2021, our GSM mobile network, our UMTS mobile network and our LTE network
each covered approximately 100% of the Bulgarian population. Vivacom’s licenses allow it to use
2x11.2 MHz on the 900 MHz spectrum band, 2x15MHz on the 1800 MHz spectrum band and 2x15MHz
on the 2100 MHz spectrum band.

As of September 30, 2021, our mobile network in Bulgaria is supported by a portfolio of 3,675 tower
sites across Bulgaria, of which 42% have fiber backhauling. As of the same date, we covered over 681
networks by roaming agreements with other Bulgarian and international operators around the world.

We have approximately 4,700 mobile towers in Bulgaria, Slovenia and Croatia, which we estimate have
collectively impacted Run-Rate Last Two-Quarter Annualized Adjusted EBITDAaL for September 30,
2021, by approximately €55-60 million.

Mobile Network Evolution

During 2021, we entered into two global framework agreements for the provision of equipment and
services for our mobile networks in Bulgaria, Croatia and Slovenia that are material to the evolution
and upkeep of our mobile networks, including commercial implementation of next generation 5G
capabilities.

- _Mobile Radio Network Equipment Agreement_

We entered into a global frame agreement with Huawei International Co. Limited (“Huawei”) for the
supply of radio network equipment for our mobile networks, which was effective as of April 16, 2021.
The duration of the contract is five years, subject to renewal and extension. Pursuant to the terms of the
contract, we agreed to purchase, and with the assistance of Huawei install and operate certain radio
equipment, receive spare parts, reuse certain legacy equipment and use or license certain other items
from Huawei upon certain agreed terms and subject to certain conditions. Entry into this global frame
agreement is a continuation of our existing work with Huawei, which we believe we have at all times
conducted in compliance with relevant laws and regulations.

- _Mobile Core Network Elements Agreement_


-----

As part of a strategy to consolidate our core network vendors, we also entered into a global frame
agreement with Nokia Solutions and Networks Oy as of June 17, 2021, for the supply, installation,
commissioning, migration, support and network evolution of mobile core network elements for our
mobile networks. The contract has a duration of five years, subject to renewal and extension. The
contract sets out the terms and conditions pursuant to which the agreed equipment and services will be
supplied during duration of the contract.

_Network Maintenance_

We introduced a new preventative maintenance platform in 2016 to monitor our network by
categorizing and ranking the nodes across our network and providing guidance about which system
maintenance works are most needed, which has improved both our network quality and customer
satisfaction experience. Furthermore, our internal maintenance regime is also stricter than industry
standards.

Vivacom made significant investments into its network over the last few years, and we plan to continue
the build out of its fiber network in carefully selected areas based on specific return on investment
criteria. We also intend to invest further in Vivacom’s fixed network, including MPLS and Metro
networks, and the fixed access network, as well as the mobile core and access networks supported by
new spectrum frequencies and microwave licenses for transmission.
