**Information Technology**

We operate a modern information technology (“IT”) infrastructure in order to support our business. Our
IT systems are generally managed in house, and also receive external support from manufacturers and
suppliers. Our IT system consists of the following key segments: our operations support system
(“OSS”), which supports our back office activities, including the operation of our network and provision
and maintenance of our customer service; our business support system (“BSS”), which supports our
customer facing activities such as billing, order management and our call center; and our mediation and
provisioning system which monitors and facilitates subscribers’ network access rights and privileges to
ensure the security of our resources and user privacy.

In early 2017, Telemach Slovenia implemented SAP platforms, joining SBB Serbia and Telemach BH
which had already implemented SAP platforms, and thus further facilitating integration. In 2021 the
same platform was implemented in Telemach Croatia and we are currently working on the roll-out for
Nova Greece. Our OSS stack is managed and developed internally, based on a standardized platform.

In Bulgaria, we have a well-developed and growing IT environment with a focus on automation and
digital presence. Vivacom’s IT systems provide high levels of automation for the majority of the
business in both BSS and OSS and are the main pillar in the digitalization process. The OSS stack
architecture is built to enable an end-to-end service fulfillment process, working together with the BSS
stack. It supports automated provisioning and assurance processes for mass services including B2C
mobile voice and data, fixed voice and data, IPTV and satellite TV and also combined services. The
BSS stack has been transformed to boost Vivacom’s omni channel strategy. Applications supporting


-----

online channels, physical shops, distant sales channels and third-party integration capabilities are
integrated with single product and offer catalog and order management. All channels are powered by
big data analytics and real time marketing offerings.

In Greece, our IT infrastructure consists of technologies for designing, developing and creating tools to
support the business operations of Nova, including virtualization, and modern hardware such as data
storage, servers, security systems and network equipment from vendors such as HP, IBM and Dell. We
also use software that is open-source or commercial for monitoring and managing its OSS systems, as
well as applications for supporting BSS systems, either developed in-house or purchased through
leading software vendors such as SAP and Oracle.

We have established our own security operations center (“SOC”) team, which is fully equipped in terms
of necessary technology and consists of trained operators to monitor and triage incidents at all times,
while further incident response is performed by engineers and cybersecurity analysts. We will continue
to focus on integrating and streamlining the different IT systems to standardize and further improve our
IT solutions.

**Competition**

We face competition from established market participants as well as new market entrants. The nature
and level of the competition we face varies for each of the products and services we offer and for each
country in which we operate. Despite regional differences in the intensity of competition, we compete
in each case on the basis of network quality, content advantage, product and service portfolio
specifications, value for money proposition, marketing, installation speeds and customer care.

Our competitors include, but are not limited to, providers of television, broadband internet, fixedtelephony services using DSL or fiber connections and mobile-telephony operators, including Telekom
Slovenije, Telekom Austria and T2 in Slovenia, Telekom Srbija and Super Nova in Serbia, A1 Bulgaria,
Telenor Bulgaria and Bulsatcom in Bulgaria, BH Telecom, HT Eronet and Mtel in Bosnia and
Herzegovina, OTE (Cosmote) and Vodafone Greece in Greece and M Tel and Crnogorski Telekom in
Montenegro. We also compete against DTH providers, including Digi and Polaris, and DTT providers
in Slovenia. Furthermore, we face competition from providers of television services using alternative
and emerging digital technologies such as IPTV and OTT television. Our Shoppster e-commerce
offering also competes with, among others, e-commerce platforms such as E Kupi in Serbia and
Mimovrste, EnaA, Big Bang, Merkur and Piazz (recently launched by Telekom Slovenije) in Slovenia,
as well as traditional retail stores such as Gigatron and Tehnomanija in Serbia. We also compete with
other sources of news, information and entertainment such as social media platforms, newspapers,
movie theatres, live sporting and music events, computer games and home video products. Please also
see “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—The cable television, broadband
_internet, DTH and telephony markets in the regions in which we operate are highly competitive.”_

**Focus on Environmental, Social and Corporate Governance (ESG) Matters**

As we have grown our Group, we have increased our emphasis on integrating ESG considerations into
the key aspects of our operations, including our decision-making and reporting processes, with Boardlevel oversight and accountability. To that end, in 2020, we established a dedicated ESG coordinator
role within the Group. We have also established a multi-disciplinary team of senior executives who,
together with independent consultants, finalized in 2020 a detailed ESG action plan and implementation
roadmap. While more than half of our Group (by revenue) already produces ESG reports, we are
working to expand our current reporting, procedures, products and activities, and are developing a
framework to better identify and address ESG considerations using, among other standards, the
Sustainability Accounting Standards Board (“SASB”) materiality matrix for telecommunications and
media. Our main goal is to provide fast and reliable connections to information, knowledge and
entertainment, which in itself represents the infrastructure of the modern world on which many of the
United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals are based.

As part of our continued development in this area, the following are key focus areas and associated
KPIs, which we are using to improve upon existing practices and set and exceed new goals for ESG
matters.

- **Environmental sustainability. To promote environmental sustainability in our operations, we**
are taking active steps to minimize our environmental footprint, while also collecting and
analyzing Group historical data to set future KPI targets for reductions in carbon emissions,
climate change policy, energy use and energy sourcing. As part of our commitment to the Paris
Climate Accords, we have committed to the Science Based Targets initiative and the Carbon
Disclosure Projects, which help to drive climate action in the private sector by enabling
companies to set emissions reduction targets with scientific data and to that end we have also
submitted a net-zero target in line with a “1.5° future.” During our data gathering, we
determined that electricity represents the greatest source (approximately 86%) and opportunity
for the reduction of carbon emissions by switching to clean energy. We focus on promoting
environmental sustainability through the use of renewable energy, reducing scrap waste,
recycling and other strategies. We are committed to reducing greenhouse gas emissions across
our offices and infrastructure and ultimately make all of our operations carbon-neutral. In 2019,
we established a solar power plant at our business premises in Slovenia with a nominal power
of 242 kW, which generated 232.61 MWh of electricity in 2020, equal to approximately 1% of
our yearly consumption. We have leveraged our experience in this project to look for additional
green energy projects which could cover a significant part of our carbon emission footprint,
such as our investment in a wind park in Bulgaria, with 70 MW of power and 238 GWh annual
production. In 2020, we consumed 295.5 GWh of energy generated from all sources and we
generated 232.6 MWh of renewable energy from our solar plant in Slovenia. In addition, we
use electric vehicles in our operations where feasible, and we work to exchange old, less-energy
efficient equipment for more energy efficient devices. In 2020, we generated approximately
128.1 thousand tons of CO2 emissions (9.3 thousand tons of scope 1 emissions and 118.8


-----

thousand tons of scope 2 and 3 emissions), including the contribution of acquired companies,
and we target to reduce these by approximately 60%, or 50.6 thousand tons, by 2030. We are
also committed to reducing the climate footprint of our customers by facilitating access to
information, connectivity and entertainment by means of our high speed network, which
provides an incentive to reduce their need to travel. Furthermore, as the rapid development of
broadband, television and IT technology necessitates the continual replacement of legacy
network elements and the upgrading of our networks to accommodate increased bandwidth
requirements and new services, we have introduced waste management procedures, and we
regularly recycle obsolete equipment. In 2020, we recycled 1,539 tons of network telecom
equipment, batteries, cables, paper and cardboard. We are also committed to minimizing waste
and we repurpose, reuse or recycle 100% of returned customer devices and accessories and aim
to extend our products’ end-of-life cycle. Certain of our larger telecommunications operations
either have achieved or are pursuing ISO 14001:2015 certification, a global standard for
environmental management. We also recognize the importance of responsible procurement and
supply chain management, and to that end, we have developed Group-level procurement
policies to align procurement activities across Group companies, including adding
environmental factors in our request for proposals when engaging with new suppliers. Our
procurement procedure includes multiple checks and verification requirements, such as
international sanctions and reputation risk evaluation.

To promote environmental sustainability in our operations, we expect each of our operating
company to (i) comply with all applicable legal requirements and group-wide environmental
policy, (ii) implement appropriate control, including specific environmental procedures, (iii)
implement an environment-focused management structure, (iv) commit to reduce energy and
fuel consumption, as well as business travel and associated greenhouse gas emissions, (v)
commit to the efficient use of resources and materials used for packaging and products to reduce
waste, (vi) commit to a circular economic model, and (viii) provide selected employees with
the relevant environmental management training to undertake their duties and responsibilities
effectively.

- **Community engagement. We actively support the communities in which we operate, and in**
2020, we named a Group-level director for corporate social responsibility to coordinate efforts
in this regard among our operating companies. At an operational level, our Group companies
exercise significant control over their own community engagement projects due to the
particularities of each company, country and culture. However, the activities of our Group
companies are guided by a common set of priorities that include education, environment and
health, and community relief. We have as a Group donated €4.7 million in 2020 and €1.1
million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to groups and activities dedicated to
protecting the environment, education and the socially vulnerable, including donations of
personal protective equipment to help fight COVID-19. We have also fostered digital
inclusivity by engaging in multiple community engagement activities in the past few years,
with a focus on using our platform to deliver knowledge to children (including programs for
online safety), students, the general public and disadvantaged groups, by leveraging our core
competencies in broadband internet and other telecommunications. For 2022, we aim to
increase the percentage of staff participating in a community engagement activity (e.g.,
volunteering time or knowledge), which in 2021 stood at 7% (excluding United Media). As part
of our obligations to protect customer data, we are aligning our Group data protection policies
to standardize processes and continue our track record of no fines since GDPR came into force.
We do this via regular training programs, penetration testing and vulnerability scanning of our
IT systems, with some of our Group companies having obtained ISO/IEC 27001:2013
certification as well.

- **Corporate and employee responsibility. We focus on building a safe, fair and inclusive**
working environment for our employees. To inform our social management targets, we collect
data on our workforce, such as gender mix (57% male, 43% female), percentage of women in


-----

management positions (32%, including our Chief Executive Officer) and percentage of disabled
employees (1%), in each case, as of September 30, 2021. For the twelve months ended
September 30, 2021, staff total turnover is 17% and we have experienced 69 workplace injury
incidents. We aim to improve these metrics throughout 2021. In particular, we track gender
equality KPIs with the aim of ensuring women’s full and effective participation and equal
opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision making in political, economic and public
life. We also have mandated diversity and inclusion rules and have documented these in
employee manuals at our Group companies, which include, among others, statutory
requirements related to workers’ rights and human rights (e.g., anti-discrimination and antimobbing) and annual employee Net Promoter Score (“eNPS”) measurements. To facilitate
further transparency and accountability, we plan to expand our anonymous suggestion boxes
already present in certain of our Group companies and establish whistle-blowing programs as
a distinct transparency function. We also offer training programs to employees which are
focused on improving job-related technical and management skills, as well as on compliance
with our internal policies. We have established internal training centers which manage the entire
training process from on-boarding to organizing advanced technical and management education
provided by external experts. In 2020, we began an ambitious eNPS training program, which
we plan to continue in 2021. During this period, we invested approximately 40 hours of training
per employee for new hires and 10 hours per existing employee across our telecommunication
operating companies. Our eNPS training efforts and other initiatives contributed to a significant
increase of 46 points in eNPS score from 2019 to 2020, and it currently averages at +10. In
addition, we have been developing a specific code of conduct, which includes elements related
to labor standards, particularly to health and safety and relevant International Labour
Organisation standards. We expect to introduce our code of conduct across all of our companies
in the first half of 2022, in order to harmonize the existing processes and standards already in
place at some of our Group companies.

- **Shareholder support for ESG development. As we continue to make progress in ESG**
matters, we are wholly supported in our efforts by our majority shareholder, BC Partners. BC
Partners is a primary signatory to the United Nations’ Principles of Responsible Investments,
adopting these principles in 2009. BC Partners has formalized its commitment to increased
standards in its own ESG strategy, and takes an active role in improving ESG awareness,
performance and compliance with us and its other portfolio companies.

**Insurance**

Our fixed assets such as technical and office equipment in our network operating centers, network hubs,
head ends and office locations are protected by insurance policies covering damage from fire and other
catastrophes. We also have separate insurance covering losses from machinery breakdown and
insurance for interruption and operating costs. While we have no insurance against the risk of failure
by subscribers to pay, we have alternative controls to mitigate this risk, including collection processes
and arrangements with collections agencies. We provide directors’ and officers’ liability insurance for
all members of our board of directors, as well as certain other persons within our Group.

We believe that our existing insurance coverage, including the amounts of coverage and the conditions
thereto, provides reasonable protection, taking into account the costs for the insurance coverage and the
potential risks to business operations. However, we cannot guarantee that no losses will be incurred or
that claims that go beyond the type and scope of the existing insurance coverage will not be filed against
it.

**_Criminal Matters Related to Telemach Slovenia (as successor to Tušmobil)_**

Certain criminal matters are still pending against Tušmobil’s (as Telemach’s Slovenia’s predecessor)
former owner Mirko Tuš and the former head of AKOS, Tomaž Simonič. Pursuant to a bill of indictment
that was filed in March 2015 (and amended in May 2019) by the public prosecutor in connection with
these criminal matters, which were initially instigated by Tušmobil’s competitors in 2008, it is alleged
that, among other things, Tušmobil and Mirko Tuš made illegal payments to Tomaž Simonič, a former
head of AKOS, to obtain the grant of a block of 2x5 MHz of spectrum in the 2100 MHz band in 2008.
The bill of indictment filed by the public prosecutor also challenges AKOS’ decision in 2006 to allow
Tušmobil to exchange a certain radio frequency band (1,800 MHz) for another band (900 MHz) at no
charge and without obtaining the views of other interested parties. It is also alleged that Tušmobil and
Mirko Tuš made illegal payments to the former head of AKOS to obtain the exchange of frequencies at
no cost. Due to the expiration of the statute of limitations, Telemach Slovenia as a legal entity has been
found free of criminal liability (with the effect of finality) and related exposure to penalties or fines.
However, as a beneficiary of the frequencies grant, Telemach Slovenia may be jointly and severally
liable with other defendants (against which proceedings are still pending) for indemnification of the
allegedly illegally gained benefit if any of the remaining defendants are found guilty. In February 2020,
the first instance court acquitted Mr. Simonič of the charges in the amended bill of indictment (misuse
of the public positions or rights). In December 2020, upon the public prosecutor’s appeal, the Higher
Court of Ljubljana annulled this judgment and returned the case to the first instance court for retrial.
The criminal proceedings against Mirko Tuš have been from time to time separated from the other trials
and may be conducted separately.

In January 2016, the Republic of Slovenia made a claim against Mirko Tuš and Telemach Slovenia for
indemnification in an amount of €7.2 million. During the pre-trial hearings, Telemach Slovenia
contested the grounds for, and challenged the amount of, this claim. While the bill of indictment filed


-----

by the public prosecutor in March 2015 had indicated that Tušmobil allegedly illegally gained benefit
in an amount of approximately €7.2 million, representing a valuation of the potential charge for the
frequency bands under challenge, which had been estimated by an expert appointed by the court for
such purpose, Telemach Slovenia has contested and opposed, and intends to continue to contest and
oppose this valuation.

If any payment obligation is imposed against Telemach Slovenia or the criminal procedure is closed
with any other negative impact in these matters, we, in turn, could seek to recover these amounts from
Tušmobil’s seller based on certain provisions set forth in the transaction documents that we have entered
into with Tušmobil’s seller. For instance, under the share sale and purchase agreement, we have
recourse to up to €168 million in indemnification from the seller for losses arising from breaches of
warranties related to financial crime, which we could seek to claim against in the event of a final, nonappealable judgment requiring Tušmobil to pay monetary fines or in the case of a negative impact to
the conduct of business, reputation and assets of Telemach Slovenia resulting from the criminal
procedure. However, we may not be successful in any actions to claim indemnity or damages from
Tušmobil’s seller in a timely manner or at all, and the indemnifying party may not have sufficient funds
to fulfil its indemnification obligations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and
_Industry—We have made and may make acquisitions or enter into asset dispositions or other_
_transactions that may present unforeseen risks, and we may not realize the financial and strategic goals_
_that were contemplated at the time of any transaction and, additionally, there are risks associated with_
_the integration of any acquisitions.”_

The AKOS criminal proceedings described above relate to the block of spectrum obtained by Tušmobil
in 2008 (and the exchange of certain frequency bands in 2006), and do not affect the ownership or
validity of the spectrum used for 4G/LTE and legacy 2G that Tušmobil was awarded in 2014 (for the
period from 2014 to 2029) or the ownership or validity of the additional 3G and 4G/LTE frequencies
allotted to Telemach Slovenia in 2016 (for periods until 2021 and 2031) or the recently acquired
spectrum at the auction in April 2021. Nevertheless, if the pending criminal proceedings are determined
in a manner adverse to Telemach Slovenia, and Telemach Slovenia is required to pay a material amount
as part of an indemnity, and Telemach Slovenia is not able to recover such amounts from the Tušmobil
seller, such developments could have a material adverse effect on our financial position and
profitability.

**_Investment Arbitration with Serbia_**

On October 6, 2020, we, together with two of our affiliates, served the Republic of Serbia with a Notice
of Dispute under the agreement on encouragement and reciprocal protection of investments between
the Kingdom of the Netherlands and the Republic of Serbia (“BIT”). In such Notice of Dispute, it was
asserted that Serbia breached several obligations under the BIT, including, among others, the obligation
to accord fair and equitable treatment, national treatment and most constant protection and security. We
argued that, beginning in 2014, we have been a target of a series of arbitrary, unlawful measures taken
by various Serbian authorities and entities as part of a widespread, orchestrated campaign to reduce
SBB Serbia’s market presence and to promote the interests of Telekom Srbija.

The Republic of Serbia failed to respond to the Notice of Dispute within the three-month deadline
established by the BIT. On January 7, 2021, we submitted a Request for Arbitration to the International
Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes. An arbitration proceeding was initiated and is currently
ongoing. On December 30, 2021, the arbitral tribunal dismissed Serbia’s request for bifurcation.

**_Investigation by the Serbian Tax Authority_**

On December 27, 2018, the Serbian Tax Authority notified us that it had begun a tax investigation of
SBB Serbia for the year ended December 31, 2012. In March 2019, the Serbian Tax Authority issued a
decision that it had recharacterized interest payments made by SBB Serbia under an intragroup loan
agreement (and certain other transactions) as dividends, the payments of which would have been subject


-----

to a 5% withholding tax. The total contingent liability under this decision amounts to €21 million,
including late interest. We have assessed these matters internally and through external consultants, and

for our Dutch entities to the Dutch Ministry of Finance on the basis that the Serbian taxation decision
is not in compliance with the double taxation treaty between the Netherlands and Serbia. The Dutch
Ministry of Finance has notified the Serbian Tax Authority of the MAP procedure. The Dutch Ministry
of Finance has also submitted a letter to the Serbian Ministry of Finance stating that Serbia has
misclassified the interest payments and is in breach of the bilateral double taxation treaty. On October
12, 2020, the Serbian Ministry of Finance annulled the Serbian Tax Authority’s decision and instructed
the Serbian Tax Authority to restart the procedure, taking into account the arguments provided in SBB
Serbia’s appeal.

**Regulatory Framework**

**_European Union_**

The EU regulatory framework for electronic communications was revised in 2018 with the adoption of
the Directive (EU) 2018/1972 of the European Parliament and of the Council of December 11, 2018 on
the European Electronic Communications Code (“EECC”). The EECC has come into full effect across
EU Member States following the expiration of the deadline for its implementation at the national level
in December 2020. The EECC codifies in one single document all the applicable laws and regulations
forming the EU regulatory framework for electronic communications. The main objectives of the EECC
are to contribute to the development of the internal market by harmonizing provisions of the
telecommunications regulatory framework, specifically in the area of spectrum and consumer rights, to
remove legal uncertainty over the application of this regulatory framework to certain over-the-top
(OTT) services, and to promote the deployment and take-up of very high-capacity networks, such as
fiber and 5G networks.

_Becoming an Operator_

The general authorization regime lays down rights and obligations for operating electronic
communication networks and/or providing electronic communication services and implies that
telecommunications providers need not wait for a decision of the competent national regulatory
authority (“NRA”) in order to start their activity. Operators abiding by the general authorization
conditions can start to operate electronic communications networks or provide electronic
communication services upon notifying the NRA of their intention to commence service. Such
notification is the maximum requirement that national authorities can impose on telecommunications
providers. However, EU Member States can also opt to implement a no-notification regime.

_Radio Spectrum_

Radio spectrum rules governing authorizations, rights of use and assignment of rights set out in the
EECC aim to facilitate the deployment of high-quality and high-speed wireless broadband coverage,
the development of new wireless technologies and the pursuit of consistency and predictability in
licensing procedures.

EU Member States can determine the most appropriate regime for authorizing the use of radio spectrum,
taking into account (i) the specific characteristics of the radio spectrum concerned; (ii) the need to
protect against harmful interference; (iii) the development of reliable conditions for radio spectrum
sharing, where appropriate; (iv) the need to ensure technical quality of communications or service; (v)
objectives of general interest as laid down by Member States in accordance with EU law; and (vi) the
need to safeguard efficient use of radio spectrum.


-----

EU Member States can authorize the use of radio spectrum for a limited period and are obliged to ensure
that the rights of radio spectrum holder for wireless broadband services are valid for a term of at least
15 years and include an adequate extension ensuring regulatory predictability over at least 20 years.
The general criteria for the renewal of individual rights should be set out in a transparent manner and
the relevant decisions on the renewal of harmonized radio spectrum licences should be taken in a timely
manner before the duration of those rights expires.

Decision-making of the NRAs on granting, amending and renewal of rights of use for radio spectrum
are intended to promote effective competition and prevent distortions of competition. The EECC,
however, left EU Member States the discretion to take appropriate measures with regard to, among
other things, the limitation of the amount of radio spectrum bands, wholesale access and roaming
conditions, spectrum reservation and grounds for refusal in the event of transfer or accumulation of
rights of use.

_Significant Market Power_

While the general aim of the EECC is for the electronic communication sector to be governed by
competition law, the EU regulatory framework sets out rules on SMP and market analysis aimed at
preventing operators with SMP (“SMP operator”) to potentially abuse their market power.

An undertaking is deemed to have SMP if, either individually or jointly with others, it enjoys a position
equivalent to dominance, namely a position of economic strength affording it the power to behave to
an appreciable extent independently of competitors, customers and ultimately consumers.

Where an NRA establishes that an operator is an SMP operator, it may impose measures or regulatory
obligations (ex-ante regulation) on the SMP operator, in order to address any market failures. The
obligations that may be imposed on the SMP operator are determined in the EECC and include (i)
obligations to ensure transparency and non-discrimination; (ii) accounting separation; (iii) access to
civil engineering; (iv) obligations of access to, and use of, specific network elements and associated
facilities; (v) price control and cost accounting obligations; and (vi) in exceptional cases, functional
separation requiring a vertically integrated SMP operator to place activities related to the wholesale
provision of the relevant access products in an independent business entity.

SMP operators may also offer commitments to open the deployment of a new, very high-capacity
network consisting of optical fiber elements up to the end-user premises or base station to co-investment
(which can be made binding by the NRA). In addition, they are required to inform the NRA in advance
of any intended transfer of their local access network assets (or a substantial part thereof) to a separate
legal entity under different ownership, or the establishment of a separate business entity in order to
provide retail providers, including their own retail divisions, with fully equivalent access products. The
scope for imposing SMP obligations is also limited in respect of companies operating exclusively in
wholesale markets.

The relevant markets in which ex ante regulation may be justified are determined by the NRA, also
taking into account the European Commission’s Recommendation on the Relevant Product and Service
Market (the “EC Recommendation”), the SMP guidelines and national circumstances, if the following
three criteria set out in the EECC are met:

(i) high and non-transitory structural, legal or regulatory barriers to entry are present;

(ii) there is a market structure which does not tend towards effective competition within the

relevant time horizon, having regard to the state of infrastructure-based competition and other

sources of competition behind the barriers to entry; and

(iii) competition law alone is insufficient to adequately address the identified market failure(s).


-----

A revised version of the EC Recommendation was issued by the European Commission in December
2020 (“New EC Recommendation”) and includes the following markets susceptible to _ex-ante_
regulation in accordance with the EECC:

Market 1: Wholesale local access provided at a fixed location

Market 2: Wholesale dedicated capacity

_Symmetric Access Obligations_

The NRAs may impose so called “symmetric” access obligations to all providers of electronic
communication networks and operators of such networks and apply to network elements that cannot be
duplicated. Symmetric access obligations can be imposed to grant access to:

(i) wiring, cables and associated facilities inside buildings or up to the first concentration or

distribution point as determined by the NRA where such point is located outside the building,

or

(ii) beyond the first concentration or distribution point, to a point that the NRA determines to be

the closest to end-users, capable of hosting a sufficient number of end-user connections to be

commercially viable for efficient access seekers.

_Numbering Resources_

EU Member States control the granting of rights of use for national numbering resources and the
management of the national numbering plans. They can assign numbers to undertakings other than
providers of electronic communications networks or services, enable an extraterritorial use of nongeographic numbers within the EU for the provision of non-interpersonal communications services and
ensure the efficient use of numbering resources.

Upon request, the NRAs may grant individual rights of use for numbering resources (e.g., telephone
numbers) to any undertaking for the operation of electronic communications networks or the provision
of services covered by a general authorization. NRAs or other competent authorities shall take decisions
on the granting of rights of use for numbering resources as soon as possible after receipt of the complete
application and within three weeks in the case of numbering resources that have been allocated for
specific purposes within the national numbering plan. When doing so, the NRAs specify whether those
rights can be transferred, and under which conditions.

Member States may allow NRAs to impose fees for the rights of use for numbering resources which
reflect the need to ensure the optimal use of those resources.

**_Bulgaria_**

Telecommunications operations in Bulgaria are governed by the Electronic Communications Act
(Zakon za electronnite saobstenia or “ZES”), which came into force on May 22, 2007 and was amended
on March 9, 2021 in order to transpose the EECC into Bulgarian legislation.

_Becoming an Operator_

A legal entity seeking to become an operator is required to notify Bulgarian Regulatory Authority
(“CRC”) about its intent to operate public communication networks or to provide public communication
services prior to the beginning of the performance of its activities. The notification must include the
required general information about the legal entity (such as the name and address of establishment etc.),
а brief description of the networks and services which will be provided, data on territorial coverage, a
contact person and the relevant details, an estimated date of the beginning of the activity and the address


-----

of the operator’s website related to the provision of public communication networks services. Within
14 days from receipt of the complete notification, CRC shall register the operator in its official register.

An operator must notify CRC about (i) changes to the information included in the original notification
(listed above) within 14 days from the relevant change; and (ii) the termination of activity within 14
days from its occurrence.

An operator is obliged to pay an annual fee to CRC, which is calculated by CRC on the basis of the
annual turnover generated by an operator from the provision of public communication networks or
public communication services in Bulgaria, and must be reported to CRC by March 15 of each year.
Generally, the annual fee is equal to 0.20% of the relevant operator’s gross yearly revenues that exceed
BGN 0.1 million. In addition to these fees, operators of electronic communication that use scarce
resources (spectrum and/or numbers) are obliged to pay the corresponding annual fees.

_Radio-Frequency Spectrum_

CRC issues decisions on the award of radio frequencies for the provision of public communication
services to end-users after holding a contest or auction, in case the number of applicants is greater than
the number of operators which may obtain an authorization of the respective free limited resource. CRC
issues the decision on the award of radio frequencies for an initial period of not less than 15 years,
which can be extended to 20 years to ensure predictability with regard to infrastructure investment
conditions, based on the use of such frequencies. The holder of a decision on the award of radio
frequencies may transfer the permission or part of its rights and respective obligations to a third-party
with CRC’s prior consent.

_Numbering Plan_

CRC adopts the numbering plan with a general act that determines the type, length, and structure of the
numbering elements, their intended use, and manner of use, including numbers for emergency calls and
numbers the use of which is harmonized based on EU regulations. This general act must also support
number portability and the introduction of new electronic communication services.

_Operators with Significant Market Power_

The definition of a SMP operator under ZES closely follows the relevant definition in the EECC. The
relevant markets susceptible to ex-ante regulation are determined by CRC taking into account principles
of competition law and the valid EC Recommendation, as applicable from time to time. While the New
EC Recommendation has delisted certain markets that were previously susceptible to _ex-ante_
regulation, CRC continues to impose ex-ante regulation measures on the following markets (determined
in the previously valid EC Recommendation):


Market M1/2014 FTR


Wholesale call termination on individual public
telephone networks provided at a fixed location


Market M2/2014 MTR Wholesale voice call termination on individual
mobile networks

In addition to the above, there are also various further legal and/or regulatory requirements, depending
on the relevant business activity of the operator.

_Electronic Media Act_

The Radio and Television Act (Zakon za radioto I televiziata or “ZRT”) came into force on July 5,
1999 and was last amended to implement Directive (EU) 2018/1808 of the European Parliament and of
the Council of November 14, 2018 (amending Directive 2010/13/EU on the coordination of certain
provisions laid down by law, regulation or administrative acts in Member States concerning the


-----

provision of audiovisual media services (Audiovisual Media Services Directive) in the light of changing
market conditions).

Neither the ZRT nor the ZES prohibits a telecommunications operator from carrying out activities of a
TV or radio broadcaster and vice versa. The Bulgarian Media Regulator (SEM) authorizes any radio
and TV operator and providers of media services under the ZRT. This authorization entitles for
broadcasting of programs by an operator which has been granted a permission by CRC for use of radiofrequency spectrum through electronic communication networks for terrestrial or satellite radio
broadcasting.

**_Croatia_**

As of the date of this offering memorandum, Croatia has not yet implemented the EECC into its national
legislation and therefore the currently applicable laws and regulations described below are based on the
existing Electronic Communication Act (Zakon o elektroničkim komunikacijama or “ZEK”), which
came into force on July 1, 2008 (as subsequently amended) and are subject to change. While there is no
specific timeline with respect to the adoption of the new Electronic Communication Act implementing
the EECC into Croatian legislation, it is expected for the first quarter of 2022.

_Becoming an Operator_

A legal entity seeking to become an operator is required to notify the Croatian Regulatory Authority for
Network Industries (“HAKOM”) about its intent to operate public communication networks or to
provide public communication services at least 15 days prior to the beginning of the performance of its
activities. The form and method of notification are defined by the Ordinance on the manner and
conditions for the provision of electronic communications networks and services issued by HAKOM
on December 15, 2011 (as subsequently amended). Within eight days from receipt of the complete
notification, HAKOM registers the operator in its official register and submits a confirmation notice to
the operator (such confirmation is not an administrative decision and does not itself create rights and
obligations under the ZEK).

An operator is obliged to pay an annual fee to HAKOM, which is calculated by HAKOM on the basis
of the annual turnover generated by an operator from the provision of public communication networks
or public communication services in Croatia, and must be reported to HAKOM by March 31 of each
year. Generally, the annual fee is equal to 0.20% of the relevant operator’s gross yearly revenues that
exceed HRK 7.5 million. In addition to these fees, all operators of electronic communication are obliged
to pay certain other fees and charges, including parafiscal charges defined by the relevant applicable
laws.

_Radio-Frequency Spectrum_

Radio frequencies for the provision of public communication services to end-users in Croatia are
awarded by HAKOM by way of a decision issued on the basis of an undertaken process (public call,
public contest or auction). A decision on the award of radio frequencies is issued for a limited time
period, taking into account appropriate time for amortization of investment, but for no longer than for
20 years. The holder of a decision on award of radio frequency must pay an annual usage fee to HAKOM
as well to the state budget.

_Numbering Plan_

HAKOM adopts the numbering plan with a general act that determines the type, length, and structure
of the numbering elements, their intended use, and manner of use, including numbers for emergency
calls and numbers the use of which is harmonized based on EU regulations. This general act must also
support number portability and the introduction of new electronic communication services.


-----

_Operators with Significant Market Power_

The definition of a SMP operator under ZEK closely follows the relevant definition in the EECC. The
relevant markets susceptible to _ex-ante regulation are determined by HAKOM taking into account_
principles of competition law and the valid EC Recommendation, as applicable from time to time. While
the New EC Recommendation has delisted certain markets that were previously susceptible to ex-ante
regulation, HAKOM continues to impose _ex-ante regulation measures on the following markets_
(determined in the previously valid EC Recommendation):

Market M1/2007 Fixed Telephony Access to the public telephone network at a fixed
location for residential and non-residential
customers

Market M1/2014 FTR Wholesale call termination on individual public
telephone networks provided at a fixed location

Market M2/2014 MTR Wholesale voice call termination on individual
mobile networks

Market M3a/2014 ULL Wholesale local access provided at a fixed
location

Market M3b/2014 Bitstream Access Wholesale central access provided at a fixed
location for mass-market products

Market M4/2014 Wholesale high quality access provided at a fixed
location

Market M14/2003 Wholesale trunk segments of high quality access
services

Market M2/2007 Call origination on the public telephone network
provided at a fixed location

In addition to the above, there are also various further legal and/or regulatory requirements, depending
on the relevant business activity of the operator.

_Electronic Media Act_

In October 2021, the Croatian Parliament adopted the new Electronic Media Act (Zakon o electroničkim
_medijima or “new ZEM”), which came into force on October 22, 2021._

The new ZEM no longer contains the provision on vertical integration as stipulated in the previous
version of the Electronic Media Act, which prohibited a telecommunications operator carrying out
activities of audiovisual and/or radio program transmission to serve as a TV and/or radio broadcaster
and/or a media service provider at the same time. In practice, this meant that entities engaging in
telecommunication operations were not allowed to engage in the transmission of audiovisual and/or
radio programs if they are under common control with a TV and/or radio broadcaster.

With the removal of the provision on vertical integration in the new ZEM, telecommunication operators
carrying out activities of audiovisual and/or radio program transmission in Croatia are now allowed to
also serve as TV and/or radio broadcasters and/or media service providers.

**_Slovenia_**

As of the date of this offering memorandum, Slovenia has not yet implemented the EECC into its
national legislation and therefore the currently applicable laws and regulations described below are
based on the existing Electronic Communication Act (ZEKom-1) and are subject to change. As of the
date of this offering memorandum, no specific timeline is available with respect to the adoption of the
new Slovenian Electronic Communication Act (ZEKom-2) implementing the EECC into Slovenian
legislation.


-----

_Becoming an Operator_

Entities who seek to operate public electronic communication networks (“PECN”) or provide public
electronic communication services (“PECS”) must notify the Agency for Communication Networks
and Services of the Republic of Slovenia (“AKOS”) using a form prescribed by AKOS. Upon the receipt
of a complete notification, AKOS subsequently registers the operator in its official register and sends a
confirmation notice to the operator (such confirmation is not an administrative decision and does not
itself create rights and obligations under the ZEKom-1).

An operator is obliged to notify AKOS in case of (i) any change in the company name or other legal
information contained in the initial notification, within 30 days of such change; (ii) any change in the
starting date of the operation of PECN or the provision of PECS or changes to the geographic area in
which PECN is operated or PECS are provided, prior to their occurrence; and (iii) the planned cessation
of provision of PECN and/or PECS, at least 90 days prior to the planned cessation.

An operator is obliged to pay an annual fee to AKOS, which is calculated by AKOS on the basis of the
annual turnover generated by an operator from the provision of PECS and/or PECN in Slovenia, and
must be reported to AKOS by March 31 of each year.

_Radio Spectrum_

Radio frequencies for the provision of public communication services to end-users in Slovenia are
awarded by AKOS by way of a decision issued on the basis of a public tender. A decision on the award
of radio frequencies is issued for a limited time period, taking into account appropriate time for
amortization of investment, but for no longer than for 15 years. The validity of a decision on the award
of radio frequencies for the provision of public communication services to end-users cannot be
extended. No special rules determining longer duration period or the possibility of extension are
determined in respect of radio spectrum holder rights for wireless broadband services. The holder of the
decision on award of radio frequencies may transfer its right to use such radio frequency to a third-party
with a prior consent of AKOS. However, operators may not accumulate radio frequencies with the
objective of limiting competition on the radio communication market.

AKOS may ex officio change the decision on award of radio frequency in order to ensure effective use
of radio frequency spectrum for the public good or for certain other causes as prescribed by law. In
addition, AKOS may, among other things, annul the decision to award a radio frequency if the award
was granted on the basis of untrue data, if the holder no longer complies with the requirements laid
down in the relevant legislation or the decision itself, or does not begin to use the radio frequency within
the prescribed time period, transfers the right to a third-party, or if the fees for the use of radio frequency
or for the effective use of a finite commodity have not been paid.

The holder of a decision on award of radio frequency must pay an annual usage fee to AKOS. The
amount of the annual fee is based on the coverage and density of population or the radio frequency,
radio frequency band width, the type of radio communications involved, or a combination of the above,
but may not restrict or hinder competition or market entry. To ensure optimal use of radio frequencies,
holders of decisions on award of radio frequencies for the provision of public communication services
must also pay a fee for the effective use of a finite commodity. The minimal amount of such payment
and terms of payment shall be determined in the decision on the initiation of the public tender procedure,
and may not unduly hinder the provision of innovative services and competition.

_Significant Market Power_

The definition of a SMP operator under ZEKom-1 closely follows the relevant definition in the EECC.
ZEKom-1, however, sets out a list of specific criteria it considers when assessing whether an operator
has SMP, including, _inter alia, the market share of the operator and its variations over time; the_


-----

existence of barriers to entry and their effect on the potential competition; the impact of large users on
the power of the operator; the stage of development of the relevant market; and the level of integration.

The scope of measures or regulatory obligations that may be imposed on a SMP operator as part of the
_ex-ante regulation are generally in line with the measures and obligations set out in the EECC, save for_
obligations on the access of civil engineering which are not envisaged in ZEKom-1. ZEKom-1 does not
include any rules allowing SMP operators to offer any commitments to open the deployment of a new
very high capacity network and does not include any exemption in respect of companies operating
exclusively in wholesale markets.

The relevant markets susceptible to ex-ante regulation are determined by AKOS taking into account
principles of competition law and taking into account the EC Recommendation, as applicable from time
to time. While the New EC Recommendation has delisted certain markets that were previously
susceptible to _ex-ante regulation, AKOS continues to impose_ _ex-ante regulation measures on the_
following markets (determined in the EC Recommendation):

Market 1: Wholesale call termination on individual public telephone networks provided at
a fixed location;

Market 2: Wholesale voice call termination on individual mobile networks;

Market 3a: Wholesale local access provided at a fixed location;

Market 3b: Wholesale central access provided at a fixed location for mass market products;
and

Market 4: Wholesale high-quality access provided at a fixed location.

While it has not yet been publicly disclosed, it has been unofficially indicated that AKOS will continue
to impose ex-ante regulation measures on all above listed markets.

_Symmetric Access Obligations_

AKOS may provide suitable operator access by way of a decision, if it assesses this to be appropriate
under the circumstances. In this respect, AKOS may impose obligations in particular on operators that
control access to end-users to the extent necessary to ensure the connection of both ends, including the
obligation to interconnect networks or, in justified cases and to the necessary extent, impose the
obligation to enable interoperability of operators’ services.

_Numbering Resources_

Numbering resources in Slovenia are managed by AKOS, which adopts the numbering plan by way of
general act determining the type, length, and structure of the numbering elements, their intended use,
and manner of use, including numbers for emergency calls, and numbers the use of which is harmonized
based on EU regulations. This general act must also support number portability and the introduction of
new electronic communication services. Numbering resources may be used by, and can be allocated to,
operators only on the basis of the AKOS’ decision on the allocation of numbering resources.

While the EECC envisages that the NRA may, under certain circumstances, also grant the right to use
for numbering resources to undertakings other than operators, ZEKom-1 limits this solely to (natural or
legal) persons who can prove that they need numbering resources for the provision of activity in the
public interest. This decision on allocation of numbering resources is issued on the basis of a specific
application pursuant to ZEKom-1. Save for when a public tender is carried out, AKOS is obliged to
issue its decision within the time limits complaint with the EECC. Such decision also sets the conditions
for the use of the allocated numbering resources.

A special numbering resources fee is payable to AKOS for the use of allocated numbering resources.

**_Greece_**


-----

The Greek electronic communication sector is mainly governed by L. 4727/2020 (the “2020 Law”)
which transposed the EECC into Greek national legal framework. The 2020 Law also regulates certain
matters (relevant to radio spectrum and satellite orbit and related frequencies rights) that have not been
transposed directly from the EECC. Certain of the main differences between the 2020 Law and the
EECC are summarized herein.

_ΕΕΤΤ_

The Hellenic Telecommunications and Post Commission (“ΕΕΤΤ”) is the Greek national regulatory
authority for telecommunication and postal markets and is responsible for majority of the tasks entrusted
to the NRAs under the EECC (as transposed into Greek national legislation).

_General Licensing_

Greek national rules are generally harmonized with the provisions of the EECC relating to the general
licensing procedure. However, the general licensing procedure does not extend to:

(i) resale of telecommunications services to users;

(ii) own use of radio equipment terminal on the basis of non-exclusive use of special radio

frequency by the user for reasons not related to economic activity, which does not constitute a

network supply or electronic communications service and is governed by the provisions of the

current legislation concerning terminal equipment and radio equipment; or

(iii) state-owned telecommunication networks.

The interested (natural or legal) persons are required to complete and submit a Registration Declaration
for Engaging in Electronic Communication Activities to EETT under a General Authorization Regime
(notification), including the minimum information necessary to enable BEREC and the ΕΕΤΤ to keep
a Register of electronic communications networks and services providers.

Operators are under an obligation to submit a supplementary or amended Registration Declaration (i)
in order to engage in the provision of additional electronic communication services or/and networks;
(ii) if they terminate the provision of some or all the electronic communication services or/and networks;
and (iii) if any change is made in the details stated in the initial Registration Declaration. Any change
of data shall be notified within fifteen (15) days from its occurrence.

The EETT may impose fees for general licensing to operators on the basis of the turnover of the
provider, a flat-rate charging system, or a combination of the two. Providers of networks electronic
communication networks and/or services are also obliged to pay the EETT annual administrative
charges, which are calculated based on the total gross income in charges zones.

EETT monitors and supervises the providers’ compliance with the existing legislation. In addition,
EETT may request providers that are subject to the General Authorization Regime or enjoy rights of
use of radio spectrum or resources numbering resources, to provide all information necessary to verify
their compliance with the above.

_Radio Spectrum_

EETT and the Greek Ministry of Digital Governance are responsible for ensuring the effective
management of the radio spectrum. In this respect, in 2019 the Greek Ministry of Defence and the
Ministry of Digital Governance adopted the National Band and Frequency Allocation Regulation by a
joint ministerial decision, which provides, inter alia, for (i) national distribution plans for radio in
services; (ii) references to restrictions related to radio-spectrum management; and (iii) reports on the
possibility of using radio equipment in specific radio frequency bands, as well as for radio frequency


-----

bands that can be used by electronic equipment for industrial mechanical, scientific, medical (Industrial,
Scientific, Medical “ISM”) or other applications.

EETT is the competent authority to grant rights of use of radio frequencies. There are certain radio
spectrum bands that do not require the granting of an individual right of use. For all other spectrum
rights, the granting procedure depends on whether or not there is a number limitation on those rights.

For the granting of radio spectrum rights of use without limitations to their number, interested
parties should submit a request to the EETT. Following the examination of the application, which takes
place in order of priority, the EETT grants the applicant the individual right to use certain radio spectrum
bands. In the case of radio spectrum rights of use with limitations to their number, the imposition of
such limit takes place by virtue of an EETT decision. If necessary to ensure the effective use of the
radio spectrum and accommodate the current supply-demand conditions in the market, the EETT
(following a relevant decision by the Minister of Digital Governance) issues a proclamation for a tender
procedure, specifying in detail the procedure and conditions of the invitation to tender. The right of use
is awarded for a specific period of time.

As of the date of this offering memorandum, an amendment of the regulation on the radio spectrum
rights of use is expected.

The 2020 Law provides for a possible exception to the obligation to follow the procedure for granting
of individual rights to use radio spectrum where the granting of individual rights of use of radio
spectrum to providers of radio or television broadcasting content services is necessary to achieve a
public interest objective.

Transfer or timeshare of individual rights to use radio spectrum

Subject to certain specific conditions, providers operating in the Greek territory may transfer or timelease individual rights of use of radio spectrum to other undertakings subject to authorization by EETT.

Procedure for limiting the number of spectrum rights to be granted

Where it is considered that the use of radio spectrum cannot be subject to a general authorization, and
upon considering whether to limit the number of rights to use radio spectrum to be granted, due regard
shall be given, inter alia, to the need to maximise the benefits for users and to facilitate the development
of competition. Accordingly, following a public consultation phase aimed at examining the need to limit
the number of rights of use for radio spectrum, the Greek Minister of Digital Governance may, in its
decision, limit the number of spectrum usage rights to be granted. This decision shall specify the type
of competitive procedure to be followed for their allocation. The Greek Minister of Digital Governance
may review the limitation of the number of spectrum usage rights to be granted, increasing or decreasing
the relevant number.

Radio spectrum supervision

EETT plans, develops and operates a network of fixed and mobile stations spectrum compliance. Any
infringement of the related provisions may be subject to administrative and/or criminal sanctions.

Satellite orbit management

The geostatic or non-orbital positions of satellites and their associated frequencies awarded or assigned
to the country constitute rare resources and public goods with significant social, cultural and economic
value, the management of which constitutes a sovereign right of the Greek State. The assignment of
such rights may only take place through an objective, transparent and impartial tender procedure with
proportionality criteria.


-----

_Significant Market Power_

The definition of a SMP operator under the 2020 Law closely follows the relevant definition in the
EECC. The relevant markets susceptible to ex-ante regulation are determined by EETT in adherence
with the guidelines on market analysis and the assessment of significant market power published by the
European Commission.

While the New EC Recommendation has delisted certain markets that were previously susceptible to
_ex-ante regulation, EETT continues to impose ex-ante regulation measures on the following markets_
(determined in the previously valid EC Recommendations):

Market 1: Wholesale call termination on individual public telephone networks provided at
a fixed location;

Market 2: Wholesale voice call termination on individual mobile networks;

Market 3a: Wholesale local access provided at a fixed location;

Market 3b: Wholesale central access provided at a fixed location for mass market products;

Market 4: Wholesale high-quality access provided at a fixed location; and

Market 14: Leased Line Trunk Segments market.

The EETT has not yet determined whether they shall continue to impose ex ante regulation measures
on the markets listed above.

_Numbering Resources_

The National Numbering Plan (NNP) is issued by the Greek Minister of Digital Governance, and
ensures the provision of adequate numbering resources in all electronic communication services
provided to the public.

The EETT manages the NNP, issues a regulation determining the procedure, the prerequisites and the
details related to the granting of rights of use and the efficient use of all national numbering resources,
assigns, binds, revokes and restricts the rights of use of numbers or sum of numbers, monitors its
implementation and defines the fees for the assignment and use of numbering resources.

The procedure for the granting of right of use of numbering resources shall be objective, transparent,
non-discriminatory, proportionate and open to every operator. EETT is responsible for the assignment
of numbering resources. Numbering resources allocation applications shall be submitted only
electronically on EETT’s digital platform. They are examined in order of priority and shall be completed
within 21 days. The relevant EETT decision is notified to the applicant.

Fees for rights of use for numbering resources

EETT imposes fees for the rights of use for numbering resources which reflect the need to ensure the
optimal use of those resources. The fees are objectively justified, transparent, non-discriminatory and
proportionate in relation to their intended purpose and shall take into account the objectives closely
following the general objectives of the EECC and the objective of ensuring the efficient use of radio
spectrum and satellite orbits.

_Rights of Way_

Telecommunications providers can, upon filing an application, receive the right of installation on
private, public or municipal properties. The authorities granting such rights should do so in a
transparent, impartial and accessible to the public manner. The holder of the right is obliged to pay a
relevant fee that is calculated according to a relevant regulation issued by EETT. No other fee is owed
by the provider.


-----

_Co-locations_

The EETT holds the power to enforce the co-location and sharing of the network infrastructure upon a
telecommunications provider that has already secured the right to use a land. The decision should aim
at the protection of the environment, public health, public security or civil planning goals.

**_Serbia_**

_General_

Under the Serbian Electronic Communication Act (“ECA”), the main piece of legislation regulating the
performance of electronic communication activities and the operation of the networks thereof in Serbia,
a company’s general authorization to conduct its business is in most cases sufficient to provide
electronic communication services. A sector-specific license is required only if the business involves
the exploitation of scarce resources, such as phone numbers or radio frequencies. Therefore, when a
company takes up an activity under the general authorization regime, all it needs to do (subject to
fulfillment of the imposed general conditions (technical and certain others) and payment of the
prescribed fees) is to notify RATEL within 15-days of doing so. In addition, the company is required
to act in compliance with general conditions during its operations and to notify RATEL of any important
changes in its activities, as well as of their termination.

_Significant Market Power Under the ECA_

Under the ECA, an operator is considered to have SMP, if it has, alone or together with other operators,
a dominant position, i.e., a position that enables it to a significant degree to act independently from its
competitors, subscribers and customers. Pursuant to the ECA, if RATEL finds the absence of effective
competition in a relevant market (and a closely related market), it will designate the operator who,
individually or jointly with other operators, has SMP on that market, by taking into account different
market conditions.

If RATEL reaches a decision designating one or more operators as having SMP, RATEL may impose
at least one of the following obligations on the respective entities:

- an obligation to publish data from accounting records, technical specifications, network

characteristics, terms and conditions for supply and use or validity periods of the offer and

prices;

- an obligation to only engage in non-discriminatory conduct;

- an obligation to keep separate accounts for interconnection and access services;

- an obligation to provide access and use of parts of its network infrastructure and associated

facilities to third parties;

- price controls and cost-based accounting;

- an obligation to make available a minimum set of leased lines;

- an obligation to offer operator selection and operator pre-selection services; and


-----

- regulation of the respective operators’ retail services, including an obligation to unbundle

products and services.

_Tariffs_

As a general matter, each operator is free to set its own tariffs. However, if RATEL finds an operator
to have SMP in a relevant market, the operator may become subject to various restrictions, including
price controls, as noted above. If an operator becomes subject to price controls, it must adopt a cost
based accounting system for the provision of specific types of interconnection and/or access services.
These controls are imposed if, in particular, RATEL determines that the absence of effective
competition enables the operator to charge exceedingly high prices or resort to price squeezes to the
detriment of end-users.

While RATEL has some flexibility in imposing these restrictions, it must take into consideration the
previous investments made by the operator while imposing the aforesaid measures, it must encourage
further investments and it must allow for a reasonable rate of return on investment in view of the risks
involved.

The burden of proof that an operator’s prices comply with the above-mentioned restrictions is on the
relevant operator. Upon RATEL’s request, the operator in question is required to provide a detailed
account of its pricing policy.

A description of the operator’s price calculations must be made publicly available and reviewed
annually by an independent auditor.

_Law on Electronic Media_

Provision of audiovisual media services via electronic communication networks is subject to a license
by the media regulator REM. Such license is valid for a period of eight calendar years and may be
extended. In order to extend the term of the license, the licensee must submit a request for the extension
of the license at least six months before its expiration. The holder of the license must notify REM of
any change in its direct or indirect ownership structure for REM’s verification as to whether the change
of control may lead to violation of the rules on media concentration (concentration of ownership or
management rights in two or more electronic media publishers, or acquisition of more than 50% of
share of daily news publishers with circulation of more than 50,000 copies annually, and audio and
AVM service providers). Failure to abide by media concentration rules may lead to license revocation.

**_Bosnia and Herzegovina_**

_Telecommunications Services_

The Bosnian Law on Communications regulates telecommunications, radio, broadcasting (including
cable television) and associated services and facilities in Bosnia and Herzegovina as well as the
establishment and the activities of the Bosnian Communications Regulatory Agency (“CRA”).

The CRA was established on March 2, 2001 and assumed the competences of the Independent Media
Commission and the Telecommunications Regulatory Agency. The CRA is responsible for developing
rules in the telecommunications and broadcasting sectors, the licensing of operators in these sectors, the
planning, management and allocation of the frequency spectrum, the implementation of technical and
quality standards and the determination and maintenance of license fees.

Telecommunications services through fixed-line and mobile networks or internet services may only be
offered if the relevant operator holds a license. A telecommunications operator is required to:


-----

- enter into written subscription contracts with its subscribers;

- provide (free of charge) a brief and plain summary of the tariffs applicable to its subscribers;

- deliver, at the request of the CRA, within a reasonable period of time, business data, network

data and traffic data including confidential data;

- ensure the proper functioning and good working condition of its system and the timely removal

of interferences and failures and notify the CRA without any undue delay of any significant

interruption in the telecommunications connections;

- set up conditions of operation, a description of services and specify the relevant tariffs, all of

which must be presented to the CRA and published in a suitable form; the operator must also

publish any changes to the conditions of operations and tariffs at least one month prior to their

effective date in a suitable form; any change to the content of a contract entitles the contracting

party to terminate its contract with the telecommunications operator within a period of four

weeks from the publication of the change; and

- offer interconnection services to other operators upon their request; if the relevant parties cannot

reach an agreement within a period of six weeks from receipt of the request, each of them may

petition the CRA to mediate the dispute.

The CRA decides upon the grant of a telecommunications license within two months of receiving an
appropriate application. In the event of competitive or comparative selection procedures the CRA may
extend the evaluation period for up to four months to ensure that such procedures are fair, reasonable,
open, non- discriminatory and transparent to all interested parties. The CRA will grant a license if the
applicant possesses the necessary technical competence and if there is no reason to assume that the
applicant will not provide the relevant services in accordance with the license, in particular as regards
quality and supply. In reaching its decision, the CRA takes into consideration the applicant’s financial
strength, its experience in the telecommunications sector and related sectors as well as its relevant
expertise. A licensee may transfer its license in whole or in part only with the consent of the CRA,
which defines the conditions for the transfer of the license.

_Operators with Significant Market Power_

A telecommunications operator with significant market power must allow third parties to access its
public telecommunications network or unbundled parts of such network. The obligation related to
interconnection does not apply if the CRA determines, based on evidence provided by the
telecommunications operator, that it would be inappropriate to require the operator to open its network.
A telecommunications operator with significant market power requires the CRA’s approval to provide
(i) voice telephony services via a fixed-line or mobile network and (ii) leased lines. In addition, a
telecommunications operator with significant market power in the telecommunications market is
required to provide to its competitors open and non-discriminatory access to its services, establish a
cost accounting system that assigns costs to all of its services and permits subsequent audits of this
system in compliance with the CRA rules and the provisions set out in the licenses, and provide a
minimum set of lines for lease to third parties. Such an operator is also prohibited from cross subsidizing
services and is subject to accounting separation of interconnection activities.


-----

In addition, a provider of public fixed-line telephony services that has been designated as an operator
of telecommunications with significant market power on the market of fixed-line public telephony
services must enable unbundled access to the local loop and related facilities on the basis of the
following principles: objectivity, transparency, non-discrimination and cost orientation and is subject
to price control.

_Audiovisual Media Services_

The provision of audiovisual media services is subject to a license by the CRA. Such services must be
provided on a non-discriminatory basis and in accordance with the law and the terms of the license. A
licensee may not restrict access to subscribers based on their nationality, religious beliefs, financial
strength or any other grounds nor is it entitled to make a selection of programs in a manner that favors
the interests of only one national or religious community in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The licensee is
required to offer the services to all citizens in the technical coverage zone and each person that accepts
the single and non-discriminatory conditions is entitled to enter into a subscription contract. Prior to the
inclusion of any audiovisual media service or a radio media service into a service package, the licensee
is required to obtain written consents from the owners of the program content or their authorized
representatives. The distribution of such services cannot be launched before the relevant consents have
been obtained.

A license for the provision of audiovisual media services is valid for a period of ten calendar years and
may be extended. In order to extend the term of the license, the licensee must submit a request for
extension of the license at least three-months before its expiration.
