###### WIND HELLAS’ BUSINESS

**Business Overview**

Wind Hellas is one of the three integrated communication providers in Greece with proprietary mobile
and fixed-line networks. It offers mobile and fixed-line telecommunication, high-speed internet services
and Pay-TV services under a unified brand and on a national basis to over 4.1 million subscribers.

Wind Hellas provides fixed-broadband and fixed-voice services, international roaming and VAS, and
mobile internet services to both residential and business customers and to other telecommunications
operators through its LTE, HSPA and GSM technologies. Wind Hellas offers unlimited data services
to all customers, and its mobile offering includes pre-paid and post-paid mobile services. As of
September 30, 2021, household and business accounts represented approximately 61% of total RGUs.
Wind Hellas owns one of the three proprietary mobile networks in Greece and is the third-largest mobile
provider in Greece, with more than 3.4 million mobile subscribers as of September 30, 2021. It is also
the third-largest fixed-line telephony provider. Its fixed-line offering includes fixed-line telephony and
broadband internet services, serving more than 0.6 million LLU & NGA subscribers as of September
30, 2021. Wind Hellas benefits from an extensive nationwide fiber optic network of approximately
6,162 kilometers (backbone and metropolitan access network) and approximately 600 kilometers of
fiber as part of the recently commenced NGA deployment. As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas also
benefits from 328 points of presence in its LLU and RSS network with a coverage of approximately
79% of active lines in Greece and full access to OTE’s last-mile at regulated terms. In addition, Wind
Hellas provides Pay-TV services to residential customers through its video platform, Wind Vision,
which it launched in April 2018 and had 0.1 million platform subscribers as of September 30, 2021.

Wind Hellas continuously invests in its network to support growth initiatives and enhance its service
offering. It also accelerated investments in digital service capability to take advantage of emerging
consumer behaviour patterns resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic. In December 2020, Wind Hellas
acquired 5G spectrum, which represented a significant milestone and laid the foundation for deploying
its 5G network roll-out while providing visibility on future license payments for seven years starting
from January 2024. As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas achieved 4G and 5G network coverage of
98% and 24%, respectively, of the 10.7 million population in Greece and continued investing in its fiber
network, reaching 431 thousand NGA lines deployed.

Wind Hellas has successfully scaled in the market over the past few years, and its total revenue for the
twelve months ended September 30, 2021 was €558.3 million compared to €537.4 million for the year
ended December 31, 2020. Its WH Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021
was €248.5 million compared to €245.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Going forward,
we believe Wind Hellas could leverage other growth opportunities to further improve its performance,
including through offering fixed-mobile convergence bundles, expanding its fiber network and
introducing B2B services.

**History**

Founded in 1992 as STET Hellas, Wind Hellas received its first Greek GSM license in September 1992
and launched commercial services in June 1993. In 2004, Wind Hellas was renamed TIM Hellas, and
in 2005, it was acquired by a consortium of private equity investment funds. Weather Investments
S.p.A. subsequently acquired Wind Hellas in 2007 and renamed it Wind Hellas Telecommunications
S.A. Since then, Wind Hellas has operated under the licensed brand name “WIND.”

In 2007, Wind Hellas merged with Q Telecommunications, which provided pre-paid mobile
telecommunications services, including voice, SMS and certain VAS, and had a fixed wireless access
license and a GSM license. In 2008, Wind Hellas also acquired and merged with Tellas
Telecommunications S.A., which was the first company to provide the Greek public with innovative
fixed-line telephony services, internet access services, combined services of fixed-line telephony and


-----

internet, as well as broadband services. Following the addition of fixed-line telecommunications, Wind
Hellas became a leading integrated telecommunications provider.

In 2010, Wind Hellas began to modernize its networks across Greece in cooperation with Huawei,
investing in HSPA and offering 3.5G services. In 2012, Wind Hellas entered into an exclusive
distribution agreement with Public to distribute all of its products through Public’s network. In addition,
in June 2013, Wind Hellas agreed to partner with Vodafone-Panafon S.A., a member of Vodafone
Group plc, to establish Victus Joint Operation, a 50/50 joint operation to facilitate partial sharing of its
2G, 3G and, since 2017, 4G mobile networks.

In 2015, Wind Hellas started its LTE roll-out plan, which allowed it to quickly close its 4G outdoor
coverage gap with competitors, and in 2016, it embarked on the pilot deployment of fiber roll-out. In
2017, Wind Hellas was awarded 40 Central Office trunks in dense urban areas, covering approximately
453 thousand lines for the development of NGA fiber infrastructure. Since then, Wind Hellas has been
awarded a further 35 thousand lines, which has enabled Wind Hellas to generate wholesale revenues
from leasing lines to other operators as well as benefit from more attractive owner-economics by
moving subscribers to its own network.

In 2017, Wind Hellas launched field trials for its streaming platforms and entered into an agreement
with Nova for access to premium Nova Sports channels through its video platform. The service was
officially launched in 2018, and Wind Hellas’ offering was the first multi-device video proposition in
Greece with Netflix integration. In the same year, Wind Hellas launched a new portfolio offering
bundled mobile and fixed services with an option for additional add-on services such as mobile data,
NGA fiber and Wind Vision.

In June 2020, Wind Hellas secured one mobile lot and three fixed lots in the bidding process of the
consolidated government connectivity procurement program SYZEFXIS II, which aims to provide an
upgraded digital telecommunications infrastructure to all general government entities in Greece. In
December 2020, Wind Hellas acquired 5G spectrum in the bands of 3.4-3.8GHz, 2.1GHz, 694-790MHz
and 24.25-27.56GHz.

In 2020, Wind Hellas Parent contributed Wind Hellas’ tower portfolios in Greece into Vantage Towers
Greece, an entity jointly owned by Vodafone Europe B.V. (“Vodafone”), in exchange for 38% for the
issued share capital of Vantage Towers Greece. In March 2021, Vodafone acquired the 38% share of
Wind Hellas Parent in Vantage Towers Greece and as of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas Parent has
no investment in Vantage Towers Greece.

On August 14, 2021, we signed an agreement with the Seller to acquire Crystal Almond Midco, an
indirect parent of Wind Hellas Telecommunications S.A. The Wind Hellas Acquisition was approved
by the European Commission on December 21, 2021, and we expect it to be consummated on or about
January 12, 2022.

**Products and services**

Wind Hellas provides a variety of post-paid and pre-paid services, including mobile, fixed-line
telephony, broadband internet (ADSL/NGA fiber) and Pay-TV services, tailored to the needs of both
its residential and business customers. As a fully integrated telecommunications operator, in addition
to offering its products and services on a standalone basis, Wind Hellas also offers them in bundled
packages, which provides customers with the convenience of having a single operator for their
communication and information needs. Over the years, Wind Hellas’ bundled offerings, which Wind
Hellas believes are known for their “simplicity” and “value for money,” have improved in effectiveness
and gained popularity among customers.

**_Mobile_**


-----

Wind Hellas is the third largest mobile provider in Greece, with approximately 3.4 million mobile
subscribers and a market share of approximately 21% by registered mobile subscribers in Greece, in
each case as of September 30, 2021. The Greek telecommunications market is characterized by strict
market discipline that has prevailed in recent years, particularly in the mobile post-paid and pre-paid
segments. Wind Hellas estimates it had total mobile voice usage of 9.5 billion minutes in the twelve
months ended September 30, 2021, compared to 5.1 billion minutes in 2012, reflecting its strengthening
market position.

In addition to its basic mobile telecommunications services, Wind Hellas offers VAS, including
messaging services, mobile internet access, information and entertainment multimedia services,
international roaming, as well as innovative “Internet of Things” and Cloud services. Wind Hellas also
offers a variety of mobile telephony handsets, data cards, SIM cards and accessories to its customers.

Wind Hellas provides services to its mobile subscribers through GSM/GPRS, HSPA and LTE
technology and through its “WIND” and “Q” brands.

For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas generated mobile telecommunication
services revenue of €205.4 million, representing 52% of its WH Service Revenue in the same period.

_Mobile subscriber base_

Wind Hellas’ mobile subscribers comprise subscribers of voice services (including incoming and
outgoing calls), non-voice services (including SMS, MMS and data services for handsets) and mobile
broadband services (wireless internet access through a laptop, tablet or dongle).

Wind Hellas reports the number of subscribers in its mobile business based on the number of SIM cards
in use and not the actual number of individuals or businesses using its services. Subscribers that pay in
advance for services are counted as pre-paid mobile subscribers, and subscribers that pay periodically
through a contractual agreement are counted as post-paid mobile subscribers. Pre-paid mobile
subscribers are counted in Wind Hellas’ subscriber base if they have activated one of its SIM cards in
the previous twelve months (for new subscribers) or if they have recharged their mobile telephone credit
in the previous twelve months and have not requested that their SIM card be deactivated and have not
switched to another telecommunications operator via mobile number portability during this period (for
its existing mobile subscribers) or because fraudulent activity has occurred. Post-paid mobile
subscribers are counted in Wind Hellas’ subscriber base if they have an active contract unless their SIM
card is deactivated upon their request or because fraudulent activity has occurred.

As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas had approximately 3.4 million mobile subscribers, of which
approximately 2.4 million were pre-paid mobile subscribers (registered customers).

**_Fixed-line_**

Wind Hellas’ fixed-line offering include fixed-line telephony and broadband internet services. As an
integrated operator, Wind Hellas offers comprehensive fixed-mobile convergence bundles for
consumers and businesses.

For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas generated fixed telecommunication
services revenue of €128.9 million, representing 32% of its WH Service Revenue in the same period.
LLU & NGA fiber services, a component of Wind Hellas’ fixed-line services, accounted for 29% of its
WH Service Revenue in the same period. In addition, Wind Hellas’ market share based on total LLU
& NGA fiber lines (excluding OTE) increased from approximately 23% as of September 30, 2014, to
approximately 30% as of September 30, 2021, based on Wind Hellas’ analysis of market participant
filings.


-----

For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas’ LLU & NGA subscriber base increased
by approximately 3% year-on-year to 0.6 million subscribers, while its churn rate decreased by
approximately 1% (to 12%) and outgoing ARPU decreased by €0.1, compared to the year ended
December 31, 2020.

_Fixed-line subscriber base_

Wind Hellas reports the number of subscribers in its fixed-line business based upon LLU & NGA. LLU
& NGA subscribers are counted as part of Wind Hellas’ subscriber base if they have an active contract.
All of Wind Hellas’ LLU & NGA subscribers are post-paid customers.

_Consumer Fixed_

Wind Hellas markets fixed-line telephony and broadband internet services to consumers through a
complete portfolio of tariff plans combining speed and bundled minutes options covering all household
needs. Additionally, Wind Hellas provides “value for money” personalized propositions to existing
consumers, promoting high and stable speeds achieved over NGA fiber network, upselling
entertainment service (e.g., Wind Vision) and consumer convergence household proposition through
mobile cross-selling.

Wind Hellas’ fixed consumer base reached 0.6 million subscribers as of September 30, 2021. As of
September 30, 2021, NGA fiber penetration of the consumer base increased to 44%, up by 21.1
percentage points compared to December 31, 2019, demonstrating Wind Hellas’ strategy to focus on
NGA speeds and superior internet experience, while gradually moving away from ADSL technology.
NGA lines accounted for approximately 63% of new fixed consumer additions as of September 30,
2021.

_Business Fixed_

Wind Hellas offers fixed-line telephony and broadband internet services to business customers tailored
to their needs and the relevant market segments (professional, SoHo, SMEs, large corporations and
public sector). Wind Hellas’ business product offerings include WIND Business Fiber and corporate
networking solutions, and a newly launched Cloud private branch exchange (“PBX”) proposition. In
addition, Wind Hellas also provides national and international wholesale services to telecommunication
providers, carriers, and VAS/IN services.

The NGA fiber & LLU subscriber base within Wind Hellas’ fixed-line business has been expanding
rapidly and reached 0.6 million subscribers as of September 30, 2021, while outgoing ARPU increased
to €20.9 primarily due to an increasing penetration of NGA fiber access lines.

**_Fixed-line and mobile convergence_**

Wind Hellas markets fixed-broadband internet and telephony services through a full portfolio of tariff
plans combining speed and bundled-minutes options covering all household needs. Additionally, Wind
Hellas provides “value for money” personalized propositions to existing customers, promoting high and
stable speeds achieved over NGA network, upselling its entertainment service (Wind Vision – IPTV)
and consumer convergence household proposition through mobile cross-selling. Wind Hellas’ fixedline offerings include fixed-line telephony and broadband internet offerings. As an integrated operator,
Wind Hellas offers comprehensive fixed-mobile convergence bundles for consumers and businesses.
In particular, Wind Hellas provides Greek households with a variety of bundled service offerings,
including double-play, triple-play and quadruple-play options. Its bundled services comprise mobile
and fixed-line telephony services, broadband internet services and Wind Vision, which provide
customers with the convenience of having a single provider for their communication and information
needs at a discount compared to purchasing individual services. Wind Hellas focuses on providing highend data-centric plans to its customers through its “more for more” and “unlimited” data plan strategy


-----

that are specifically tailored to the needs of Consumer Converged Households and business accounts.
Wind Hellas has developed a combined portfolio that provides substantial value and benefits and is
distinct to standalone products in line with this strategy. In particular, its “W” standalone mobile
portfolio served as a basis for the new Wind One bundled product offering with three tariff levels,
including a high-end unlimited data offer.

As of September 30, 2021, the churn rate of Wind Hellas’ Consumer Converged Household (i.e., the
sum of tax numbers with at least one consumer of mobile voice and one consumer of LLU & NGA fiber
products) was 12% compared to 18% as of December 31, 2018. Wind Hellas’ Consumer Converged
Household base and penetration rates have exhibited substantial growth since 2009. Wind Hellas’
Consumer Converged Households recently increased from approximately 230 thousand as of December
31, 2019, to approximately 273 thousand as of September 30, 2021, representing a 18% increase. In
addition, Consumer Converged Households’ average revenue per account (“ARPA”) was higher than
the sum of average standalone mobile and average standalone fixed ARPA. As of September 30, 2021,
ARPA stood at €49.7 in the Consumer Converged Households as opposed to €23.0 in the standalone
mobile product offering and to €20.8 in the standalone fixed-line product offering.

**_Wind Vision_**

Wind Hellas offers Pay-TV services to residential customers through its video platform, Wind Vision.
The video platform was launched in April 2018, offering rich content including, linear TV channels,
integrated third-party video on demand applications, as well as other unique features and functionalities
for enhanced content viewing. Wind Vision is offered through a DTT/IP hybrid set-top box, which is
WiFi and Bluetooth-enabled, 4k and HDR-capable, and runs on an Android TV platform, giving access
to more than 7,000 applications optimized for TV through the Google Play Store. The service is also
available on iOS and Android-based portable devices (smartphones and tablets), enabling a
‘multiscreen’ experience through a unified user interface. Wind Hellas is the first operator in Greece to
fully integrate Netflix into its video platform, followed by Vodafone TV; while the rest of the Pay-TV
platforms in Greece are still not certified to offer Netflix via their set top boxes. Although Netflix is
available in most of the Smart TVs, Wind Vision remains the only platform in Greece offering a fully
integrated user experience with Netflix, enabling via billing integration the capability to opt-in to the
Netflix service without using a credit card. Wind Vision offers two packages to existing or new fixedline customers, with a complete content line-up of well-known thematic linear channels. The “full”
package also includes premium sports content, through a wholesale distribution agreement for the local
Novasports channels. The factors that differentiate Wind Vision’s offering include the extensive feature
set available at launch (including popular functionalities such as ‘Voice Search’, program ‘Restart’ and
‘Catch-up’, personal cloud recordings, etc.) and a comprehensive roadmap. In 2020, Wind Hellas added
Chromecast, a web-player extending the ‘multiscreen’ experience to laptop and desktop PCs, and
upgraded its platform operating system to Android ‘P’ release. In addition, Wind Hellas entered into a
cooperation agreement with Amazon to integrate the ‘Prime Video’ application into its user interface.
In 2021, a number of additional features were added, including a Bluetooth-enabled remote control with
microphone, user-set TV program ‘Reminders’, ‘User-generated’ TV channel lists, on-screen ‘TV
Messages’. The Greek public broadcaster’s popular application ‘ERTflix’ was also fully integrated into
Wind Vision set top box.

As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas had 0.1 million video platform subscribers. Wind Hellas’ video
platform generated revenues of €4.1 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2021.

**Business divisions**

Wind Hellas provides mobile and fixed-line services throughout Greece and considers its business
operations split into three separate divisions: Consumer, Business and Wholesale.

**_Consumer_**


-----

Wind Hellas’ Consumer division comprises pre-paid mobile, post-paid mobile, fixed-line and

Wind Hellas believes that it will experience the most significant growth in its Consumer division

Despite the negative impact from the COVID-19 pandemic, Wind Hellas’ customer base in its

_Consumer pre-paid mobile services_

Wind Hellas offers pre-paid mobile services under two brands: the ‘WIND’ brand, which is the natural

Wind Hellas’ pre-paid brands are strongly focused on value management, coupled with highly effective

focus on digital capabilities via the development of state-of-the-art mobile applications, with the aim of

As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas’ customer base had 1.0 million pre-paid mobile subscribers

_Consumer post-paid mobile services_

Wind Hellas offers a wide range of post-paid mobile services. Wind Hellas’ consumer post-paid mobile

-----

most of its subscriber base to long-term contracts, with 75% of its subscriber base in contracts of at least

Wind Hellas’ Business division comprises post-paid mobile, fixed-line and broadband services. Wind

Wind Hellas’ Wholesale division comprises NGA fiber wholesale, wholesale voice, transit and

has undertaken several initiatives to strengthen its brand image and increase customer satisfaction and


-----

efficiency in recent years. In 2018, it launched a full-scale store renovation program and renovated 185
stores. The renovation program included relocating stores to more attractive locations, rationalizing the
store network footprint, optimizing overall rent expenses by taking advantage of real estate
opportunities, and implementing a frontline IT system upgrade and integration to enable best-in-class
CRM activities. Moreover, Wind Hellas made significant investments to create an NGA fiber and Wind
Vision-related section within its shops to promote its new product offerings. On the back of all these
initiatives, sales generated from Wind stores have increased to an average monthly contribution of 70%
of Wind Hellas’ total sales in the year ended December 31, 2020. In 2020, while Wind Stores remained
open despite the lockdown measures implemented in Greece in response to the COVID-19 pandemic,
they have collectively experienced a drop in traffic of approximately 25%. However, this was
counterbalanced by improved sales conversion rates (i.e., the ratio between successful sales and
customer visits at Wind stores), resulting in a 10% increase in annual sales, which has kept Wind stores
sales contribution at 70% of overall sales.

**_Stores of Public_**

In 2012, Wind Hellas entered into a 15-year exclusive commercial agreement with Public to distribute
products and services through its stores in Greece.

Public is a major retailer in Greece for smartphones and tablets and TVs, with a fast-growing electronics
distribution online network platform, offering a wide selection of products including audio, video,
books, computing and mobile. As of September 30, 2021, Public operated a network of 52 stores in
Greece covering all major cities. Wind Hellas’ key priority is to develop its fixed and TV propositions
further through the network of Public, taking advantage of its high traffic and TV hardware sales, with
a particular focus on innovative and appealing bundle offers. In 2020, this retail channel was negatively
impacted by the lockdown measures implemented in Greece in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
For a significant portion of the year, retail stores remained closed or were impacted by restrictive
shopping measures, which resulted in a drop in its sales contribution, which however was absorbed by
sales via online channels.

**_Online sales and digital activities_**

Wind Hellas’ online sales and digital CRM initiatives have increased in recent years and have driven
its online presence and enhanced customer experience. Online pre-paid top-up revenue increased by
24% for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, with online top-ups comprising 27% of its total
pre-paid recharge revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 compared to 22% and 15%
in the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively.

Wind Hellas has also developed a so-called “Phygital” channel, combining features of both digital and
physical sales channels by allowing customers to respond to social media digital campaigns with a
“click-to-call” request and receive a call-back from an outbound telesales agent to service their requests,
completing the relevant application and sending the contract for signature. Wind Hellas significantly
accelerated its online customer acquisition both on a digital basis and through inbound “click-to-call”
traffic through its Phygital channel. Digital and Phygital channels combined accounted for
approximately 10% of Wind Hellas’ overall post-paid sales in the nine months ended September 30,
2021, compared to approximately 5% and 3% in the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019,
respectively.

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, in 2020, the Phygital channel was ramped up by expanding
online campaigns on affiliated partners’ website sites, to counterbalance the drop in sales of its doorto-door sales channels, which were negatively impacted by the lockdown measures implemented in
Greece. Sales from affiliated partners’ websites represented approximately 52% of Wind Hellas’ total
digital and Phygital sales and 5% of its overall sales for the nine months ended September 30, 2021. In
connection with the re-opening of Wind Hellas’ door-to-door channels following the ease of the


-----

lockdown measures, Wind Hellas’ overall sales capacity increased compared to before the beginning
of the pandemic.

**Branding and marketing Branding**

Wind Hellas operates under the “WIND” name and brand under a license agreement with Wind
Telecomunicazioni S.p.A. The “WIND” brand was established in June 2007 and nowadays represents
one of the key players in the Greek telecommunication market. In recent years, Wind Hellas has
succeeded in enhancing its brand image and is becoming acknowledged as a dynamic and daring brand.
Wind Hellas positions itself as a trusted and fully integrated telecommunication operator with a holistic
product offering and a differentiated brand experience, built around the performance, trust and
reputation of the WIND brand.

**Customer service**

Wind Hellas has developed a simplified user-friendly product and service offering and a customer
service platform that enables it to offer best-in-class customer experience.

Wind Hellas focuses continuously on improving its customer service to further increase customer
satisfaction and decrease churn rates. Wind Hellas has dedicated teams that proactively manage
relationships with customers. It has refined its customer service processes within the last few years
across all of its divisions and currently monitors all customer service performance measures closely. In
particular, Wind Hellas has invested in upgrading its call center, installed natural languageunderstanding systems to optimize call routing and introduced self-care web services to enhance the
online customer experience. As a result, in recent years the number of total incoming calls has declined,
the average handling time of incidents has improved, and the number of repeat calls has declined in line
with an increase in first-call resolution.

In 2020, Wind Hellas’ call center exhibited high levels of customer satisfaction in terms of overall call
center experience, with “effective response” being its key positive differentiating factor. Moreover,
Wind Hellas has significantly improved its customer satisfaction across all segments and as of
December 31, 2020, its overall customer satisfaction level for consumer and business segments as well
as for technical support was 91%. In 2020, Wind Hellas had to transition all of its customer care agents
from an on-premises to a work-from-home set-up due to the COVID-19 pandemic. At the same time, it
managed to improve all the most important customer care KPIs by introducing a flexible cooperation
system between inbound customer care teams and outbound saving teams to handle call volume spikes
using an organized system of same-day call-backs. As a result, Wind Hellas is now able to sustain a
30% work-from-home set-up, whereby agents rotate on a weekly basis between work-from-home and
on-premises, which unlocks significant cost savings.

In 2020, Wind Hellas established an asynchronous digital chat team, which shows improved
productivity compared to phone agents and presently handles approximately 15,000 chats per month.
During the year, Wind Hellas expanded this team through a blended agents initiative (permitting both
phone and digital chats) which presently uses Facebook’s messenger platform, but can be expanded to
include Viber and other OTTs. To improve business continuity, decrease disruption risks and reduce
operating expenses, Wind Hellas also established a complimentary customer care team outside of
Greece, which accounts for approximately 25% of total calls.

**Network and facilities**

Wind Hellas has made significant investments in its mobile network over the years despite the economic
difficulties of Greece, and currently owns a complete spectrum portfolio. Starting in 2010, Wind Hellas
began upgrading its mobile network to Huawei’s SRAN equipment. In addition, the Victus Joint
Operation has been providing Wind Hellas with a solid platform to expand and improve its 2G/3G/4G
coverage, improve quality and generate significant cost savings and operating expense reductions
compared to expanding the network independently.


-----

In 2011, Wind Hellas renewed its rights to use GSM 900 MHz frequencies. In 2014, it also acquired
800 MHz and 2600 MHz frequencies, followed by a fast LTE roll-out. In November 2017, Wind Hellas
renewed its rights to use 1,800 MHz and was assigned three lots of 2x5 MHz for a total amount of €59.1
million, for a duration of 17 years and 10 months. In February 2017, the NTPC completed the
assignment procedure for the 26 GHz spectrum. Wind Hellas was assigned a license for one block of
2x56 MHz for a total amount of €1.0 million, for a duration of 15 years. In December 2020, Wind
Hellas acquired 5G spectrum, which represented a significant milestone and laid the foundation for
deploying its 5G network roll-out while providing visibility on future license payments for seven years
starting from January 2024.

Wind Hellas expanded its LTE sites from approximately 200 as of December 31, 2014, to more than
3,141 LTE sites as of September 30, 2021. These upgrades have expanded coverage and improved
network quality, as evidenced by the decrease in the number of calls dropped while effectively reducing
the operational costs of its network. As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas estimates that its 5G
network covered approximately 24%, its 4G network covered 98%, its 3G network covered 95% and
its 2G network covered 99% of the approximately 10.7 million population of Greece, and Wind Hellas
has sufficiently addressed the coverage gap compared to its competitors.

Wind Hellas’ network architecture provides a solid base for quality service. DWDM backbone network
interconnects all major locations of its core network, supporting the evolution to full IP transport, and
the backbone transmission network employs approximately 5,450 kilometers of high resilience ring
structured fiber optic cables across Greece. Wind Hellas currently has an efficient and fully resilient
optical backbone network that fully covers its IP transport needs for both fixed-line and mobile
broadband services. It also has the potential to evolve to support even higher bandwidth needs. Wind
Hellas’ core network is modernized and fully supports its current and planned IP and LTE requirements.
As of September 30, 2021, approximately 600 kilometers of fiber was built as part of its NGA fiber
optic deployment.

On the fixed-line front, Wind Hellas benefits from approximately 328 points of presence in its LLU and
RSS network with a coverage of approximately 79% of active lines in Greece and full access to OTE’s
last-mile at regulated terms, in each case as of September 30, 2021.

Following the decision of the NTPC on the VDSL Vectoring plan in 2017, Wind Hellas was awarded
40 Central Office trunks in dense urban areas, covering approximately 453 thousand lines for the
development of NGA fiber infrastructure using FTTC Super Vectoring 35b and FttH/GPON
technologies. Since 2019, Wind Hellas was assigned an additional scope of approximately 35 thousand
lines by the NTPC, reaching a total of approximately 488 thousand vectoring lines. At the same time,
Wind Hellas deploys an extended (unregulated) FttH network in the inner ring of its Central Offices,
covering approximately 115 thousand lines. Wind Hellas estimates to cover almost 97% of active lines
using FttC/VDSL Super Vectoring and FttH/GPON technologies.

Wind Hellas manages to maintain network availability and network accessibility at very high levels as
a result of careful capacity planning and prudent site selection for directed expansion.

**_Mobile overview_**

Wind Hellas’ network is sufficiently versatile to support its VAS while simultaneously meeting
increased traffic demands and performance requirements. Its mobile network currently offers mobile
consumer services, such as voice, SMS, MMS and data services in all radio access network
technologies. Wind Hellas’ newly modernized network uses dual Carrier High Speed Downlink Packet
Access (“HSDPA”), LTE Carrier Aggregation and 5G ENDC (E-UTRAN New Radio – Dual
Connectivity) Radio Access Technology.

**_Radio network_**

Wind Hellas’ radio network has evolved to an SRAN architecture, having replaced all 2G Ericsson and
3G Nokia Siemens Network legacy base transceiver stations with Huawei’s multi-technology (SRAN)
equipment. As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas reached 3,342 unique macro base station locations
throughout Greece. Wind Hellas’ RAN modernization started in 2010 and was bolstered in 2014
primarily due to the Victus Joint Operation, which brought capacity expansion, the addition of new
functionalities and the enhancement of Wind Hellas’ network infrastructure. This modernization was
also supported by the latest generation radio access technologies, namely single cabinet/SRAN
equipment and 3G coverage expansion, with new broadband offerings (42 Mbps). Wind Hellas’ RAN
modernization project has facilitated spectrum re-farming and the deployment of the LTE 800MHz,
LTE 1800MHz and LTE 2600MHz spectrum bands. Since 2014, L1800 re-farming has been initiated
on 5 MHz and starting in 2016, L1800 re-farming to 10 MHz has been extended to the rest of its
network. Wind Hellas also uses LTE Carrier Aggregation and in 2020, it introduced 5G technology on
the newly acquired 2100MHz and 3600MHz spectrum bands. ENDC technologies used by Wind Hellas
are enabled to support up to 1.5G and 4.4G carriers aggregation while the Dynamic Spectrum Sharing
(DSS) functionality is enabled on the 2100MHz spectrum band to support both 4G and 5G data services.
In addition, Wind Hellas introduced 4x4 antenna Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) functionality
on its mid-bands to further enhance its data coverage and capacity while introducing high order 64x64
MIMO at 3600MHz.

_Mobile transmission_

Wind Hellas continued to modernize its transmission network and radio network. Approximately 80
kilometers of fiber optic network (“MAN”) interconnects with its master locations (i.e., where there is
a core network presence). In addition, Wind Hellas uses circuits over DWDM to provide the required
intra-connectivity between remote core network locations.


-----

Backbone network consists of a combination of DWDM circuits and a high nationwide capacity (trunk)
microwave links (approximately 210) utilizing SDH or pure IP.

An extended transmission microwave access and aggregation network presently contains over 3,300
microwave links. In addition to microwave access, Wind Hellas utilizes MAN for sites connectivity.
As of September 30, 2021, approximately 585 sites are backhauled through fiber and IP MPLS
equipment (140 in point of connection (“POC”) locations and 445 FttS). IP MPLS network is deployed
in the core network nodes (28 IP MPLS nodes) and in the nodes that concentrate high traffic volume
(about 115 POC locations, with approximately 140 nodes) and finally in the FttS locations servicing
the site traffic (approximately 275 nodes).

_Mobile core and VAS network overview_

Wind Hellas has also developed its split architecture mobile circuit switch to include more capabilities
and a more modern network design. In 2020, it completed the transformation of the former network of
eight mobile switching servers (“MSS”) nodes and 12 Media Gateways (“MGWs”) to four new MSS
blade cluster technology nodes and eight MGWs.

All circuit switching core functionalities have been consolidated into the MSS blade cluster technology.
For subscriber management, Wind Hellas uses Ericsson’s modernized User Data Consolidation
(“UDC”). UDC enables centralization based on Data Layered Architecture. This provides a centralized
subscriber data repository to different applications (CUDB) while the business logic runs on front-end
entities. The legacy home location registry (HLR) function for 2G/3G subscribers and the High-Speed
Synchronization (HSS) function for 4G subscribers are currently running over front-end logic.

Furthermore, Wind Hellas developed an IP Multimedia System (“IMS”) network serving both mobile
(through the “Voice over LTE” service) and fixed-line subscribers. The Voice over LTE service is
commercially viable since 2019 and subscribers are gradually migrating on it. In addition, Wind Hellas’
“Voice over Wifi” Service introduction is ongoing and is expected to be launched in the fourth quarter
of 2021.

Wind Hellas’ mobile data network is deployed over Ericsson’s legacy Evolved Packet Core (“EPC”)
solution, which is a triple-access core supporting GPRS, Wideband Code Division Multiple Access
(WCDMA) and LTE simultaneously. The EPC offers an optimized network architecture, which, in
combination with LTE technology, results in higher bit rates, faster throughput, and lower latency. Since
the end of 2020, the EPC network has been configured to benefit from 5G capabilities, for example,
even higher bit rates. Wind Hellas’ mobile data network is geo-redundant, physically deployed in two
different sites in Athens. Additionally, it has been recently upgraded to support narrowband-“Internet
of Things” technology.

_VAS network_

Wind Hellas provides VAS services to subscribers (SMS, MMS, voice mailbox, etc.). Moreover, the
Ericsson NGIN platform offers mobile and fixed intelligent network services, such as maximum call
duration, premium numbers, dynamic international routing and location dependent services.

**_Fixed-line and core network_**

Wind Hellas’ fixed-line network provides voice and internet services to subscribers and corporate
customers. Wind Hellas has local equipment in OTE’s local sites across Greece for voice and internet
capabilities providing high bandwidth rates to end-users. Wind Hellas’ fiber optic access network
interconnects the majority of physical sites (200), while 94 are backhauled via leased lines and 34 via
microwave radio links. Wind Hellas offers “Voice over Broadband” (“VoBB”) and internet service with
high bandwidth rates to end-users by ADSL2+, VDSL2, and SHDSL technologies. In addition to the


-----

expanded LLU Network, in 2017, Wind Hellas started the deployment of its NGA fiber network for
ultra-high speeds utilizing vectoring techniques and GPON networks.

All of Wind Hellas’ fixed-line voice services are currently served by a common IMS system that offers
geo-redundancy and high availability. The common IMS system, which also serves mobile Voice over
LTE services, is deployed in four sites in Athens and Thessaloniki (two sites in Athens and two sites in
Thessaloniki). Fixed-voice services offered to Wind Hellas’ customers are old black line voice/LLU,
VoBB/NGA residential, SoHo, SME customers and Integrated Services Digital Network Primary Rate
Interface (“ISDN-PRI”) and SIP Trunking. At the end of 2019, Wind Hellas introduced the
Cisco/Broadworks servers’ platform, integrated with the IMS system to provide unified communication
and Cloud PBX services launched in April 2020. The Cisco/Broadworks platform is also used to host
Fixed ISDN-PRI (E1) Services, which until the third quarter of 2020 were served through legacy Timedivision multiplexing switches.

**_Fixed-line transmission and IP backbone_**

Implemented in 2008, the DWDM backbone network connects all major locations of Wind Hellas’ core
network. Its transmission backbone network benefits from an extensive fiber optic deployment of
approximately 5,450 kilometers, including approximately 1,900 kilometers of exchanges with Nova
and Vodafone Greece. The DWDM network is implemented nationwide. A significant portion of this
network, namely in the Peloponnese area and west backbone Athens-Thessaloniki, is currently capable
of providing up to 88λ of 100G each, while 44λ are installed. The rest part of backbone network – east
backbone Athens-Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki-Alexandroupoli and Chania-Heraklio in Crete – is
implemented with legacy DWDM equipment, capable of providing up to multiple λ(16, 32, 48) of
10/100G capacity. The initial DWDM modernization plan is scheduled to be completed in 2022 and the
remaining portions of the network are expected to be modernized according to traffic growth needs.
This is expected to lead to a unified NG-DWDM network, capable of supporting 100G and 200G circuit
with efficiency and cost effectiveness, given protection capability and high network availability. High
capacity circuits (STM 16, 1G, 10G and 100G) are activated through DWDM network, addressing the
needs of core fixed-line and mobile networks as well as corporate and wholesale. A legacy SDH
network is also implemented over the same optical fiber network (over DWDM), but has been gradually
reduced and is expected to be dismantled in the coming years.

Wind Hellas’ IP backbone network consists of a next-generation transport network of routers and
switches able to support converged voice and data services over IP and is a fully redundant network
based on IP MPLS technology. Wind Hellas’ core network in Athens and Thessaloniki has been recently
modernized to support high-density 100G connectivity, while the modernization of the network in
Patras and Larissa is in progress and is expected to be completed by the end of 2021. New equipment
from Nokia is replacing the existing Juniper nodes. The IP backbone offers layer three and layer two
services for both its fixed-line and mobile networks.

Wind Hellas’ metro Ethernet network offers data services to its fixed-line subscribers. It is a fully
redundant network based on 100G fiber optic technology and is deployed in two metro core and six
metro aggregation sites in Athens. Metro Ethernet services are also available in Thessaloniki, Patras,
Kalamata, Larissa and Crete.

A fully modernized metro Ethernet network is available in Thessaloniki, Kalamata and Tripoli, using
state-of-the-art network equipment from Cisco Systems. Wind Hellas has also recently redesigned the
metro aggregation network in Larissa, Patra and Crete to support traffic growth and improve network
availability. Wind Hellas is also in the process of redesigning its metro access network across Greece
by extending MPLS to the access to increase capacity, improve operational efficiency and support new
services.

Wind Hellas’ OSS environment includes numerous applications, each responsible for their own part of
the business’ operation. OSS applications are function-specific and are used for technical customer


-----

support such as incident management and intelligent workflows that drive troubleshooting actions.
Being focused on the network and services, Wind OSS applications are used by network planners,
service designers, service operations, network operations, network engineering teams and technical
customer support.

**_Network strategy_**

Wind Hellas’ mobile network strategy is tailored to accommodate the increasing demand for data in the
mobile market. Wind Hellas’ goal is to be a first-tier operator in terms of network quality, with a primary
focus on 4G Carrier Aggregation and 5G. Wind Hellas has significantly increased its coverage in rural
and urban areas with lower costs by network sharing through the Victus Joint Operation with Vodafone
Greece. Under the Victus Joint Operation, Wind Hellas shares approximately 100% of rural sites and
approximately 60% of urban sites, which will provide a net gain of over 800 locations by project
completion compared to 2014.

Following the successful spectrum auction in 2014, Wind Hellas uses the acquired 800MHz band as a
key element of its strategy for quickly extending LTE coverage across Greece. Wind Hellas uses the
1800MHz band as a coverage and capacity layer while the 2600MHz band is primarily used for
capacity. Through its network-sharing project, Wind Hellas not only strengthened its 2G (900/1800
MHz) and 3G (2100MHz) footprint in line with competitors, but also leveraged its nationwide LTE
deployment. Following the successful 5G spectrum auction in 2020, Wind Hellas’ plans to fully utilize
its mid-bands (1800MHz, 2100MHz and 2600MHz) to maximize its 4G/5G capacity and 5G coverage
while continuing its frequency re-farming project (gradual for 1800MHz and via 3G shutdown for the
2100MHz) to adequately meet the rising demand for data traffic. Moreover, 5G at 3600MHz is deployed
on selected areas of commercial interest offering excellent data services, while 5G at 700MHz is mainly
deployed at rural areas for wide 5G coverage. As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas has established
over 350 5G sites.

Since November 2017, Wind Hellas has started deploying NGA and offering related ultra-fast
broadband service to its customers. Wind Hellas believes that its NGA fibre investment will support
the change of its position in the fixed-line market, driven by an increase in the number of high-speed
customers. At the same time, Wind Hellas aims to introduce flexibility in its technology mix to
maximize its return on investment.

Wind Hellas has completed the modernization of several elements of its network infrastructure
including its mobile voice circuit-switch core and is in the process to complete the first phase of its
DWDM network. It has deployed IMS, migrating customers and interconnections from TDM to IP and
has introduced VoLTE. In the coming years, Wind Hellas plans to continue with the modernization of
its IP core network, its VAS systems, its Domain Name Systems (DNS) and the rest DWDM,
introducing new features and capabilities.

Wind Hellas also plans to introduce a 5G standalone (SA) network architecture through Ericsson 5GC
nodes. Through the introduction of Network Functions Virtualization (NFV) Cloud, Wind Hellas aims
towards the gradual “cloudification” of its network and the introduction of increasingly intelligent and
more closed-loop and data-driven OSS solutions to achieve operational efficiency and maximize
customer experience. This is combined with its data center strategy to concentrate the core controlling
elements (control plane) in two sites and payload network elements (user plane) to two more sites, while
the remaining owned sites will be used as radio and transmission only concentration points. This data
center strategy is expected to lead to network optimization and operating expenses savings through the
optimization of four owned sites and the evacuation of two rented sites, one of which was finalized in
2021, while the other is to follow in 2022.

Through various pilot projects, Wind Hellas investigates additional options for Fixed Wireless Access
(FWA) while its network strategy is also focused on the growing demand for “Internet of Things” and


-----

vertical solutions, and it seeks to actively prepare the organization for large-scale projects such as 5G
corridors and smart power meters.

**The Vantage Towers Disposal**

In December 2020, Wind Hellas Parent, the direct shareholder of Wind Hellas Telecommunications
S.A., contributed Wind Hellas Telecommunications S.A.’s tower portfolios in Greece, comprising
approximately 5,200 towers, into Vantage Towers Greece, an entity jointly owned by Vodafone, in
exchange for 38% for the issued share capital of Vantage Towers Greece and an aggregate payment of
€112.5 million from Vodafone. Through the Vantage Towers Disposal, Wind Hellas unlocked
significant value in its infrastructure, secured the long-term maintenance and development of its passive
tower assets and at the same time strengthened its active network sharing agreement with Vodafone
Greece. In March 2021, Vodafone acquired the 38% share of Wind Hellas Parent in Vantage Towers
Greece for a consideration of €287.5 million, which, together with the aggregate payment of €112.5
million made by Vodafone, brought the total value received by Wind Hellas Parent for the Vantage
Tower Disposal to €400.0 million. As of September 30, 2021, Wind Hellas Parent has no investment in
Vantage Towers Greece. As part of the Vantage Towers Disposal, Wind Hellas and Vodafone signed a
new long-term MSA, with an initial term of eight years, which can be extended, subject to certain
conditions, to a maximum of 32 years. Under the MSA, Vantage Towers Greece will be the preferred
supplier of new towers for Wind Hellas and Vodafone Greece, each of which has agreed to commit as
an anchor tenant on 250 new sites (500 in total) to be built by Vantage Towers Greece over five years
which started from November 17, 2020.

For more details on the Vantage Towers Disposal, please refer to “Wind Hellas’ Management’s
_Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting_
_Comparability of Wind Hellas’ Results of Operations—The Vantage Towers Disposal.”_

**The Victus Joint Operation**

In 2014, Wind Hellas and Vodafone-Panafon S.A., a member of Vodafone Group plc, established
Victus Joint Operation. The main objective of this 50/50 joint operation is to manage the radio access
and transmission networks (RAN) of its parent companies and implement a partial active radio network
sharing (RAN sharing) to facilitate partial sharing of 2G, 3G and 4G mobile networks, mostly in rural
and limited urban areas of Greece. The Victus Joint Operation started its operations the same year, with
the first shared sites established at the end of 2014. The sharing project between Vodafone Greece and
Wind Hellas’ rural and urban networks is expected to be completed in 2022, after which each party will
maintain independent spectrum usage. Following the Vantage Towers Disposal, Wind Hellas has also
put in place a five-year framework for cooperation with respect to a shared 4G/5G network
modernization and coverage enhancement.

**Fiber Asset Separation**

On January 3, 2021, Wind Hellas transferred its fiber network business, including its 6,162 kilometers
fiber optic network and certain other related assets, and related wholesale activities by way of demerger
into FiberCo, a newly established and separate subsidiary of Crystal Almond Midco. We estimate the
fiber network business contributed €10.2 million to WH Adjusted EBITDAaL for the twelve months
ended September 30, 2021, and €5.4 million to WH Last Two Quarter Adjusted EBITDAaL basis for
September 30, 2021.

Following completion of the carve-out of Wind Hellas’ fiber assets and in order to fund the fiber rollout, FiberCo, as borrower, will enter into a senior term loan facility providing loans for an aggregate
amount of up to €92 million (up to 50% of which will be provided through the European Commission’s
Recovery and Resilience Facility) and a revolving credit facility for the issuance of letters of guarantees
and/or letters of credit for an aggregate amount up to €16 million (which combined amount shall not
exceed an aggregate amount of €100 million) with Eurobank S.A. and certain other financial
institutions, as lenders, and Wind Hellas Parent, as third party security provider. For a description of


-----

this financing, please refer to “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Wind Hellas’ Fiber
_Assets Financing.” FiberCo is an Unrestricted Subsidiary under the Bridge Facilities and therefore is_
not subject to the covenants included therein. On the Wind Hellas Acquisition Closing Date, FiberCo
is expected to be designated as an Unrestricted Subsidiary under the existing Indentures and the Existing
Revolving Credit Facility, and therefore not to be subject to the covenants therein. In addition, FiberCo
will be an Unrestricted Subsidiary under the SSN Indenture and therefore will not be subject to the
covenants included therein.

**Information technology systems and infrastructure**

Wind Hellas’ information IT systems and infrastructure are designed and built based on its enterprise
architecture principles. These principles are founded on client experience and the build-up of a digital
ecosystem that embraces modern development and integration environments, automation and controls
to ensure continuity, integrity and availability of data and applications assets. Wind Hellas’ IT
infrastructure is a major enabler for its company-wide simplification and digital transformation
initiatives, including the simplification and rationalization of its product offerings.

Wind Hellas’ IT systems comprise a large number of applications split into the following broad
categories: (i) systems of engagement (“SoE”) or front office systems, focused on ensuring a seamless
and secure customer experience, including web, iOS and Android applications, dealers and shop
systems, eBill and eCare applications, and internal supporting systems; (ii) systems of record (“SoR”)
or business systems, including state-of-the-art and continuously evolving platforms for CRM, order
management, billing and provisioning, enterprise resource planning (ERP), enterprise application
integration (EAI), real-time credit risk, fraud management & prevention and revenue assurance,; (iii)
systems of insights (“SoI”), integrating data from SoE and SoR and analyzing them to produce
meaningful insights for use by Wind Hellas’ commercial, marketing and customer support teams, as
well as for decisions spanning from product management to operations support; and (iv) systems of
trust (“SoT”) focused on security, authentication and authorization processes ensuring compliance with
applicable laws, guidelines, best practices and regulatory requirements. All Wind Hellas’ IT
applications and software are based on leading industry platforms and systems built and supported by
vendors such as Ericsson, IBM, Intec, SAP, Oracle/Siebel, Microsoft, HP, Comptel and EMC.

Wind Hellas’ IT landscape enables it to connect to third-party and “Internet of Things” platforms, as
needed, to ensure that new functionalities and services are easily and seamlessly implemented. This
ability supports Wind Hellas’ plans to expand its services to areas and applications developed as part
of the 5G-enabled capabilities and ecosystem. Wind Hellas’ databases are largely based on Oracle and
it is migrating to Oracle’s newest platform, Exadata, which offers superior performance, the highest
availability, simplified management and a secure-by-design concept with encryption enabled by default.
Wind Hellas is implementing an IT modernization roadmap that will involve all of its IT systems and
applications, including new generation cloud-based systems.

**Compensation of Senior Management**

We typically enter into consultancy or advisory agreements with senior management members,
primarily through holding companies owned by them, pursuant to which they are entitled to certain
consultancy fees, which form part of the aggregate compensation paid to our senior management
members. Alternatively, from time to time, we enter into direct employment agreements with senior
management members. The aggregate compensation paid in the year ended December 31, 2020 to our
directors was €4.0 million, consisting of fixed salary, annual consultancy fees and performance related
components (which may include certain ESG criteria).

**Corporate Compliance**

We and our operating subsidiaries follow a global anti-corruption policy, a trade sanctions policy, and
an acquisition due diligence policy. These policies are aimed at facilitating our compliance with
applicable anti- corruption and trade sanctions laws and regulations that apply by virtue of our


-----

geographical operations. Our acquisition due diligence policy sets out a framework for anti-corruption,
trade sanctions, and anti-money laundering diligence procedures for our add-on acquisitions, and we
have retained specialist legal counsel on a number of occasions to review proposed acquisitions from a
corruption and sanctions perspective. We also have procedures regarding conducting appropriate risk
based due diligence before retaining third-party service providers, ranging from catering firms to
technical contractors and business consultants.

Our policies are maintained by our internal legal department. We also retain specialist counsel to assist
with compliance diligence on material acquisitions. Moreover, from time to time when we are
considering entering into a roaming agreement or other contract with a service provider in a geography
that poses heightened trade sanctions risk, we engage specialist compliance counsel to review the
opportunity, consistent with our policies and legal obligations.

###### PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS

The Issuer is an indirect, wholly-owned subsidiary of Adria Topco, which was the entity directly
acquired in the United Group Acquisition, and following the United Group Acquisition, BC Partners
LLP indirectly (through wholly or majority owned intermediate holding companies) controls the Issuer.
See “Summary—Summary Corporate and Financing Structure.” As of the date of this offering
memorandum, BC Partners owns approximately 56% of Summer Parent S.à r.l., senior management
owns approximately 41%, EBRD owns approximately 2% and DG Management DWC-LLC owns
approximately 1%.

BC Partners is a leading alternative global investment firm focused on private equity, credit, and real
estate, that is currently investing its eleventh flagship private equity fund. BC Partners is one of the
most experienced private equity firms in Europe and has continually operated for over three decades as
a pan-European partnership with a strong presence in North America. BC Partners currently advises 11
successive funds, and since inception has completed 124 private equity investments representing €161
billion of enterprise value across 18 countries. BC Partners operates across four core sectors including
Industrial & Business Services, consumer & retail, healthcare and TMT and employs an investment
team of 67 professionals with over 540 years of combined private equity experience operating from
four offices: New York, London, Paris and Hamburg.

**Shareholders’ Agreement**

In connection with the United Group Acquisition, Summer Invest S.à r.l., an indirect parent of the
Issuer, entered into a shareholders agreement with its co-investors (the “Shareholders’ Agreement”).
The Shareholders’ Agreement (as amended from time to time) governs various rights of Summer Invest
S.à r.l., Gerrard Enterprises LLC, Gerrard MIP Limited and Cable Management Company Ltd. in
relation to, inter alia, their shareholding in Summer Parent S.à r.l and its direct and indirect subsidiaries.
Pursuant to the Shareholders’ Agreement, Summer Invest S.à r.l. is entitled to appoint or remove a
majority of the board of directors of Summer Parent S.à r.l. The Shareholders’ Agreement requires that
certain specified actions in relation to Summer Parent S.à r.l. and its direct and indirect subsidiaries may
not take place without the consent of each of Gerrard Enterprises LLC and Cable Management
Company Ltd (in each case for such time as certain shareholding thresholds in the securities of Summer
Parent S.à r.l. are met). These include amendments to the organizational documents that would have an
adverse effect on Gerrard Enterprises LLC or Cable Management Company Ltd. in a manner which is
disproportionate to any other holders of securities in Summer Parent S.à r.l., certain amendments to the
rights attaching to the shares in Summer Parent S.à r.l., the adoption of any material change to the
business plan of Adria Topco and any voluntary liquidation or bankruptcy of Summer Parent S.à r.l or
its direct or indirect subsidiaries, including Adria Topco.

**Senior Secured Bridge Facility Agreement**

The Issuer, as borrower, entered into a senior secured bridge facility agreement on January 7, 2022,
among, inter alios, J.P. Morgan AG, as agent, and UniCredit AG, London Branch, as security agent
(the “Senior Secured Bridge Facility Agreement”). The committed amounts of €630 million and €350
million are expected to be funded, respectively, under the Senior Secured Fixed Rate Bridge Facility
and the Senior Secured Floating Rate Bridge Facility, prior to the Wind Hellas Acquisition Closing
Date.

On or about the Wind Hellas Acquisition Closing Date, the Issuer will use the proceeds from the Bridge
Facilities, together with cash on hand and amounts borrowed under the Existing Revolving Credit
Facility and/or certain working capital or local facilities, to (i) pay, directly or indirectly, the cash
consideration for the acquisition of the Target in connection with the Wind Hellas Acquisition, which
is expected to occur on or about January 12, 2022, (ii) refinance certain existing net indebtedness of
Wind Hellas (including the Wind Hellas Indebtedness Refinancing) and (iii) pay transaction costs
associated with the Wind Hellas Acquisition, the Acquisition Financing and the Wind Hellas
Indebtedness Refinancing. See “Summary—The Transactions—The Financing of the Wind Hellas
_Acquisition and the Wind Hellas Indebtedness Refinancing.”_

On or about the Issue Date, the entirety of borrowings under the Senior Secured Bridge Facility
Agreement are expected to be repaid at par, including accrued and unpaid interest, with the proceeds
from the Offering and cash on hand. See “Use of Proceeds” and _“Plan of Distribution—Other_
_Relationships.”_

**_Ranking_**

The Existing Notes are senior obligations of the Issuer, secured by their respective Collateral (as defined
in the respective Indentures) on a first-priority basis (subject to certain exceptions), along with
obligations under the other Existing Notes and the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement
(subject to certain exceptions); senior in right of payment to any indebtedness of the Issuer that is
expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Existing Notes; effectively senior in right of payment
of any existing or future unsecured obligations of the Issuer; unconditionally guaranteed on a senior
secured basis by the Guarantors thereof (subject to certain limitations); effectively subordinated to any
existing or future indebtedness of the Issuer and its subsidiaries that is secured by property and assets
that do not secure the Existing 2024 SSNs (subject to certain limitations); and structurally subordinated
to any existing or future indebtedness of the subsidiaries of the Issuer that do not guarantee the
respective Existing Notes.

**_Interest Rates, Payment Dates and Maturity_**

_Existing 2024 SSNs_

The Existing 2024 SSNs bear interest at a rate of 4.875% per annum. Interest on the Existing 2024 SSNs
is payable semi-annually in arrears on January 15 and July 15 of each year, which commenced on
January 15, 2018. The Existing 2024 SSNs will mature on July 1, 2024.

_Existing 2025 FRNs_

The Existing 2025 FRNs bear interest at a per annum rate equal to three-month EURIBOR (as defined
in the 2019 Indenture and which is subject to a zero floor and re set quarterly), plus 4.125%, as
determined by a calculation agent. Interest on the Existing 2025 FRNs is payable quarterly in arrears
on February 15, May 15, August 15 and November 15 of each year, commencing on August 15, 2019.
The Existing 2025 FRNs will mature on May 15, 2025.

_Existing 2026 SSNs_


-----

The Existing 2026 SSNs bear interest at a rate of 3.125% per annum. Interest on the Existing 2026 SSNs
is payable semi-annually in arrears on August 15 and February 15 of each year, which commenced on
August 15, 2020. The Existing 2026 SSNs will mature on February 15, 2026.

_Existing 2026 FRNs_

The Existing 2026 FRNs bear interest at a per annum rate equal to three-month EURIBOR (as defined
in the 2020 Indenture and which is subject to a zero floor and re set quarterly), plus 3.25%, as determined
by a calculation agent. Interest on the Existing 2026 FRNs is payable quarterly in arrears on February
15, May 15, August 15 and November 15 of each year, commencing on May 15, 2020. The Existing
2026 FRNs will mature on February 15, 2026.

**_Guarantees_**

The Existing Notes are guaranteed on a senior basis by certain guarantors. The guarantee of each such
guarantor is a senior obligation of that guarantor and is secured by the collateral (as described below)
on a first-priority basis (subject to certain exceptions) along with obligations under the Existing
Revolving Credit Facility. Each such guarantee of the Existing Notes is subordinated in right of payment
to all existing and future senior debt of that guarantor that is secured by property and assets that do not
secure such guarantee, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness,
and is senior in right of payment to any future subordinated indebtedness of such guarantor. The
guarantees of the Existing Notes are subject to certain limitations under applicable law.

**_Security_**

The Existing Notes and the related guarantees are secured by the collateral pursuant to the Intercreditor
Agreement. The collateral also secures the obligations under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and
certain hedging obligations pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement.

_General_

Following the occurrence of certain change of control events, each holder of Existing Notes will have
the right to require United Group B.V. to repurchase all or a portion of that holder’s Existing Notes at
a purchase price equal to 101% of the aggregate principal amount of Existing Notes repurchased, plus
accrued and unpaid interest and certain additional amounts, if any, on the Existing Notes repurchased
to the date of purchase, unless such Notes are redeemed.

In connection with certain tender offers or offers to purchase all of a series of the Existing Notes (except
that this provision only applies to the Existing 2024 SSNs in connection with a Change of Control Offer
(as defined in the 2017 Indenture)), in the event that holders of not less than 90% of the aggregate
principal amount of the applicable series of the then outstanding Existing Notes validly tender and do
not validly withdraw such Existing Notes in such tender offer or offer to purchase the Issuer will have
the right to redeem all (but not less than all) of such series of the Existing Notes that remain outstanding
following such purchase at a redemption price in cash equal to the price offered to other holders (or, in


-----

the case of the Existing 2024 SSNs, 101% of the aggregate principal amount of such Existing 2024
SSNs), plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, thereon, to, but excluding, the date of such redemption.

In addition, in the event that United Group B.V. or any Guarantor becomes obligated to pay additional
amounts (as defined in the applicable Indentures) to holders of the applicable series of Existing Notes
as a result of certain changes affecting taxes applicable to payments on the applicable series of Existing
Notes, it may redeem the applicable series of Existing Notes in whole but not in part at any time at
100% of the principal amount of the applicable series of Existing Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest
to the redemption date.

**_Covenants_**

The Indentures contain covenants that, among other things, limit the ability of the Company and its
subsidiaries to:

- incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock;

- layer debt;

- make restricted payments, including dividends or other distributions;

- prepay or redeem subordinated debt or equity;

- make certain investments;

- create or permit to exist certain liens;

- transfer, lease or sell certain assets;

- enter into arrangements that impose restrictions on the ability of subsidiaries to pay dividends or
make other payments;

- engage in certain transactions with affiliates;

- consolidate, merge or transfer all or substantially all of our assets and the assets of our
subsidiaries on a consolidated basis;

- impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the applicable series of Existing
Notes; and

- amend certain documents.

These covenants are subject to a number of important limitations and exceptions.

**_Events of Default_**

The Indentures contain customary events of default, including, among others, the non-payment of
principal or interest on the applicable series of Existing Notes, certain failures to perform or observe
any other obligation under the Indentures or the security documents, as applicable, the failure to pay
certain principal amounts of indebtedness when due or judgments and the bankruptcy or insolvency of
the Company, the Issuer or any Restricted Subsidiary or group of Restricted Subsidiaries that constitute
individually, or taken together as a group would constitute, a Significant Subsidiary (as defined in the
Indentures, as applicable). The occurrence of any of the events of default would permit or result in the
acceleration of all obligations outstanding under such Existing Notes.
