Insolvency proceedings are initiated upon a written petition of an authorized person. Authorized persons
include the debtor and all creditors who have a legally recognized interest in the conduct of the
proceedings. The creditor is required to demonstrate, by attaching appropriate documentation, that its
claim and the inability of the debtor to make payments is probable. Only the insolvency debtor is entitled
to initiate insolvency proceedings due to threatened insolvency.

Insolvency proceedings are generally conducted in two phases, a preliminary phase and the insolvency
proceedings themselves. The preliminary procedure is conducted by the insolvency court, which can
also appoint an interim insolvency administrator. The main purpose of the preliminary procedure is to
determine in principle whether the conditions for the opening insolvency are satisfied, i.e. whether any
of the insolvency grounds exist, whether there is a sufficient basis for the petition, whether there are
sufficient funds to cover the costs of the insolvency proceedings and whether the current operations can
be maintained and continued without detriment to the debtor, potential insolvency estate and/or
creditors. The insolvency proceedings, once opened, are conducted by the insolvency administrator
appointed by the court and insolvency judge. An alternative to these two-step proceedings is direct
bankruptcy, in cases where (i) a petition is filed by the company’s liquidator or (ii) a creditor files an
insolvency petition supported by a final and binding decision on enforcement that is not satisfied for a
period of at least 90 days.


-----

The general effects of the opening of insolvency proceedings include a stay of pending court and arbitral
proceedings involving the insolvency estate, and pro rata satisfaction of creditors upon sale of the
debtor’s assets by the administrator, in accordance with their payment ranks. Creditors with a separate
satisfaction right (mortgagees, pledgees, creditors to which the debtor transferred rights as security,
creditors with retention rights) have payment priority in insolvency proceedings and have the right to
separate settlement from the proceeds of the asset serving as collateral.

Only the insolvency administrator is authorized to dispose of the debtor’s assets and any disposal by
the insolvency debtor is without legal effect, except in the case of disposals to which general rules of
legitimate reliance on land registers or other appropriate public registers apply.

As of the date of the opening of insolvency proceedings, all bank accounts are closed and the insolvency
administrator opens a new bank account onto which all insolvency debtor’s funds from the closed
accounts are transferred. There is no provision ensuring that the pledge on closed bank accounts
transfers onto the new bank account.

Guarantees and other security for third-party debt provided within a certain period preceding the
opening of the insolvency proceedings may be challenged if they can be considered as giving preference
to certain creditors, as follows:

- guarantees and security given within the period of 12 months prior to the submission of the
petition for the opening of insolvency proceedings, if at that time the debtor was insolvent or
the creditor knew of such insolvency or did not know due to gross negligence;

- guarantees and security given after the submission of the petition for the opening of insolvency
proceedings if the creditor knew of the debtor’s insolvency or the motion for the opening of the
insolvency proceedings at the time or did not know due to gross negligence;

- guarantees and security given in the 90-days preceding the petition or after the submission
thereof; and

- guarantees and security given within the six months preceding the petition for the opening of
the insolvency proceedings if the debtor was insolvent at such time.

If the creditor is a related party, the awareness of the debtor’s insolvency is presumed. In addition, loans
granted in substitution to capital contributions are subordinated to all other claims during the insolvency
proceedings. Capital replacing loans are defined as loans that are granted at a critical time for the
company, when the company’s shareholders could have been reasonably expected to contribute capital
to the company, rather than grant loans. This also includes other legally binding transactions that are
economically equivalent to loan.

Granting of security for the claim of a company’s shareholder for repayment of a loan (or an equivalent
thereof) given at the time when capital contribution should have been provided is voidable if the
transaction took place within five years immediately preceding the opening of insolvency proceedings
or after the petition.

A legally binding transaction settling the claim of a company’s shareholder for repayment of a loan or
economically equivalent transaction is voidable if the transaction took place in the three years preceding
the opening of proceedings or after the petition. It is unclear whether the loans which fall under this
provision are only those given by the direct shareholder or also include loans by indirect shareholders
or affiliates controlled by (in)direct shareholders and there is no relevant court practice.

**_Law on Financial Dealings considerations_**

Pursuant to the Financial Dealings Act of FBiH, if illiquidity occurs (as defined under that law), the
company cannot execute any payments except those necessary in the ordinary course of business and


-----

those aimed at restoring liquidity. The following are deemed payments in the ordinary course of
business:

(a) procurement of goods and services for ordinary business activities;

(b) operational costs of business (energy, water and similar);

(c) salaries of workers;

(d) VAT, excise duties, social contributions and other taxes that have to be calculated and
paid in accordance with the law;

(e) costs related to procedures before public bodies; and

(f) costs related to documentation needed for commencement and implementation of
financial consolidation and restructuring activities.

In addition, the Financial Dealings Act prescribes that a company cannot perform any activity that may
damage creditors or put certain creditors into unfavorable position, in particular:

- diverting cash payments or financial flows to other persons;

- lending;

- distributing dividends, profits or payment of profits in advance;

- transferring rights to third parties, and especially to related companies; and

- procuring automobiles or spare parts for such vehicles, payments for business entertainment,
accommodation expenses and similar.

Accordingly, a company affected by illiquidity cannot make payments under a guarantee while that
situation is pending.

In addition, pursuant to the Financial Dealings Act, companies are obliged to maintain capital adequacy.
Capital inadequacy exists if as of the date of the relevant financial statements, losses, including losses
carried forward from earlier financial years, amount to at least 1/2 of the registered capital. In case of
capital inadequacy, the management of the company is obliged to implement measures intended for
restoring capital adequacy within its competence, such as finding adequate sources of financing, as well
as convening a shareholders assembly and proposing to shareholders to take measures within its
competence (such as, e.g. reducing registered capital to cover losses).

**Luxembourg**

**_Luxembourg Insolvency Considerations_**

Pursuant to Luxembourg insolvency laws, your ability to receive payment under the Senior Secured
Notes may be more limited than would be the case under U.S. bankruptcy laws. Under Luxembourg
law, the following types of proceedings (together referred to as insolvency proceedings) may be initiated
against a company incorporated in Luxembourg having its centre of main interests (within the meaning
of the E.U. Insolvency Regulation) or an establishment in Luxembourg (in the latter case assuming that
the centre of main interests is located in a jurisdiction where the E.U. Insolvency Regulation is
applicable):

- bankruptcy proceedings (faillite), the opening of which may be requested by the company, by
any of its creditors or by the courts ex officio. Following such a request, the Luxembourg courts
having jurisdiction may open bankruptcy proceedings if a Luxembourg company: (i) is in a


-----

state of cessation of payments (cessation des paiements); and (ii) has lost its commercial
creditworthiness (ébranlement de crédit). The main effect of such proceedings is the sale of the
assets and allocation of the proceeds of such sale between creditors taking into account their
rank of privilege, as well as the suspension of all measures of enforcement against the company,
except, subject to certain limited exceptions (please see the below applicable provision of the
Luxembourg law dated August 5, 2005 concerning financial collateral arrangements, as
amended (the “Financial Collateral Law 2005”)), for enforcement by secured creditors and the
payment of the secured creditors in accordance with their rank upon realization of the assets.
In addition, the managers or directors of a Luxembourg company that ceases its payments (i.e.
is unable to pay its debts as they fall due with normal means of payment) must within a month
of them having become aware of the company’s cessation of payments, file a petition for
bankruptcy (faillite) with the court clerk of the district court of the company’s registered office.
A law of December 19, 2020 (amended on June 30, 2021) has suspended this one month delay
until December 31, 2021. If the managers or directors fail to comply with such provision they
may be held (i) liable towards the company or any third parties on the basis of principles of
managers’ / directors’ liability for any loss suffered and (ii) criminally liable for simple
bankruptcy (banqueroute simple) in accordance with article 574 of the Luxembourg
commercial code.

- controlled management proceedings (gestion contrôlée), the opening of which may only be
requested by the company and not by its creditors and under which a Luxembourg court may
order the provisional stay of enforcement of claims except for secured creditors (please see the
below applicable provision of the Financial Collateral Law 2005); or

- composition proceedings (concordat préventif de la faillite), the opening of which may only be
requested by the company and not by its creditors directly. The Luxembourg court’s decision
to admit a company to composition proceedings triggers a provisional stay on enforcement of
claims by creditors except, among others, for secured creditors (please see the below applicable
provisions of the Financial Collateral Law 2005).

- In addition to these proceedings, your ability to receive payment on the Senior Secured Notes
may be affected by a decision of a Luxembourg court to grant a stay on payments (sursis de
_paiement) or to put a Luxembourg company into judicial liquidation (liquidation judiciaire)._
Judicial liquidation proceedings may be opened at the request of the public prosecutor against
companies pursuing an activity violating criminal laws or that are in serious breach or violation
of the Luxembourg commercial code or of the Law 1915. The management of such liquidation
proceedings will generally follow similar rules as those applicable to Luxembourg bankruptcy
proceedings.

Liability of any of the Guarantors existing under the laws of Luxembourg in respect of the relevant
Notes will, in the event of a liquidation of the company following bankruptcy or judicial liquidation
proceedings, only rank after the cost of liquidation (including any debt incurred for the purpose of such
liquidation) and any claims that are preferred under Luxembourg law. Preferential claims under
Luxembourg law include, among others:

- remuneration owed to employees (last six months’ wages amounting to a maximum of six times
the minimum social salary);

- employees’ contributions to social security;

- certain amounts owed to the Luxembourg Revenue;

- employer’s contribution to social security;

- landlord, pledgor not under the Financial Collateral Law 2005; and


-----

- value added tax and other taxes and duties owed to the Luxembourg VAT administration.

Assets over which a security interest has been granted will in principle not be available for distribution
to unsecured and unpreferred creditors (except after enforcement and to the extent a surplus is realized).

Favorable rules apply in relation to security interests of claims or financial instruments securing
monetary claims (or claims for the delivery of financial instruments) pursuant to the Financial Collateral
Law 2005. Article 20 of the Financial Collateral Law 2005 provides that Luxembourg law financial
collateral arrangements (pledges, security assignments and repo agreements) over claims and financial
instruments, as well as valuation and enforcement measures agreed upon by the parties are valid and
enforceable even if entered into during the pre-bankruptcy preference period (période suspecte) against
third parties, commissioners, receivers, liquidators and other similar persons notwithstanding the
insolvency proceedings (save in the case of fraud).

Article 24 of the Financial Collateral Law 2005 provides that foreign law security interests over claims
or financial instruments granted by a Luxembourg pledgor will be valid and enforceable as a matter of
Luxembourg law notwithstanding any Luxembourg insolvency proceedings, if such foreign law
security interests are similar in nature to a Luxembourg security interest falling within the scope of the
Financial Collateral Law 2005. If article 24 applies, Luxembourg preference period rules are disapplied
(save the case of fraud).

Article 21(2) of the Financial Collateral Law 2005 provides that where a financial collateral
arrangement has been entered into after the opening of liquidation proceedings or the coming into force
of reorganization measures or the entry into force of such measures, such arrangement is enforceable
against third parties, administrators, insolvency receivers, liquidators and other similar persons if the
collateral taker proves that it was unaware of the fact that such proceedings had been opened or that
such measures had been taken or that it could not reasonably be aware of such proceedings, measures
or arrangement.

**_Impact of Luxembourg Insolvency Proceedings on Transactions_**

During such insolvency proceedings, all enforcement measures by unsecured creditors are suspended.
Other than as described above, the ability of certain secured creditors to enforce their security interest
may also be limited, in particular in the event of controlled management proceedings expressly
providing that the rights of secured creditors are frozen until a final decision has been taken by a
Luxembourg court as to the petition for controlled management, and may be affected thereafter by a
reorganization order given by the court. A reorganization order requires the prior approval by more than
50% of the creditors representing more than 50% of any of the relevant Guarantor’s liabilities in order
to take effect.

Furthermore, you should note that declarations of default and subsequent acceleration (such as
acceleration upon the occurrence of an event of default) may not be enforceable during controlled
management proceedings. However, during such controlled management proceedings a notice of
default may still be served.

Luxembourg insolvency laws may also affect transactions entered into or payments made by any of the
relevant Guarantors incorporated under the laws of Luxembourg during the preference period (période
suspecte) which is a maximum of six months preceding the judgment declaring bankruptcy, except that
in certain specific situations the court may set the start of the suspect period at an earlier date. In
particular:

- pursuant to article 445 of the Luxembourg code of commerce (Code de commerce), specified
transactions (such as, in particular, the granting of a security interest for antecedent debts save
in respect of financial collateral arrangements within the meaning of the Financial Collateral
Law 2005; payment of debts which have not fallen due, whether payment is made in cash or by


-----

way of assignment, sale, set-off or by any other means; the payment of debts which have fallen
due by any means other than in cash or by bill of exchange; the sale of assets without
consideration or with substantially inadequate consideration) entered into during the preference
period (or the ten days preceding it) must be set aside or declared null and void, if so requested
by the insolvency receiver;

- pursuant to article 446 of the Luxembourg code of commerce, payments made for matured
debts as well as other transactions concluded for consideration during the preference period are
subject to cancellation by the court upon proceedings instituted by the insolvency receiver if
they were concluded with the knowledge of the bankrupt party’s cessation of payments; and

- pursuant to article 448 of the Luxembourg code of commerce and article 1167 of the
Luxembourg civil code (action paulienne), the insolvency receiver (acting on behalf of the
creditors) has the right to challenge any fraudulent payments and transactions, including the
granting of security with an intent to defraud, made prior to the bankruptcy, without any time
limit.

In principle, a bankruptcy order rendered by a Luxembourg court does not result in the automatic
termination of contracts except for employment agreements and powers of attorney. The contracts,
therefore, subsist after the bankruptcy order. However, the bankruptcy receiver may choose to terminate
certain contracts so as to avoid worsening the financial situation of the company. As of the date of
adjudication of bankruptcy, no interest on any unsecured claim will accrue vis à vis the bankruptcy
estate. Insolvency proceedings may hence have a material adverse effect on any of the relevant
Guarantors’ business and assets and the relevant Guarantors’ respective obligations under the Senior
Secured Notes.

Finally, international aspects of Luxembourg bankruptcy, controlled management or composition
proceedings may be subject to the E.U. Insolvency Regulation. In particular, rights in rem over assets
located in another jurisdiction where the E.U. Insolvency Regulation will not be affected by the opening
of insolvency proceedings, without prejudice however to the applicability of rules relating to the
voidness, voidability or unenforceability of legal acts detrimental to all the creditors (subject to the
application of article 24 of the Financial Collateral Law 2005 as described above and article 16 of the
E.U. Insolvency Regulation).

**_Luxembourg Law Collateral Considerations_**

Under Luxembourg law, contracts are in principle formed by the mere agreement (consentement)
between the parties thereto. However, additional steps are required to enforce security interests against
third parties.

If there are assets located or deemed to be located in Luxembourg, the security interests over such assets
will be governed by Luxembourg law and must be created, perfected and enforced in accordance with
Luxembourg law. The Financial Collateral Law 2005 governs the creation, validity, perfection and
enforcement of pledges over securities, bank account balances and receivables located or deemed to be
located in Luxembourg.

Security interests such as pledges, and transfer of ownership as a security, granted on financial
instruments and claims are governed by the Financial Collateral Law 2005. Pursuant to such law, pledge
is effected, not by transfer of title, but by a transfer of possession of the pledged assets to the pledgor
or to a third-party acting as depository for the pledgor and the pledgor’s preference rights over the
pledged assets only remain in existence as long as the pledgor or the depository remains in possession
of such assets.

A physical transfer of possession not being possible for intangibles such as monetary claims, the
Financial Collateral Law 2005 provides for a fictitious transfer of possession which is effected by
mechanisms which depend on the nature of the intangibles involved. In case of registered shares, the


-----

dispossession is achieved by the entry of the security interest in the share register of the relevant
Luxembourg company. In case of claims, dispossession is effected as against the debtor and any third
parties by the execution of the relevant pledge agreement. Nonetheless, the debtor of a pledged claim
may validly discharge its obligation by performance rendered to the pledgor as long as it has no
knowledge of the pledge. Dispossession of cash collateral is achieved by the security interest thereon
being notified by the debtor and the acceptance thereof by the debtor of such claims.

Absent perfection, the holder of the security interest may have difficulty enforcing his/its rights in the
collateral with regard to third parties, including a trustee in bankruptcy and other creditors who claim a
security interest in the same collateral. Finally, since the ranking of pledges is determined by the date
on which they became enforceable against third parties, a security interest created on a later date over
the same collateral, but which come into force for third parties earlier (by way of registration in the
appropriate register or by notification) has priority.

**_Luxembourg Guarantee Considerations_**

The Law 1915 does not provide for rules governing the ability of a Luxembourg company to guarantee
the indebtedness of another entity of the same group. A company may give a guarantee provided the
giving of the guarantee is covered by the company’s corporate purpose, corporate benefit and is in the
best interest of the company. Although no statutory definition of corporate benefit (intérêt social) exists
under Luxembourg law, corporate benefit is widely interpreted and includes any transactions from
which the company derives a direct or indirect economic or commercial benefit in return (such as an
economic or commercial benefit) and whether the benefit is proportionate to the burden of the
assistance. It is generally held that within a group of companies, the corporate interest of each individual
corporate entity can include, to a certain extent, the interest of the group, and that the existence of a
group interest can in certain cases result in the guarantee being held enforceable even where corporate
benefit is not established. In this way, reciprocal assistance from one group company to another does
not necessarily conflict with the interest of the assisting company. However, this assistance must be
temporary, in proportion to the real financial means of the assisting company (i.e., limited to an
aggregate amount not exceeding the assisting company’s own funds (capitaux propres)), the company
must receive some benefit or there must be a balance between the respective commitments of all the
affiliates and the companies involved must form part of a genuine group operating under a common
strategy aimed at a common objective. As a result, the guarantees/security interests granted by a
Luxembourg company may be subject to limitations in order to ensure their enforceability. Further, a
guarantee or security interest that substantially exceeds the guarantor’s or security provider’s ability to
meet its obligations to the beneficiary of the guarantee/security provider and to its other creditors, or
from which the Luxembourg company derives no or very limited direct benefit in return, or where no
direct or indirect consideration is granted to the company in exchange, would expose its directors or
managers to personal liability. In addition to any criminal and civil liability incurred by the directors or
managers of the Luxembourg company, in extreme circumstances the guarantee or security interest
could itself be held unenforceable, if it is held that it is contrary to public policy (ordre public), in the
case of facts consisting of a misuse of corporate assets. Any guarantee granted in connection with the
Senior Secured Notes by Luxembourg companies may be limited to a certain percentage of, among
others, the relevant company’s net worth. The SSN Indenture will provide for general limitation
language to the effect that each guarantee granted therein and each security interest granted as well as
any other obligation, liability or indemnification under a security document will be limited to the
maximum amount that can be guaranteed/ secured by the relevant guarantor/security provider with
respect to the aggregate obligations and exposure of the guarantor/security provider without rendering
the relevant guarantee/security interest voidable or otherwise ineffective under Luxembourg and other
applicable law. If one or more of these laws and defenses are applicable, a Guarantor may have no
liability or decreased liability under its guarantee or the security documents to which it is a party.

**Bulgaria**

**_Overview of limitations_**


-----

The validity, binding effect and enforceability of guarantees/security interests granted by Bulgarian
guarantors may be limited or otherwise be affected by the applicable stabilization or insolvency
proceedings against the Bulgarian guarantors, avoidance or similar laws of general application relating
to or affecting the enforcement of creditors’ rights and remedies, as well as financial assistance
prohibitions. These are reviewed in turn below.

**_Stabilization Proceedings_**

As of 2017 Bulgarian law also provides for a pre-insolvency restructuring procedure called
“stabilization procedure.” It currently exists as an additional procedure to the traditional restructuring
as a part of the insolvency procedure, and it is similarly to the insolvency procedure a procedure, the
main steps in which must be sanctioned by a court. The stabilization procedure under the Bulgarian
Commerce Act may be applied when there is a “threat of insolvency” but where the debtor is still not
insolvent. Actually, all court cases since the inception of the new procure have been focused on whether
the requirements for launching stabilization were fulfilled and all publicly available judgments so far,
the courts held that the debtor was actually insolvent (in most cases over-indebted), so insolvency rather
than stabilization procedure had to be opened. We are not aware of any case where the new procedure
was applied, and the debtor was successfully restructured to avoid insolvency. In terms of substance,
the stabilization procedure provides for a temporary standstill where all court enforcement and out of
court enforcement procedures (including those under special pledges) shall be stopped. Further there
are rules for partial cram down of the debtor’s liabilities. As of the date of this offering memorandum,
Bulgaria has not yet transposed Directive (EU) 2019/1023. Although a draft bill was published on the
webpage of the Bulgarian government on February 26, 2021, the legislative implementation process
that starts with a submission of a draft bill to the Bulgarian Parliament has not yet been commenced. In
2021, the citizens of Bulgaria voted in three snap parliamentary elections that took place in April, July
and November, respectively, following which some of the country’s largest parties eventually managed
to produce a working coalition government in December 2021. Therefore, the delay in the
implementation of Directive (EU) 2019/1023, the deadline for which expired on July 17, 2021, should
come to an end and is expected to be implemented in the first half of 2022. The exact timing for such
implementation will depend on the formation and stability of a new government.

**_Insolvency Proceedings_**

Should a Bulgarian guarantor have its “centre of main interests” (which is presumed to be the case due
to their incorporation in Bulgaria, unless something else is proven) they may be subject to Bulgarian
insolvency proceedings.

The insolvency proceedings do not affect out of court enforcement over Bulgarian special pledges, only
if the out of court enforcement was commenced before launching of the insolvency proceedings.
Otherwise the pledgee under a special pledge may only satisfy within the insolvency proceedings having
a first-ranking priority over the insolvency proceeds from the collateral.

A Bulgarian guarantor would be deemed insolvent in any of the following three cases occurs. The first
case is one of balance sheet insolvency (over indebtedness). When a creditor claims that a debtor is
balance sheet insolvent (as a ground for commencement of insolvency proceedings against the latter) it
has to be established that the debtor’s “liabilities exceed his assets.” All liabilities must be compared to
all assets for the purpose. This includes all existing liabilities including those that are not yet due (e.g.
future payments under an existing contract). Contingent (conditional) liabilities however are not
covered. There is no formal requirement that the negative balance for the purposes of over indebtedness
should be substantial and though the dominating understanding among scholars is that minor negative
balance should not be taken into account where the prospects for the entity are positive, it cannot be
ruled out that even a minor negative balance may trigger over indebtedness. The second case is the one
of cash flow insolvency. This means a state of inability to pay: (i) a monetary obligation under or in
relation to a commercial transaction, or (ii) public law obligation towards the State/municipalities
connected with the commercial activity of the entity; or (iii) private law obligation towards the


-----

State/municipalities. So, in the cash flow insolvency scenario a creditor must establish both: (i) the
existence of a particular payment obligation of any of the three types listed above that was due but was
not paid (i.e.—the “First Condition”), and the inability of the debtor to pay (“Second Condition”). The
First Condition involves establishment of only factual matters. The Second Condition however requires
again a comparison between assets and liabilities of the debtor, although in a more limited manner
(compared to the over indebtedness scenario). In particular (according to the case law) in order to
determine whether a debtor is unable to pay, the ratio has to be established between the current/shortterm assets (i.e. those that can be easily turned into cash) vis à vis short-term liabilities (i.e. existing
liabilities with a maturity of up to 1 year in the future). If the ratio is below 1 (meaning that the shortterm liabilities exceed the short-term assets), it is normally presumed that the debtor is unable to pay
(i.e. the Second Condition is met). The third case where insolvency proceedings should be opened is
the one of “concealed insolvency.” This means that an entity is concealing commercial activity behind
an insolvent entity, so if that is proven to be case insolvency proceedings must be opened against the
former.

In general, the opening of insolvency proceedings by a Bulgarian court does not result in the automatic
termination of contracts. However, the insolvency administrator may choose to terminate certain
contracts as to avoid the worsening of the financial condition of the company. Any power of attorney
terminates upon initiation of bankruptcy proceedings provided that the insolvency court has established
that the debtor jeopardizes the interests of creditors and that the debtor has been deprived of the right to
manage and dispose of the property of the company.

Insolvency proceedings may therefore have a material adverse effect on the relevant business and assets
of United Group Bulgaria, Viva Telecom and BTC (the “Bulgarian Guarantors”) and their respective
obligations with respect to the Senior Secured Notes.

**_Avoidance Claims_**

Within the insolvency proceedings certain Bulgarian avoidance rule may have to be considered. The
general claim that creditors may take recourse to, even if there is no insolvency is Actio Pauliana
(павлов иск) under art. 135 of the Obligations and Contracts Act. Under that claim a creditor may
request that any act of the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider having a detrimental effect on the
creditor be declared void as against the creditor, provided that the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider
knew about that detrimental effect at the time of performing the act. In the context of non-gratuitous
acts, the plaintiff (creditor) must furthermore prove that counterparty (creditor) to the Bulgarian
guarantor/security provider also knew about the detrimental effect of the challenged act on other
creditors. This means proof that both the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider and its counterparty
knew there were other creditors having valid claims existing before the challenged act and the act in
question was detrimental to them. Pure knowledge is sufficient, it is not necessary to prove that there
was intention to inflict detrimental effect on the other creditors. However, if the parties intend to defraud
the other creditors it is not necessary as a prerequisite for the Actio Pauliana that the respective creditor’s
claim should have arisen before the challenged act. The detrimental effect for the purposes of Actio
Pauliana exists if the possibility for the creditor to satisfy himself from the Bulgarian guarantor/security
provider’s property is reduced, which means that via the challenged act created or increased its state of
inability to pay to other creditors.

In addition (subject to some technical exceptions) the following acts and transactions may be declared
null and void with respect to the insolvency creditors if made by the Bulgarian guarantor/security
provider after the initial date of insolvency or over indebtedness and cumulatively—within the
timelines—under the following items (i) (iii) before the submission of the application for opening of
insolvency proceedings: (i) performance of a monetary obligation that was not yet due (неизискуемо)
regardless of the manner of performance made within a one year period; (ii) performance of a monetary
obligation that was due (изискуемо) regardless of the manner of performance made within a six month
period; and (iii) establishing a pledge, mortgage or personal security (i.e. a guarantee) to secure a
previously not secured obligation made within a two year period.


-----

In addition to other general statutory rules providing for setting aside of certain acts and transactions,
the following acts and transactions carried out by the debtor (within the timeline under items 1 3 below)
before the submission of the application for opening of insolvency proceedings may be set aside with
respect to the insolvency creditors: (i) establishment of a mortgage, pledge or personal security for
another person’s debts, effected within one year, but not earlier than the date of the insolvency or over
indebtedness, as the case may be; (ii) establishment of a mortgage, pledge or personal security for
another person’s debts to the benefit of a creditor, which is a related party to the debtor, effected within
two years; (iii) a transaction that is detrimental to the creditors, a party to which is a person related to
the debtor, effected within two years; (iv) a transaction where the consideration provided by the
insolvent Bulgarian guarantor/security provider exceeds significantly the consideration granted by its
counterparty, effected within 2 years period before the submission of the application for opening of
insolvency proceedings but not earlier than the date when the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider
was in a state of inability to pay or over indebtedness; (v) gratuitous transaction made within a two year
period (resp. three years if made to a related person).

Lastly, the following shall be considered null and void (in accordance with art. 646, par. 1 of the
Bulgarian Commerce Act (Търговски закон)) with respect to the insolvency creditors if carried out
after the date of the decision on opening of insolvency proceedings and in violation of the insolvency
procedures: (i) performance of an obligation that had occurred prior to the date of the decision on
opening of insolvency proceedings; (ii) establishing a pledge, or mortgage; (iii) transactions with rights
or properties from the insolvency estate.

**_Limitations with respect to corporate benefit_**

Bulgarian law does not explicitly require the existence of a corporate benefit upon the grant of security
for a third-party debt. However, the grant of the SSN Guarantees and the security interests by the
Bulgarian Guarantors without benefit or obvious rationale for the Bulgarian Guarantors may be
interpreted as an act with a detrimental effect and thus subject to certain of the claims set forth in
“Avoidance Claims” above, such as: (i) actio pauliana (Павлов иск) within and outside of insolvency
and (ii) insolvency avoidance claims within insolvency.

**_Limitations to avoid overindebtedness_**

The obligations of the Bulgarian Guarantors are further limited to the extent that they result in (i) over
indebtedness (свръхзадлъжнялост) in the meaning of Article 742, paragraph 1 of the Bulgarian
Commerce Act (Търговски закон), promulgated in State Gazette No. 48/18.06.1991, effective July 1,
1991, as amended, and (ii) a state of immediate threat of insolvency in the sense of Article 762,
paragraph 1 (непосредствена опасност от неплатежоспособност) of the Bulgarian Commerce Act.

**_Limitations with respect to subordination arrangements_**

The subordination arrangements in the SSN Guarantees assumed by the Bulgarian Guarantors (see “SSN
_Guarantees” above) may not be enforceable against third parties in case of enforcement proceedings_
against the Bulgarian Guarantors. There is still no court judgement in Bulgaria confirming that the
respective public or private bailiff (държавен или частен съдебен изпълнител) or insolvency
administrator (синдик) who would be in charge of the distribution among creditors should in case of
such arrangements disregard the statutory rules on ranking of creditors and apply instead the contractual
subordination arrangements. Certain academic scholars insist that subordination arrangements may not
be binding to any third-party different to those under the contract and would in particular would not
bind the respective public or private bailiff (държавен или частен съдебен изпълнител) or insolvency
administrator (синдик) as the procedural rules for creditors ranking are mandatory in nature.

**_Use of Security Agent and Parallel Debt_**

Under Bulgarian law, security interests can be granted to a security trustee for the claims of all
bondholders only if the security trustee is a bank. Parallel debt arrangements governed by a foreign
system of law are also often used, mainly for credit agreements where the Bulgarian security trustee
concept is not applicable.

We note that parallel debt structures governed by a foreign law under which such arrangements are
valid and enforceable have not yet been tested in Bulgarian courts.

**_Enforcement over Bulgarian Special Pledges—General Rules_**

Under Bulgarian law, depending on the type of security, certain perfection requirements as set forth
below must be satisfied in order for a security to become enforceable.

The following enforcement mechanisms are possible: (i) court execution over dematerialized shares in
a joint stock company (and sale) pursuant to the statutory provisions on execution and securing of claims
(for which a prior writ of execution is required); and (ii) out of court execution over dematerialized
shares in a joint stock company or shares (quotas) in a limited liability company through a private sale,
pursuant to the currently effective legislation (subject to amendments effective as of January 2023
(unless extensions are introduced), which require the out-of-court proceedings to be carried out under
rules involving greater transparency and publicity than the existing rules), whereas the choice between
court or out of court execution is at the sole discretion of the pledgor.

Regarding collateral enforcement in this section only out of court enforcement of non-possessory
special pledges (over going concerns, shares in limited liability companies and joint stock companies)
under Bulgarian law will be considered. The term “out of court” refers to an extra judicial summary
procedure for the seizure and sale of the collateral (i.e., a procedure without court involvement),
pursuant to the rules set out in the Bulgarian Special Pledges Act. Under the Bulgarian Special Pledges
Act, such out of court enforcement (i) does not require a prior Bulgarian, or any other court judgment,
arbitral award, writ of execution or other judicial ruling; (ii) may be undertaken without acceleration of
the Senior Secured Notes for the amount outstanding and payable under the Senior Secured Notes at
the date of enforcement; and (iii) may be carried out simultaneously, independently and irrespective of
any insolvency proceedings that may be opened with respect to the Bulgarian guarantor/security
provider. This out of court Collateral enforcement is in effect a “fast track” recovery procedure
irrespective of any other pending or contemplated actions or litigation proceedings.

The enforcement starts with a notification of the commencement of out of court pledge enforcement to
the Bulgarian Central Register of Special Pledges or another register depending on the type of collateral
by the Trustee, on behalf and at the direction of holders of the Senior Secured Notes. This does not
require the assistance or the consent of the respective Bulgarian pledgor. The Trustee shall notify the
respective pledgor of the commencement of the out of court enforcement proceeding, specifying,
amongst other information, the nature of the default, the outstanding amount due and payable, and the
collateral subject to sale. This notification may be served on the pledgee immediately following the
notification to the respective register. Upon service of the above-mentioned notifications to the register
and the applicable pledgor the Trustee is entitled to take possession of the Collateral that is the subject
of enforcement. In the event the pledgor refuses to voluntarily surrender such Collateral, the Trustee
may seek the intervention of and engage a bailiff (public or private enforcement officer) at the expense
of the pledgor. On the basis of a certificate from the register confirming that enforcement has been
initiated, such bailiff is entitled to force the pledgor to surrender the collateral, with police assistance,
as necessary. The collateral sale may occur after expiry of a 2 week grace period from the notification


-----

to the register, to enable making voluntary payment before the collateral is sold. During this grace
period, the Trustee may nevertheless organize the collateral sale (take possession of the collateral,
engage the depository (as defined below), identify creditors, and so on). The collateral sale must be
undertaken by and in the name of the Trustee. The Trustee must make reasonable efforts to achieve the
best price for the collateral and there are some specific requirements to publicize the terms of the sale
in advance by registration with the register. As of January 1, 2023, the Trustee should report in the
respective register, at least 14 days before expiry of the sale period, all details about the pledgor and the
property being sold, the minimum price, the rules of the sale, place and date of the sale and the deadline
for acceptance of offers. The Trustee may engage the pledgor, assuming it is cooperative, as its agent
to manage the actual collateral sale process. The Trustee shall appoint a professional accountant or a
bailiff (the “Depository”) who will administer the proceeds collected from the collateral sale. Amongst
other things, the Depository shall (i) identify the creditors who have rights to the collateral that is subject
to enforcement (“Qualified Creditors”) and notify the Qualified Creditors, who have two weeks to
comment, after which the definitive list of Qualified Creditors is finalized and is not subject to
challenge, (ii) open a special purpose depository bank account in the name of the Depository for the
collection of sale proceeds, (iii) provide information on the contemplated distribution of proceed to the
creditor(s) (which will be only the Trustee as creditor on behalf of the Bondholders), and (iv) if there
are no objections or challenges, distribute such proceeds to the creditors (which will be only the Trustee
as creditor on behalf of the Bondholders).

**_Specifics regarding Pledge over Shares in Joint Stock Companies (such as BTC) and Enforcement_**
**_over such Shares_**

Shares in a joint stock company, existing in a dematerialized form (such as the shares in BTC) may be
pledged under the Bulgarian Special Pledges Act. This requires an agreement in writing and registration
with the Bulgarian Central Depository which is the institution in whose databases dematerialized shares
exist in a legal form.

Enforcement over such shares requires respectively that the commencement of enforcement should be
registered with the Central Depository AD. The enforcement may take place by an out of court transfer
of the pledged shares so that the pledgee may satisfy the secured debt directly from its sale proceeds.

**_Specifics regarding Pledge over Shares in Limited Liability Companies (such as Viva Telecom and_**
**_United Group Bulgaria) and Enforcement over such Shares_**

Shares in a limited liability company (such as Viva Telecom and United Group Bulgaria) may be
pledged under the Bulgarian Special Pledges Act. This requires an agreement in writing with notarized
signatures and registration with the Bulgarian Commerce Register. Enforcement over such shares
requires respectively that the commencement of enforcement should be registered with the Bulgarian
Commerce Register.

The pledgee will be restricted in its options in case of enforcement only to enforcement through a
liquidation of the company the shares in which are pledged, and the pledgee may satisfy the secured
debt only out of the liquidation quota for the pledgor whose quota, in turn, may only be formed after
voluntary liquidation proceedings. In particular, the general possibility under the Bulgarian Special
Pledges Act to sell the pledged property out of court is inapplicable when it comes to enforcement over
shares in a limited liability company. The attempts of some lawyers nevertheless to effect such an
enforcement sale of shares in a limited liability company are regularly dismissed by the authorities in
Bulgaria.

**_Bulgarian Guarantee Considerations_**

Except for bank guarantees, under Bulgarian law there are no provisions regulating abstract guarantees
that are independent of the novation or replacement of the guaranteed debt or of any changes to the
creditors and the debtors under the guaranteed debt. Thus, even if a guarantee is valid under the
applicable law, the Bulgarian Guarantors may oppose its validity based on certain Bulgarian law


-----

principles claiming that they are rules of overriding nature that should be applied regardless of the
foreign applicable law. Although the overriding nature of the local rules has been confirmed by court
practice with regard to certain of the limitations set forth below, there is no conclusive case law
evidencing that the remaining rules would not be considered as overriding mandatory rules and/or rules
of public policy. Such rules are as follows:

(i) a guarantee will terminate upon novation (including by way of change of the parties or
replacement of the debt) or transfer of the guaranteed debt, unless the relevant Bulgarian
guarantor expressly agrees that the guarantee extends to the novated or transferred obligations;

(ii) a Bulgarian guarantor will not be liable for any increased amount of the guaranteed debt, unless
it has expressly agreed to such liability, and the extension of maturity of the guaranteed debt in
relation to the debtor is not effective in relation to the Bulgarian guarantor, unless the Bulgarian
guarantor has expressly agreed to such extension;

(iii) a Bulgarian guarantor will not remain liable under the guarantee after the due date for repayment
of the debt, unless the creditor has claimed repayment from the principal debtor within six months
as of that repayment date; and

(iv) since under Bulgarian law a guarantee would be considered as an accessory personal security,
the waiver of the right to refer to the personal defenses of the respective debtor as well as to the
set-off right of the respective debtor may not be enforceable under mandatory Bulgarian law and
therefore the Bulgarian guarantor can avail itself of such personal defenses and set-off rights. For
the same reason, the valid existence and the scope of the guarantee depends on the valid existence
and the scope of the guaranteed debt.

**Greece**

**_Insolvency proceedings_**

In Greece, insolvency and pre-insolvency proceedings are governed primarily by Greek law 4738/2020
(the “Greek Bankruptcy Code”).

The Greek Bankruptcy Code provides for the following insolvency proceedings:

(a) bankruptcy—liquidation procedure (article 75 et seq. of the Greek Bankruptcy Code).

(b) rehabilitation procedure (article 31 et seq. of the Greek Bankruptcy Code); and

(c) out-of-court debt settlement procedure (article 5 et seq. of the Greek Bankruptcy Code).

On March 1, 2021, the Greek Bankruptcy Code repealed Greek law 4307/2014, which previously
provided for an extraordinary special administration process intended to facilitate the sale of a debtor’s
business as a going concern, or the sale of individual business sectors and of individual assets, which
do not constitute business sectors. However, Greek law 4307/2014 continues to apply to proceedings
that were pending before the entry into effect of the Greek Bankruptcy Code.

_Bankruptcy—liquidation procedure_

Bankruptcy proceedings are applicable to both legal entities pursuing an economic objective, including
_sociétés anonymes and limited liability companies, and to natural persons. A debtor may request to be_
declared bankrupt when it is unable to fulfill its overdue financial obligations in a general and permanent
way (cessation of payments), or when the debtor foresees an imminent inability to fulfill its financial
obligations when they become due and payable (threatened cessation of payments). Cessation of
payments is presumed by law if a debtor does not repay due financial obligations to the Greek State,
social security institutions, or credit or financial institutions of an amount of at least 40% of the total


-----

due obligations for a period of at least six months, provided that the non-performing obligation is in
excess of €30,000.

Bankruptcy proceedings may be initiated only through the issuance of a court decision upon application
of the insolvent debtor, its creditors or, for public interest purposes, of public prosecutor. The debtor is
obliged to apply for bankruptcy any time before the cessation of payments but in any case within 30
days from its occurrence.

Anyone having legitimate interest in a bankruptcy proceeding may file an application for interim
measures after the filing of the bankruptcy application. The court may rule for the imposition of any
interim measures it deemed appropriate to prevent any harm to the creditors due to the deterioration of
the insolvent debtor’s assets or reduction of the value thereof, including the suspension of individual
enforcement actions until the court’s decision on the electronic solvency registry. Such suspension shall
not apply to enforcement actions by secured creditors on assets on which they have received security in
rem. Moreover, the interim measures shall not affect any rights under a financial collateral agreement,
or a close-out netting provision within the meaning, of Greek law 3301/2004.

The competent bodies of the bankruptcy proceedings include the bankruptcy court, the judge rapporteur,
the bankruptcy administrator and the creditors’ assembly.

Upon issuance by the bankruptcy court of the decision declaring bankruptcy, and subject to the
application of the provisions on the small-scale bankruptcy, a judge rapporteur, a judge and a
bankruptcy administrator (σύνδικος) are appointed and the estate of the debtor is sealed. After the
initiation of the bankruptcy proceedings, the bankruptcy procedure is supervised by the judge rapporteur
and administered by the bankruptcy administrator, who is obliged at a later stage to publicly invite the
creditors to announce their claims in order for them to be verified by the administrator.

Transactions entered into by the debtor in the period between commencement of the cessation of
payments and the declaration of bankruptcy (the “suspect period”), or, in cases of transactions that are
mandatorily revoked, in the period between the six months preceding the suspect period and the end of
the suspect period, which are deemed detrimental to the debtor’s creditors, are either mandatorily
revoked by the bankruptcy court or are revocable at the court’s discretion. Application for the revocation
of any such transactions before the bankruptcy court is generally filed by the bankruptcy administrator.
Exceptionally, a creditor may also file such application if it has requested the bankruptcy administrator
to apply for a revocation and the latter fails to take any action within two months from the creditor’s
request.

The following transactions are deemed to be detrimental to the creditors of the insolvent entity and are
mandatorily revoked by the court: (a) donations, gratuitous dispositions and all transactions conducted
at an undervalue; (b) payments of obligations that were not due and payable; (c) payments of due and
payable obligations that were not made in cash or in the agreed means of payment, except for voluntary
transfers of real estate to credit or financial institution against payment of debtor’s due and payable
obligations; and (d) provision of security in order to secure pre-existing claims for which the debtor had
not assumed an obligation to provide such security, or in order to secure new claims assumed by the
debtor in replacement of pre-existing obligations (subject to the legislative decree of 17.7/13.8.1923).

Any contract or payment of due and payable obligations within the suspect period may also be revoked
at the court’s discretion, provided that the third party knew that the debtor was in cessation of payments
and that the contract or payment was detrimental to the debtor’s creditors.

In addition, acts of the insolvent debtor concluded during a five-year period before the declaration of
bankruptcy are revoked if the debtor acted with the intention to harm or to benefit certain of its creditors
and its counterparties knew that the debtor was acting maliciously.


-----

Upon declaration of bankruptcy, there is a moratorium (suspension) on enforcement of individual
claims by creditors. In particular, it is prohibited to initiate or continue any enforcement procedures, or
to file any new lawsuits or continue any (pending) litigation against the insolvent debtor in connection
with the insolvency estate. Such prohibition does not apply to creditors with claims that have been
secured by specific privilege or security in rem on specific assets of the insolvency estate for a period
of nine months following the declaration of bankruptcy. The above exemption does not apply in cases
of sale of assets of a business as a functional whole whereby the secured asset forms part of such
functional whole.

Following the finalization of the creditors’ claims verification, the bankruptcy process enters into the
stage of liquidation of the debtor’s business and assets, either as a whole or on an itemized basis. The
liquidation proceeds are then distributed to the announced and verified creditors. The distribution of the
liquidation proceeds takes place in accordance with the applicable creditors’ ranking rules.

The bankruptcy proceedings are terminated upon: (a) the sale of all debtor’s assets and distribution of
the proceeds to the creditors; or (b) the cessation of such proceedings either due to lack of assets or due
to the lapse of five years from the formation of the creditors’ assembly or 15 years from the declaration
of bankruptcy; or (c) the full repayment of all creditors’ claims (including principal and interest) accrued
up to the declaration of bankruptcy.

The Greek Bankruptcy Code also sets forth a simplified procedure with respect to “small-scale”
bankruptcy proceedings; i.e., for natural persons with assets up to €350,000 and for legal entities
meeting any two of the following criteria: (a) turnover up to €700,000, (b) assets of up to €350,000 and
(c) an average of 10 employees.

_Rehabilitation procedure_

The Greek Bankruptcy Code sets out a collective pre-bankruptcy rehabilitation procedure that allows
debtors, who pursue a business activity, have their center of principal interests in Greece and are in a
status of general cessation of payments or facing an imminent threat of cessation of payments, to avoid
bankruptcy and remain operational on the basis of a rehabilitation plan (the “rehabilitation plan”). The
objective of such scheme is the execution and ratification by the court of a rehabilitation agreement
between either the debtor and its creditors or between the creditors with the aim to enable the debtor to
satisfy, in whole or in part, its creditors and remains operational, following ratification of the
rehabilitation agreement. The hearing date for the ratification of the rehabilitation agreement is set
within two months from the submission of the application to the competent court.

The rehabilitation agreement is ratified by a court decision following the submission of an application
to the competent court by: (a) the insolvent debtor or a creditor who is a party to the rehabilitation
agreement, _provided that the rehabilitation agreement has been concluded between the debtor and_
creditors representing 50% of claims with a special privilege and 50% of all other claims, in either case
affected by the rehabilitation agreement; or (b) any of the creditors, if the rehabilitation agreement has
been concluded without the participation of the debtor, provided that (i) such creditors represent 50%
of claims with a special privilege and 50% of all other claims, in either case affected by the rehabilitation
agreement, and (ii) the debtor is already in cessation of payments.

In the event that the rehabilitation agreement is not concluded with creditors representing the above
percentages, the competent court may still ratify such agreement provided that: (a) it has been approved
by creditors representing 60% of the total claims against the debtor, including 40% of claims with a
special privilege, (b) the non-consenting affected creditors are treated favorably compared to any
creditor with a claim of a lower rank; (c) no category of creditors shall receive, under the terms of the
rehabilitation agreement, a value in excess of its total claim against the debtor; and (d) for cases of very
small entities, the rehabilitation agreement has been proposed or approved by the debtor.


-----

The following need also to be satisfied in order for the rehabilitation agreement to be ratified by the
competent court: (a) it needs to be reasonably expected that the debtor’s business will become viable
following ratification of the rehabilitation agreement; (b) it needs to be reasonably expected that the
position of the creditors is not impaired; (c) the entering into the rehabilitation agreement did not come
as a result of wilful misconduct or other unfair practices or bad faith of the debtor, creditor or any other
third party and does not violate any mandatory Greek law provisions; (d) the rehabilitation agreement
does not violate the equal treatment of creditors; and (e) debtor’s consent (in the event that the
application to the court has been submitted only by the creditors).

Upon ratification, the rehabilitation plan is binding upon all creditors, including any dissenting and nonparticipating creditors.

From the submission of the application for the ratification of the rehabilitation agreement and until the
issuance of a relevant court decision, any individual or collective enforcement action against the debtor
is automatically suspended for a maximum period of four months. Such suspension is available only
one time per debtor. Following the above mentioned four-month period, a moratorium may be imposed
following an application to that effect by anyone having a legal interest. In case of material business or
social reasons, such moratorium may also be extended in favor of guarantors. Additionally, a
moratorium may also be imposed even before the submission of the application for the ratification of
the rehabilitation agreement, following an application by the debtor or a creditor provided that: (a) the
applicant files a written declaration of creditors representing at least 20% of the total debtors’ claims,
stating that such claims form part of the negotiation process with the aim to reach an agreement; and
(b) there is an urgent situation or an imminent danger in accordance with the provisions of the Greek
Code of Civil Procedure. Such moratorium is valid until the application for the ratification of the
rehabilitation agreement and up to a maximum period of four months.

_Out-of-court debt settlement procedure_

Under the out-of-court debt settlement process set out in the Greek Bankruptcy Code, individuals or
legal entities eligible to be declared bankrupt may apply online to the Special Secretariat for Private
Debt Management of the Ministry of Finance through an electronic platform for the settlement of their
debt towards: (a) financial institutions, including servicers, (b) the Greek State, and (c) social security
institutions, subject to certain exemptions (e.g., a debtor may not file an application for the opening of
an out-of-court debt settlement process in the event that 90% of its total debts is to a single financial
institution). Upon filing of the application, there is a moratorium (suspension) on enforcement of claims
requested to be settled. Investment service providers, undertakings for collective investment in
transferable securities, alternative investment funds and their managers, credit, financial and
insurance/reinsurance institutions fall outside the scope of the Greek Bankruptcy Code and are therefore
not eligible to apply as debtors for the opening of the out-of-court debt settlement process.

Creditors that are financial institutions may accept the invitation for out-of-court debt settlement and
submit a settlement proposal to the debtor. A restructuring agreement is then executed, provided that
the debtor and the majority of the participating creditors (i.e., 60% or more in terms of the value of the
relevant claims) who are financial institutions and participating secured creditors representing at least
40% of the total secured claims of financial institutions consent. The results of such settlement apply to
all financial institutions involved. If the proposal provides for debt settlement against the Greek State
and social security institutions, such creditors are deemed to have automatically consented, subject to
certain requirements being fulfilled.

The process may also be initiated by the creditors, at their own discretion, upon service of an invitation
to the debtor to apply for the opening of such procedure within 45 days from such invitation. The lapse
of this period without the filing of a relevant application by the debtor terminates the process.

**_Provisions on Guarantee_**


-----

Under Greek corporate law, a Greek societe anonyme is prohibited from granting loans or providing
securities and/or guarantees for the acquisition of its own shares or the shares of its direct or indirect
parent, unless a specific whitewash procedure is followed, and the minimum net equity position is
preserved. In relation to the SSN Guarantee to be granted by Wind Hellas Telecommunications S.A.,
the amount of the guarantee, indemnity or other liability or obligation of Wind Hellas
Telecommunications S.A. under the SSN Indenture and any documentation related to the Transactions
will be limited to the amount of the direct or indirect corporate benefit derived by Wind Hellas; i.e., any
amounts of the proceeds from the Bridge Facilities that will be provided to Wind Hellas in connection
with the Wind Hellas Indebtedness Refinancing.

Subject to the general provisions setting out the scope of its Guarantee, Wind Hellas will waive certain
rights and defenses under the SSN Indenture that would otherwise be available to it, including but not
limited to: (i) any right to refuse payment before the person seeking enforcement has first requested
such payment from the Issuer or the Guarantors (in Greek enstasi dizisseos, article 855 of the Greek
Civil Code); (ii) any right of the Issuer or the Guarantors to object against the person seeking
enforcement (article 853 of the Greek Civil Code); (iii) any right of recourse against the Issuer or the
Guarantors or right to demand security from the Issuer or the Guarantors, in each case until full
repayment of any amount due; (iv) any right of substitution in personam or in rem of the person seeking
enforcement, even if Wind Hellas has paid in full any claims of the person seeking enforcement (article
858 of the Greek Civil Code); (v) any right to be released from its guarantee, indemnity or other
liabilities or obligations hereunder until the full discharge of any claims of the person seeking
enforcement against the Issuer or the Guarantors (article 864 of the Greek Civil Code); and (vi) any
right to demand security under the conditions laid down in article 861 of the Greek Civil Code.

**Stabilization**

The Stabilizing Manager may engage in over-allotment, stabilizing transactions and covering
transactions in accordance with Regulation M under the Exchange Act. Over-allotment involves sales
in excess of the offering size, which creates a short position for the Stabilizing Manager. Stabilizing
transactions permit bidders to purchase the underlying security so long as the stabilizing bids do not
exceed a specified maximum. Covering transactions involve purchases of the Senior Secured Notes in
the open market after the distribution has been completed in order to cover short positions.

The Stabilizing Manager is not required to engage in these activities, and may end these activities at
any time. Accordingly, no assurance can be given as to the liquidity of, or trading markets for, the
Senior Secured Notes. These stabilizing transactions and covering transactions may cause the price of
the Senior Secured Notes to be higher than it would otherwise be in the absence of these transactions.

Pursuant to a reorganization by the Stabilizing Manager in accordance with Council Regulation (EC)
No. 2157/2001 of October 8, 2001 on the Statute for a European company (SE), on or about January
22, 2022, the Stabilizing Manager will change its legal form to a European Company (Societas
Europeaes or “SE”) and will be known as J.P. Morgan SE.

**Short Positions**

In connection with the offering of the Senior Secured Notes, the Initial Purchasers may purchase and
sell the Senior Secured Notes in the open market. These transactions may include short sales, stabilizing
transactions and purchases to cover positions created by short sales. Short sales involve the sale by the
Stabilizing Manager of a greater number of Notes than they are required to purchase in the offering of
the Senior Secured Notes. Stabilizing transactions consist of certain bids or purchases made for the
purpose of preventing or retarding a decline in the market price of the Senior Secured Notes while the
offering of the Senior Secured Notes is in progress.

These activities by the Stabilizing Manager, as well as other purchases by the Initial Purchasers for their
own accounts, may stabilize, maintain or otherwise affect the market price of the Senior Secured Notes.
As a result, the price of the Senior Secured Notes may be higher than the price that otherwise might
exist in the open market. If these activities are commenced, they may be discontinued by the Initial
Purchasers at any time. These transactions may be effected in the over the counter market or otherwise.

Persons who purchase Senior Secured Notes from the Initial Purchasers may be required to pay stamp
duty, taxes, and other charges in accordance with the laws and practice of the country of purchase in
addition to the offering price set forth on the cover page hereof.

**Settlement**

The Issuer expects that delivery of the Senior Secured Notes will be made to investors on or about the

the date of this offering memorandum (such settlement being referred to as “T+ ”). Under Rule
15(c)6-1 under the Exchange Act, trades in the secondary market are required to settle in business
days, unless the parties to any such trade expressly agree otherwise. Accordingly, purchasers who wish
to trade the Senior Secured Notes on the date of pricing will be required, by virtue of the fact that the
Senior Secured Notes will initially settle business days following the date of pricing of the Senior
Secured Notes, to specify an alternative settlement cycle at the time of such trade to prevent a failed
settlement. Purchasers of the Senior Secured Notes who wish to make such trades should consult their
own advisors.

The Senior Secured Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should

a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of

customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II;
or (iii) not a qualified investor as defined in the Prospectus Regulation. Consequently no key
information document required by the PRIIPs Regulation for offering or selling the Senior Secured
Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the EEA has been prepared and therefore
offering or selling the Senior Secured Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor
in the EEA may be unlawful under the PRIIPS Regulation. This offering memorandum has been
prepared on the basis that any offer of Notes in any Member State of the EEA will be made pursuant to
an exemption under the Prospectus Regulation from the requirement to publish a prospectus for offers
of the Senior Secured Notes. This offering memorandum is not a prospectus for the purposes of the
Prospectus Regulation.
