###### ENFORCEABILITY OF JUDGMENTS

The Issuer is a Dutch company. The Existing Subsidiary Guarantors are entities organized under the
laws of the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Bosnia, Bulgaria and Herzegovina and Slovenia. The Wind
Hellas Guarantor is organized under the laws of Greece. All the respective directors and executive
officers of the Issuer and the Guarantors reside outside of the United States. Substantially all of the
assets of the Issuer and the Guarantors and their respective directors and officers are located outside the
United States. Although the Issuer and the Guarantors have agreed, in accordance with the terms of the
SSN Indenture, to accept service of process in the United States through agents designated for such
purpose, it may not be possible for holders of the Senior Secured Notes to (a) effect service of process
upon the Issuer, the Guarantors or their respective directors or officers, or (b) enforce judgments of
courts of the United States predicated upon the civil liability of such entities or persons under the U.S.
securities laws and state securities laws or other laws against any such entities or persons in the courts
of a foreign jurisdiction.

**The Netherlands**

The Issuer and the Dutch Guarantors are incorporated under Dutch law and have their registered seat in
the Netherlands. None of the directors of the Issuer or the Dutch Guarantors reside in the United States
and a substantial amount of the Issuer’s assets, and a substantial amount of the assets of the Dutch
Guarantors are located outside of the United States. Civil liabilities based on the securities laws of the
United States may not be enforceable in the Netherlands, either in an original action or in an action to
enforce a judgment obtained in U.S. courts.

The United States and the Netherlands currently do not have a treaty providing for the reciprocal
recognition and enforcement of judgments, other than arbitration awards, in civil and commercial
matters. Consequently, a final judgment for payment given by any court in the United States, whether
or not predicated solely upon

U.S. securities laws, would not be enforceable in the Netherlands. In order to obtain a judgment which
is enforceable in the Netherlands, the claim must be re litigated before a competent Dutch court. A
Dutch court will, under current practice, generally confirm a final, conclusive and enforceable U.S.
judgement without substantive re-examination or re litigation on the merits if (a) that judgment results
from proceedings compatible with the Dutch concept of due process, (b) that judgment does not
contravene public policy (openbare orde) of the Netherlands, (c) the jurisdiction of the court has been
based on an internationally acceptable ground,(d) the judgment by the court is not incompatible with a
judgment rendered between the same parties by a Dutch court, or with an earlier judgment rendered
between the same parties by a non-Dutch court in a dispute that concerns the same subject and is based
on the same cause, provided that the earlier judgment qualifies for recognition in the Netherlands and
(e) the judgment is—according to the laws of the country of origin—formally capable of being enforced
(e.g. is readily enforceable, has not been annulled in appeal or its enforceability has not been subjected
to a certain timeframe).

Subject to the foregoing and provided that service of process occurs in accordance with applicable
treaties, investors may be able to enforce in the Netherlands, judgments in civil and commercial matters
obtained from

U.S. federal or state courts. However, no assurance can be given that such judgments will be
enforceable. In addition, it is doubtful whether a Dutch court would accept jurisdiction and impose civil
liability in an original action commenced in the Netherlands and predicated solely upon U.S. federal
securities laws.

Any enforcement of agreements governed by foreign law and any foreign judgments in the Netherlands
will be subject to the rules of Dutch civil procedure. Judgments may be rendered in a foreign currency
but enforcement is executed in EUR at the applicable rate of exchange. Enforcement of obligations in


-----

the Netherlands will be subject to the nature of the remedies available in the courts of the Netherlands.
Under certain circumstances, a Dutch court has the power to stay proceedings (aanhouden) or to declare
that it has no jurisdiction, if concurrent proceedings are being brought elsewhere.

A Dutch court may reduce the amount of damages granted by a U.S. court and recognize damages only
to the extent that they are necessary to compensate actual losses and damages.

**Slovenia**

The United States and Slovenia are not currently party to a treaty for the reciprocal recognition and
enforcement of judgments, other than arbitral awards rendered in accordance with the New York
Convention. Therefore, an enforceable judgment for the payment of monies rendered by a U.S. federal
or state court based on civil liability would not be directly enforceable in Slovenia. However, a valid
and legally binding judgment from a court of competent jurisdiction in the United States may be
recognized and enforced by a court of competent jurisdiction in Slovenia, subject to compliance with
the enforcement procedures set forth in Articles 94 et seq. of the Slovenian Private International Law
and Procedure Act (Zakon o mednarodnem zasebnem pravu in postopku). Following such recognition,
judgments of non-Slovenian courts have the same status and legal effect as those issued by Slovenian
courts.

The Slovenian courts will recognize a U.S. judgment if the judgment is legally binding in the United
States and provided that all of the following conditions are met:

- the matter does not fall within the exclusive jurisdiction of a Slovenian court;

- the jurisdiction of the U.S. court was not based solely on the citizenship of the plaintiff, the
property of the defendant in the United States or personal service of the claim to the defendant;

- the U.S. court did not ignore the parties’ agreement on jurisdiction of Slovenian court;

- a Slovenian court has not issued a legally binding decision on the same matter and no other
foreign court decision has been recognized in Slovenia (res iudicata) (and in case of lis pendens
the recognition process is on hold);

- the recognition of the U.S. judgment would not contravene the public policy of Slovenia (ordre
public);

- reciprocity is established (reciprocity is presumed unless proven otherwise; additionally,
absence of reciprocity is irrelevant when recognition or enforcement of a decision by a foreign
court is sought by a Slovenian citizen); and

- there were no procedural irregularities in the proceedings before the U.S. court that prevented
the party against which the judgment was issued to take part in the procedure (no breach of due
process rights).

Subject to the above conditions, Slovenian courts will not review the merits of the foreign judgment.
Slovenian courts also do not review whether the foreign court has acted in accordance with its own
procedural laws— any such issues have to be resolved through an appeal process in that foreign
jurisdiction.

The request for recognition of a U.S. judgment must include the original judgment or a certified copy,
a certificate of finality of the judgment, and a certified translation of the judgment.

If, upon recognition of a U.S. judgment in Slovenia, an opposing party does not pay its debt voluntarily,
a request for enforcement of the judgment must be made. This request must include a certificate of
enforceability of the judgment under the applicable U.S. law.


-----

The international competence of courts and the recognition and enforcement of judgments of competent
courts of a EU Member State (other than Slovenia) are governed by Council Regulation (EC) No.
1215/2012 of 12 December 2012 on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in
civil and commercial matters. In accordance with this regulation, if a court or competent authority so
requires in connection with the recognition and the enforcement of a foreign judgment, a translation of
the relevant documents must be produced and the translation must be certified by a person qualified to
do so in one of the member states. A judgment may not be recognized if its recognition is manifestly
contrary to public policy in the Member State in which recognition is sought; where it was given in
default of appearance, if the defendant was not served with the document which instituted the
proceedings or with an equivalent document in sufficient time and in such a way as to enable him to
arrange for his defense, unless the defendant failed to commence proceedings to challenge the judgment
when it was possible for him to do so; if it is irreconcilable with a judgment given in a dispute between
the same parties in the Member State in which recognition is sought; if it is irreconcilable with an earlier
judgment given in another Member State or in a third state involving the same cause of action and
between the same parties, provided that the earlier judgment fulfills the conditions necessary for its
recognition in the Member State addressed; or if it conflicts with Section 6 of Chapter II of the regulation
dealing with exclusive jurisdiction of the courts of Member States. Under no circumstances may a
foreign judgment be reviewed as to its substance.

In the event of any proceedings being brought in a Slovenian court in respect of a monetary obligation
expressed to be payable in a currency other than euro, a Slovenian court would have power to give
judgment expressed as an order to pay a currency other than euro. However, enforcement of the
judgment against any party in Slovenia would generally be available only in euro and for such purposes
all claims or debts would be converted into euro.

**Serbia**

Under the general conflict of laws rules, judgments of non-Serbian courts can be enforced in Serbia
only if they are recognized by a Serbian court.

Recognition of a foreign judgment may be refused if:

- the respondent proves that it was not able to participate in the proceedings, particularly if it
could not have participated in the proceedings because there was no personal service of process;

- the court of Serbia, by virtue of Serbian Law, has exclusive jurisdiction in the relevant subject
matter;

- a Serbian court or other official body has already passed or recognized a decision on the same
subject matter;

- the foreign judgment is found by the Serbian court to be contrary to the “foundations of social
and political order as determined in the Constitution” (i.e. public order);

- if a Serbian court establishes that there is no reciprocity in the matter of recognition and
enforcement of judgments rendered in commercial matters between Serbia and the home
country of the judgment; and

- if the judgment is not final and conclusive (i.e. there are further appeals or revocation
procedures or similar actions have been commenced or are allowed).

From a procedural perspective, a foreign court judgment may be recognized (and further enforced) in
Serbia as part of a separate recognition procedure or as a preliminary question in the regular
enforcement proceedings.

Reciprocity is presumed until proven otherwise, and de facto reciprocity is sufficient.


-----

Serbia is not a party to any multilateral or bilateral treaty pursuant to which the judgments of U.K. or
U.S. courts would be recognized and enforced. However, U.K. and U.S. court judgments can be
recognized and enforced pursuant to the general rules given above. Factual reciprocity between Serbia
and the U.K. and factual reciprocity between Serbia and the U.S. have been previously confirmed by
the Ministry of Justice but may be re-examined in a particular case if doubts exist as to its continuing
existence. In addition, the Ministry of Justice has not previously confirmed factual reciprocity between
Serbia and individual federal states.

The party seeking recognition/enforcement must submit to the court:

- motion for recognition/enforcement;

- a confirmation by the foreign court that the foreign court’s judgment is final (i.e. that the
judgment cannot be appealed anymore) and enforceable between the parties under the law of
the home country of the judgment;

- the original judgment or its verified copy; and

- a verified Serbian translation of the judgment.

**Bosnia and Herzegovina**

Under the general conflict of laws rules, judgments of non-Bosnian courts can be enforced in Bosnia
and Herzegovina (“BiH”) only if they are recognized by a court in BiH.

Recognition of a foreign judgment may be refused if:

- the respondent proves that it was not able to participate in the proceedings due to procedural
irregularities, particularly if it could not have participated in the proceedings because there was
no personal service of process;

- the court of BiH, by virtue of law of BiH, has exclusive jurisdiction in the relevant subject
matter;

- a BiH court or other official body has already passed or recognized a decision on the same
subject matter;

- the foreign judgment is found by the BiH court to be contrary to the constitution or public policy
of BiH;

- a BiH court establishes that there is no reciprocity in the matter of recognition and enforcement
of judgments passed in commercial matters between BiH and the foreign country in which the
pertinent judgment was passed; and

- if the decision is not final and conclusive (i.e. there are further appeals or revocation procedures
or similar actions have been commenced or are allowed).

Reciprocity is presumed until proven otherwise. However, enforceability of judgments of U.S. or UK
courts in BiH cannot be confirmed. BiH is not a party to any multilateral or bilateral treaty pursuant to
which the judgments of U.S. or UK courts would be recognized and enforced, and it appears that there
are no cases that have established the principle of “factual reciprocity.”

**Luxembourg**

Each Luxembourg Guarantor is incorporated under the laws of Luxembourg and all of the managers
and executive officers of the Guarantors incorporated under the laws of Luxembourg are non-residents
of the United States. Furthermore, a substantial portion of the assets of each of the Guarantors


-----

incorporated under the laws of Luxembourg is located outside the United States. As a result, it may not
be possible for investors to effect service of process within the United States upon the relevant
Guarantors, or to enforce against any of them judgments of U.S. courts predicated upon the civil liability
provisions of U.S. federal or state securities laws.

We have been advised by our Luxembourg counsel that the United States and Luxembourg are not
currently bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments, other
than arbitral awards rendered in civil and commercial matters. According to such counsel, an
enforceable judgment for the payment of monies rendered by any U.S. Federal or state court based on
civil liability, whether or not predicated solely upon the U.S. securities laws, would not directly be
enforceable in Luxembourg. However, a party who received such favorable judgment in a U.S. court
may initiate enforcement proceedings in Luxembourg (exequatur) by requesting enforcement of the
U.S. judgment by the District Court (Tribunal d’Arrondissement) pursuant to Section 678 of the New
Luxembourg Code of Civil Procedure. The District Court will authorize the enforcement in
Luxembourg of the U.S. judgment if it is satisfied that all of the following conditions are met:

- the U.S. judgment is final and enforceable (“exécutoire”) in the United States;

- the U.S. court awarding the judgment must have had jurisdiction to adjudicate the respective
matter both under applicable U.S. Federal or state jurisdictions rules, and under applicable
Luxembourg international private law conflict of jurisdiction rules and local law;

- the U.S. court has applied the substantive law as designated by Luxembourg conflict of laws
rules, or at least, the order must not contravene the principles underlying those rules;

- the U.S. judgment does not contravene international public policy or order as understood under
the laws of Luxembourg or has not been given in proceedings of a tax, penal or criminal nature
(which would include awards of damages made under civil liabilities provisions of the U.S.
federal securities laws, or other laws, to the extent that the same would be classified by
Luxembourg courts as being of a penal or punitive nature (for example, fines or punitive
damages)). Ordinarily an award of monetary damages would not be considered as a penalty,
but if the monetary damages include punitive damages, such punitive damages may be
considered as a penalty;

- the U.S. court has acted in accordance with its own procedural laws;

- the judgment rendered by the U.S. court submitted to Luxembourg exequatur proceedings does
not contradict a judgment which has been rendered in the forum of the Luxembourg courts;

- the principles of fair trial and due process have been complied with and in particular the U.S.
judgment was granted following proceedings where the counterparty had the opportunity to
appear, and if it appeared, to present a defense; and

- the U.S. judgment was not granted pursuant to an evasion of Luxembourg law (“fraude à la loi
_luxembourgeoise”)._

Subject to the above conditions, Luxembourg courts tend not to review the merits of a foreign judgment,
although there is no statutory prohibition.

We have also been advised by our Luxembourg counsel that if an original action is brought in
Luxembourg, Luxembourg courts may refuse to apply the designated law (i) if the choice of such law
was not made bona fide and (ii) if its application contravenes Luxembourg public policy or is manifestly
incompatible with Luxembourg international policy rules. In an action brought in Luxembourg on the
basis of U.S. federal or state securities laws, Luxembourg courts may not have the requisite power to
grant the remedies sought. Also, an exequatur may be refused in respect of punitive damages.


-----

Further, in the event of any proceedings being brought in a Luxembourg court in respect of a monetary
obligation expressed to be payable in a currency other than Euro, a Luxembourg court would have
power to give judgment expressed as an order to pay a currency other than Euro. However, enforcement
of the judgment against any party in Luxembourg would be available only in Euro and for such purposes
all claims or debts would be converted into Euro.

**Bulgaria**

The United States and Bulgaria are not currently party to a treaty for the reciprocal recognition and
enforcement of judgments, other than arbitral awards rendered in accordance with the New York
Convention. However, a valid and legally binding judgment from a New York court may arguably be
recognized and enforced by a Bulgarian court under the general recognition and enforcement rules of
the Bulgarian Private International Law Code.

The rules under the Bulgarian Private International Law Code verbatim do not restrict the choice of
court arrangements to those of EU member states so it is arguable that choice of the courts of non-EU
member states are covered. However, an exclusive jurisdiction clause in favor of New York courts may
be unenforceable in Bulgaria due to art. 4, par. 1 of the Brussels Regulation (Recast) which provides
that “subject to this Regulation, persons domiciled in a Member State shall, whatever their nationality,
be sued in the courts of that Member State.” This rule may be interpreted as not permitting choice of
courts arrangements different from those under the Brussels Regulation (Recast) as EU Regulations are
deemed to override any EU member state national laws. We are not aware of any case law of the Court
of Justice of the European Union that sheds light on how choice of New York courts arrangements
should be treated. However, according to current Bulgaria case law, foreign judgements from non-EEA
countries issued following a choice of court in favour of such non-EEA courts, should be upheld
(Judgement No 3978 of 6.07.2020 of Sofia Citi Court under case No 15843/2018 and Judgement No
260632 of 30.12.2020 of Sofia Citi Court under case No 1743/2019). If and as soon as the Hague
Convention of June 30, 2005 on Choice of Court Agreements (which has been ratified by the EU) will
be ratified by the United States (which is a signatory of this convention), this may result in increased
certainty that New York judgements following choice of court in favour of New York courts will be
upheld.

Subject to the above qualification, if it is accepted that the Brussels Regulation (Recast) is not an
obstacle to the application of the Bulgarian Private International Law Code, a New York court
judgement may be recognized and enforced if the following conditions are met:

(i) the New York court had jurisdiction according to the provisions of Bulgarian law, but not if the
only ground for the jurisdiction of the New York court over the dispute was the incorporation
(nationality) of the plaintiff in the jurisdiction of the seized court;

(ii) a copy of the statement of claim was served on the defendant, the parties were duly summonsed,
and the fundamental procedural principles of Bulgarian law, related to their defense have not
been violated;

(iii) there is no Bulgarian court judgment in force based on the same facts, involving the same cause
of action and between the same parties;

(iv) there are no pending proceedings based on the same facts, involving the same cause of action and
between the same parties before a Bulgarian court, which has been brought earlier than the case
instituted before the New York court on which there is judgement whose
recognition/enforcement is being sought;

(v) the recognition or enforcement is not contrary to Bulgarian public policy.

Regarding the first requirement for recognition/enforcement as listed above, i.e., competence of the
New York court under Bulgarian law, there is an express choice of court rule in the Private International


-----

Law Code (applicable also to a choice of court in favor of non-EU member states) whereby the parties
may choose via agreement in writing a foreign (non-Bulgarian) jurisdiction in relation to proprietary
matters provided that the dispute does not fall within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Bulgarian courts.
As the Brussels Regulation (Recast) takes precedence over Bulgarian domestic private international
law, a choice in favor of New York courts must furthermore not violate the exclusive jurisdiction of the
courts of other member states if the prerequisites for such exclusive jurisdiction exist under the EU
Brussels Regulation (Recast).

The action for enforcement of a New York judgment must be brought before the Sofia City Court.
Alongside the statement of claim (i.e., the request for recognition and enforcement), the following
documents must be presented:

(i) a certified copy of the judgment, authenticated by the New York court, and

(ii) a certificate issued by the New York court, confirming that said judgment has entered into force.

These documents must be certified in accordance with the Hague Convention Abolishing the
Requirement of Legalisation for Foreign Public Documents (i.e. the Apostille Convention) and
translated into Bulgarian by a translator certified by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of
Bulgaria.

The Sofia City Court must of its own motion establish the existence of the conditions for recognition/
enforcement listed above. The defendant in the proceedings for recognition or enforcement of a New
York judgement may not invoke violations of item (ii) of the list above if the defendant could have
raised challenges to such conditions before the New York court but failed to do so. In the
recognition/enforcement proceedings, the Bulgarian court would not examine the merits of the dispute
as decided by the New York court.

The debtor may in the recognition/enforcement proceedings raise the defense that the obligation has
been extinguished on the basis of circumstances that have occurred after the New York judgement
entered into force. The debtor however may not raise the defense that the obligation has been
extinguished as per the preceding sentence if the Bulgarian judgment admitting enforcement has entered
into force.

The judgment of the Sofia City Court in relation to the recognition of a New York court judgment is
subject to appeal before the Sofia Court of Appeals. The decision of the Sofia Court of Appeals is
subject to appeal before the Supreme Court of Cassation. The cassation procedure is conditional on the
prior admission for appeal and the party challenging the appellate judgment should provide evidence
that the statutory grounds for cassation are satisfied. The Supreme Court of Cassation grants the
appellant a leave to appeal before considering the cassation appeal on its merits. The cassation appeal
to the Supreme Court of Cassation does not suspend execution of the judgment of the appellate court.
Thus, the judgment of the Sofia Court of Appeals shall be enforceable and a party may initiate
enforcement proceedings immediately after the judgment of the appellate court.

**Greece**

Wind Hellas Telecommunications S.A. is a société anonyme (company limited by shares) incorporated
under the laws of Greece. All of its directors and executive officers reside outside the United States.
Wind Hellas Telecommunications S.A.’s assets and the assets of its directors and executive officers are
located principally in Greece and other countries outside the United States.

Civil liabilities based on the securities laws of the United States may not be enforceable in Greece,
either in an original action or in an action to enforce a judgment obtained in U.S. courts. A final
judgment for the payment of money rendered by any U.S. federal or state court based on civil liability,
whether or not based on U.S. federal or state securities laws, would not be automatically enforceable in
Greece on the basis that: (a) the United States is not a member to the Lugano Convention of December


-----

21, 2007, as currently in force; and (b) the United States and Greece currently do not have a treaty
providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments, other than arbitration awards, in
civil and commercial matters.

Consequently, the recognition and enforcement of judgments of U.S. courts in Greece is governed solely
by the provisions of the Greek Code of Civil Procedure, according to which a foreign judgment can be
recognized and declared enforceable in Greece. The enforcement of judgments of U.S. courts in Greece
can be effected following a petition of the winning party creditor before the Single Member Court of
First Instance of the debtor’s place of residence.

A final and enforceable judgment in the U.S. courts would be recognized and enforceable by the Greek
courts without re-examination or re-litigation of the matters adjudicated, provided that such judgment
meets the requirements of article 323 of the Greek Code of Civil Procedure, which requires that:

(i) such judgment constitutes res judicata (final judgment) according to the law of the state in which
it was rendered;

(ii) such judgment has been issued by a court having jurisdiction according to Greek law to hear the
particular case;

(iii) the unsuccessful party to the proceedings leading to such judgment has not been deprived of its
rights to participate in such proceedings and defend itself other than by application of the rules
of procedure applicable to nationals of the jurisdiction of the court which rendered the judgment;

(iv) such judgment is not contrary to a previous judgment issued by a competent court of the Hellenic
Republic concerning the same dispute between the same parties and constituting res judicata; and

(v) such judgment is not contrary to the Greek principles of boni mores or public policy.

Further and subject to the provisions of any applicable international treaties, foreign judgments are
recognized and considered as res judicata and enforceable in Greece without further procedure if they
are also res judicata pursuant to the law of the country where they were issued provided that the
conditions under (ii) through (v) above are also met.

If the above conditions are cumulatively met, a final judgment for payment awarded by a court in the
United States can be recognized and declared enforceable in Greece, without being reviewed as to the
merits and with no further procedure. However, as punitive damages are not available under Greek law,
Greek courts may deny the recognition and enforcement of punitive damages, or decrease such damages
as the Greek courts deem appropriate at the request of the defendant if such damages are considered
disproportionate.

Management is responsible for the preparation and presentation of this condensed consolidated
interim financial information in accordance with International Accounting Standard 34 – ‘Interim

###### Scope of Review

We conducted our review in accordance with International Standard on Review Engagements 2410,
‘Review of Interim Financial Information Performed by the Independent Auditor of the Entity’. A
review of interim financial information consists of making inquiries, primarily of persons responsible
for financial and accounting matters, and applying analytical and other review procedures. A review is
substantially less in scope than an audit conducted in accordance with International Standards on
Auditing and consequently does not enable us to obtain assurance that we would become aware of all
significant matters that might be identified in an audit. Accordingly, we do not express an audit
opinion.

###### Conclusion

Based on our review, nothing has come to our attention that causes us to believe that the
accompanying condensed consolidated interim financial statements are not prepared, in all material
respects, in accordance with International Accounting Standard 34 – _‘Interim financial reporting’ as_

## NOTES TO THE CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED INTERIM FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

###### 1. General information

Adria Midco B.V. (the Company) is a company domiciled in Netherlands, registered on 3 October 2013.

The condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Company for the period ended 30 September
2021 comprise the Company and its subsidiaries (together referred to as the “Group”). List of subsidiaries is
presented in the note 37.

The Group is one of the largest telecommunication operators in South East Europe providing video, data, voice
and mobile telephone services to residential and business subscribers. The Group has media activities which fall
into following categories: content production, distribution, advertising and digital. The Group’s activities are mainly
based in Serbia, Slovenia, Montenegro, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Macedonia, Croatia, Bulgaria and Greece.

On 4 March 2019 Summer Bidco B.V., an entity controlled by Funds advised by BC Partners completed the
acquisition of majority ownership of the Group following the receipt of all necessary regulatory approvals.

###### 2. Basis of preparation

 2.1. Statement of compliance

These condensed consolidated interim financial statements for the nine and three months period ended 30
September 2021 have been prepared in accordance with International Accounting Standard IAS 34 Interim
Financial Reporting as adopted by EU and should be read in conjunction with the Group’s last annual
consolidated financial statements as at 31 December 2020. They do not include all of the information for a full
set of IFRS financial statements. However, the selected explanatory notes are included to explain events and
transactions that are significant to an understanding of the changes in the Group’s financial position and
performance since the last annual financial statements. These consolidated interim financial statements are not
statutory consolidated financial statements and they are prepared for the purpose of providing information to
owners and providers of financing to the Group.

IFRS requires the management to adopt accounting policies that are the most appropriate to the Group’s
circumstances. These have been applied consistently to all the years presented, unless otherwise stated.

Certain comparative amounts do not correspond to the 2020 consolidated financial statements and reflect
reclassification adjustments made to conform to the current period presentation. Specifically, the following
comparative balances as of 31 December 2020 were reclassified in the consolidated statement of financial
position as of 30 September 2021:

   - Short term provisions in the amount of EUR 2,600 thousand (as of 31 December 2020 EUR 9,433
thousand) are now presented within line Short-term provisions, whilst in consolidated financial
statements as of 31 December 2020 were presented in line Trade and other payables.

The statement of financial position was impacted, but due to the fact that change is not significant for the opening
balance sheet presenting an additional statement of financial position is not considered to be relevant for the
Group.

The condensed consolidated interim financial statements were authorized for issue by the Board of Directors on
26 November 2021.

###### 2.2. Basis of measurement

The condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Group for the period ended 30 September 2021
have been prepared under the historical cost convention except for certain financial instruments, investment
property and assets held for sale.

###### 2.3. Going concern 

The Group has reported a net loss for the nine-month period ended 30 September 2021 in the amount of EUR
61,962 thousand (net loss for the nine-month period ended 30 September 2020: EUR 33, 438 thousand) which
is mainly attributable to increase in finance cost due to additional bonds issued during 2020 and 2021 (bonds
were used for the acquisition of VIVACOM Group, repayment of a portion of the amounts drawn under the
Revolving Credit Facility that were used to fund the purchase price for the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition
and to pay transaction costs associated with the bond offering (note 31)), as well as increase in other operating
expense and income tax expense.

The Group has reported a net loss for the nine-month period ended 30 September 2020 in the amount of EUR
33,438 thousand which was influenced mainly by higher finance costs caused by issuing new bonds (note 31).

As at reporting date, the Group reported negative equity in the amount of EUR 46,845 thousand. In October
2021, parent company contributed amount of EUR 19 million in cash which decreased amount of negative
equity. The management is considering actions in order to recover equity. Capital requirements are monitored
on a stand-alone basis and not on the consolidated level and that Adria Midco B.V. has positive equity as at
reporting date.

The expansion of the Group is based on a leveraged buyout strategy resulting in an increased finance debt and
the associated net finance expenses. The Group’s key performance indicators is Adjusted Earnings Before
Interest, Tax, Depreciation and Amortization (Adjusted EBITDA) (see note 5 for definition). Adjusted EBITDA
for the nine-month period ended 30 September 2021 has increased by 83% comparing to the same period for
the 2020. Significant increase in Adjusted EBITDA mainly is result of acquired companies (note 21).

The Group regularly (daily and monthly) analyses liquidity projections, internal financial reports, availability of
financial assets and ability to repay its liabilities through daily and/or monthly review of budgeted and actual
cash flows and monitoring of maturity of the Group’s receivables and liabilities.

Primary sources of the Group’s liquidity and funds for capital expenditures, acquisitions and other investments
have been operating cash flows, revolving credit facilities, ancillary lending facilities and leases. The Group has
reported net cash inflow from operating activities in the amount of EUR 395,302 thousand for the nine-month
period ended 30 September 2021. The Group was able to repay its obligations when they fell due in the normal
course of business with no defaults in repayment of debt, the associated financial interest expenses nor any
other liabilities. As at reporting date, the Group has outstanding loans in the amount of EUR 71,848 thousand
and bond liabilities (including interest) in the amount of EUR 3,564,903 thousand which matures from 2024 to
2028. In February 2020, the Group issued bonds in the amount of EUR 1,675,000 thousand for the purpose of
acquisition of VIVACOM Group as well as early repayment of one bond tranche and repayment part of the RCF.
These bonds issuance is with maturity date in 2026 and 2028 (note 31). In November 2020, additional bonds
were issued in the amount of EUR 400 million with maturity in 2027 and in January 2021 additional EUR 150
million with the same maturity. In July 2021 the Group issued new bonds in the amount of EUR 300 million with
maturity in August 2028.

As at reporting date the Group has an undrawn revolving credit line in the amount of EUR 477,085 thousand
(31 December 2020: EUR 353,422 thousand) (note 31).

According to the Group’s business plan for 2021, the Group will continue to grow and expects increase in
Adjusted EBITDA, which will provide sufficient ground for financing debt, capital expenditures and working
capital.

###### 2.4. COVID-19

The existence of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) was confirmed in early 2020 and has spread rapidly from
mainland China across the globe, causing disruptions to businesses and economic activity and it continued to
shape its course in 2021.

Economic development over the coming months will depend on the spread of infection. Vaccines against
COVID-19 became available in December 2020 which substantially reduce the probability of infection.

The impact of this outbreak on macroeconomic forecasts and markets are incorporated into the Group’s
estimates of expected credit loss provisions for financial assets and other impairments assessments in 2021,
including but not limited to: Goodwill, Property, plant and equipment, Intangible assets and Programming rights.

Management has reasonable expectations that the Group has adequate resources to continue in operational
existence for the foreseeable future. The results of management review of the Group’s market, operations and
financials in the past year and a forecast for at least twelve months after the date of signing of the financial
statements provides a sound basis for the appropriateness of using the going concern assumption in the
preparation of the Group’s financial statements for the period ended 30 September 2021, though the existence
of Coronavirus (COVID-19) means there is generally a level of uncertainty in the wider macro market.

Management concluded that the range of possible outcomes considered at arriving at this judgment does not
give rise to material uncertainties related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s
ability to continue as a going concern for at least twelve months from the date of authorization of the financial
statements for issue.

**2.4.1. Revenues and Adjusted EBITDA**

There is positive impact to organic consolidated revenues in 2021 amounts of 6% comparing the same period
last year. The Group recorded iccrease of 3% in organic Adjusted EBITDA comparing to the same period 2020
mainly. The organic means the Group before the acquisitions of Telemach Croatia, VIVACOM Group and
Forthnet Group.

The Group’s telco segments have continued to meet customers’ expectations on service level and network
operating centre has maintained normal service levels. No significant change in customer database is
experienced during reporting period ended 30 September 2021. Negative effect of increase in bad debt and
decline in revenue from sale of handsets and roaming was mainly offset with decline in churn rate due to
limitation in direct sale to customers. At the same time, the Group has implemented cost savings measures
such as: decrease in travelling, representation and consulting costs.

In its Media segment (organic), external revenue increased by 14% comparing to the same period previous year
mainly as a result of increase in advertising revenue in 2021 compared to 2020, which was highly affected by

###### 2.5. Use of estimates and judgments 

The condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Group for the reporting period require
management to make judgments, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of accounting
policies and the Group’s reported financial position, results or cash flows and disclosure of contingent
assets or liabilities during the reporting period. Actual outcomes could differ from those estimates.

Estimates and judgments are based on historical experience and other factors, including industry practices
and expectations of future events that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances.

Estimates and underlying assumptions are reviewed on an on-going basis. Revisions to accounting
estimates are recognized in the period in which the estimates are revised and in any future periods
affected.

The accounting estimates and judgements applied in these condensed consolidated interim financial
statements are the same as those applied in the Group’s consolidated financial statements as at and for
the year ended 31 December 2020.

###### 2.6. Functional and presentation currency 

These condensed consolidated interim financial statements are presented in Euros, which is the Company’s
functional currency. Items included in the financial statements of each of the Group’s entities are measured
using the currency of the primary economic environment in which the entity operates (“the functional currency”).

Transactions in foreign currencies are translated to the respective functional currencies of Group entities at
exchange rates at the dates of the transactions. Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign
currencies at the reporting date are translated to the functional currency at the exchange rate at that date.
Non-monetary assets and liabilities that are measured at fair value in a foreign currency are translated to the
functional currency at the exchange rate when the fair value was determined. Foreign currency differences are

**Foreign operations**

The results and financial position of all Group entities that have a functional currency different from the

the transaction dates, in which case income and expenses are translated at the rate on the dates of
transactions) and,

   - the translation adjustment resulting from the use of these different rates is included in other
comprehensive income

Goodwill and fair value adjustments arising on the acquisition of a foreign operation are treated as assets and

###### 2.7. Current or non-current classification

Assets are classified as current in the condensed consolidated interim financial statements where recovery is
expected within 12 months of the reporting date. All assets where recovery is expected more than 12 months
from the reporting date and all deferred tax assets, goodwill and intangible assets, property, plant and equipment
and investments in associates and joint ventures are reported as non-current.

Liabilities are classified as current unless the Group has an unconditional right to defer settlement of the liability
for at least 12 months after the reporting date. For provisions, where the timing of settlement is uncertain,
amounts are classified as non-current where settlement is expected more than 12 months from the reporting
date. In addition, deferred tax liabilities and employment benefits are reported as non-current.

###### 3. Financial risk management 

This note presents information about the Group’s objectives, policies and processes for measuring and
managing credit, liquidity and market risk. Also presents the exposure and sensitivity of the Group to these
risks.

There is no change of financial risk and financial risk management compared to consolidated financial
statements as at 31 December 2020.

The Group’s managing board has overall responsibility for the establishment and oversight of the Group’s risk
management framework, and development and monitoring of the Group’s risk management policies.

The Group’s risk management policies are established to identify and analyse the risks faced by the Group,
to set appropriate risk limits and controls, and to monitor risks and adherence to limits. Risk management
policies and systems are reviewed regularly to reflect changes in market conditions and the Group’s activities.
The Group, through its training and management standards and procedures, aims to maintain a disciplined
and constructive control environment in which all employees understand their roles and obligations.

The finance function monitors compliance with the Group’s risk management policies and procedures, and
provides top management with feedback regarding the performance of the framework in relation to the risk faced
by the Group.

###### 3.1. Credit risk 

Credit risk is the risk of financial loss to the Group if a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument fails to
meet its contractual obligations, and arises principally from the Group’s receivables from customers, contract
assets, cash and cash equivalents held at banks, loans and financial guarantees issued by the Group and the
indemnification asset.

###### 3.2. Liquidity risk 

Liquidity risk is the risk that the Group will encounter difficulty in meeting the obligations associated with its
financial liabilities that are settled by delivering cash or another financial asset. The Group’s approach to
managing liquidity is to ensure, as far as possible, that it will always have sufficient liquidity to meet its liabilities
when due, under both normal and stressed conditions, without incurring unacceptable losses or risking
damage to the Group’s reputation.

The Group’s policy on liquidity is to maintain sufficient liquid resources to meet its obligations as they fall due,
which has been achieved through appropriate bank arrangements (note 31). Typically, the Group seeks to ensure
that it has sufficient cash on demand to meet expected current liabilities as they fall due, including the servicing of
financial obligations; this excludes the potential impact of extreme circumstances that cannot reasonably be
predicted, such as natural disasters.

The Group has covenants relating to Revolving Credit Facility and bonds. Covenants relating to bonds are active
only when the Group decides to issue new bonds or refinance old one. Covenants relating to RCF are monitored
regularly (note 31).

###### 3.3. Market risk 

Market risk is the risk that changes in market prices, such as foreign exchange rates, interest rates and equity
prices will affect the Group’s income or the value of its holdings of financial instruments. The objective of market
risk management is to manage and control market risk exposures within acceptable parameters, while optimizing
the return.

###### 3.3.1. Currency risk

Currency risk arises when future commercial transactions or recognized assets or liabilities are denominated in
a currency that is not the functional currency of the Group entity holding the asset or obligation.

Different entities within the Group have different functional currencies, based on the underlying economic
conditions of their operations. Other than Euro, which is the Company’s functional currency, the Group’s
subsidiaries have local functional currencies: Serbian dinar (“RSD”), Croatian kuna (“HRK”), Bosnian
Konvertibilna marka (“BAM”), Bulgarian lev (“BGN”) and Swiss franc (“CHF”). The Bosnia Konvertibilna marka
and Bulgarian lev are pegged to the Euro. Accordingly, the main exposure to currency risk relates to purchases
and borrowings which are denominated in Euros and US dollars, while a significant share of the Group’s revenue
is denominated in Serbian dinars, Swiss franc and Croatian kuna.

The Group has exposure to currency fluctuation (depreciation) of RSD (Serbian dinar) to Euro given that it has
significant operations through SBB Serbia for which RSD is the functional currency and that has significant
borrowings in Euro. The Group’s currency risk policy for this exposure is implemented through regular price
adjustments on the Serbian market, following the depreciation of Serbian dinar against Euro.

###### 3.3.2. Price risk

The Group is not exposed to material price risks on its financial instruments.

###### 3.3.3. Interest rate risk

The Group’s cash flow interest rate risk arises from long-term borrowings, loans to related parties issued at
variable rates and lease liabilities, whereas the borrowings at the fixed rate are exposed to fair value risk
nevertheless it does not impact the financial statements as these borrowings are measured at amortised cost.
The Group closely monitors current market rates in order to minimize negative effects of significant movements
in market rates. The Group does not use these instruments for speculative purposes.

As at reporting date, if interest rates on currency denominated borrowings (with floating rate) had been 1%
higher with all other variables held constant, net profit for the year would have been EUR 7,424 thousand lower

###### 3.4. Fair value hierarchy

Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction
between market participants at the measurement date. The best evidence of fair value is the price in an active
market. An active market is one in which transactions for the asset or liability take place with sufficient frequency
and volume to provide pricing information on an ongoing basis.

Valuation techniques such as discounted cash flow models or models based on recent arm’s length transactions or
consideration of financial data of the investees are used to measure fair value of certain financial instruments for
which external market pricing information is not available. Fair value measurements are analysed by level in the fair
value hierarchy as follows:

   - level one is measurements at quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or
liabilities,

   - level two measurements are valuations techniques with all material inputs observable for the asset or
liability, either directly (that is, as prices) or indirectly (that is, derived from prices), and

   - level three measurements are valuations not based on solely observable market data (that is, the
measurement requires significant unobservable inputs). Transfers between levels of the fair value
hierarchy are deemed to have occurred at the end of the reporting period.

The table below shows the carrying amounts and fair values of financial assets and financial liabilities, including
their levels in fair values hierarchy. It does not include information for financial assets and financial liabilities not
measured at fair value if the carrying amount if reasonable approximation of fair value.

The fair values of the Other financial liabilities – bonds are calculated by discounting the future cash flows to
net present values using appropriate market rates prevailing at reporting date. The valuation basis is level 2.
This classification comprises items where fair value is determined from inputs other than quoted prices that are
observable for the liability, either directly or indirectly.

###### 4. Capital management 

Due to the structure of long-term financing through leveraged buyout arrangement, the management policy is
to maintain a stable return on investment so as to maintain investor, creditor and market confidence and to
sustain future development of the business. The Group’s performance management is focused on generating
budgeted Adjusted EBITDA as well as maintaining overall liquidity position to repay the financial debt (note 3.2).
An important key performance indicator for the communication with investors, analysts, and rating agencies are
Net leverage (calculated as Net Debt to Annualized Last Two Quarters Adjusted EBITDA) and Pro Forma Net
leverage (calculated as Adjusted Pro Forma Net Debt to Annualized Last Two Quarters Pro Forma Adjusted
EBITDA). “Annualised” amounts are calculated by multiplying the amounts for last two quarters by 2. This
standalone ratio stood at 4.61x at reporting date (31 December 2020: 4.58x) and Pro forma ratio stood at 4.65x
at reporting date (31 December 2020: 4.70x).

Annualized Last Two Quarters Adjusted EBITDA, Annualized Last Two Quarters Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA,
Net Debt and Adjusted Pro Forma Net Debt are non-GAAP figures not governed by International Financial
Reporting Standards, and their definition and calculation may vary from one company to another.

Net debt and Annualized Last Two Quarters Adjusted EBITDA are measures prepared by the Group on a Pro
Forma basis and present hypothetically the Group’s Net debt and Annualised Last Two Quarters Adjusted EBITDA
as though the acquisitions of companies (for which the Group acquired during reporting period) and other events
and operations that are directly related to these acquisitions, had taken place at 1 April 2021.

Annualized Last Two Quarters Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted Pro Forma Net Debt are measures
prepared by the Group on a Pro Forma basis and present hypothetically the Group’s Adjusted Pro Forma Net
Debt and Annualised Last Two Quarters Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA as though the acquisitions (which the Group
acquired during reporting period), as well as other acquisitions (for which the Group signed agreements for
acquisition and are in process of receiving regulatory approvals) and other events and operations that are directly
related to these acquisitions, had taken place at 1 April 2021.

The unaudited/unreviewed pro forma been prepared solely for management purposes and due to its nature
presents a hypothetical situation; therefore, it does not present the actual results financial results, financial
standing, and any other financial measures of the Group for the presented periods, had the events and operations
discussed really taken place on the assumed dates, and its purpose is not to determine the actual results and
financial standing in any future periods.

###### 5. Operating segments

The Group is a pan regional distribution platform of cable and satellite Pay-Tv, broadband internet and telephony
services with various offerings in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Greece,
Montenegro and North Macedonia. Its business has grown substantially in terms of scale, geographic reach
and service offering during the period under review through both organic growth and acquisitions. In addition,
the corporate organization of the Group’s business has changed during this period as business has grown and
been integrated.

Segment information is provided partially on the basis of geographic areas and partially based on an
organizational structure, being the basis on which the Group manages its operations.

The following summary describes the operations in each of the Group’s reportable segments.

   - Serbia Group includes cable operations in Serbia and DTH (satellite TV) operations in Macedonia.
Satellite operations in Macedonia account for minor part of the overall operations of Serbia Group
segment,

   - Bulgaria Group includes telecom operations in Bulgaria,

   - Slovenia Group includes cable and DTH operations and mobile telephony services in Slovenia,

   - Greece Group includes telecom and media operations in Greece,

   - Bosnia Group includes cable and DTH operations in Bosnia and Herzegovina,

   - Montenegro Group includes cable and DTH operations in Montenegro,

   - Croatia Group includes mobile telephony services in Croatia,

   - Media Group includes media (including advertising) and content operations in the region. This segment
includes the results of our media and content business in the former Yugoslav region including the results
of N1 Info, Grand Production, Orlando Kids, Nova TV, Nova M and Nova BH, as well as Direct Media as
Nova Broadcasting Group, Vestnik Telegraph EOOD and Dan Graf d.o.o. acquired in 2021 (note 21).

   - Other segments include our other operating business, such as EON TV International (previously named
Solford), Shoppster and non-operating holding companies (United Group B.V., Adria Cable B.V., Adria
Serbia Holdco B.V., Slovenia Broadband S.A.R.L.). Under Other segments, the Group reported newly
acquired companies Mainstream d.o.o., IT4Biz d.o.o. and D express d.o.o. Revenue reported in other is
mainly generated by EON TV International (previously named Solford), Shoppster, Mainstream d.o.o.
and D express d.o.o.

There were no changes in relation to composition of segments and measurement of segment profit/loss
comparing to consolidated financial statements for 2020 expect for acquired companies Nova Broadcasting
Group, Vestnik Telegraph EOOD and Dan Graf d.o.o., (note 21) in 2021 which are included in Media Group,
Net 1 EOOD, ComNet Sofia EAD, Digital Cable Television OOD (note 21) which are included in Bulgaria Group
and Mainstream d.o.o., IT4Biz d.o.o. and D express d.o.o. which are included under Other segment.

Information regarding the results of each reportable segment is included below. Performance is measured
based on segment earnings before net finance cost, tax, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) and Adjusted
EBITDA, as included in the internal management reports that are reviewed by the Group’s management.

EBITDA is a supplemental measure of financial performance that is not required by, or presented in accordance
with IFRS. “EBITDA” is defined by the Group as Profit/(Loss) for the period plus income tax (benefit)/expense,
depreciation, amortization of intangible assets and net finance costs and share of profit/loss of equity-accounted
investee.

Adjusted EBITDA represents EBITDA adjusted for shareholder-related costs, legal and advisory – M&A related
costs, group restructuring costs, income from the disposal of companies, impairment charges for obsolete
equipment in Slovenia, other management-related costs, specific penalties, additional impact of application of
new standards (for transitory period) and other non-core operating expenses, which Group views as nonoperating and not recurring to the operations of the Group (note 15).

###### 5.1. Description of products and services from which each reportable segment derives
 its revenue

The Group’s main activities are providing of Video, Data, Voice and Mobile services to subscribers in the
countries of South-East Europe as well as content provision via various platforms. The Group operates in
Serbia, Greece, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro and North Macedonia providing Video, Data and Voice
services. In Slovenia and Bulgaria in addition to Video, Data and Voice provides mobile phone services. In
Croatia providing mobile phone services.

Video service include provision of TV channel mix and IP Video streaming services, which is marketed into
basic, extended and premium packages. TV mix range from 60 to over 100 TV channels.

Data service comprise internet packages for residential and business customers, as well as various
supplementary services for business customers (connectivity and managed services, data centre and cloud
services).

Voice service relates to fixed line services to residential and business customers.

Mobile phone services relate to post-paid, prepaid, roaming and wholesale services provided to customers.

United Media is the leading media company in South East Europe, broadcasting more than 55 channels
available for terrestrial, cable, DTH, OTT and IPTV platforms. Content operations are driven by carriage fee
revenues which are coming from sales of pay-tv channel to cable operators across SEE region and advertising
revenue from both terrestrial TV stations and pay-tv stations. The Group is the owner of pay-tv channels
including flagship brands like “Sport Klub”, Diema Sport, regional news channel 'N1', general entertainment
channels Nova S, Diema, Diema Family, movie channels like Cinemania and Kino Nova, children channels
“Pikaboo”, ”Vavoom“ and newly launched IDJ Kids, music channels “Grand”, “IDJ”, Magic TV, The Voice as well
as terrestrial TV stations Nova in Bulgaria, Nova TV and Doma TV in Croatia, Nova M in Montenegro and Nova
BH in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Recently, United Media started to invest heavily in its digital portfolio, out of
which the most prominent web portals are nova.bg, vesti.bg, vbox7 with reach of more than 80% of Bulgarian
population, dnevnik.hr (number 1 portal in Croatia), n1info.com, nova.rs, danas.rs and many more. In addition
to this, Direct Media group, a leading media-buying agency, provides advertising and media services to
companies in the region. Recently UM has entered into radio market in Bulgaria with 5 radio stations including
radio Veselina, the most popular radio station in the country together with print market in Bulgaria and Serbia
(Danas and City magazine).

###### 5.2. Factors that management used to identify the reportable segments

Most of the Group’s business segments are mainly based on the Group’s geographic regions, Serbia, Bulgaria,
Slovenia, Greece, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia and Montenegro, and the media segment is broadly based
on product distribution. They are managed separately because each business unit requires different marketing
strategies and service level.

costs), cable and mobile network build out, upgrades, maintenance and other investments, computer
hardware and software and content rights.

CODM evaluates performance of each segment based on revenue, Adjusted EBITDA, EBITDA and other key
performance indicators (e.g. average revenue per user, Adjusted CAPEX) and does not regularly review assets
and liabilities of the segments.

Income tax expense is recognized at the amount determined by multiplying the profit/(loss) before tax for every
component for the interim reporting period by management’s best estimate of the annual income tax rate
expected for the full financial year, adjusted for the tax effects of certain items recognized in the full in interim
period. As such, the effective tax rate in the interim financial statements may differ from management’s estimate
of the effective tax rate for the annual financial statements.

The estimated average tax rate used for the nine-months period ended 30 September 2021 is 24%, compared
to 45% for the nine months ended 30 September 2020. In period ended 30 September 2021 the Group reported
higher loss before tax mainly as a result of increase of operating profit due to acquired companies which was
offset by increase in financing cost due to new financing. Increase in current tax expense is mainly result of full
impact of companies acquired in 2020. Increase in current tax expense was offset by change in deferred tax
benefit. All this resulted in decrease in tax rate for the reporting period, compared to previous period year.

###### 21.2. Pending acquisitions

**Optima Telekom d.d.**

In July 2021, the Group has reached a deal with Hrvatski Telekom and Zagrebacka Banka to acquire a majority
sharesin the Croatian operator Optima Telekom d.d., which offers a range of fixed internet and pay-TV services.
The Group will acquire the 17.41% of shares held by Hrvatski Telekom and the 36.90% shares owned by
Zagrebacka Banka. This acquisition will fully converged telecom operation offering the full range of telco
services – including TV – on its own infrastructure.

Under the terms of the agreement, completion of the deal was contingent on a change in Croatia’s Electronic
Media Act, which prohibited vertical integration between pay TV broadcasters and distributors. Croatia's
Electronic Media Act was changed in October 2021 and no longer prohibits vertical integration. The transaction
is also conditional upon approval by relevant competition authorities.

**Wind Hellas Telecommunications SA**

On 14 August 2021, the Group concluded agreement to acquire 100% shares in WIND Hellas
Telecommunications S.A. (WIND) in Greece. The Company has a total of 4.2 million users and offers mobile,
fixed, internet, and television services and generates revenues in excess of €500 million annually.

Acquiring and integrating strong local telecom and media businesses onto own platform is a core part of Group's
European growth strategy. Greece is a key market for the Group and with the acquisition of Wind, the Group is
able to create a leading converged operator and contribute to the development of Greece’s telecoms sector
through investments in network infrastructure, content, technology, and innovative products and services and
be a leading force in the digitalisation of the country.

In the event of termination of the agreement, by way of compensation for any losses and damages suffered by
the Seller, the Group would pay amount of EUR 100 million.

The transaction is subject to customary regulatory approvals and is expected to be completed in 2022.

**Other acquisitions**

On 29 April 2021 the Group concluded agreement to acquire entire share capital of local internet and TV
operators Networx-Bulgaria EOOD, TVN Distribution Bulgaria EOOD and Telco Infrastructures EOOD in
Bulgaria. The transactions are subject to relevant regulatory approvals.

Considering the timing of finalisation of transactions for these entities, the disclosures required by IFRS 3 are
not presented in this report due to the fact that the information received from acquired companies has not yet
reached the stage when management can reliably disclose the details.

On 20 August 2021, the Group concluded agreement to acquire 80% ownership in Tessa Energy EOOD in
Bulgaria, for consideration of EUR 7 million. Transaction is subject to customary merger clearances and is
expected to close in Q4 2021. Tessa Energy EOOD will invest in Kremena Wind park of 70MW capacity. With
this investment, the Group will be producing more energy than currently consumes in Bulgaria, and the project
will significantly decrease the Group’s carbon footprint. In addition to strategic fit with the Group’s ESG strategy,
this project is expected to be a financially viable investment, yielding high teens IRR for the Group.

**Bonds**

Bonds are rated by Moody’s forward view rated B2 and S&P Global rated B.

On 27 July 2017 the Group issued bonds in the nominal amount of EUR 1,350,000 thousand. Bonds were
issued in three tranches:

   - First tranche in the nominal amount of EUR 575,000 thousand, bears interest rate of 4.375% p.a. and
matures on 1 July 2022. Interest is payable semi-annually on each 15 January and 15 July. Effective
interest rate of 4.778% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds. This tranche was fully repaid
on 6 February 2020. Due to early redemption option exercised in the February 2020, total amount of
EUR 12,587 thousand was recognized as finance expense in period ended 31 December 2019.

   - Second tranche in the nominal amount of EUR 325,000 thousand, bears interest rate of 4.875% p.a. and
matures on 1 July 2024. Interest is payable semi-annually on each 15 January and 15 July. Effective
interest rate of 5.224% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds.

   - Third tranche in the amount of EUR 450,000 thousand, bears floating rate of 3M Euribor+ 4.375% and
matures on 1 July 2023. Interest is payable quarterly on each 15 October, 15 January, 15 April and 15
July. Third tranche was early repaid on 17 May 2019 with no impact on profit or loss.

On 17 May 2019, the Group issued bonds in the nominal amount of EUR 550,000 thousand which matures on
15 May 2025, bears interest rate of 3m EURIBOR+4.125%. Interest is payable on each 15 February, 15 May,
15 August and 15 November. Effective interest rate of 4.454% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds.

On 4 July 2019, the Group issued bonds in the aggregate amount of EUR 207,000 thousand (including premium)
which matures on 1 July 2024, bears interest rate of 4.875 %. Interest is payable semi-annually on each 15
January and 15 July. Effective interest rate of 4.48% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds.

On 6 February 2020, the Group issued bonds in the nominal amount of EUR 1,675,000 thousand. Bond is
issued in three tranches:

   - First tranche in the nominal amount of EUR 600 million bears interest rate of 3.125% and matures on 15
February 2026. Effective interest rate of 3.4% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds.

   - Second tranche in the nominal amount of EUR 450 million bears floating interest rate of 3M

###### 31.3. Loan covenants 

Based on the agreement for revolving credit facility, the Group is required to comply with a leverage ratio to
consolidated pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA for the period most recent four consecutive financial quarters
ending prior to the date of determination of the ratio. Leverage ratio is calculated as aggregate outstanding
indebtedness of the Group and should not exceed ratio 9:1. Indebtedness is calculated as total financial
liabilities decreased by level of cash and cash equivalents as at reporting date. Satisfaction of the covenant is
tested quarterly. The Group has been in compliance with the above requirements as at and for the periods
ended 30 September 2021 and 31 December 2020, and to the date of issuance of this report.

###### 34. Related parties

In considering each possible related party relationship, attention is focused on the substance of the relationship,
not merely the legal form.

Related parties may enter into transactions, which unrelated parties might not, and transactions between related
parties may not be affected on the same terms, conditions and amounts as transactions between unrelated
parties.

Other significant shareholders are those with the power to participate in the financial and operating policy
decisions of the Group with which they transact, through controlling over 20% of the Group’s voting power.

Parties referred to below as “other related parties” are the parties other than the parent, entities with joint control
of, or significant influence over, the entity, subsidiaries, associates, joint ventures, key management personnel.

Transactions with related parties were entered into during the ordinary course of business on normal commercial
terms.

###### 34.4. Long term incentive scheme (LTIS)

On 27 September 2018, Summer Bidco B.V., an entity controlled by Funds advised by BC Partners, entered
into a share purchase agreement (“SPA”) to acquire the entire share capital (excluding treasury shares) of Adria
Topco B.V. (the “Target”) from Adria Luxco S.a.r.l. (the “Seller”). The Agreement provided a platform for a
reasonable expectation of the certain management to be awarded based on the performance of the
shareholders in the event of any exit of their investment in Adria Topco or the Group by those shareholders.

The Group has recognized cumulative effect of the Agreement in its consolidated financial statements for the
period ending 30 September 2021, as equity-settled Group Share-based payment transaction under IFRS 2 –
Share-based payment.

From the perspective of the Group financial performance for the period ending 30 September 2021, the
recognition of the transaction resulted in a lower reported net profit of the Group, in the amount of EUR 7,695
thousand. The same amounts of EUR 7,695 thousand, as guided by IFRS 2, the Group recognized an increase
in equity (Contribution from shareholder). The transaction would be a non-cash, no recourse transaction without
an impact on the financial position of the Group.

###### Auditor’s responsibilities for the audit of the consolidated financial statements

Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial
statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue
an auditor’s report that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is
not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with ISAs will always detect a material
misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material
if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic
decisions of users taken on the basis of these consolidated financial statements.

As part of an audit in accordance with ISAs, we exercise professional judgment and maintain
professional scepticism throughout the audit. We also:

- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements,
whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks, and
obtain audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. The risk
of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from
error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the
override of internal control.

- Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit
procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an
opinion on the effectiveness of the Group’s internal control.

- Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting
estimates and related disclosures made by management.

- Conclude on the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting
and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events
or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern.
If we conclude that a material uncertainty exists, we are required to draw attention in our auditor’s
report to the related disclosures in the consolidated financial statements or, if such disclosures are
inadequate, to modify our opinion. Our conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up
to the date of our auditor’s report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Group to
cease to continue as a going concern.

- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the consolidated financial statements,
including the disclosures, and whether the consolidated financial statements represent the
underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation.

- Obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or
business activities within the Group to express an opinion on the consolidated financial
statements. We are responsible for the direction, supervision and performance of the Group audit.
We remain solely responsible for our audit opinion.

We communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the planned
scope and timing of the audit and significant audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in
internal control that we identify during our audit.

# NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

###### 1. General information

Adria Midco B.V. (the Company) is a company domiciled in Netherlands, registered on 3 October 2013.

The consolidated financial statements of the Company for the year ended 31 December 2020 comprise the
Company and its subsidiaries (together referred to as the “Group”). List of subsidiaries is presented in the note
41.

The Group is one of the largest telecommunication operators in South East Europe providing video, data, voice
and mobile telephone services to residential and business subscribers. The Group has media activities which fall
into following categories: content production, distribution, advertising and digital. The Group’s activities are mainly
based in Serbia, Slovenia, Montenegro, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Macedonia, Croatia, Bulgaria and Greece.

On 4 March 2019 Summer Bidco B.V., an entity controlled by Funds advised by BC Partners completed the
acquisition of majority ownership of the Group following the receipt of all necessary regulatory approvals.

###### 2. Basis of preparation

This section sets out Group’s significant accounting policies that relate to the financial statements as a whole and
describes the critical accounting judgements and estimates that management has identified as having a
potentially material impact on the Group’s consolidated financial statements. Where an accounting policy is
generally applicable to a specific note to the financial statements, the policy is described within that note. Below
are presented the new accounting pronouncements that the Group will adopt in future years and current view of
the impact they will have on the Group’s financial reporting.

###### 2.1. Statement of compliance

The consolidated financial statements of the Group have been prepared in accordance with International
Financial Reporting Standards (IFRSs), as adopted by the European Union (EU). These consolidated financial
statements are not statutory consolidated financial statements and they are prepared for the purpose of providing
information to owners of the Group.

IFRS requires the management to adopt accounting policies that are the most appropriate to the Group’s
circumstances. These have been applied consistently to all the years presented, unless otherwise stated.

In 2020 the Group changed accounting policy for investment property. This change to significant accounting
policies is described in note 3.

Certain comparative amounts do not correspond to the 2019 consolidated financial statements and reflect
reclassification adjustments made to conform to the current period presentation. Specifically, the following
comparative balances as of 31 December 2019 were reclassified in the consolidated statement of financial
position as of 31 December 2020:

   - Interest payable EUR 33,294 thousand (as of 31 December 2019 EUR 26,323 thousand) is now
presented within line Interest payables – bond, whilst in consolidated financial statements as of 31
December 2019 where it was presented in line Trade and other payables.

   - Impairment losses on trade and other receivables, including contract assets and Impairment losses on
other financial assets are renamed in 2020 into Net impairment on trade and other receivables, including
contract assets and Net impairment on other financial assets.

The above change was considered by the Group as a change in accounting policy and in line with IAS 8 it was
applied retrospectively, however due to the nature of the change, the statement of financial position was

###### 2.2. Basis of measurement
