_Definition of lease_

Previously, the Group determined at contract inception whether an arrangement was or contained a lease
under the IFRIC 4 and IAS 17. The Group now assesses whether the contract is or contains lease based
on the new definition of lease. Under IFRS 16, a contract is, or contains, a lease if the contract conveys
a right to control the use of an identified asset for a period of time in exchange of consideration.

The Group applies the practical expedient to grandfather the definition of a lease on transition. This
means that it will apply IFRS 16 to all contracts entered into before 1 January 2019 and identified as
leases in accordance with IAS 17 and IFRIC 4.

_As a lessee_

The Group leases many assets including properties, satellite capacity, facilities and infrastructure which
were previously recognized under operating lease.

Leases are negotiated on an individual basis and contain a wide range of different terms and conditions
(including termination and renewal rights). The main lease features are summarised below:

- Properties are leased for the fixed period of 1 to 23 years, starting from the date of first
implementation of IFRS 16. The contracts contain an option to renew the lease. The majority of
lease payments are fixed, some with variable part based on index or rate.

- Base stations are leased for the fixed period of 1 to 30 years, starting from the date of first
implementation. The lease payments are fixed or fixed with variable part based on index or rate.

- Machinery and equipment are leased for one to eight years, starting from the date of first
implementation. The leased payments are fixed.

- Optical fibres are rented for the fixed period of 1 to 15 years. The lease payments are fixed.

###### Where the Group is a lessor in a lease which transfers substantially all the risks and rewards incidental to ownership to the lessee, the assets leased out does not present identifiable assets, though it is used by the Group as well, e.g. cable network.

_Transition and impacts on transition_

The Group applies the simplified transition approach and does not restate comparative amounts for the
year prior to first adoption. Right-of-use assets for property leases is measured on transition as if the
new rules had always been applied. All other right-of-use assets are measured at the amount of the lease
liability on adoption (adjusted for any prepaid or accrued lease expenses).

For leases that were classified as finance leases applying IAS 17, the carrying amount of the right-ofuse asset and the lease liability at the date of initial application is the carrying amount of the lease asset
and lease liability immediately before that date measured applying IAS 17. For those leases, the Group
account for the right-of-use asset and the lease liability applying IFRS 16 from the date of initial
application.

**5.** **Financial risk management**

**Overview**

The Group has exposure to the following risks from its use of financial instruments:

  - credit risk,

  - liquidity risk, and

  - market risk.

This note presents information about the Group’s exposure to each of the above risks, the Group’s
objectives, policies and processes for measuring and managing risk, and the Group’s management
of capital. There is no change of financial risk and financial risk management compared to
consolidated financial statements as at 31 December 2018.

**Risk management framework**

The Group’s managing board has overall responsibility for the establishment and oversight of the
Group’s risk management framework, and development and monitoring of the Group’s risk management
policies.

The Group’s risk management policies are established to identify and analyse the risks faced by
the Group, to set appropriate risk limits and controls, and to monitor risks and adherence to limits.
Risk management policies and systems are reviewed regularly to reflect changes in market conditions
and the Group’s activities. The Group, through its training and management standards and procedures,
aims to maintain a disciplined and constructive control environment in which all employees understand
their roles and obligations.

The finance function monitors compliance with the Group’s risk management policies and procedures,
and provides top management with feedback regarding the performance of the framework in relation to
the risk faced by the Group.

**a)** **Credit risk**

Credit risk is the risk of financial loss to the Group if a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument
fails to meet its contractual obligations, and arises principally from the Group’s receivables from
customers, contract assets, cash and cash equivalents held at banks, loans and off-balance sheet guarantees.

Further disclosure relating to credit risk is presented in the note 22.

**_Trade and other receivables (including contract assets)_**

The Group’s exposure to credit risk is influenced mainly by the individual characteristics of each
customer. The Group assesses that it has no significant concentration of credit risk due to its exposure to
a broad customer base in each service line. No concentration of credit risk on a geographical basis is
assessed as material. The Group has policies that limit the amount of credit exposure for each
customer including services disconnection procedure.

The Group’s risk procedure limits the credit risk through short credit period available (invoices are due for
payment within 15 days from the date of issue) and 3 levels of dunning letters in different time intervals.
The Group outsourced collection activities of all receivables which are overdue more than 6 months to
collection company.

**_Cash and cash equivalents_**

The Group held cash and cash equivalents of EUR 250,058 thousand as 31 December 2019 (31 December
2018: EUR 43,430 thousand) with reputable local commercial banks, which represents its maximum
credit exposure on these assets. Out of the total amount of cash and cash equivalents, the amount of
EUR 207 million is placed on escrow account for the purpose of the acquisition of Tele2 (note 29).
Management actively monitors credit risk exposure and given that the Group only has invested in bank
deposits management does not expect any counterparty to fail to meet its obligations.

**b)** **Liquidity risk**

Liquidity risk is the risk that the Group will encounter difficulty in meeting the obligations associated
with its financial liabilities that are settled by delivering cash or another financial asset. The Group’s
approach to managing liquidity is to ensure, as far as possible, that it will always have sufficient liquidity
to meet its liabilities when due, under both normal and stressed conditions, without incurring
unacceptable losses or risking damage to the Group’s reputation.

The Group’s policy on liquidity is to maintain sufficient liquid resources to meet its obligations as they
fall due, which has been achieved through appropriate bank arrangements (note 32). Typically, the Group
seeks to ensure that it has sufficient cash on demand to meet expected current liabilities as they fall due,
including the servicing of financial obligations; this excludes the potential impact of extreme
circumstances that cannot reasonably be predicted, such as natural disasters.

The Group has covenants relating to Revolving Credit Facility and bonds. Covenants relating to bonds are
active only when the Group decides to issue new bonds or refinance old one. Covenants relating to RCF
are monitored regularly (note 32).

The liquidity table presenting the contractual maturities of financial liabilities at undiscounted amounts is
presented in the note 22.

**c)** **Market risk**

Market risk is the risk that changes in market prices, such as foreign exchange rates, interest rates and
equity prices will affect the Group’s income or the value of its holdings of financial instruments. The
objective of market risk management is to manage and control market risk exposures within acceptable
parameters, while optimizing the return.

_i)_ _Currency risk_

Currency risk arises when future commercial transactions or recognized assets or liabilities are
denominated in a currency that is not the functional currency of the Group entity holding the asset or
obligation.

Different entities within the Group have different functional currencies, based on the underlying
economic conditions of their operations. Other than Euro, which is the Company’s functional
currency, the Group’s subsidiaries have local functional currencies: Serbian dinar (“RSD”),
Croatian kuna (“HRK”) and Swiss franc (“CHF”). Accordingly, the main exposure to currency risk
comes from relates to purchases and borrowings which are denominated in Euros and US dollars,
while a significant share of the Group’s revenue is denominated in Serbian dinars. The Group has
exposure to currency fluctuation (depreciation) of RSD (Serbian dinar) to Euro given that it has
significant operations through SBB Serbia for which RSD is the functional currency and that has
significant borrowings in Euro. The Group’s currency risk policy for this exposure is implemented

_iii)_ _Interest rate risk_

significant movements in market rates. The Group does not use these instruments for speculative purposes.

**Capital management**

Due to the structure of long-term financing through leveraged buyout arrangement, the management
policy is to maintain a stable return on investment so as to maintain investor, creditor and market
confidence and to sustain future development of the business. The Group’s performance management is
focused on generating budgeted Adjusted EBITDA as well as maintaining overall liquidity position to
repay the financial debt (note 22). An important key performance indicator for the communication with
investors, analysts, and rating agencies is Net leverage (calculated as Adjusted Net Debt to Annualized
Last Two Quarters Adjusted Pro Forma EBITDA). This ratio stood at 4.71x at December 31, 2019
(December 31, 2018: 4.88x). Annualized Last Two Quarters Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted Net Debt
are non-GAAP figures not governed by International Financial Reporting Standards, and their definition
and calculation may vary from one company to another.

Annualized Last Two Quarters Proforma Adjusted EBITDA represents Adjusted EBITDA (as defined
in note 7) adjusted for the reasonably anticipated synergies and cost savings from acquired companies,
mainly Tele2, as though the full effect of synergies and cost savings were realized on the first day of the
relevant period.

Adjusted Net Debt represents total debt of the Group adjusted by adjusted cash and cash equivalents
and IFRS 16 effects.

Adjusted cash and cash equivalents represent cash and cash equivalents adjusted by cash used for
acquisition of Tele2 and received bond premia.

**6.** **Critical accounting estimates and judgments**

The consolidated financial statements require management to make judgments, estimates and
assumptions that affect the application of accounting policies and the reported amounts of assets,
liabilities, income and expenses. Actual results may differ from these estimates.

Estimates and judgments are continually evaluated and are based on historical experience and other
factors, including industry practices and expectations of future events that are believed to be
reasonable under the circumstances. Revisions to accounting estimates are recognized in the period in
which the estimates are revised and in any future periods affected.

Judgements that have the most significant effect on the amounts recognised in the consolidated
financial statements and estimates that can cause a significant adjustment to the carrying amount of
assets and liabilities within the next financial year included:

- Impairment of goodwill

The Group tests annually whether goodwill with indefinite useful life, suffer any impairment in
accordance with the Group’s accounting policy. Discounted cash flow method for annual impairment
testing is based on management assumptions on projected revenue growth and market research for the
relevant markets, competitive environment and management strategy for the next five years (note 20).

- Contractual customer relationships

The Group tests annually impairment indicators of contractual customer relationships. Discounted cash
flow method is based on management assumptions on projected revenue growth and market research for
the relevant markets, competitive environment and management strategy for the next five years.

- Expected credit loss

The calculation and measurement of expected credit loss in relation to trade receivables and contract
assets is an area where significant judgement is required to select an appropriate methodology, models
and data inputs. Details of ECL measurement methodology are disclosed in note 3(e). In the calculation
of the default rate, the Group’s models predominantly use historical information which is derived from
the Group’s systems of market data.

- Recognition of revenue and allocation of transaction price

The Group is determining and allocating the transaction prices to separate performance obligations in the
contract; the allocation is based on the reference to their relative standalone selling prices that could be
obtained if the promised goods and services were sold individually in a separate transaction. The
standalone selling prices are determined based on the list prices at which the Group sells handsets and
telecommunication services, if sold separately.

- Advertising and media selling

The Group recognized revenue from advertising and media selling on gross basis, i.e. acting as principal.
In arriving to that conclusion, the management has taken into consideration guidance of IFRS 15 on
principle vs agent as well as local industry practice. The main assumptions taken by management are
that the Group control the price and service. Additionally, local industry practice for the similar
companies and the same reporting framework, is to act as principals.

**7.** **Operating segments**

Operating segments are components that engage in business activities that may earn revenues or incur
expenses as a result of the services provided. Segment information is provided partially on the basis of
geographic areas and partially based on an organizational structure, being the basis on which the Group
manages its operations. Operating results of segments are regularly reviewed by the chief operating
decision maker (CODM) and discrete financial information is available on that level. Revenue is
attributed to a country based on the location of the sub-group reporting the revenue.

The functions of CODM are performed by the Managing directors of the Group.

The Group has five operating segments, four in cable and internet and one in media business line, which
are the Group’s strategic divisions. Cable strategic divisions for each of key markets, offer similar
services and are managed jointly since they have unified service development and marketing strategy.
Media segment represents content operating. For each of the strategic divisions, the CODM reviews
internal management reports on at least monthly basis. The reportable segments equal the operating
segments thus no aggregation of operating segments was performed for the reporting purposes.

The following summary describes the operations in each of the Group’s reportable segments.

- Serbia Group includes cable operations in Serbia and DTH (satellite TV) operations in Macedonia.
Satellite operations in Macedonia account for minor part of the overall operations of Serbia Group
segment,

- Slovenia Group includes cable and DTH operations and mobile telephony services in Slovenia,

- Bosnia Group includes cable and DTH operations in Bosnia and Herzegovina,

- Montenegro Group includes cable and DTH operations in Montenegro (Montenegro is viewed as
segment after acquisition of M-kabl d.o.o. in 2016, as before this acquisition the Group did not have
cable operations in Montenegro),

- Media Group includes media (including advertising) and content operations in the region. This
segment includes the results of our media and content business in the former Yugoslav region
including the results of N1 Info, Grand Production, Orlando Kids, Nova TV, Nova M and Nova BH,
as well as Direct Media.

- Other segments includes our other operating business, such as Solford and non-operating holding
companies (United Group B.V., Adria Cable B.V., Adria Serbia Holdco B.V., Slovenia Broadband
S.A.R.L.). Revenue reported in other is mainly generated by Solford.

There were no changes in relation to composition of segments and measurement of segment profit/loss
comparing to consolidated financial statements for 2018.

Information regarding the results of each reportable segment is included below. Performance is
measured based on segment earnings before net finance cost, tax, depreciation and amortization
(EBITDA) and Adjusted EBITDA, as included in the internal management reports that are reviewed by
the Group’s management.

EBITDA is a supplemental measure of financial performance that is not required by, or presented in
accordance with IFRS. “EBITDA” is defined by the Group as Profit/(Loss) for the period plus income
tax (benefit)/expense, depreciation, amortization of intangible assets and net finance costs.

Adjusted EBITDA represents EBITDA adjusted for shareholder-related costs, legal and advisory –

additional impact of application of new standards (just for transitory period) and other non-core
operating expenses, which Group views as non-operating and not recurring to the operations of the
Group (note 17).

Segment Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA (note 17) is used to measure performance as
management believes that such information is the most relevant in evaluating the results of certain
segments relative to other entities that operate within these industries.

(a) Description of products and services from which each reportable segment derives its revenue

The Group’s main activities are providing of Video, Data and Voice services to subscribers in the
countries of South-East Europe. The Group operates in Serbia providing Video, Data and Voice services,
as well as in four other countries: Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro and Macedonia
providing Video and Data services.

Video service include provision of TV channel mix and IP Video streaming services, which is marketed
into basic, extended and premium packages. TV mix range from 60 to over 100 TV channels.

Data service comprise internet packages for residential and business customers, as well as various
supplementary services for business customers (connectivity and managed services, data centre and
cloud services).

Voice service relates to fixed line services to residential and business customers.

Mobile phone services relate to post-paid, prepaid, roaming and wholesale services provided to
customers.

Media Group includes content operations in the entire former Yugoslav region. Content operations
represent carriage fee revenue that relates to sales of pay-tv channel to other cable operators and
advertising revenue from terrestrial TV stations. The Group is the owner of pay-tv channels including
brands like “Sport Klub”, movie channel “Cinemania”, children channels “Ultra” and ”Orlando“ and
music channel “Grand”, as well as terrestrial TV stations Nova TV, Nova M and Nova BH. In addition
to this, Direct Media group provides advertising and media services to companies in the region.

(b) Factors that management used to identify the reportable segments

Four of the Group’s business segments are mainly based on the Group’s geographic regions, Serbia,
Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro, and the other business segment is broadly based on
product distribution. They are managed separately because each business unit requires different
marketing strategies and service level.

The CODM reviews financial information prepared based on IFRS adjusted to meet the requirements of

i. Management consolidation adjustments can differ from the ones required by IFRS

ii. non-IFRS profit measures (such as earnings before income tax, depreciation and amortization –

consisting primarily of set top box purchases and other customer capital expenditure,
installations (including capitalized labour costs), cable and mobile network build out, upgrades,
maintenance and other investments, computer hardware and software and content rights.

CODM evaluates performance of each segment based on revenue, Adjusted EBITDA, EBITDA and

assets and liabilities of the segments.

Non-deductible tax expenses in the amount of EUR 17,497 thousand (2018: EUR 15,414 thousand)
mainly relates to interest expenses over thin capitalisation rate, LTIS and impairments of financial
assets.

SBB and Telemach d.o.o., Slovenia are entities which primarily utilise tax losses and use tax holiday
for investments in plant and equipment. During 2016, SBB managed to satisfy conditions to apply for
another 10 years cycle of tax holiday, i.e. to employ 100 employees and invest more than EUR 8.5m.
In 2019, SBB is utilizing the tax holiday which reduces its nominal income tax liability by 64.63%, and
which expires in 10 years (in 2025).

SBB is eligible for investment incentives (tax holiday) according to Article 50a to 50i Serbian Corporate
Income Tax (CIT). For SBB this is a second use of this type of investment tax credit. The company met
required conditions to use an investment tax credit for the second time in 2016. The investment tax
credit is applied for ten years. Start of investment in fixed assets for the second investment tax credit is
1 January 2016. Each year the proportion for this investment needs to be calculated. Calculation of this
percentage represent the ratio of investment in fixed assets that meet requirements from Serbian CIT
art 50a to 50i (certain assets need to be excluded such as aircraft and watercrafts, passenger cars,
furniture and assets that hasn’t been paid during the cumulative period) and total investment in fix assets
(for period from 1 January 2016 - according to invested amount in fixed assets and for previous period
according to fixed amount of assets book value). The percentage which can be apply as investment tax
credit on calculated CIT is changing every year.

Deferred tax assets have not been recognised in respect of tax losses, because it is more likely than not
that future taxable profit will not be available against which the Group can use the benefits therefrom.

The cash flow projections included specific estimates for five years and a terminal growth rate thereafter.

annual Adjusted EBITDA growth rate, consistent with the assumptions that a market participant would
make.

Budgeted Adjusted EBITDA was estimated taking into account past experience, adjusted as follows:

and market research for the relevant markets, competitive environment and management
strategy for the next five years.

  - Corporate costs not included in individual CGU. Therefore, it shows the cash outflows from the
continuing use of the assets.

**Sensitivity analysis**

The management has identified that there are no reasonably possible changes in a key business and
valuation assumptions in Serbia Group, Slovenia Group and Media Group which could cause the
carrying amount to exceed the recoverable amount.

For Bosnia Group, if WACC would increase for 2% carrying amount would exceed the recoverable
amount by EUR 5,199 thousand.

For Montenegro Group, if WACC would increase for 2% carrying amount would exceed the recoverable
amount by EUR 890 thousand.

_Short term loans and deposits_

A loss allowance in relation to short term loans and deposits is determined individually for each balance.
In order to assess credit risk publicly available information to determine default rates. No exposure to
any significant credit risk was identified, so the calculation of the loss allowances resulted in immaterial
amounts.

_Cash and cash equivalents_

The Group holds cash in a number of banks in order to avoid concentration risk. A loss allowance in
relation to cash and cash equivalents is determined individually for each balance with a given financial
institution. In order to assess credit risk, external credit ratings and publicly available information on
default rates for a given rating of Standard & Poor’s rating agency were used. As all cash balances have
a low credit risk as at the reporting date and comparative period, the Group applied the practical
expedient available under IFRS 9 and determined the loss allowances based on 12-month expected credit
losses. The calculation of the loss allowances resulted in an immaterial amount.

###### Consolidated Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2019 

In thousands of EUR (unless otherwise stated)

Adjustment to the nominal amount of bond and RCF is necessary because they are recorded at amortized
cost. Based on this, upon origination of the bond and RCF, transaction costs were included in the
financial liabilities recognized. Interest expense recorded includes amortization of these transaction
costs deferred at initial recognition to maturity amount using the effective interest method. Amortized
transaction costs are not presented separately and is included in the carrying values of the borrowings
(as a reducing item). Bonds are rated by Moody’s forward view rated B2 and S&P Global rated B.

**Other financial liabilities - Bonds**

As at 27 July 2017 the Group issued bonds in the nominal amount of EUR 1,350,000 thousand. Bonds
were issued in three tranches

  - First tranche in the nominal amount of EUR 575,000 thousand, bears interest rate of 4.375%
p.a. and matures on 1 July 2022. Interest is payable semi-annually on each 15 January and 15
July. Effective interest rate of 4.778% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds.

  - Second tranche in the nominal amount of EUR 325,000 thousand, bears interest rate of 4.875%
p.a. and matures on 1 July 2024. Interest is payable semi-annually on each 15 January and 15
July. Effective interest rate of 5.204% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds.

  - Third tranche in the amount of EUR 450,000 thousand, bears floating rate of 3M Euribor+
4.375% and matures on 1 July 2023. Interest is payable quarterly on each 15 October, 15
January, 15 April and 15 July. Third tranche was early repaid on 17 May 2019 with no impact
on profit or loss .

As at 17 May 2019 issued bonds in the nominal amount of EUR 550,000 thousand which matures on
15 May 2025, bears interest rate of 3m EURIBOR+4.125%. Interest is payable on each 15 February,
15 May, 15 August and 15 November. Effective interest rate of 4.41% is used for calculation of carrying
values of bonds.

As at 4 July 2019 issued bonds in the aggregate amount of EUR 207,000 (including premium) thousand
which matures on 1 July 2024, bears interest rate of 4.875 %. Interest is payable semi-annually on each
15 January and 15 July. Effective interest rate of 4.151% is used for calculation of carrying values of
bonds.

**Revolving credit facility (RCF)**

As at 31 December 2019, the Group has Revolving Loan facilities with total available amount of EUR
243 million, out of which the undrawn amount is EUR 153 million. Maturity date of loans are from
2020 till 2023.

The bank loan facilities have been secured by a pledge on 100% of the shares of Adria Midco B.V. and
direct subsidiary entities as well as property, plant and equipment, intangible assets and receivables.

**Loan covenants**

Based on the agreement for RCF, the Group is required to comply with a leverage ratio to consolidated
Adjusted EBITDA for the period most recent four consecutive financial quarters ending prior to the
date of determination of the ratio. Leverage ratio is calculated as aggregate outstanding indebtedness of
the Group and should not exceed ratio 9:1. Indebtedness is calculated as total financial liabilities
decreased by level of cash and cash equivalents as at reporting date. Satisfaction of the covenant is
tested quarterly. The Group has been in compliance with the above requirements as at and for the year
ended 31 December 2019 and 31 December 2018, and to the date of issuance of this report.

**iv)** **Long Term Incentive Scheme**

- On 16 May 2018, the shareholders of ultimate holding company, Adria Luxco S.à r.l. (Adria
Luxco), entered into a Long-Term Incentive Scheme (the “LTIS Agreement”) pursuant to which
certain members of management will be compensated in an amount determined by reference to the
performance of the shareholders of Adria Luxco in the event of any exit of their investment in
Adria Luxco or Group by those shareholders. The Agreement provided a platform for a reasonable
expectation of the management to be awarded based on the performance of the shareholders in the
event of any exit of their investment in Adria Luxco or the Group by those shareholders.

- General Terms and Conditions of the LTIS Agreement included:

  - an obligation of the shareholders of Adria Luxco, conditioned upon a predetermined
accumulated return on invested capital (measured by money-multiple and internal rate of return
tests) in the event of any exit of their investment in Adria Luxco or Group, to award a bonus
payment to existing management of the Group;

   - the amount of the bonus payment calculated as a percentage of the proceeds received by the
shareholders of Adria Luxco and based on above mentioned accumulated return on invested capital
achieved by such shareholders;

  - the payment of exit proceeds earmarked for the bonus payment is to be made by each
shareholder to an intermediary vehicle in cash within 30 days of receipt of such exit proceeds, with
no recourse to the Group, including the ultimate holding company Adria Luxco; no stock options
or other derivative financial instruments are part of the LTIS Agreement;

  - no company in the Group, including the ultimate holding company Adria Luxco, has any
obligation under the LTIS Agreement to settle the bonus payment to the management. The LTIS
is funded/settled in its entirety by the Group’s external shareholders.

- On 27 September 2018, Summer Bidco B.V., an entity controlled by Funds advised by BC
Partners, entered into a share purchase agreement (“SPA”) to acquire the entire share capital
(excluding treasury shares) of Adria Topco BV (the “Target”) from Adria Luxco Sarl (the
“Seller”). The consummation of the Group Acquisition pursuant to the Group Share Purchase
Agreement which was subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including clearance by
competition authorities concluded on 4 March 2019. The consummation of the Group acquisition
represented an Exit under the LTIS Agreement.

- The Group has recognized the effects of the LTIS Agreement in its consolidated financial
statements for the period ending 31 December 2019, as equity-settled Group Share-based payment
transaction under IFRS 2 – Share-based payment – as LTIS Agreement is structured in a Group
context where multiple Group entities receive services from employees. It also provides the
responsibility of shareholders to settle the bonus (share-based payment) to employees who are
providing services to several group companies.

- The bonus amount under the LTIS Agreement at closing amounted to EUR 54,468 thousand, which
relates to the period of services provided from the LTIS Agreement signing to the grant date when
all parties will have shared understanding of key conditions pertaining LTIS Agreement. The
service period ended 31 August 2019. The Group recognized in its consolidated financial
statements for the period ending 31 December 2019 related expense in the amount of EUR 21,659
thousand, which corresponds to the eligible managers’ period of service from LTIS Agreement
signing to the end of the reporting period.

- From the perspective of the Group financial performance for the period ending 31 December 2018,
the recognition of the transaction resulted in a lower reported net profit of the Group, in the amount

_Investigation of the Serbian Commission for Protection of Competition in Serbia_

In November 2018 the Serbian Commission for Protection of Competition (“CPC”) issued a preliminary
notice stating that (i) it believed SBB holds a dominant position in the retail market for distributing
media content; (ii) price increases made by SBB were not justified by actual costs; and (iii) as a result,
SBB may have abused a dominant position through excessive pricing. On 15 May 2019 CPC issued
decision on suspension of further investigation.

_Investigation of Tax Authority in Serbia_

On 27 December 2017, the Serbian Ministry of Finance Tax Authority (the “Serbian Tax Authority”)
started tax investigation of SBB for the year ended 31 December 2012. According to the Serbian Tax
Authority’s decision issued in March 2019, it has recharacterized interest payments made by SBB
Serbia under an intragroup loan agreement (and certain other transactions) as dividends, which would
have been subject to a 5% withholding tax. Total liability determined amounts to EUR 21 million,
including the late interest. The management assessment, supported by analysis done by external
consultants (both legal and tax experts) is that there is no ground for the claim as it is not substantiated
by the evidence and regulation. The Group appealed to this decision and received approval for
postponing of payment until resolution of appeal.

_Legal cases in Slovenia_

1. The award of 5 MHz on 2100 MHz spectrum frequency within its 3G licenses in 2008 to Tušmobil

(now Telemach Slovenia) is currently subject of judicial review before the Administrative Court
against the decision issued by the Slovenian Agency for Communication Networks and Services
(“Agency”). In court, Telemach Slovenia is challenging Agency’s decision of May 2019, by which
the Agency in the renewed frequencies allotment procedure has rejected Tušmobil’s request for
allocation of said radiofrequencies and reversed its allotment decision of 2008, coming into the
effect as of 31 December 2019. Based on Telemach Slovenia’s proposal, in June 2019, the
Administrative Court issued an interim injunction and therewith stayed the Agency’s decision of
May 2019 until the court reaches a final decision on Telemach’s lawsuit against Agency’s decision
of May 2019. The procedure before the Administrative Court concerning the Telemach Slovenia’s
lawsuit is pending. Loss of the described frequency licence would lead to capacity reduction, which

might cause decrease in quality of service in certain areas. However, additional frequencies granted
in 2016 (and currently used by Telemach Slovenia) would support the Group to mitigate the impact
of any potential loss of 3G frequencies due to a renewal of the licence allocation procedure or other
revocation or impairment of the 3G license that was granted in 2008.

2. From 2012 onwards, the Slovenian Association of Composers and Authors (“SAZAS”) commenced

many legal proceedings against all cable operators in Slovenia (including Telemach Slovenia)
claiming infringement of copyrights and damages for the cable retransmission of musical works.
Up to now, SAZAS initiated twenty-eight legal proceedings against Telemach Slovenia claiming
copyright remuneration for cable retransmission of music works for periods between October 2010
and December 2015. In eighteen proceedings, courts already issued a final decision awarding
SAZAS with monthly remuneration amounting to approx. EUR 0.20 per subscriber for cable
retransmission of music works in TV and radio channels. On average, SAZAS was awarded with
approx. 30 % - 40% of its original claim. Telemach already complied with these final judgements
and paid the awarded amounts to SAZAS, while filed extraordinary legal means against courts’
final decisions which are for the present being reviewed by the Constitutional Court (in nine cases)
and Supreme Court of Slovenia (in one case). In five proceedings, the court of first instance issued
judgements, which were all appealed by both litigating parties to the Higher Court, while five
proceedings are still pending before the court of first instance.

3. In September 2018, the Slovenian Competition Protection Agency ruled that the Group’s

acquisition of United Media Distribution (then IKO Balkan) in 2012 is incompatible with
competition rules. The Slovenian Competition Protection Agency (hereinafter - the Agency)
ordered the Group to divest the activity of broadcasting Sport Klub (SK) TV channels within nine
months and imposed a ban prohibiting the Group from broadcasting sports TV channels in Slovenia
for three years from the date of divestment (with the exception of the existing Fight Channel). In
October 2018, the Slovenian Supreme Court issued our proposed interim injunction and stayed the
implementation of the Agency’s divestment decision until a final decision on the merits of this case
has been issued. The lawsuit against the divestment decision is pending. In addition, in a separate
misdemeanour proceeding a fine of up to a legal maximum of 10% of annual revenue of the Group
could be imposed for each of the next two breaches: (i) filing of concentration notification to the
Agency with delay and (ii) breaching of the stand still obligation. In May 2019, the Agency issued
decision on misdemeanour procedure by which financial fine in the amount of EUR 3.7 million was
imposed. The Group appealed against the decision and seek to annul or change decision in order to
abolish the financial fine or at least lower it.

4. In February 2015, the Slovenian Competition Protection Agency initiated a proceeding regarding

the abuse of dominant market position by United Media Limited, IKO Balkan (now United Media
Distribution) and its Slovenian subsidiary IKO Media PRO d.o.o. (former subsidiary of the IKO
Balkan - liquidated in 2016) in the wholesale market for the supply of pay TV sports channels in
Slovenia for a period beginning around August 2012. This proceeding is currently still in its initial
stages as no statement of objections has been issued by the Slovenian Competition Protection
Agency. If the Agency in this procedure ruled that the dominant position existed and was abused a
fine of up to the legal maximum of 10% of annual revenue of the previously described companies
involved in the procedure could be imposed. The Group management, supported by its legal
advisors, at this point assessed that it is likely that fine could be imposed and that level of fine would
not have material adverse impact on its financial position.

_COVID-19_

The existence of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) was confirmed in early 2020 and has spread rapidly
from mainland China across the globe, causing disruptions to businesses and economic activity. Many
governments across the world have imposed travel restrictions, lock downs and social distancing with
a view to reducing the spread of the virus and hopefully minimizing the number of fatalities. The Group
considers this outbreak to be a non-adjusting post balance sheet event.

Whilst inherently uncertain, and the management expects some impact to operations and performance
but currently does not believe that the COVID-19 outbreak will directly have a material adverse effect
on the Group’s financial condition or liquidity for the foreseeable future such that it is not appropriate
to apply the going concern principal to these financial statements.

The impact of this outbreak on macroeconomic forecasts and markets are expected to be incorporated
into the Group’s estimates of expected credit loss provisions and other impairments assessments in
2020, including but not limited to: Goodwill, Property, plant and equipment, Intangible assets and
programming rights.

Please also see disclosures in note 2(c) Going Concern.

The Group’s management holds that they are not aware of any other significant post balance sheet
events that could affect the consolidated financial statements for 31 December 2019 or require separate
disclosure.

**2.** **BASIS OF ACCOUNTING AND MEASUREMENT**

These unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 Interim
Financial Reporting, as adopted by the European Union (EU). They do not include all the information required for full annual
consolidated financial statements prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (“IFRS”) as adopted by
the EU and they should be read in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements of the Company as at and for the year
ended 31 December 2020. However, selected explanatory notes are included to explain events and transactions that are significant
to an understanding of the changes in financial position and performance of the Company since the last annual consolidated
financial statements. These unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements were approved by the Company on 25
November 2021.
The unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements have been prepared on the historical cost basis, except for
equity investments, which are measured on a fair value basis through other comprehensive income on each reporting date.

_Going concern_

The Company has prepared these interim financial statements on a going concern basis as it maintains adequate available liquidity
to continue its operations, despite the negative working capital, due to the nature of the business provided that the operating cashflows remain positive. In making this assessment management has taken account of the effect of Covid-19 on the operating
company, WIND Hellas.

**COVID-19**
During the third quarter as the vaccination campaign acquired critical mass many of the mobility restrictions that were in place in
Greece were lifted, especially for vaccinated citizens. Although certain restrictions continued to be in place, such as caps for on
site working, requirements to produce vaccination certificates or negative test results to engage in certain activities, and others,
economic activity recovered strongly and the country experienced a significantly improved tourist season compared to the prior
year.
In this environment Wind Hellas remained focused on the execution of its strategic plan, whilst delivering accelerated commercial
performance and leveraging on the improved overall economic environment. At the same time health and wellbeing of colleagues
and customers remained the Group’s top priority and it continued to implement all safety guidelines indicated by authorities
including 50% remote working, thermometry at building entry points, and mandatory use of masks on Company premises. The
Company has been recently awarded with a “Pandemic Management” distinction, for its actions during COVID-19.

At present, the Greek economy remains fully open with complete freedom granted to vaccinated citizens. However, Covid
infection case count has been rapidly rising over recent weeks and the government is considering a series of new measures to
incentivize vaccination and prevent further strain on the health system.

Wind Hellas continues to monitor the situation and to develop contingency plans should the health and safety or economic
conditions deteriorate as a result of the current resurgence of the pandemic.

**3.** **FUNCTIONAL AND PRESENTATION CURRENCY**

These unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements are presented in Euro, which is the Company’s functional
currency. All financial information presented in Euro has been rounded to the nearest thousand, except where otherwise indicated.

**4.** **USE OF JUDGEMENTS AND ESTIMATES**

In preparing these unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements, management has made judgements, estimates
and assumptions that affect the application of accounting policies and the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, income and
expense. Actual results may differ from these estimates.

Management has applied the Company’s accounting policies and used the same key sources of estimation uncertainty in these
unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements as those applied in the consolidated financial statements as at and
for the year ended 31 December 2020.

**_Measurement of fair values_**
A number of the Company’s accounting policies and disclosures require the determination of fair value for both financial and nonfinancial assets and liabilities.

When measuring the fair value of an asset or liability, the Company uses market observable data as far as possible. Fair values are
categorized into different levels in a fair value hierarchy based on the inputs used in the valuation techniques as follows:

Level 1: quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
Level 2: inputs other than quoted prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly

(i.e., as prices) or indirectly (i.e., derived from prices).

If the inputs used to measure the fair value of an asset or liability are categorized in different levels of the fair value hierarchy,
then the fair value measurement is categorized in its entirety at the same level of the fair value hierarchy as the lowest level input
that is significant to the entire measurement. There have been no transfers between levels of the fair value hierarchy as at 30
September 2021.

Further information about the assumptions made in measuring fair values is included in Note 24.

**5.** **SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES – NEW STANDARDS**

The accounting policies applied by the Company in these unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements are the
same as those applied by the Company in its consolidated financial statements as at and for the year ended 31 December 2020.

Amendments to IFRS have been issued for annual periods beginning after 1 January 2021, but they do not have any significant
impact on the Group’s financial statements. The Company, with its independent actuary, will assess the decision made by the
IFRS Interpretation Committee in April 2021 regarding the recognition of service (IAS 19) and will incorporate any impact in the
Financial Statements of 31 December 2021.

The aforementioned decision has immediate effect, and its implementation is expected to lead to a change in the existing
accounting policy. At this time, it is not possible to reasonably determine the effect of this change.

**6.** **BUSINESS DIVISION SALE**

During 2020 Crystal Almond S.à r.l. (“Crystal Almond”), entered into an agreement with Vodafone Europe B.V. (“Vodafone”)
(the “Contribution Agreement”), to contribute its tower portfolios in Greece in exchange for a 38% for the issued share capital of
Vantage Towers Greece (a jointly owned entity which, was recorded as an Investment Held for Sale at a value of €310 million as
of 31 December 2020) and certain additional payments. On 25 March 2021, Vodafone acquired the 38% share of Crystal Almond
in Vantage Towers Greece with a payment of €287.5 million. In line with the provisions of the sell down SPA there was also a
cash sweep payment to Crystal Almond of €4.9 million. As of 30 September 2021, Crystal Almond S.à r.l. has no investment in
Vantage Towers Greece.

**19.** **SHARE CAPITAL AND PREMIUM**

As at 30 September 2021 and at 31 December 2020, the authorized and issued share capital of Crystal Almond Intermediary
Holdings Limited amounted to 466,666,666 shares with nil par value of which 466,666,666 shares are designated as nonredeemable ordinary shares. All issued shares are fully paid. The share capital is zero and the disclosed amount relates to share
premium. There has been no issuance of shares in the nine months ended 30 September 2021.

In previous years, Crystal Almond Holdings Limited, the Company’s parent company, established share-based payment
arrangements for certain of its directors and key management employees to purchase shares in the parent company, namely

**Measurement of fair values**
A number of the Company’s accounting policies and disclosures require the measurement of fair value. Where applicable, further
information about the assumptions made in determining fair value is disclosed in the relevant notes.

_Loan_ _due from related party and interest rates used for determining fair value_
The fair value measurement for disclosure purposes of the loan due from a related party at each reporting date is determined as the
present value of expected future cash flows, discounted at the market rate of interest at the reporting date. The interest rate used to
discount estimated cash flows of the loan due from a related party are based on the Euro-market two-year yield curve at the
reporting date plus an adequate spread, and was 2.53% as at 30 September 2021 (2020: 2.49%).

_Third party loan_
The fair value measurement for disclosure purposes of third party loans has been determined by using the bond listing price on
The International Stock Exchange at the reporting date, which has been categorized as level 1.

**Financial risk management**
Other aspects of the Company’s financial risk management objectives and policies are consistent with those disclosed in the
consolidated financial statements as at and for the year ended 31 December 2020.

**30.** **SALE PURCHASE AGREEMENT**

On 16 August 2021, WIND Hellas announced the signing of a share purchase agreement between its ultimate parent company,
Crystal Almond Holdings and regional telecommunications and media operator in Southeast Europe, United Group. Under the
agreement, United Group will acquire Wind Hellas through the purchase of 100% of the share capital of Crystal Almond
Intermediary Holdings Limited.
The transaction is expected to complete in 2022, following receipt of customary regulatory approvals.
United Group has indicated that it currently expects to repay the €525.0 million Senior Secured Notes due 2024, issued by Crystal
Almond S.a r.l. in connection with the completion of the acquisition.

**2.** **BASIS OF ACCOUNTING AND MEASUREMENT**

These consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting
Standards (“IFRS”) as adopted by the European Union (E.U.). The consolidated financial statements were approved by
the Board of Directors on 9 April 2021.

The consolidated financial statements have been prepared on the historical cost basis, except for the equity investment
financial asset, which is measured at fair value through other comprehensive income (OCI) on each reporting date.

Significant accounting policies are included in Note 5. These policies have been consistently applied to all years presented,
unless otherwise stated.

_Going concern_

The Company has prepared these financial statements on a going concern basis as it maintains adequate available liquidity
to continue its operations, despite the negative working capital. In making this assessment management has taken account
of the effect of Covid-19 on the operating company, WIND Hellas.

**COVID-19**

In an effort to curb increasing cases of COVID-19, the Greek Government imposed a new nationwide lockdown, initially
for two weeks, from 4 March 2021. This followed on a series of measures that have been in place on a rolling basis since
November 2020 with restrictions on mobility and economic activity tightened or loosened depending on COVID-19
caseload.

Wind Hellas continues to focus on mitigating the risks posed by the pandemic. It remains vigilant in its efforts to protect
the health and wellbeing of its colleagues and customers, with almost all of its employees currently working from home.
For those at the office, use of masks is mandatory in all spaces and thermometry is performed on all individuals at building
entry points.

Wind Hellas continues to monitor the impact of the pandemic on its performance. Up to now, the pandemic has had a

**B.** **Measurement of fair values**

A number of the Company’s accounting policies and disclosures require the measurement of fair value for both financial
and non-financial assets and liabilities.

When measuring the fair value of an asset or liability, the Company uses observable market data as far as possible. Fair
values are categorized into different levels in a fair value hierarchy based on the inputs used in the valuation techniques
as follows:

_Level 1:_ quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.

_Level 2:_ direct or indirect inputs other than quoted prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset
or liability

_Level 3:_ inputs for the asset or liability that are not based on observable market data

If the inputs used to measure the fair value of an asset or liability fall into different levels of the fair value hierarchy, then
the fair value measurement is categorized in its entirety in the same level of the fair value hierarchy as the lowest level
input that is significant to the entire measurement. There have been no transfers between levels of the fair value hierarchy
as at 31 December 2020.

Further information about the assumptions made in measuring fair values is included in the following notes:

- Note 25 – share based payment arrangements,

- Note 29 – financial instruments.

**5.** **SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES**

**Significant accounting policies applicable to these consolidated financial statements.**

**(a)** **Basis of consolidation**

**(i) Business combinations or restructuring transactions under common control**

Business combinations or restructuring transactions arising from transfers of interests in entities or a group of
assets in which all of the combining entities or group of assets or businesses are ultimately controlled by the same
party or parties both before and after the business combination or restructuring transaction are considered business
combinations or restructuring transactions involving entities under common control. The Company accounts for
these common control transactions from the date the transaction is effective.

Assets and liabilities transferred are recognized at the carrying amounts shown previously in the controlling key
stakeholders’ consolidated financial statements with any difference between the value of the assets and liabilities
and the sum of the restructuring consideration plus transaction costs recognized directly in equity as a reserve
(“other reserves”).

The Company accounts for business combinations using the acquisition method when control is transferred to the
Company (see (ii) below). The consideration transferred and the identifiable net assets acquired are generally
measured at fair value. Any goodwill that arises is tested annually for impairment. Any gain on a bargain purchase
is recognized in profit or loss immediately. Transaction costs are expensed as incurred, except if related to the
issue of debt or equity securities. The consideration transferred does not include amounts related to the settlement
of pre-existing relationships. Such amounts are generally recognized in profit or loss.

**(ii) Subsidiaries**

Subsidiaries are entities controlled by the Company. The Company controls an entity when it is exposed to, or has
rights to, variable returns from its involvement with the entity and has the ability to affect those returns through
its power over the entity. The financial statements of subsidiaries are included in the consolidated financial
statements from the date that control commences until the date that control ceases.

Upon loss of control, the Company derecognizes the assets and liabilities of the subsidiary, any non-controlling
interests and other components of equity related to the subsidiary. Any resulting gain or loss is recognized in profit
or loss.

**(iii) Transactions eliminated on consolidation**

Intra-group balances and transactions and any unrealized income and expenses arising from intra-group
transactions are eliminated in preparing the consolidated financial statements.

**(b)** **Financial instruments**

i) Recognition, classification and initial measurement

Trade receivables are initially recognized when they originate. All other financial assets and financial liabilities
are initially recognized when the Company becomes a party to the contractual provisions of the instrument.

Financial assets – classification, subsequent measurement and gains and losses

On initial measurement, a financial asset is classified at amortised cost, FVOCI or FVTPL. A financial asset is
measured at amortised cost if it meets both the following conditions and is not designated at FVTPL: (1)It is held
within a business model whose objective is to hold assets to collect contractual cash flows ;and (2) Its contractual
terms give rise on specified dates to cash flows that are solely payments of principal and interest on the principal
amount outstanding. All financial assets not classified as measured at amortised cost as described above, are
classified as FVTPL. For investments in equity instruments the Company has irrevocably elected to account for

**In thousands of Euro, unless otherwise stated**

them at FVOCI. Cash and cash equivalents comprise cash in hand and deposits held on call with banks. The
Company considers time deposits and certificates of deposit with original maturity of three months or less to be
cash equivalents.
Financial assets at amortized cost continue to be measured at amortized cost using the effective interest method.
The amortized cost is reduced by impairment losses. Interest income and impairment losses are recognized in
profit or loss. Any gain or loss on derecognition is recognized in profit or loss.
Equity investments at FVOCI are measured subsequently at fair value. There is no subsequent reclassification of
fair value gains and losses to profit or loss following the derecognition of the investment. Dividends are recognized
as income in profit or loss unless the dividend clearly represents a recovery of part of the cost of the investment.

Financial liabilities – classification, subsequent measurement and gains and losses
Financial liabilities are classified as measured at amortised cost or FVTPL. A financial liability is classified as at
FVTPL if it is classified as held-for-trading, it is a derivative or it is designated as such on initial recognition.
Financial liabilities at FVTPL are measured at fair value and net gains and losses, including any interest expense,
are recognized in profit or loss. Other financial liabilities are measured subsequently at amortised cost using the
effective interest method. Interest expense and foreign exchange gains and losses are recognized in profit or loss.
Any gain or loss on derecognition is also recognized in profit or loss.

ii) Derecognition

Financial assets
The Company derecognizes a financial asset when the contractual rights to the cash flows from the asset expire,
or it transfers the rights to receive the contractual cash flows from the financial asset in a transaction in which
substantially all the risks and rewards of ownership of the financial asset are transferred or it neither transfers nor
retains substantially all of the risks and rewards of ownership and does not retain control over the transferred asset.

Financial liabilities
The Company derecognizes a financial liability when its contractual obligations are discharged, cancelled or
expire. Where an existing financial liability is replaced by another from the same lender on substantially different
terms, or the terms of an existing liability are substantially modified, such an exchange or modification is treated
as a de-recognition of the original liability and the recognition of a new liability and the difference in the respective
amounts is recognized in the profit or loss.

iii) Offsetting

Financial assets and liabilities are offset and the net amount presented in the consolidated statement of financial
position when, and only when, the Company has a legal right to offset the amounts and intends either to settle on
a net basis or to realize the assets and settle the liability simultaneously.

**(c)** **Foreign currency**

Transactions in foreign currencies are translated into the functional currency of the Company’s entities at exchange
rates at the dates of the transactions. Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies at the
reporting date are retranslated to the functional currency at the exchange rate at that date. Non-monetary assets
and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies that are measured at fair value are translated to the functional
currency at the exchange rate at the date that the fair value was determined. Foreign currency differences arising
on re-translation are recognized in profit or loss. Non-monetary items that are measured based on historical cost
in a foreign currency are translated using the exchange rate at the date of the transaction.

**(d)** **Share capital**

Ordinary shares are classified as equity. Incremental costs directly attributable to the issue of ordinary shares are
recognized as a deduction from equity.

**(e)** **Property, plant and equipment**

Property, plant and equipment are measured at cost less accumulated depreciation and any accumulated
impairment losses. Cost includes expenditure that is directly attributable to the acquisition or construction of the

asset and capitalized borrowing costs. Gains or losses on disposal of an item of property, plant and equipment are
determined by comparing the net proceeds from disposal with the carrying amount of property, plant and
equipment and are included in profit or loss. Subsequent expenditure is capitalized only if it is probable that the
future economic benefits associated with the expenditure will flow to the Company.
_Depreciation_
Depreciation is calculated to write off the cost of property, plant and equipment to their estimated residual values.
Depreciation is recognized in the profit or loss on a straight-line basis at rates equivalent to the estimated average
economic useful lives of the property, plant and equipment. Leased assets are depreciated over the shorter of the
estimated useful life of the asset and the lease term unless it is reasonably certain that the Company will obtain
ownership by the end of the lease term. Leasehold improvements are amortized over the shorter of the period
between their estimated useful life and the term of the lease. Land is not depreciated. Depreciation methods, useful
lives and residual values are reviewed at each reporting date and adjusted if appropriate.
The rates used for determining depreciation, reflecting the estimated useful lives of property, plant and equipment
for the current and comparative periods are as follows:

Annual rates

Buildings 2% - 8%

Plant and machinery 5% - 25%

Other tangible assets 10% - 50%

**(f)** **Intangible assets**
(i) Licenses: Separately acquired licenses are measured initially at cost and are subsequently carried at cost less

accumulated amortization less any accumulated impairment loss. Amortization commences from the date the
licenses are available for use over their estimated useful lives which is between 15-18 years depending on the
license. Amortization is calculated on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful lives and is recognized
as an expense in the profit or loss from the date the licenses are available for use.

(ii) Other intangible assets: Other intangible assets are measured at cost less accumulated amortization and

accumulated impairment losses. Their estimated useful lives are as follows:

a) Computer software: 3-4 years.

b) Other intangible assets: i. Customer relationships: 8-11 years; ii. contracts for fixed network connections:

12 years; and iii. the right of use backbone network contract: 10 years.

Subsequent expenditure is capitalized only when it increases the future economic benefits embodied in the specific
asset to which it relates. All other expenditure is recognized in profit or loss as incurred.

Amortization methods, useful lives and residual values are reviewed at each reporting date and adjusted if
appropriate.

**(g)** **Leases**

**A)** **As a lessee:**

The Company leases various assets, including fibre optic cables, antenna sites, local loop unbundling circuits (“LLU”),
hosting space services, shops and buildings. Under IFRS 16, the Company recognizes right-of-use assets and lease
liabilities for leases on the balance sheet.

The Company recognizes a right-of-use asset and a lease liability at the lease commencement date. The right-of-use asset
is initially measured at cost, and subsequently at cost less any accumulated depreciation and impairment losses, adjusted
for certain remeasurements of the lease liability.
The lease liability is initially measured at the present value of the lease payments that are not paid at the commencement
date, discounted using the Company’s incremental borrowing rate. The lease liability is subsequently increased by the
interest cost on the lease liability and decreased by lease payments made. It is remeasured when there is a change in future
lease payments arising from a change in an index or rate, a change in the estimate of the amount expected to be payable

**(h)** **Inventories**

Inventories are measured at the lower of cost and net realizable value. The cost of inventories is based on the
weighted average cost method and includes expenditure incurred in acquiring the inventories and other costs
incurred in bringing them to their existing location and condition. Net realizable value is the estimated selling price
in the normal course of business, less costs to sell.

**(i)** **Impairment of assets**

(i) Financial assets

The Company recognizes loss allowances on expected credit losses (ECLs) on trade receivables, contract assets,
cash and cash equivalents and loans due from related parties. The Company assesses on a forward-looking basis
the ECLs associated with its debt instruments carried at amortised cost. The Company measures loss allowance
for trade receivables and contract assets at an amount equal to lifetime ECLs and twelve-month ECLs for the loan
due from a related party.

To measure the ECL in relation to trade receivables and contract assets, the Company has assessed the possible
default events for financial assets by utilizing an ageing analysis, taking into account the Company’s historical
credit loss experience and customers churn adjusted for forward-looking factors specific to the debtors and the
economic environment.

When determining whether the credit risk of a financial asset has increased significantly since initial recognition
and when estimating ECLs, the Company considers reasonable and supportable information that is relevant and
available without undue cost or effort. This includes both quantitative and qualitative information and analysis,
based on the Group’s historical experience and informed credit assessment, that includes forward-looking
information.

Write-off: The gross carrying amount of a financial asset is written off when the Company has no reasonable
expectation of recovering a financial asset in its entirety or a portion thereof. For individual customers, the
Company has a policy of writing off the gross carrying amount when the financial asset is 180 days past due based
on historical experience of recoveries of similar assets. For corporate customers, the Company makes an
assessment with respect to the timing and amount of write-off based on whether there is a reasonable expectation
of recovery on a case by case basis.

(ii) Non-financial assets

The carrying amounts of the Company’s non-financial assets, other than inventories and deferred tax assets, are
reviewed at each reporting date to determine whether there is any indication of impairment. If any such indication
exists, then the asset’s recoverable amount is estimated.

The recoverable amount of an asset or cash-generating unit is the higher of its value in use and its fair value less
costs to sell. In assessing value in use, the estimated future cash flows are discounted to their present value using
a pre-tax discount rate that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific
to the asset or cash-generating unit (CGU). An impairment loss is recognized if the carrying amount of an asset or
its CGU exceeds its estimated recoverable amount. Impairment losses are recognized in profit or loss.

Impairment losses recognized in prior periods are assessed at each reporting date for any indications that the loss
has decreased or no longer exists. An impairment loss is reversed only to the extent that the asset’s carrying amount
does not exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined, net of depreciation or amortization, if no
impairment loss had been recognized.

**(j)** **Employee benefits**

(i) Short-term employee benefits

Short term employee benefit obligations are expensed as the related service is provided.

(ii) Post-employment benefits

Post-employment benefits include two categories: (1) defined contribution plans and (2) defined benefit plans.

A defined contribution plan is a post-employment benefit plan under which an entity pays fixed contributions into
a separate entity and will have no legal or constructive obligation to pay further amounts. The obligation is
recognized as an employee benefit expense in profit or loss in the periods during which services are rendered by
employees.

A defined benefit plan is a post-employment benefit plan other than a defined contribution plan. The Company’s
obligation in respect of defined benefit pension plans is calculated by estimating the amount of future benefit that
employees have earned in return for their service in the current and prior periods, and then discounted to determine
its present value. The discount rate is the yield at the reporting date on high quality corporate bonds that have
maturity dates approximating to the terms of the Company’s obligations and denominated in the same currency in
which the benefits are expected to be paid.

The calculation of the defined benefit obligation is performed annually by a qualified actuary using the projected
unit credit method. Remeasurements of the defined benefit liability, which comprise actuarial gains and losses, are
recognized immediately in OCI.

(iii) Termination benefits

Termination benefits are expensed at the earlier of when the Company can no longer withdraw the offer of those
benefits and when the Company recognizes costs for a restructuring.

**(k)** **Share-based Payment Arrangements**

The grant-date fair value of equity-settled share-based payment arrangements granted to directors and employees
are recognized as an expense, either as personnel expenses or purchases and services expenses dependent on the
entitled person, with a corresponding increase in equity, over the vesting period of the awards. The amount
recognized as an expense is adjusted to reflect the number of awards for which the related service and non-market
performance conditions are expected to be met, such that the amount ultimately recognized as an expense is based
on the number of awards that meet the related service and non-market performance conditions at the vesting date.

**(l)** **Provisions**

A provision is recognized if the Company has a present legal or constructive obligation as a result of a past event
and it is probable that an outflow of economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation, and the amount can

that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific to the liability. The

**(m)** **Revenue from contracts with customers**

Revenues primarily comprise revenue from telecommunications services and handset sales. Revenue is recognized
at an amount to which the Company expects to be entitled in exchange for transferring promised goods or services
to a customer. For each contract with a customer, at contract inception, the Company identifies the promised goods
or services, determines which of those goods and services will be treated as distinct performance obligations and
determines the total transaction price, taking into account any discounts and subsidies provided to the customer.

_Revenue from telecommunication services_
Revenue arising from post-paid traffic in excess of the free traffic included in the monthly fee and value-added
services is recognized based on usage made by each customer and interconnection revenue and international
roaming revenue is recognized based on usage made by subscribers to other telephone operators.
_Multiple-element arrangements (bundled packages)_
For contracts that include multiple elements at contract inception, (sale of subsidized handsets delivered in advance
combined with mobile telecommunication services), the total transaction price is allocated to the separate
performance obligations based on the relative stand-alone selling prices of the handset and the service. At contract
inception the Company recognizes revenue for the handset upon transfer of control, which is on delivery and
acceptance of the handset by the customer. The unbilled revenue is recorded in the statement of financial position
as a contract asset, which is amortized over the contract period in the monthly service revenue.
_Telecommunication handsets and equipment revenue_
Under IFRS 15, revenue from the sale of telecommunication equipment such as mobile handsets and accessories
is recognized at the time when the customer obtains control of such devices.

_Contract asset and contract liability_
Contract assets are recognized by the Company when it has a right to consideration in exchange for goods or
services it has transferred to a customer before the customer pays consideration or before payment is due, excluding
any amounts presented as a receivable. The Company recognizes a receivable where the right to consideration is
unconditional and only the passage of time is required before payment of that consideration is due.
Contract assets arise for the Company as a result of the earlier recognition of revenues in the case of multipleelement arrangements with subsidized products delivered in advance and sales through dealers/franchisees of
service agreements as the subsidy cost to dealers is recognized against service revenue during the relevant contract
period.
If a customer pays consideration or the Company has a right to an amount of consideration that is unconditional
before the Company transfers a good or service to the customer, the Company presents the contract as a contract
liability when the payment is made or the payment is due (whichever is earlier). Contract liabilities primarily arise
from monthly fees charged to customers in advance, unused airtime for prepaid scratch cards, and material rights
which result from the direct sales channel for subsidies provided to customers subsequent to contract inception.

_Contract Costs_
Incremental costs to obtain a contract such as commissions paid to dealers are recognized as non-current assets if
expected to be recoverable and amortized over the estimated period of customer relationship. Costs of obtaining a
contract that are not incremental are expensed as incurred.
Costs to obtain a contract are amortized over the minimum contract period for mobile post-paid customers and the
average customer retention period for prepaid mobile customers and fixed services (including internet and TV)
customers. The average customer retention period is estimated with reference to historical churn rate for the
respective customer base and is reviewed at each reporting period and revised if a significant change is necessary.
Costs to fulfill a contract before a good or service is provided to a customer which are not within the scope of
another standard, are recognized as an asset only if the following three criteria are met: (a) the costs relate directly
to the contract or to an anticipated contract that the entity can specifically identify; (b) the costs generate or
enhance resources of the entity that will be used in satisfying (or in continuing to satisfy) performance obligations
in the future; (c) the costs are expected to be recovered.
