The amortization period for these assets is reviewed at each reporting date and revised if a significant change is
necessary. The assets are periodically reviewed for impairment. Where a contract is terminated before its minimum
contract term, any remaining asset balances are written off immediately in the statement of profit or loss and other
comprehensive income.

Contract costs primarily relate to commissions paid to dealers and franchisees categorized as incremental customer
acquisition costs for securing mobile, prepaid and fixed service customers, and expenditure incurred by third
parties for fixed service customer set-up costs before the activation of the services and the installation of terminal
equipment.

**(n)** **Taxation**

Income tax expense comprises current and deferred tax. Current and deferred taxes are recognized in profit or loss
except to the extent that they relate to a business combination, or items recognized directly in equity or in OCI.
Current tax comprises the expected tax payable or receivable on the taxable income or loss for the year, using tax
rates enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date, and any adjustment to tax payable or receivable in
respect of previous years.

Deferred tax is recognized in respect of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and
liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for taxation purposes. Deferred tax is not
recognized for the following temporary differences: the initial recognition of assets or liabilities in a transaction
that is not a business combination and that affects neither accounting nor taxable profit, and temporary differences
relating to investments in subsidiaries, associates and joint arrangements to the extent that the Company is able to
control the timing of the reversal of the temporary differences and it is probable that they will not reverse in the
foreseeable future. In addition, deferred tax is not recognized on taxable temporary differences arising on the initial
recognition of goodwill.

Deferred tax is measured at the tax rates that are expected to be applied to the temporary differences when they
reverse, based on the laws that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the reporting date. Deferred tax
assets and liabilities are offset where there is a legally enforceable right to offset current tax assets and liabilities
and where the deferred tax balances relate to the same taxation authority. Current tax assets and tax liabilities are
offset where the entity has a legally enforceable right to offset and intends either to settle on a net basis, or to
realize the asset and settle the liability simultaneously.

A deferred tax asset is recognized for unused tax losses and deductible temporary differences to the extent that it
is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be utilized. Future taxable profits
are determined based on the reversal of relevant taxable temporary differences. If the amount of the taxable
temporary difference is insufficient to recognize a deferred tax asset in full, then future taxable profits, adjusted
for reversals of existing temporary differences, are considered. Deferred tax assets are reviewed at each reporting
date and are reduced to the extent that it is no longer probable that the related tax benefit will be realized. Such
reductions are reversed when the probability of future taxable profits improves.

**(o)** **Finance income and finance costs**

Finance income comprises mainly interest income on funds invested. Interest income is recognized as it accrues
in the profit or loss using the effective interest method.

Finance costs comprise mainly interest expense, amortization of discounts and premiums on financial liabilities,
and, the unwinding of the discount on provisions and impairment losses recognized on financial assets (other than
trade receivables). Interest income or expense is recognized as it accrues in the profit or loss using the effective
interest method. Foreign currency gains and losses are reported on a net basis.

The effective interest rate is the rate that exactly discounts estimated future cash payments or receipts through the
expected life of the financial instrument to the gross carrying amount of the financial asset, or the amortised cost
of the financial liability.

**(p)** **Joint arrangements**

The Company classifies its interest in joint arrangements as either joint operations (if the Company has rights to
the assets and obligations for the liabilities, relating to an arrangement) or joint ventures (if the Company has rights
only to the net assets of an arrangement). When making this assessment, the Company considers the structure of
the arrangement, the legal form of any separate vehicles, the contractual terms of the arrangements and other facts
and circumstances.

The Company incorporates its share of the assets, liabilities and transactions of the joint operation in its
consolidated financial statements at each reporting period end. Amounts charged by the joint operation to the
Company, resulting balances and transactions and any unrealized income and expenses arising from such
transactions are eliminated in preparing the consolidated financial statements.

The Company has no investments in joint ventures.

**New standards and interpretations not yet adopted**

Whilst a number of new accounting standards are effective for annual periods beginning after 1 January 2020 and earlier
application is permitted, the Company has not early adopted the following new standards in preparing these consolidated
financial statements.

**IAS 1 (Amendment) ‘Classification of liabilities as short-term or long-term’ (effective for annual periods beginning**
on or after 1 January 2022)

The amendment clarifies that liabilities are classified as short-term or long-term based on the entitlements in force at the
end of the reporting period. The classification is not affected by the entity's expectations or events after the reporting date.
In addition, the amendment clarifies the meaning of the term "settlement" of an obligation in IAS 1. The amendment has
not yet been adopted by the European Union.

**IFRS 10 and IAS 28 (Amendments) ‘Sale or Contribution of Assets between an Investor and its Associate or Joint**
**Venture’ (effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2022)**

The amendments address an acknowledged inconsistency between the requirements of IFRS 10 and those in IAS 28, in
dealing with the sale or contribution of assets between an investor and its associate or joint venture. The main consequence
of the amendments is that a full gain or loss is recognized when a transaction involves a business (whether it is held in a
subsidiary or not). A partial gain or loss is recognized when a transaction involves assets that do not constitute a business,
even if these assets are held in a subsidiary. In December 2015 the IASB postponed the effective date of this amendment
indefinitely pending the outcome of its research project on the equity method of accounting. The amendments have not
yet been endorsed by the European Union.

None of these are expected to have a significant effect on the consolidated financial statements of the Company. There
are no other IFRS or IFRIC interpretations that are not yet effective that would be expected to have a material impact on
the Company.

**6.** **BUSINESS DIVISION SALE**

On 24 July 2020 the Company’s wholly owned subsidiary Crystal Almond S.à r.l. (“Crystal Almond”), entered into an
agreement with Vodafone Europe B.V. (“Vodafone”) (the “Contribution Agreement”), a 100% owned subsidiary of
Vodafone Group Plc, for the parties to contribute their tower portfolios in Greece to a jointly owned entity (“Vantage
Towers Greece”). On 27 October 2020 the General Assembly of WIND Hellas approved the partial demerger of the
WIND Hellas business related to the tower portfolio.

Crystal Almond Towers S.A. was established and approved by the Greek Commercial Registry on 17 November 2020.
Besides business related to the tower portfolio, WIND Hellas also transferred part of a corporate loan due by WIND
Hellas to Crystal Almond S.à r.l. amounting to €87.5 million. At this point Crystal Almond S.à r.l. had two wholly owned
subsidiaries, WIND Hellas and Crystal Almond Towers S.A.

On 21 December 2020 completion of the transaction contemplated in the Contribution Agreement took place, and Crystal
Almond contributed its shares in Crystal Almond Towers S.A. to Vantage Towers Greece and in exchange received 38%
of the issued share capital of Vantage Towers Greece and an aggregate payment of €112.5 million from Vodafone effected
by way of a cash payment of €25 million and a cash repayment of the €87.5 million corporate loan that had been
transferred to Crystal Almond Towers S.A. At the same time the parties executed a sell down Sale and Purchase
Agreement (“SPA”) and a shareholders’ agreement. By virtue of the sell down SPA Vodafone received an option to
acquire Crystal Almond’s 38% share in Vantage Towers Greece at any time up to 31 December 2021, an option which
was also triggered automatically in the event of an IPO of Vantage Towers Europe, the parent company of Vantage
Towers Greece. The consideration upon exercise of the call option would be €287.5 million bringing the total value of
the transaction for Crystal Almond to €400 million. If the call option was not exercised and the IPO did not occur, the
parties would be able to unwind the transaction and pursue alternative options separately.

On 17 November 2020 Crystal Almond Towers S.A. began offering services to Wind Hellas under a new long-term
Master Services Agreement (“MSA”). The MSA has an initial eight-year term and Wind Hellas has a unilateral option to
extend the MSA twice, each extension being for eight years and the term may be extended until the lapse of a fourth eight
year term (maximum term of 32 years). The MSA describes the charges for services that Vantage Towers Greece will
provide to Wind Hellas. It also has provisions that aim to secure equal treatment of Wind Hellas with Vodafone Greece;
such equal treatment will be monitored by an independent monitor. Under the MSA, Wind Hellas and Vodafone Greece
have each agreed to commit as an anchor tenant on 250 new sites (500 in total BTS) to be built by Vantage Towers Greece
over a five-year period starting from 17 November 2020 with at least one hundred and twenty (120) of those BTS Sites
to be ordered within thirty-six (36) months of 17 November 2020.

As a result of these transactions, in November 2020 the Company derecognised a net liability of €(64)million related to
the Towers division demerger. In December 2020, upon completion of the transaction contemplated in the Contribution
Agreement, the Company lost control of its subsidiary Crystal Almond Towers S.A. As a result, a net gain of €377 million
related to the transaction was recognised in the profit or loss and other comprehensive income statement, and the
investment in Vantage Towers Greece was recorded as an “Investment held for sale” of €310 million in the Consolidated
Statement of Financial Position.

**Subsequent events**

In March 2021, following completion of the Vantage Towers Europe IPO, Vodafone’s call option for the Crystal Almond
remaining 38% share in Vantage Towers Greece was triggered. This resulted in an additional payment of €287.5 million
which was made on 25 March 2021 and brought the aggregate proceeds from the transaction for Crystal Almond to €400
million. In line with the provisions of the sell down SPA there was also a cash sweep payment to Crystal Almond of €4.9
million. As of 25 March 2021, Crystal Almond S.à r.l. has no investment in Vantage Towers Greece.

2024 under a New York law governed Indenture dated 17 October 2019. The SSNs are listed on the International Stock
Exchange (ISE).
The SSNs are senior obligations of the Issuer (Crystal Almond S.à r.l.) and guaranteed on a senior basis by Crystal Almond
Intermediary Holdings Limited and Wind Hellas.

The Senior Secured Notes contain customary high yield covenants.

Transaction costs directly related to the issuance of the Senior Secured Notes have reduced the loan proceeds and are
amortized over the life of the Senior Secured Notes using the effective interest method.

Senior Secured Revolving Credit Facility (SSRCF):
On 17 October 2019 Crystal Almond S.à r.l. as Borrower entered into a Senior Secured Revolving Credit Facility (SSRCF)
Agreement with Goldman Sachs International Bank, JP Morgan AG and HSBC Bank Plc as Lenders, for €75,000 on a
committed basis. The SSRCF matures 54 months after the issue date. The interest rate equals the aggregate of a 3% p.a.
margin and EURIBOR (0% EURIBOR floor). The commitment fee is 0.90%.
The SSRCF is guaranteed by Crystal Almond Intermediary Holdings Limited and Wind Hellas. The scope of security and
guarantees of the SSRCF are the same as for the SSNs but no security has been given over the Wind Hellas shares.
The SSRCF includes a Consolidated Net Leverage Ratio (Consolidated Net Leverage to Consolidated EBITDA) that
should not exceed 5.0 to 1.0 tested on a quarterly basis and calculated on the consolidated financial statements of Crystal
Almond Intermediary Holdings Limited.

On 17 March 2020, the Company drew down €75 million from the SSRCF for a period of nine months. On 17 September
2020 the Company repaid €35 million of the SSRCF and rolled over the remaining €40 million, it also paid interest of
€1,150 and a commitment fee of €286. On 17 December 2020 the Company re-drew down €35 million. As at 31 December
2020, the whole of the SSRCF facility amounting to €75 million was drawn. The Company repaid the SSRCF in full as
well as interest of €503 on 18 January 2021.

**Contingencies**

(i) Litigation

The Company is currently involved in various legal proceedings and has claims pending that have arisen in the ordinary
course of business. The most significant outstanding legal cases are as follows:

**_i)_** **_Fixed Microwave Holdings (ex Rolaware): In June 2008 WIND sold (via the secondary spectrum market) a fixed_**
wireless access license to the Cyprus based company Rolaware Limited, for a price of €5,250. The National
Telecommunications Posts Committee (“EETT”) provided its clearance for this transaction in the third quarter of 2009.
Subsequently, EETT found that the buyer had failed to meet the criteria under the license for its use. The Regulatory
Authority resolved that Rolaware was in breach of EETT’s initial decision and ordered the license to be returned to WIND
Hellas. EETT required the latter to sell the license or it would be revoked. Following several extensions and a further
hearing, EETT revoked the fixed wireless access license. As a consequence, WIND Hellas filed a petition before the
Administrative Courts against the EETT decision in 2013 and also filed a lawsuit against the buyer, Rolaware Limited,
before the Athens Courts, claiming payment of the remaining consideration of €3,250 under the relevant sale agreement.
The Court issued a decision in favour of WIND Hellas in January 2018 and the Rolaware claims were dismissed.
Microwave Holdings (ex-Rolaware Limited) filed an appeal which was scheduled to be heard on 23 May 2019 but the
hearing was called off due to the Greek Elections and a new hearing was scheduled for 7 May 2020. Due to the advent of
the COVID-19 pandemic, the hearing was cancelled, and a new hearing date was scheduled for 4 February 2021, but this
has also been deferred. The Company is waiting for a new hearing date.

**_ii)_** **_PANOU EPE case: In May 2015, an unfavourable decision was rendered against WIND Hellas for a legal case relating_**
to a supplier that was providing power to remote base transceiver stations (BTS sites). The Court issued its ruling in
January 2018 upholding the WIND Hellas appeal and dismissing the claim filed by PANOU EPE. The plaintiff filed a
new lawsuit and the case was heard on 10 October 2018 at which the plaintiff’s lawsuit was dismissed in total. The
plaintiff has filed an appeal and the hearing was set for 2 April 2020. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the hearing
cancelled, and a new hearing date was scheduled for 1 April 2021, but this has also been deferred. The Company is waiting
for a new hearing date.

**29.** **FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT AND FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS**

**A.** **Financial risk management**

The Company has exposure to the following risks from its use of financial instruments:

  - credit risk

  - liquidity risk

  - market risk

**_i)_** **_Risk management framework_**

The Board of Directors of the Crystal Almond Holdings Limited Group of companies, which includes the Company and
the operating subsidiary, WIND Hellas, has overall responsibility for the establishment and oversight of the Company’s
risk management framework. The Company’s risk management policies are established to identify and analyze the risks
faced by the Company, to set appropriate risk limits and controls, and to monitor risks and adherence to limits. Risk
management policies and systems are reviewed regularly to reflect changes in market conditions and the Company’s
activities.

**_ii)_** **_Credit risk_**

Credit risk is the risk of financial loss to the Company if a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument fails to meet
its contractual obligations, and arises principally from the Company’s receivables from customers, loans and receivables
from related parties, accrued interest thereon and cash and cash equivalents.
The maximum exposure to credit risk at the reporting date was as follows:

Trade receivables and contract assets:
The Company’s exposure to credit risk is influenced mainly by the individual characteristics of each customer but is also
affected by the demographics of the Company’s customer base, the default risk of the industry and local market
competitiveness in which customers operate. The Company’s customers primarily include contract billing consumers and
business subscribers, receivables due from telephone operators and from the distribution network for purchase of
terminals, SIM cards and scratch cards (note 16). 83.2% (2019: 71.7%) of amounts due from telephone operators as at 31
December 2020 was attributable to three major national mobile and fixed telecommunication operators which are also
suppliers to the Company, where payables due to these operators represented 69.3% (2019: 63.6%) of the total trade
payables due to telephone operators. 5.6% (2019: 8.1%) of the Company’s total revenues and 10.9% (2019: 16.0%) of
the Company’s total operating costs were attributable to interconnection revenues and costs associated with these three

operators. There was no other concentration of credit risks relating to customers. The operations of the Company are only

Aged debts typically arise from customer credit problems, disputes or fraud. The Company has established a credit control
policy that provides that all new subscribers undergo a credit check prior to being accepted. The Company has a system
to monitor unusual or fraudulent activity in order to minimize the risk of bad debt. In monitoring customer credit risk,
customers are grouped according to their credit characteristics, including whether they are an individual or legal entity,
whether they are wholesale, retail or end-user customer, aging profile, maturity and existence of previous financial
difficulties. In doing so for its end-user customers, the Company utilizes a credit risk application scoring system. Trade
receivable balances that have not been collected by the Company’s approved credit period are followed up through a
standardized process which includes temporarily barring outgoing services. Non-payment, having followed the process
results in disconnection of services and placement for post cancelation collection. All customers have been categorized
in three segments based on their initial score and transactional behaviour. The treatment of each segment is based on the
respective risk factor. The Company also receives guarantees from its wholesalers and franchisees in order to mitigate its
credit risk.

The Company establishes an allowance for impairment that represents its estimate of incurred and/or expected losses in
respect of trade receivables. The main components of this allowance are a specific loss component that relates to
individually significant exposures, and a collective loss component established for groups of similar assets in respect of
losses that have been incurred or anticipated but not yet identified. The collective loss allowance is determined based on
historical data of payment statistics for similar financial assets adjusted by customer churn for forward-looking factors
specific to the debtors and the economic environment. An allowance account is used to record impairment losses unless
the Company is satisfied that no recovery is possible; at that point the amount is considered irrecoverable and is written
off directly against the financial asset and after taking into consideration existing legislation.

**C.** **Measurement of fair values**

A number of the Company’s accounting policies and disclosures require the determination of fair value for both financial
and non-financial assets and liabilities. Fair values have been determined for measurement and /or disclosure purposes
based on the methods indicated below.

_Loans due from related parties_
The fair value of loans due from related parties is estimated as the present value of expected future cash flows, discounted
at the market rate of interest at the reporting date. Fair value is determined at initial recognition and, for disclosure
purposes, at each annual reporting date.

The interest rates used to discount estimated cash flows of loans and receivables based on the market yield curve at the
reporting date plus an adequate spread were 2.49% (2019: 2.79%).

_Third party loan_
The fair value measurement of third party loans for disclosure purposes has been determined by using the bond listing
price on the International Stock Exchange at the reporting date, which has been categorized as level 1 fair value.

**30.** **JOINT OPERATION**

The Company has a 50% share in Victus Networks S.A. (“Victus”), a joint arrangement for network sharing. Victus
operates exclusively for the benefit of WIND Hellas and Vodafone-Panafon S.A. to manage the radio access and
transmission networks (RAN) of both companies and to implement a partial active radio network sharing (RAN sharing),
mostly in rural and in limited selected urban areas of Greece for the next twenty (20) years.
No asset transfer to Victus has occurred and each party continues to own those assets that are subject to sharing.
The Company has performed an assessment of this network sharing agreement and has concluded that it should be
accounted for as a joint operation. It includes its share of the assets, liabilities and transactions of the joint operation in
these consolidated financial statements.

**1. General information**

**The Parent Company – Bulgarian Telecommunications Company EAD**

Bulgarian Telecommunications Company EAD (“BTC”, the “Parent Company” or the “Company”) with UIC 831642181
registered in the Commercial Register of Bulgaria, is a single owned joint stock company, domiciled in Bulgaria, with its
registration address: 115i, Tsarigradsko shose Blvd, 1784 Sofia. BTC’s activities include development, operation and
maintenance of the national fixed and mobile network and data system for the Republic of Bulgaria.

Until 31 July 2020 the Ultimate Parent Company was Viva Telecom (Luxembourg) S.A. (“VTL”) which through InterV
Investment S.à r.l. owned 100% of the equity of Viva Telecom Bulgaria OOD which is the parent of the Company. The largest
shareholder in VTL with a 46% stake was Viva Edge Telecom Limited which was ultimately owned by Mr. Spas Roussev. Other
minority investors were comprised of entities affiliated with OJSC VTB Bank, Delta Capital Investments OOD (ultimately
controlled by Messrs. Milen Velchev, George Velchev and Krassimir Katev), Mr. Michael Tennenbaum and companies
managed by Mezzanine Management Central Europe II Limited.

On 7 November 2019 it was announced that United Group, the leading telecoms and media business operating in South Eastern
Europe, has agreed to acquire Viva Telecom Bulgaria. The European Commission has examined the transaction under the
normal merger review procedure and has approved the acquisition on 3 April 2020. The deal was finalized on 31 July 2020
whereas the shares in Viva Telecom Bulgaria were acquired by United Group Bulgaria EOOD
As a result, as of 30 September 2020 the ultimate parent of the Company is Summer Parent S.a r.l. (an entity controlled by
funds advised by BC Partners) which indirectly through United Group Bulgaria EOOD owns 100% of the equity of Viva
Telecom Bulgaria.

**The Group**

As at 30 September 2020 and 31 December 2019 the Group includes the subsidiary entities BTC Net EOOD, NURTS Bulgaria
EAD, NURTS Digital EAD and Net Is Sat EOOD.

As at 30 September 2019 the Group included the subsidiary entities BTC Net EOOD, NURTS Bulgaria EAD, NURTS Digital
EAD and the joint venture Paytech OOD.

**BTC Security EOOD/ Renamed to BTC Net EOOD**

The subsidiary was registered in the Register of commercial companies of Sofia City Court on 27 October 2004 with share
capital of BGN 5 thousand. Its main activity is provision of security services to BTC AD and the companies controlled by it.
BTC is the sole owner of this company.

The registered subject of business activity of BTC Net is building and operation of data transfer networks for the provision of
domestic and international value added services and sale of telecommunication network facilities, development and exploitation
of other telecommunication networks, and provision of other telecommunications services, as well as any other commercial
activities.

On September 30, 2009 BTC Net EOOD was merged into BTC Security EOOD.

The legal merger of the entities was registered in the Commercial Register on October 15, 2009. As a result, BTC Net has
ceased to exist as a separate legal entity, by virtue of law BTC Security has become universal legal successor of BTC Net and
all assets, rights and obligations of BTC Net have passed to BTC Security automatically as of that date. On October 16, 2009
the successor BTC Security was renamed to BTC Net EOOD.

**NURTS Bulgaria EAD**

NURTS Bulgaria EAD is a commercial company registered in the Commercial Register in 1 April 2010 with subject of
business activity: development, operation and maintenance of public electronic communication networks and data systems in
Bulgaria, as well as providing telecommunication services through them, including terrestrial broadcasting of television and
radio programs, analogue radio-relay and satellite transmission services, collocation services and other commercial activities.
The registered share capital amounts to BGN 151,482,310 comprising of shares with nominal value of BGN 1 each.

**NURTS Digital EAD**

NURTS Bulgaria EAD owns 100 % of the share capital of NURTS Digital EAD, which is a joint stock company registered in
the Commercial Register on 15 April 2009 with principal activity construction, operation and maintenance of public electronic
communication networks, equipment and information systems in Bulgaria, as well as providing electronic communications
services through them, including terrestrial broadcasting of television and radio programs. The registered share capital amounts
to BGN 120,00,000 comprising of shares with nominal value of BGN 500 each.

**Net Is Sat EOOD**

NET IS SAT is a commercial company registered in the Commercial Register in 3 November 1997. Its main activity is offering
individual business telecom solutions, including providing optical and wireless Internet access, fixed call service, Virtual
Private Networks (VPN), wholesale international VoIP termination services, network and data management. The registered
share capital amounts to BGN 3,832,000.

**Paytech EOOD**

Paytech is a commercial company registered in the Commercial Register on 17 April 2019 as a joint venture between BTC and
Bulgarian-American Credit Bank AD. Its main activity is development and provision of mobile payments. BTC held 50% of the
registered share capital of the entity, amounting to BGN 1,000,000 for the period 17 April to 7 October 2019. The articles of
association stipulated joint management of the entity whereas the joint venture partners had equal representatives in the General
Meeting of the Shareholders, the entity was jointly represented by two managers of the Company each nominated by the
respective shareholder and any General Meeting matter concerning the entity required joint decision of the shareholders. Based
on that BTC treated its investment in Paytech as a joint venture. On 7 October 2019 BTC sold its 50% share in Paytech OOD to
Bulgarian-American Credit Bank AD.

**3.2. Significant events during the reporting period**

As a preventive measure against the outburst of COVID-19 (Coronavirus) in Europe, on 13 March 2020 a state of emergency
was declared in the territory of Bulgaria. All visits in certain commercial establishments such as restaurants, shopping centres,
entertainment and gaming halls, etc. were suspended for two months. On 23 March 2020 Мeasures and Аctions during a State
of Emergency Act was adopted, aimed at mitigating the negative consequences of the epidemic on citizens and businesses.
While the core activities of the Group were not directly affected by these measures, certain negative impact on its financial
position and performance during the reporting period could be largely attributed to the COVID-19 related developments.
Though no reasonable estimate of the exact financial effect of the coronavirus outbreak can be made, the impacted items of the
profit and loss statement, statement of financial position and accounting estimates and judgments are presented below.
Net impairment losses on financial and contract assets increased as a result of delays in customer payments during the second
quarter of the year, resulting respectively in higher ECL rates and increase in allowance for impairment of trade and lease
receivables measured by applying the IFRS 9 simplified approach. During the third quarter of the year the receivables
collectability improved and as at the reporting date and the subsequent periods it is close to pre-coronavirus levels (refer to Note
5).

The coronavirus pandemic had a negative impact on the Mobile services revenue due to lower roaming revenue, primarily as a
result of coronavirus-induced travel restrictions. This was partially offset by decrease in interconnect and roaming expenses.
Further impact on service revenues are limited by the increased demand for telecom services during the periods of coronavirus
related restrictions.

During the reporting period the incremental borrowing rates applicable to the the Group lease liabilities were reconsidered and
no significant changes to the pre-coronavirus rates were determined. The other critical accounting estimates and judgements
disclosed in the annual financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2019 were evaluated as not impacted by the
coronavirus pandemic.

Potential prolonged recession and a deepening crisis could impact on growth prospects, customer spending and collection, and
may result in assumptions and estimates that could trigger material adjustments to the carrying value of assets and liabilities in
the future. In particular, management expects the assumptions and estimates used in determining impairment of Trade and other
receivables, Contract assets, Property, plant and equipment, Intangible assets, Right-of-use assets and valuation of Investment
property, and the related Deferred tax assets and liabilities to be affected. Nevertheless, at the date of these financial statements
the Company continues to generate profits and sufficent cash from operations, supporting its activities. The directors, in light of
their assessment of expected future cash flows are satisfied that the Company will be able to meet its obligations as they fall due
for a period of at least 12 months from the reporting date. Therefore the Company continues to apply the going concern basis of
preparation.

On July 31, 2020 United Group Bulgaria EOOD granted to VIVACOM a related party loan with maturity of 10 years and bullet
repayment at maturity. With the funds received, VIVACOM has prepaid all liabilities under the SFA. As a result, VIVACOM’s
long-term debt obligation to third-party financing institutions stipulating 6-month repayment schedules and finally due in 2023
was replaced by a related party loan due 2030 which enables better liquidity management compared to the previous SFA
exposure.

Incremental costs of obtaining a contract are additional costs that would have not been incurred had the contract not been

are incurred prior to fulfillment and cannot be capitalized under any other standard. The capitalized contract costs are
recognised in the profit or loss as: 1) depreciation and amortization on a straight-line basis over the minimum enforceable
contract period, or 2) other operating expenses when impairment loss is recognized, if their carrying amount exceeds the
remaining amount of consideration that the Group expects to receive, less the costs that relate directly to providing the goods or
services that have not been recognized as expenses.

**Measurement of fair value**
_Fair value hierarchy_

Land is measured at fair value, in accordance with the revaluation model of IAS 16. The fair value of land was determined as at
31 December 2018 by external, independent property valuers, having appropriate recognized professional qualification and
recent experience in the location and category of the property being valued.

The fair value measurement for land of BGN 5,361 thousand has been categorised as a Level 3 fair value based on the inputs to
the valuation technique used.

_Valuation technique and significant unobservable inputs_

The valuation technique used is Market comparison - the fair value is based on the market price of properties with similar
location and category. At the date of valuation no active market existed and the market value was determined based on offers to
sell similar plots under the assumption that these are the end prices. The offered prices have been adjusted with: discount rate
ranging from 10% to 15% to reflect the actual reduction in the offered price, based on the trends of actual transactions;
adjustment coefficients, derived on the basis of characteristics of the respective plots like size, environmental and
geomorphologic condition, level of development and transport accessibility, and improvements of the land. The estimated fair
value of the individual properties would increase/(decrease) had the respective discount rate were lower/(higher) and the
adjustments coefficients were higher/(lower).

**Investment property**

As a result of the improvements and modernization of its fixed network during the past years BTC achieved substantial
optimization of the technical areas in its own buildings. The level of usage of each building is being assessed as at the end of
each reporting period. Where the Group uses only part of a property it owns, utilisation of less than 25% is regarded as
immaterial and the property is presented as an investment property. The movement in Investment property is presented below:

In November 2013 BTC announced the successful completion of its debut bond offering of €400 million 6⅝% Senior Secured
Notes due 2018 on the Irish Stock Exchange pursuant to Rule 144A / Regulation S (the "Notes"). The proceeds from the bond
offering were used by the Company to repay its existing indebtedness under the amended and restated loan agreement in full.
The interest on the Notes was payable semi-annually on May 15 and November 15 of each year, commencing May 15, 2014. In
relation to the admission of the Notes the Company received a credit rating of B1 by Moody's and BB- by Standard & Poor's
Ratings Services. On 29 March 2018 and 16 May 2018 respectively Moody's upgraded the long-term corporate credit rating of
the Company to Ba3 and S&P Global Ratings reconfirmed it as BB- and in November 2019 both agencies placed the corporate
credit ratings on review. On 27 March 2020 S&P Global Ratings downgraded the corporate credit rating to B+ and on 30
September 2020 lowered it to B, and withdrew the rating at VIVACOM’s request.

BTC underwent a consent solicitation procedure for a waiver of the existing change of control provisions and amendment of
certain definitions and ratios applicable to the Notes. The procedure was initiated in relation to the acquisition by VTL of 100%
of the shares of InterV Investment S.a.r.l. On 13 June 2016, Vivacom obtained the necessary consent of 87.43% of bondholders.
The amendments of Notes' provisions entered into effect upon the execution of the first supplemental indenture on June 10,
2016 which became operative on 7 September 2016, when all the conditions precedent in the first supplemental indenture were
either satisfied or waived.

Simultaneously with the bond offering BTC has concluded EUR 35 million Revolving Credit Facility with Societe Generale
Expressbank AD under which the Company may borrow funds for the repayment of its debt under the amended and restated
loan agreement, financing of its working capital purposes and issue of bank guarantees and letters of credit. The RCF was
initially agreed to be available up to 30 November 2016. The interest on the principal amounts owing by the Company under the
RCF is payable monthly and was initially agreed to be the aggregate of 1 month EURIBOR plus a margin of 4% per year.
Effective from 26 May 2014 the margin was reduced to 3,75% per year and from 14 November 2016 the margin was further
reduced to 1,45% per year and the term was extended to 31 May 2018.

On 22 December 2017 the Company entered into an up to EUR 365 million Senior Facilities Agreement (SFA) arranged by
Citibank N.A., London Branch and VTB Bank (Deutschland) AG (currently VTB Bank (Europe) SE). The purpose of the
facility was to refinance all amounts due under the Existing HY Bonds, payment of fees and costs under the facility and capital
expenditure in respect of the Company's investment and development program. The SFA comprised of a term loan Facility A,
term loan Facility B, a Short-term Facility and a Revolving Facility. The maximum tenor was 5.25 years after the first
Utilization under the SFA, which occurred on 14 April 2018. The interest on the facilities was based on EURIBOR plus a
Margin between 1.25 and 3.75 per cent per annum.

The liabilities of the Company under the SFA were guaranteed by BTC Net EOOD (subsidiary) and Viva Telecom Bulgaria
OOD (parent of the Company) and were further secured by: 1) a non-possessory pledge in accordance with the Special Pledges
Act on the going concern of the Company, which included among other receivables of the Company under certain bank
accounts, insurance policies, related parties and customer receivables, as well as certain tangible and intangible assets (including
trademarks), inventory and real estates of the Company; 2) a non-possessory pledge in accordance with the Special Pledges Act
over the going concern of BTC Net, which included among other assets the receivables of BTC Net under certain bank
accounts; 3) a non-possessory pledge in accordance with the Special Pledges Act over the going concern of Viva Telecom
Bulgaria OOD, which included among other assets the receivables of Viva Telecom Bulgaria EOOD under certain bank
accounts and the shares of the Company; 4) a non-possessory pledge in accordance with the Special Pledges Act over the shares
of the Company; 5) a pledge in accordance with the Agreements on Financial Collateral Act over the shares of the Company; 6)
a non-possessory pledge in accordance with the Special Pledges Act over the shares of BTC Net and a possessory pledge over
the shares of NURTS Bulgaria EAD.
On 19 April 2018 the Company successfully completed the refinancing of its Notes ahead of their maturity date and has delisted
the Notes from the Official List and from trading on the Main Securities Market of the Irish Stock Exchange. As of the date of
these financial statements the Company has deregistered the relevant securities under the Notes.

Simultaneously with the SFA the Company extended the maturity of the Existing EUR 35 million Revolving Credit Facility
(RCF)with Societe Generale Expressbank AD to 18 April 2021 and reduced the applicable Margin to between 1.05 and 1.75 per
cent per annum. The Company has established the respective securities under the extended RCF on a pari passu basis by the
same scope and type of security provided by the Company under the SFA.

On 31 July 2020 United Group Bulgaria EOOD granted related party loan to BTC and with the received funds BTC
successfully prepaid all liabilities under the SFA and the above referred securities under the SFA are in the course of
deregistration. The outstanding principal amount of the related party loan is due in 10 years. The applicable interest is payable
quarterly in arrears and is negotiated to be initially equal to 4.65 per cent per annum and following the completion of a third
party transfer pricing study - to such per cent per annum determined thereunder.
Simultaneously with the repayment of the SFA, BTC also terminated the Revolving Credit Facility which securities are
currently in the course of deregistration.

**Legal reserve**

The legal reserve is set up as required by the Bulgarian Commercial Act and equals one tenth of the share capital.

**Revaluation reserve**

The revaluation reserve relates to the revaluation of Land and Investment property.

**Fair value reserve**

The fair value reserve comprises the cumulative net change in the fair value of financial assets at fair value through other
comprehensive income until the investments are derecognised or impaired.

**Hedging reserve**

The hedging reserve comprises the effective portion of the cumulative net change in the fair value of cash flow hedges related to
hedged transactions that have not yet occurred.

**Other reserves**

The other reserve comprises of the cummulative effect of the remeasurements of retirement benefit obligation and cost of hedging

**Segment information**


Management has determined the operating segments based on the reports reviewed by the Managing Board that are used to make
strategic decisions. The business, considered on a product perspective is currently organized into three lines of business – Fixed
line of business, Mobile line of business and NURTS business. NURTS business represents the acquired in July 2015 company
NURTS Bulgaria EAD and its wholly own subsidiary NURTS Digital EAD. Principal activities are as follows:

   - Fixed line of business – voice and data services over the fixed network and pay TV (both DTH and IPTV);

   - Mobile line of business – mobile services (GSM, UMTS and LTE Standards);

   - NURTS business – TV and radio broadcasting, collocation services and maintenance of telecom infrastructure.

The Managing Board assesses the performance of the business segments based on a measure of gross margin. Revenue and gross
margin information as reviewed by the Managing Board for the nine months ended 30 September 2020 and 2019 is presented

associates of the members and their close parties;

**Loans**

As per Loan Agreement dated 22 April 2014 BTC provided to Viva Telecom Bulgaria EOOD a revolving credit facility for the
amount of up to EUR 2,000 thousand. The applicable interest rate was initially agreed to be the aggregate of 6M Euribor plus a
margin of 6.5% p.a. Effective from 30 November 2016 the margin is renegotiated to 7% p.a. and the amount of the loan increased
to up to EUR 3,800 thousand. During 2017 and 2018 the amount of the loan has been increased to up EUR 24,000 thousand and

**Contingencies**


The Company is a participant in several lawsuits and administrative proceedings. On 4 July 2016, Empreno Ventures Limited
commenced legal proceedings in Bulgaria, challenging the validity of the first supplemental indenture (as referred in Note 15).
Following the review on three instances, the Bulgarian courts finally dismissed the case on 16 March 2017 and the claim was
rejected. On 26 August 2016, LIC Telecommunications S.à r.l. commenced legal proceedings in Luxembourg that, among other
things, challenge the validity of the first supplemental indenture (as disclosed in Note 15) and claim damages amounting to EUR
62 million. In 2018 and 2019 judgments were rendered by two instance courts in Luxembourg which declared the request of LIC
Telecommunications S.à r.l inadmissible and declined jurisdiction, which entered into force during the reporting period. BTC
considered the legal proceedings in both Bulgaria and Luxembourg as being unmeritorious and devoid of any proper legal basis.

**Contingencies (continued)**


The transactions for assignment of receivables on cash deposits in Corporate Commercial Bank AD – in bankruptcy (CCB), were
executed in 2014 as per the provisions of the applicable law. One of the assigned receivables was utilised by NURTS Bulgaria
EAD in order to set-off its obligations to CCB under a bond issued by NURTS Bulgaria EAD in 2013. CCB held 25,723 bonds
with a nominal of EUR 1,000 each and in September 2014 NURTS Bulgaria EAD has set-off the principal in the amount of BGN
50,310 and applicable interest due to CCB in the amount of BGN 1,350 thousand against its own cash held in CCB accounts and
assigned CCB cash receivables from third parties, including BTC. Despite of the validly executed transactions, the receivers of
CCB have recognized only partially the set-off from NURTS Bulgaria EAD (BGN 1,543 thousand) where the remaining amount
of BGN 50,117 thousand and other owned cash in CCB of BGN 116 thousand is included in the list of accepted receivables of
CCB creditors. No financial assets or liabilities in relation to this matter were recognized in these financial statements. On 2 May
2017 NURTS Bulgaria EAD was notified for commencement by CCB of legal proceedings for the challenge of the set-off.

On 14 May 2018 the first instance court cast a decision, as a result of which the NURTS set-offs against CCB were declared
partially null and void and partially invalid vis-à-vis the creditors of CCB. The decision has not entered into force and has been
appealed before the Sofia Court of Appeal.

On 12 December 2019 CCB has withdrawn its claim against NURTS and on 20 December 2019 has initiated a procedure for the
sale of the bonds held by CCB within which the above-referred issues between CCB and NURTS were finally resolved during the
reporting period. Accordingly a provision was recognized by NURTS in 2019. As a consequence, the bonds and NURTS
respectively were deregistered from the public register for issuers of securities maintained by the Bulgarian Financial Supervision
Commission.

After the reporting period Nurts Bulgaria AD was served with documents relating to a case that has been filed by the
administrators of CCB against NURTS Bulgaria EAD claiming the return of certain assets originating from CCB. As the purported
limitation period for filing such claims has expired and NURTS Bulgaria EAD has already settled all CCB claims, management
believes that any chance of transfer of benefits with regards to this case to be remote and no provision has been recognised in these
financial statements.

Based on the information available, management is satisfied that there is no unprovided liability arising from these lawsuits and
administrative proceedings, however there are inherent uncertainties related to the outcome of the cases. The recognised provisions
for lawsuits are further disclosed in Note 14.

The Group has bank guarantees issued to third parties which amount to BGN 9,615 thousand as of 30 September 2020 (31
December 2019: BGN 2,738 thousand).

NURTS Bulgaria EAD was notified by CCB that pursuant to a contract concluded on January 16, 2013 the Company has stepped
in as co-debtor in third party's obligation in the amount of EUR 12,300 thousand. The management of the company is in a process
of confirmation of the relevant circumstances, whereas as per the date of the present financial statements no reliable and
indisputable evidences were received for the existence of such contingent liability, nor for its exact amount (if such liability
exists). Respectively, no liability or provision has been recognized as at December 31, 2019, and contingent liability was
disclosed. During the reporting period NURTS Bulgaria EAD has acquired the above referred third party's obligations towards
CCB and thus, any contingent liability is deemed unenforceable and extinguished.
